Hello,

I know that this is only peripherally related to raves, but sometimes this is
a good community to get real information from.

First, NOTE:   please ONLY reply to ME  --- no replies to sfraves (check your
headers before sending!).

SO, I'd like to know how many days of USENET messages are kept by your
Internet supplier? (eg 7 days, 14 days, 21 days or  ? )

The local monopoly keeps cutting down the number of days as the number of
groups increases, in order to avoid buying more disk space. 

SO, I need to know what the average and range is, in order to shame him into
bumping it back up.  :-)

Please, only reply if you get your USENET newsgroups from a PUBLIC Internet
supplier (such as Netcom) as opposed to reading it at work.

In other word, if you work at apple, don't reply to me about how many they
happen to keep at apple.com .

Thanks!

Ken
ken@macshasta.com

Yesterday I was at the party in the park and someone from this network (I 
think that maybe he is one of the originals on this network) came up to 
me and said if I minded the fact that a lot of people on this network 
were against me.  For a start, nobody is against anybody it's all just a 
matter of opinion.  If I had to face persecution/prosecution everytime I 
wanted to go out dancing it would not detere me one bit and I would hope 
that would go for anybody else who calls him/herself a raver.  And 
secondly, if people can't take what I say or think that I am being to 
negative then that's your problem.  If you can't take what I am saying 
then you are a lightweight and raving is only for the hardcore.  I, 
personally, could 
not give a fuck what people think of me.  I guess the following little 
rhyme sums it all up for me:
Raving is only for the hardcore,
For people who know the score. 
If you want some more,
Get on the dance floor.

     I would also like to take this oppotunity to say thank you to Mark 
and Tracy for a truely beautiful party yesterday.  Tracy, some times the 
music you play is so beautiful and so well written and so well mixed by 
you that at times it makes me cry and at others it makes me laugh out 
loud with joy.  Takke it from me Tracy, I have heard a lot of DJ's from 
all over the world in the last seven years and you are deffinatly one of 
the best DJ's I have ever heard.  When are you going to bring some tapes 
out?  It also had one of the nicest vibes I have experienced at a party 
for quite some time; it made me feel quite homesick.
     Thanks to all concerned for a lovly afternoon.  Look forward to 
seeing you all at Sunset today.  I'll be in my usual place by the speaker.
TRISTAN.

Rainbow Gathering trip report
=============================

Am now in Holbrook,  Az at a coffee shop,   where I was able to "plug in" and
extract my mail and upload this.

We left Sat evening at 10 pm,   arrived in Sedona,  Arizona,  our first stop
on the way to the Rainbow gathering.    I took the first drive shift,  and
brought
us to Arizona at about 10 am the next day,   after driving ll through the night.

>From here,  we are only 4 1/2 hours away from Tres Piedres.   Our plan is to get
up to the rest stop and get a little sleep before the final push to arrive
very early Monday Morning.

More later....

Crunchman

My coputer tells me that on Fri, 30 Jun 1995, Chris Chervin shared:

> Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 18:27:31 -0700
> From: Chris Chervin <sequoia1@ix.netcom.com>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: Please go to organic-- get way down!
> 
> Hey all,
> 
> Why is MTV filming a rave?  They dont even play house music.  
> 
> We all know that MTV is Bogus bull-shit but it is MTV.  It is big time 
> media.  The objective it to turn everyone on to this.  It is so magical 
> that we must teach the world.  Dont you feel that desire to have the 
> family grow?  If Organic goes off and MTV films it going off than that 
> is just fantastic. It is almost an obligation to make it to this party. 
> This is an excellent oppurtunity to turn someone out there on to what 
> life is all about.  Fuck-Yea!!!
> 
> love chris

Dear Chris,

	Thank you for clarifying this issue for me with your message.  
I'll admit, I initially found the idea of MTV filming at a rave 
distasteful.  But after reading your message, I realize you're right.  We 
have to present a positive image to non-ravers, whatever package they may 
come in, because positivity, love, and good vibes is what we are all 
about!  Moreover, the simple fact of the matter is, that anything on the 
"cutting edge" of culture that attracts significant numbers of young 
people, such as raves, is going to attract media organs like MTV (i.e., 
if you build it, they will come.)  I think the best way to react to this 
is by doing something unexpected, daring, and fun, yet not hostile in any 
way.  The "MTV Sucks" t-shirt idea strikes me as a good one.  Why not 
throw in a bit of good-natured self-deprecation, and at the same time, 
display something they will not dare to air?  Make shirts that say "MTV 
Sucks -- We Swallow!  :) "
	Or better yet, wear nothing at all at the party...

		Provocatively Yours,

					*** Starchild ***


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul  3 11:03:18 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA22135; Mon, 3 Jul 1995 11:03:18 -0700
Received: from netcom14.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA22129; Mon, 3 Jul 1995 11:03:15 -0700
Received: by netcom14.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id LAA25044; Mon, 3 Jul 1995 11:02:09 -0700
Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 11:02:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: Peter Fogel <peterf@netcom.com>
Subject: freedom
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9507031039.A21274-0100000@netcom14>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This party probably had the best music and on the best sound system I've 
ever heard at a party!  OOoohh wweeee did I have a great time!
We arrived sometime after 1am.  After wandering around in the dark trying 
to find some friends tent and camp set up, we finally located Lee and 
Janie with their famous bean bag chair.  It wasn't long after that other 
friends and their tents came by.  This was really helpful to have this 
base camp to go back to.  Even with a big group of people I still had 
trouble finding this basecamp every time I went back to it as there 
wasn't much light, except the incredible lazer show in the distance and a 
flashing stobe light by the dance floor.
Going to the dancefloor was an adventure as I wandered in the dark, and 
every once in a while would bump into other people I knew and other 
wandering ravers doing their own exploring.
After getting my feel of the surroundings, the incredible music just 
carryed me away.  The music felt soooo good, I don't think I ever danced 
so much at any party.  It wasn't easy for me to keep my body from jumping 
and bouncing to get a short rest.  I felt so immersed in the music and 
the energy around, my body just followed along and it felt so good to dance, 
release, and recycle the energy.
Although the water had run out by the time we arrived, and there wasn't 
any food being offered that we found, like the flyer said, it didn't matter.
Fortunately we had some of our own, and the great music way more than 
made up for any of that.
I got to say I really took full advantage in expressing my freedom by 
dancing all over the place, and I don't know if I ever felt more free 
than than this party.
Thanks Martin, all the great djs and everyone else for being part of the 
energy of this great party!


:)
peter

i can't believe it!  when i finally woke up this morning (i had to come
to work :( )  i was still smiling!  ahhhh, afterglow!
we went to organic saturday afternoon for a little dancing in the
dustbowl - fantastic!  i met so many people (so many sfravers!) my 
head was spinning.  all the music was really great, especially the 
old breakdance...i love that stuff.  big special thanks to tracy
for starting my day off right.  she was spinnin' when we got there
and it just threw me right onto the dancefloor and right into the mood.
after a little refueling at some excelent chinese restaurant we headed
for the hills, and more dustbowl dancing.
now, did i say i met people at organic?  well my head had just stopped
spinning when we got there, and then, jesus, here it goes again!  more
great people, more awesome music, and one phat laser show!  in spite
of it all, though, the best lights were those (heavenly) shooting
stars.  the stars and house music outside were perfect.  everything had
its own rythm - the music, the heavens, and the ravers - and it all
converged there in those hills just to get down!  
then, on top of all the other great things that night was the
jungle/dub/ambient/loseyourmindandrollaroundonthecarpet tent.  that was
the best!  so many friendly people and really really good music.  every
time i came back (i couldn't stay away too long) the music was different.
big hugs and thanks to everbody there.  it was great to meet all of you...
brian, blackadder, krystal, ... all of you!  and karen, what are doing
leaving town as soon as i meet you?  you are all the BEST!!!  
big special thanks to mike clay and diane tabellija for the rides!
what a wonderful weekend!  anybody up for nation tonight?

seth

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SF Raves)

Hi All,

The recent use of the phrase "fuck you" brought to mind this passage.  
Though the recent usage is a week stale, I still thought you might 
enjoy it.  It's from Carl Sagan's book, "Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors."

   We go to great lengths to deny our animal heritage, and not just in
   scientific and philosophical discourse.  You can glimpse the denial in
   the shaving of men's faces; in clothing and other adornments; in the
   great lengths gone to in the preparation of meat to disguise the fact
   that an animal is being killed, flayed, and eaten.  The common primate
   practice of pseudosexual mounting of males by males to express dominance
   is not widespread in humans, and some have taken comfort from this fact.
   But the most potent form of verbal abuse in English and many other
   languages is "Fuck you," with the pronoun "I" implicit at the beginning.
   The speaker is vividly asserting his claim to higher status, and his
   contempt for those he considers subordinate.  Characteristically, humans
   have converted a postural image into a linguistic one with barely a
   change in nuance.  The phrase is uttered millions of times each day, all
   over the planet, with hardly anyone stopping to think what it means.
   Often, it escapes our lips unbidden.  It is satisfying to say.  It
   serves its purpose.  It is a badge of the primate order, revealing
   something of our nature despite all our denials and pretensions.

Ook-ook eep,

Purple Tiger

...Another one of those dazed and confused weekends where time not spent 
enjoying the party was used in pursuit of the next one. Along the way 
recognizing more and more people of that same circuit. A famaliar face asks 
for my name and for some reason I answer "It's really not that important." 
Not trying to be stuck-up, but at that particular moment in time just 
happened to feel that it was true. 

...A few people commented that the music Saturday night wasn't as 
specalized as they were accustomed to. I think that for such a large 
outdoor crowd-control situation that doesn't have any enclosed walls to 
compress the molecules you need a different sound: a steady pulse that 
woun't dissapate or lose itself. It also gave me the oppurtunity to wander 
circles around a field, walk up a hill and then come down a mountain, and 
explore quite a few other neat places: which is a dance you really can't 
do in most clubs or wharehouses.  

...The bus transportation from the city made it possible for myself and a 
handful of other kids to reach Freedom, a unique event that normally 
would have been beyond our individual means of production. It's nice to 
see when someone takes the time to put their words into action and create 
something more tangable than some cliche slogan on a flyer, esspically 
when it would seem to be a wiser financial move to do without it all 
together.

Thanks.

Bolger

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul  3 21:55:42 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA21449; Mon, 3 Jul 1995 21:55:42 -0700
Received: from saclink1.csus.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id VAA21442; Mon, 3 Jul 1995 21:55:39 -0700
Received: by saclink1.csus.edu

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 21:53:42 -0700 (PDT)
From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: short weekend report
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9507032108.A118-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I wore myself out this weekend doing the rave marathon, and boy did it 
feel GOOD! I'm very pleasantly exhausted. :)
Organic Saturday afternoon, Freedom Saturday night, and Sunset on Sunday.

Freedom was incredible.  I had been to smallish parties for the last 6 
months, so the sheer number of people was almost overwhelming. It took 
awhile find a spot where it didn't feel like a busy sidewalk with people 
coming and leaving constantly. Once I found that spot though, I was 
locked into the groove all night long.  I never tranced so hard in all my 
life! That music and my "altered state of mind" took me on a very 
intense journey.  Remember that song that sounded like a race car?!?!
HOLEY SHEEEIT!! That was sooooooo cool! I couldn't sit down all night 
long, and I was like a zombie on my feet by the time Spun finished his 
set.  But towards the middle of Garth's set I found a second wind with 
the help of my friend Greg's bubbly energy.  I loved the way we all 
formed a circle and held hands in the early morning sun.  Aaahhh I love 
raving! :)  Take care everybody!

love,
Amy

From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)

Subject: re: BSP's
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 23:22:38 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2261      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Recently , Rick Riffle asked us all nicely about doing a Blatant Self 
Promotion (BSP) to the SFRaves mailist:
> Subject: BSP's
> 
> Is it wrong for me to post a show I know about to the list?  Is that
> considered a BSP?  

 Only is the "self" part is involved. 

> What if I'm dj'ing, or if it's my show.  

 Yup - those are instances of BSPs.

> I've posted
> show's I've dj'd at to the list, because I want people to know about them.
> I don't say come to the show because I'm dj'ing, but I will probably make
> mention that I'm playing.  Is that wrong of me to do?  

 I don't feel it's wrong , as long as you establish the "self" part - what
seems to annoy a lot of folks on SFRaves is the posting of "advertisements"
that lack a personal touch - more of a feeling of a sales pitch rather than
a friend telling other friends about their party that's coming up.

 At the risk of missing some important points and coming up with advice
that nobody agrees with , here's my best-guess guidelines for BSPs on
SFRaves -

1. Keep it humble. Your may consider your event a hyper-meta-physical
   ultra-fabulous greatest-thing-since-Megatripolis gift-to-ravers ,
   but try to keep that attitude to a minimum in your post. We've heard
   enough corporate egomania in 30 second commercials to tolerate much
   of the same in our email. 

2. Keep it personal. If you've been distributing flyers , don't bother
   to repeat every single line of promo and hype. Even if you don't 
   have flyers , don't let it read like a flyer! As I suggested above,
   the tone of a friend talking to other friends goes down better.

3. Keep it terse . If you're using more than 48 lines of text to tell
   us about your event , maybe you should do some editing...
   [ One exception - Don't stint on the directions! ]
 
> I just keep reading
> stuff about BSP's and wonder if I'm one of them. 

 You can't BE one , unless you walk around with your rave flyers stapled
to your forehead!

> Am I supposed to just mail directly to the sfraves calendar keeper 
> and not post to the list?
 
 Go ahead and post those messages to SFRaves.  Just keep 'em humble , 
personal , and terse , and you won't catch any flack from me! 

 Larry "PR , sweetie , PR !!!" Ching / larryc@netcom.com

I don't know what's been going on in your private email, but I'm sure you've
only experienced the opinions of a small number of the list members.  There
are literally hundreds of people reading this list, and some of them may
agree with your earlier posts.  One thing is for sure, you're not going to
find any aggreement with your above assertions on this list.  Why?  Well, if
they agreed with you they certainly wouldn't be on this list, right?  So try
not to alienate everyone with general statements.

> Goddess only knows why people who call themselves ravers and offer up
> goodwill at the drop of a hat on the dancefloor, see it fit to burn witches
> in cyberspace.

The list's character changes all the time depending on which posters are
hammering email that week.  Relax, ride out the storm, and don't take things
personally.

Subject: Relgion, Alien's & the Internet Re: Internet Bill of Rights 
In-Reply-To: <199506271814.LAA01370@netcom2.netcom.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950703232155.18313B-100000@liberty.liberty.com>

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Dear All;

	I feel somehow they will say that the Internet is excluded from
Freedom of Speech, reasons to follow. But I do feel that you are right
Neil, that if the Internet had exsisted back in the 18th Century they
would have included as part of Freedom of Speech, most definately, & 
more on the positive Internet potential later.

	I feel they will attempt to exclude it from under contituional
control because they need more ways to control us, and the Internet if it
falls into the hands of the government has the power & the future
potential to do that. 

	Old Relgion is slowly fadeing away, the believe in Christ based
God in our soceity diminsies everyday. I personally feel man created this
entity for the purpose, initially of explaining things that couldn't be
explained, and also found that it was effective tool for controling the 
masses and bringing about order from chaos.

	Please do not confuse spiritually with relgion, they are two very
different things. For I like to think am a very spiritual person, or at
least to say I try an approach this state of being. But relgion by
defination is a system of worship, devised by people. 

	The Bible & its simlar counterparts, were documents that was
interpreted & passed down from person to person, generation to generation,
literally at times, by word of mouth. Due to this form of record keeping I
feel that the Bible & its counter parts have a very high proability, or at
least a lot of opportunity, of being altered or corrupted along the way.
Especially knowing and taking into account human nature, greed, lust
...etc. Also taking into account the levels of corruption in the various
houses of God though out history, war, fire ...etc. 

	So what would happen to the state of world stability if all of a
sudden, relgion, or believe in a God, was found out to be incorrect or
void. That would mean, that you would spend your time on earth here, and
then die, and that would be it. I feel that some people would just rape,
pillage & kill, to serve their own needs, without any fear of reprocusions
of an after life eg heaven & hell. This would be especially prevalent in
3rd world societies, where ignorance & fear already rule. I think most of 
us got the idea that hurting people wasn't ok, from some form of relgion 
either in our lifes or our parents lives.

	So what could prove that God doesn't exsist, lets say that whole
Aliens think turned out to be true, that there were other lifeforms out
there. We were, as the Bible tells us, created in the image of
God(whatever that means). Christ, the Son of God, was a man, and was
created in our image according to the Bible. So then all of a sudden you
get these little dudes with antenni(just Kidding), and four arms, on world
wide TV. How will relgion explain this, the Bible makes no reference to
other planets, or even other lifeforms other than human(I'm not a student
of the Bible, however). Relgion will attempt to explain it with yet
another interpretation, vision(Da Pope on Acid), dream, or say these
creatures/beings are the spawn of the Devil(nothing like a little
planetary racisum). Which I feel will only serve to further the
non-exsistance of God, by weaking faith further(more spreading of hate). I
also feel that present day reglion conflicts with itself a lot, but I
could go on forever with that one; and for example the Pope's recent 
racist comment about Buddisum.

	I feel we are not alone in our universe, and that our government 
as well as other governments know this, and see that the old systems of 
control are starting to weaken. Everyday we see more & more world chaos 
on our TV's. Nothing is, sacred or the same anymore, and everything is 
changing so fast. As they say, constant change is here to stay.

	Here comes the internet, digital technology, total control of
potentially all digitized knowledge, history, & potentialy even reality. 
This type of technology can easially & eventually be in every home, hut, &
cave in our world. Its just a matter of resources, meaning things that can
be created by society. In otherwords, no new technology has to be created
or devised, the systems need to be enlarged however to acomadate the
expanded user base. Most houses built in and after the 70's are already
wired for a telephone, videophone, & cable. The telephone company
installed the digital switching networks necessary to make the present and
not to distant future Internet function, 5 - 7 years a head of schedule. 
The telephone company, which is to a larger degree a major part of the
internet, is always in a state of upgrading/retrofiting old equipment with
new equipment. Harddrive prices are at an all time low, something like
,39/mb, down from .90/mb, just last year. Memory chips still remain
pricey, but I image in time they will fall as well, as does the price of
most computer stuff. Look for memory to be traded on the comodites market,
within 10 years, that's my prediction. The average price of a relatively 
powerful computer is afordable by most indivuals and families. 

	So why hasn't it already happened? There is a user education lag,
with a relativeity cyptic interface to deal with, meaning ATT Unix System
5 Version 4 & its clones. Although, more point & click netbrowsers 
are making it easier for even the most novice of users to surf the 
net, eg Netscape, Mosaic. More of peoplekinds written knowledge needs to
be digitized, and stored for available access on the net, this means that
everything from books to newspapers, need to be routinely digitized, along
with all da backlog/archives of the worlds knowledge. The commerial
people, people that provide services, and products on the Internet need to
start offering more for less money, and with more payment alternatives
than a credit card to purchase whatever, eg bankcard ...etc. The banks,
and other services need to, even though they are already on the Internet,
expand their systems & services to handle commerical traffic's size &
needs. But for the most part the systems of the net just need to be
enlarged to handle more users, providers, & vendors. In digital
technology, each time you upgrade or enlarge your system's cabilites, you
at least double your exsisting capacity, geometrically expanding each step
up. 

	The Internet's sorta like an addictive drug that you give people,
you get them hooked in, two or three generations pass, and this is the way
people are used to doing things, like getting mail, paying bills, cashless
society & other basic life stuff. They forget how things were done before,
they become dependent on the this system, and way of doing things. For
example, being an engineer I have a lot of mathematical skill. Yet I
heavially rely on a calculator to do my routine calcualtions. I remember I
was out in the field one day and my batteries died. I had to do the
calcualtions myself, and what was cake in grade school became a royal pain
in the butt for even the most basic of calculations. So what happens if a
system of checks & balances aren't in place on the Internet, and our
government or a corporation decides to pull the pug on whomever they don't
like or agree with. You are then locked out, your penniless(cashless
society), you can't get basic services, at the push of a button your an
excile in your own home & country. It sounds like something from Big
Brother, but in a digitized world, where information can be changed, all
things are possible, from a minor mistake, to history being changed. 
There needs to be strict data integity monitors, either a commitee of
human beings, or something hardcoded in the data to protect the information
that is history. Because as more & more of the world's knowledge is
digitized, the less we will be relient on the written/printed word. 

	As much as our governments look to the internet as a way to 
control societies & people, it looks on it with tremenous fear as well. The 
internet has the potential of making societies where DIRECT democary 
works. DIRECT democary is were the people wright, and vote on all 
legsiation that has to due with that particular country. No more congress 
people or representatives, I would however image the need for some staff to 
take care of some of the lesser task's of government. You as a citzen 
would be responsible for taking part in our government, from your 
desktop, voting & introducing significant legislation. 

	It has the potential to end fear poltics, by getting the peoples
of the world talking with each other. The internet levels the power
playing field, it gives indivuals the power to reach millions, meaning
everyone is the same. The more the whole of society embraces this
technology, the more power we will have as indivuals, and the less BS our 
governments will be able feed us. With the Internet you have a common 
world language, a machine language, but its common. There is no doubt in my
mind that the Internet can play a significant role in helping bring about 
world peace. With the use of videophones, an electronic language 
translators, the leaders of our world can meet more often, and more 
informally.

	It has the potential to improve our environment, for example if
all regular mail went to E-Mail. We would use sooo much less paper, have
to cut down fewer trees. With video phone links, the necessity to travel
would be reduced, reducing our overall usage & dependence on poluting
fossil & nuclear fission fuels, by several orders of magnitude. People
could stay home with their families and work over the phone lines,
improving the quality of the family unit in our country & the world ..etc. 

	As far as a knowledge base, and an education tool. The internet
can bring the sum of the world's digitized knowledge to the remotest of
the world's corners, and with a videophone link, a teacher as well. Which
means it has the potential to end world ignorance and also education the
world. Also once digitized, the content & appearence of acient reference
books, and manuscripts can be made available to anyone, not just
researchers, anytime their needed. Everybook, in every libray around the 
world at your finger tips.

	I personally will take any attempt by our government to limit, censor,
or control the internet, as a direct attack on the Constituion of the U.S, 
by our government. But I do feel more ammendments are needed to the 
constition to ensure our freedom & the freedom of the net, into & though the 
22nd century.

	The Consitution & the Delaration of Indenpence are beautiful
documents. I was born on the day they signed the Delaration of Indenpence,
only 186 years later. They called themselves an assembly of demigods, the
authors of those two documents. They are old documents, where we are a
modern society compared to 200 years ago. They must be carefully brought
into modern times, without any compromise to our personal freedom. I feel
the reason some of the other countries have been able to do so well, so
fast, is because they have a relativity new consitution & charter, take
Japan for example, their consitution has only been around since the end of
WW2. 

	Well, I take this stuff pretty seriously as you can tell, less the
Aliens & Relgion stuff. The Aliens & Relgion stuff is just a theroy, 
its got a lot of holes, but no more than any of the modern relgions do at 
present. I understand why, if these beings did exsist why our 
government would want to keep the knowledge of their exsist a very important 
secret. On the positive side I feel such knowledge could destablize our
world further. On the negative side, well lets not even thing about that.

	Being born on a day where so much psychic energy was & is
happening, its hard to explain my relationship with it, and the way it
makes me feel. I believe in the self, I believe thats where our savalation
is, by acknowledging the self, and how truely wonderful & unique you are,
you can't help but see it in others, and know that all creatures big &
small, intelligent & dumb, have a right to be, and exsist, in their
natural state, and on their path. So anything that assits us in developing
our uniqueness and indivuallity, gives us more headroom, gives us more
freedom, allows us to find & fufill our indivual destinies, transfers more
power from the governments & corporations to the indivuals/self, I am of
course for. 

	The Internet as it grows and becomes more a part of our everyday
lifes, means that we must elect computer literate politicians(Not Petey),
who believe in a free internet, and understand the potential that the
internet can bring to a free society, our world's environment, and our
world's stability & and also its pitfalls and traps that could potentially
enslave a free soceity. The way I look at it, the next 10 years is going
to be like 1776, only we won't be fighting the british for our freedom, we
will be fighting our government, corporations, and people who want to
limit our personal, and our children's freedom and Liberty on net. Nows
the time to make your voices, concerns, and idea's heard, not after the
legisaltion is written, by people like Exon, who are computer 
illiteriate. Also, being the world's Internet leader, what we achieve or 
fail to acomplish with regard to the amount of personal freedom allowed 
on the net, will set the standard for the world. The world, with 
reference to the net will take our lead, so net awareness, participation 
in electronic protest against efforts to limit net freedom, and active 
participation in elections for candiates who are computer literiate, 
and are for pro-Internet freedom, are necessary to ensure that the internet 
remains as unrestricted as it is today.

	I remember the movie Sneakers, when Robert Redferd was talking
with his x partner, and the x-partner said, that today's power is not
about who has the most bombs & missles, it's who controls the information,
and I really believe that. I don't want to have to get a permit to send
someone a post just because it's out of the country. I don't want my
private messages read by a government censor, checking for content. I
personally want to be able to get access to & be in charge of all my
personal information, say what I feel & think, and go where ever I have
legal access to go to on the net; how bout you? The future is my
responsibility.

> 
> I like Tristan's statement and agree w/ the sentiment. IMHO, there's no
> need for an internet bill of rights because it should be 100% covered
> by existing protections provided by the constitution and in particular
> "freedom of speech." Any "special" internet bills will just be a way to
> slowly regulate it, shut it down, and make it less easy to use for acts
> of FREEDOM and SEDITION against oppressive governments. 
> 
> The reason why the gummint is running scared is precisely because the
> internet, personal publishing, easy and potentially anonymous/secure
> communications all allow us to maintain better vigil over our freedoms
> and rights, which is  something which the US founding fathers sought
> when they formed the US gummint. This of course runs contrary to the
> actual practices of our government -- decisions being made behind
> closed doors, with "national security" used as a front and a cover
> story. That and lobbying/rulemaking done by a clique of moneyed,
> well-connected insiders (political action commities, for example) that
> attempt to shove laws through before the public finds out what is going
> on. The internet cuts through all the guff, at least for the people
> vigilant enough, and literate enough to know how to read. However, this
> tool will only work for people that care, and are smart enough to
> engage their critical abilities, or at least not to be swayed by
> Goebbels-like emotion-rich/fact-starved oratory (e.g. Rush Limbaugh).
> The price of freedom is eternal vigilance, a terminal/modem, and
> $17.50/month to your internet provider.
> 
> One can say the same thing about the internet that Arlo Guthrie said
> about his guitar: "THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS!" Lets open the floodgates
> to all and *DISCUSS*, or *DEBATE*, or whatever. Make FLAMES not BOMBs!
> 
> --------------------
> 
> However, I do have one nit to pick (as usual) w/ tristan's post:
> 
> > am intelligent enough to be able to decide what I can and and what I can 
> > not with out a set of rules, or a bunch of men, telling me what to and 
> > how to think. Remember, the terms regulation suppression are exactly the 
> > same.

Rick,

  I don't mind BSP's in the least as long as they are 1) fairly short and to
the point  2) not trying to BSP your own long winded philosophy of how the
whole of rave culture should go ( now who would do that ? )  3) have to do
with rave related activity and 4) you're not trying to sell Rickco "spinning
knife" sets or how to pick up ravers at a party books.... in other words 
don't try to sell me cheeze products best left for the late LATE show ads...


  If these really "elitist" conditions are met, I'd be the first to defend
your right to post to the list and I will very much on the whole even welcome
your posts....

My $.02

Subject: Freekdom
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 4 Jul 95 10:20:58 PDT
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com, greysix@netcom.com
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Freedom was pretty intense.  We got there before 1 and bypassed the stuffy
ambient and boring vendor tents for the main party grounds where a hard
trancey John Williams assault was taking place.  The sound was incredible,
perhaps the best I've ever heard, and the visuals were nice, too.

As expected for a big party this early, the energy was chaotic.  People 
were wandering about, greeting each other, hanging out, dancing solo or in 
clumps.  There was plenty of room, but aimless partiers collided in the dark
as they tried to figure out where they should be.  The music wasn't doing
much for me but I decided to check out the dance situation anyway.  It
was a pretty dismal scene.  With a thousand or so people, it seemed  strange
that there was so much wide open space in the area in from of the DJ booth
where you'd expect the vibe to be thickest. 

There was a wide range of people and styles at this party; from suburban kids
in their mall-bought outfits to genuine freakozoids.  Many seemed to be there
because it was a holiday weekend.  There were a lot of what i'd describe as 
"hicks"; the kind that are always getting abducted from their farms by UFOs
and then dropped off somewhere else years later not remembering anything.  I 
really don't have the adjectives to describe some of the many oddities; it
was as though every neighborhood in Northern California sent a couple of 
their weirdest citizens as representatives.  Plenty of ravers showed up too,
or at least people who looked like ravers.  We even recognized a few. d:)

So basically, I felt that the vibe kinda sucked for a "rave".  Although 
most were having fun with their friends and many were dancing, there was 
a lack of unity and group focus.  Usually it's the music that brings us
together, but on this night people were there to party, or just be out 
somewhere.  As far as drugs goes, there seemed to be 2 kinds of people;
those who were doing them and those who looked like they wanted to be
drinking alchohol.

The sound was amazing and when Tony came on, nothing else mattered.  Fuck
the group vibe, there was some serious music going on.  I though he spun one
of his best sets ever: acid-drenched beats that hit you like giant rubber 
balls...or something like that.  I was in sonic heaven.  Spun's set was
even more amazing; trippy psychedelic stuff with indescribably wild
polyrythms.

When the light came out it looked like a freak show; something inbetween a 
circus and an insane asylum.  It was *very* entertaining.  

Then, near the end of Spun's set, something seemed to change.  I was
saying to Janie (for the nth time) This music is incredible!" and I noticed 
that a tight group of dancers had formed at the center to complement 
the speaker tweakers who had been going off relentlessly up on the platforms
for most of the night.  Mark Ameba was being a total lunatic up on the
roof of the DJ booth and people were starting to scream.  The makeup of the
crowd seemed to have shifted as though a new crop had just shown up from
another party. When Garth took the helm, 9 hours into the event, it suddenly
felt like a true rave to me.  Had Garth brought his own posse just
for his set?  I did a reality check, sharing many of my views with others
(not that anyone still left at this party had much of a grip on reality
anymore).  Some agreed, some felt the vibe had been fine from the beginning.

Garth played a set similar to the one at the bandshell.  He was all over the
place; some slow deep funk that was absolutely wicked, disco, house, even
herbie hancock... it all sounded great and continued to blow my mind.

When it was over we tried to score some breakfast.   I managed to wave to
Joe who was still spinning to half-dead bodies in the ambient tent and I
hugged Ethan whose face was frozen with a shiteating grin.  At this point, 
though, I had been reduced to a semi-coherant idiot, and so it was time 
to hit the road.


Lee
_______________________________________________________________________________ lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, here I am home again the the Great White North.  Apart from the fact
that I now get to live in the main floor of a big house, I WANT TO BE IN
SF!!!!

I was completely blown away by the thoughtfulness and friendliness of
everyone I met.  I experienced such an outpouring of love and generosity
that I have NO idea how I'll be able to repay you all ...... except that if
any of you are going to be heading up to Vancouver, you have a place to
stay!!!!! :)

I'm so glad that I got to experience a Sunset and an Organic ...... and
everything else I got to experience ....

Big skwooshy hugs go out to Amy S., Tony T., Jake, Matt, DJ Ethan, Michael
C., Jan, Sarvi, Peter F., Seth, Brian M., and all the other SF ravers I met
whose names escape me because I'm DAMN tired.

David Minuk, I'm sorry we weren't able to hook up ... I tried to call you
on Wednesday night but you were on the modem for hours .... :( oh well,
next time.

Starchild, I apologize for not calling back on Friday evening but things
got a little screwy ... and then I got sidetracked by some little pits of
paper ... I enjoyed meeting you very much and everyone here LOVES the
flyers you gave me.

Very special thanks and cuddles go out to Brian Darkness for Thursday
afternoon, Saturday's little favour, and just for being himself.  Let me
know when you're gonna use that free ticket!

And last but most CERTAINLY not least .... to Black Adder & his lady Reagan
for being such amazing hosts.  You're marvelous and I hope to see you up
here soon so I can give back a little of what you gave to me.

I left my heart in San Francisco .....


karen

From: "Michael E. Clay" <meclay@netcom.com>
Subject: Boy Do I Appreciate F&F
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9507041234.A16040-0100000@netcom9>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk


The more events I go to the more I come to realize just how special F&F and
Harmony and Sunset and Cloud Factory and New Moon ( and some other small
idenpendant collectives really are ).... I had a great time at Organic in the
park and then Freedom ( but F&F's still top it because for me the best energy
at Freedom was that of my independant friends anyway )...

Last night, silly boy, I decided to go to Nation thinking with big name DJ's
( at high cost ) the vibe would be worth it... talk about a waste of my money
and time... boring... been there done it... Disco lives - the vibe was 
EXACTLY like Denver Disco clubs I went to in the mid 70's... Not bad per se
but just very flat and boring in the light of an F&F... I'm spoiled!!! People
were shouting on the dance floor true but that does not a good party make...

As an experiment I went around the club twice trying my best to make eye 
contact with ONLY ONE partial success - one woman caught my gaze for an 
instant - oopps too much commitment - break off quick - whew here's my man 
just in time... I almost laughed as she went back to her coupled state...
But I did find out that dancing in couples is still alive and well...
 
I hope that nobody who goes to these club affairs really thinks it has 
much to do with raving... it has the music, it has the lasers, it has the
visuals but it really, REALLY, REALLY lacks the "VIBEEEEE" -- where is
Milton when we need him ?

 So we must get on with the show and get these independent celebrations
happening - they really are where it's at and they really are something
very beyond the ordinary....

Just thinking,

Mike


 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & Estatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

RE: BSP's again -

 In your promo posting to SFRaves , if your event is going to charge
admission ( or even just a donation ) , MENTION IT! Even if you don't
know how much will be asked for , including what little you know
will go towards building goodwill for your BSP. 

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

My computer tells me that on Tue, 4 Jul 1995, Larry Ching shared:

> Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 18:17:20 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Larry Ching <larryc@netcom.com>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: More BSP Etiquette
> 
> 
> RE: BSP's again -
> 
>  In your promo posting to SFRaves , if your event is going to charge
> admission ( or even just a donation ) , MENTION IT! Even if you don't
> know how much will be asked for , including what little you know
> will go towards building goodwill for your BSP. 
> 
>  Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

	On a similar note, I have observed that many promoters neglect to 
mention the amount they're going to charge, either on their fliers or on 
their voice-mail messages.
	This is a blatant discourtesy to those who will be attending the 
party, and when I see it, it tells me that the persons throwing the party 
are more concerned with making money than with building community.
	There's only one good reason I can see for not letting people 
know the cost -- you're afraid that if they knew, they wouldn't come.	
	Some promoters take a halfway approach.  They'll announce that 
cover will be "only $5 before 11pm," failing to mention that the price 
will double thereafter and knowing full well that the party won't really 
get going until midnight anyway.  
	Kind of reminds me of those auto dealer ads you hear on the 
radio: "No money down! No monthly payments till June of 97!"  Of course 
they don't mention that starting next June, you'll be paying $1000 a 
month each month for the next 20 years, and if you miss a payment there's 
a $100 finance charge, plus compound interest.
	I don't mind paying $15 or $20 for a really good, big party, but 
it better be worth it.  And if you think it is, have the guts to tell 
people up front how much they'll have to pay.

	Galactic hugs & cosmic kisses,

	        		*** Starchild ***

"To each according to their ability to service the needs
        of others, as directed by the valuations of those served."

		-Ian Goddard's revision of Karl Marx's maxim.

Good news!  There's a calendar-only list, if that's all you want.

subscribe sfraves-calendar

in the body of the message.  You can also get it via WWW at
http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html
any time you wish.

 I've been thinking of organizing a dinner in the South Bay
as a kind of pre-event get-together. Folks from North Bay , Mid Peninsula,
South Bay, and points east could meet and eat before drivng over HW880/17 
to the event. 

 Please keep me informed!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

 "Those who can't rave , post ..."

>From: Peter Fogel <peterf@netcom.com>
>Subject: freedom

>We arrived sometime after 1am.  ...
>Although the water had run out by the time we arrived, and there wasn't 

>any food being offered that we found, like the flyer said, it didn't matter.
>Fortunately we had some of our own, and the great music way more than 

>made up for any of that.

whoa!  the water had run out?  staying well-hydrated is a medical necessity  
when using MDMA, especially in combination with physical exertion.  safe guess  
that a few people at Freedom were dosed and dancing, eh?  seems to me it's  
grossly negligent for a producer of a full-price commercial rave not to have  
plenty of water on hand.  in fact, i believe that great britain, after several  
rave/MDMA deaths, enacted a law requiring that clubs/raves make water freely  
available.  i'm glad that you and others had a great time, peter, but if the  
water ran out at Freedom, and early at that, seems to me Rave Consumer Reports  
would rate the event NOT ACCEPTABLE.


>From: Starchild <rrose@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>

>	On a similar note, I have observed that many promoters neglect to 

>mention the amount they're going to charge, either on their fliers or on 

>their voice-mail messages.
>	This is a blatant discourtesy to those who will be attending the 

>party, and when I see it, it tells me that the persons throwing the party 

>are more concerned with making money than with building community.
>	There's only one good reason I can see for not letting people 

>know the cost -- you're afraid that if they knew, they wouldn't come.

couldn't agree more.  i've pretty much adopted a policy of not attending raves  
for which pricing is not fully disclosed in advance.  for a few years now, i've  
left messages on rave info line vmailboxes politely asking for this information  
- the same producers that haven't disclosed prices in the past continue not to  
do so.  i agree with starchild's assessment of the probable motive.  i'll rave  
elsewhere, thanks.

sorry for bitching.  on a positive note, i thought the sunset party on sunday  
was especially nice (my favorite nearby location!).  not many people dancing  
circa four thirty, but by six or so it was gearing up.  warm, mellow, friendly  
gathering.  wish i could've stayed longer.  thank you once again, Pacific gang!   
- bob

Hey all,

        This isn't strictly rave related, but I thought some of you would
find this interesting.  It just goes to show how many lies you can spread
when you've got money on your side.

>
>file://www.clark.net/pub/murple/local/beer.vs.drugs
>
>
>>                                BEER VS. DRUGS
>> 
>>      This incredible heap of shit is from a propaganda poster produced by
>> Anheuser-Busch, the "Proud distributors" of Budweiser, Michelob, Busch,
>> Natural Light, and LA Carlsberg beers, Elephant malt liquor, and Eagle brand
>> snacks. They also donate $50,000 yearly to the PDFA, and in June 1991, while
>> sponsoring a rock festival in Houston, replaced Santana with REO Speedwagon
>> after Carlos Santana's pot bust. At any rate, this poster is a big part of
>> why I no longer drink much alcohol in general, and no US made beers in
>> general. It is a marvelous work of the fine art of diarrheal printing, and
>> its singleminded babbling makes it worthy of framing or use as a dartboard.
>> Also makes fine toilet paper. Best yet, print it out on a rolling paper and
>> twist a big joint with it.
>>      It is a chart comparing beer on one side and "illegal drugs" on the
>> other. Note the amusing grouping of pot with two addictive drugs. It is
>> quite funny how "crack" and "cocaine" are two separate drugs in this
>> posters' universe. The ending paragraph is quite humorous as well. Enjoy!
>>      PS: There is a pretty widespread boycott of Anheuser-Busch until they
>> retract these blatant lies among anti-WoSD peoples. Perhaps you should
>> consider joining in on it.
>> 
>> ---Begin Propaganda Mode---
>>

Precedence: bulk


If I may be permitted an observation:

Flamewars happen when both sides of an argument invest ego in their
remarks.  This is not necessarily bad, but it often seems to happen
after the fact.  For example:

A makes an offhand comment about a party
being boring (or whatever), and B defends that party, and
instead of leaving it at that, A decides that B's view is a
challenge to the legitimacy of their own, and invests ego in it.
According to the ego, "there can be only one", and A attacks B.

B is hurt by this attack, and hir ego strikes back.  Now both agree
that there must be a winner and a loser, and combat is engaged.

When people talk face-to-face, there exist a multitude of non-verbal
cues to let people know how everyone is feeling.  Online, these do not
exist, since people have to get over a certain threshold of emotion
in order to post.  Therefore, the usual signals that let people know
that everyone either a) agrees with you, b) agrees with your friend,
c) thinks both of you are full of shit, or d) really doesn't care 
who's right, are all absent, and the little tempest of flying curses
veers off into the sunset.

I don't think people shouldn't argue.  I do think people should 
consider carefully whether to invest themselves in an intellectual
proposition, and also that sometimes silence is a more impressive argument
than insult.

// g

PS: If you're going to insult someone, please make it entertaining, OK?
That way we can at least laugh over the gratuitous violence.

Grigsbeast <grigsby@shell.portal.com> wrote:
> Flamewars happen when both sides of an argument invest ego in their
> remarks.  This is not necessarily bad, but it often seems to happen
> after the fact.  For example:
>
> [lots of good stuff deleted]

I'd like to add some comments of my own, if I could.

* Often, there is no need for a "winner" and a "loser".  As
  long as positions from both sides are aired, the readers
  can decide for themselves... In fact, most of the readers
  probably won't care one way or the other!  But as long as
  people feel they need to get in the last word, flamewars
  go on forever...

* Apologizing and admitting you're wrong when you ARE
  wrong is one of the hardest things to do, but it's
  also one of the most noble.  Keep that in mind.  I have a
  lot of respect for people who can do this, and very little
  for people who try to "win" every argument just for the
  sake of winning.

This has been your sappy thought for the day.  We now return
you to your regularly scheduled programming.

-Sho
--
sho@physics.purdue.edu <<-- finger this account to find out what I'm
                            having for lunch!

From: Robert Jesse <rjesse@us.oracle.com>

Received: by NeXT.Mailer (1.87.1)
Received: by NeXT Mailer (1.87.1)
To: sfraves@sfraves.org
Subject: church/religion
Reply-To: bob@csp.org
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>From: hpcprod@lcc1.nsc.com (Craig Lauxman)

>ps. About the church thing, dance is a form of prayer for me so when I go
>to events it's almost like going to church. 


amen!  er, i agree.

surely there are lots of reasons to be uninterested in, or even to dislike,  
what most of us think of as "church" or "religion" - images of rigid,  
controlling, moralistic, patriarchal, institutions that have been responsible  
for lots of bloodshed and misery.  but not all "churches" or "religions" are  
like that.

sometimes it's easier to adopt a new word than to change the unwanted  
associations surrounding an established word.  hence "gay" instead of  
"homosexual"; "african-american" instead of "colored".  and so many of us think  
of ourselves as "spiritual" rather than "religious".

in the case of religion, however, there is a reason to reclaim the distasteful  
word instead of replacing it:  the first amendment to the U.S. constitution  
protects the free exercise of religion, not free exercise of spirituality.   
that right seems too valuable to throw away just because we don't like what  
some religions have been.

instead of dwelling on distasteful past or present "religions", how about  
imagining religions that we *would* like?

people knowing there wouldn't be a party?

At 1:09 PM 7/5/95, Rick Riffle wrote:
>>Also, all this stuff about the Celistian profocies is also
>>bullshit.  It's all a lie invented by the Illuminatai in an effort
>>to brain wash people who can not believe in God.
>>TRISTAN.
>
>
>In your opinion ofcource?
>
>Personally, that book came in near the beginning of my spiruality, which is
>now the dominate force in my life.  CP helped to crystalize alot of beliefs
>and feelings that I developed on my own through my own experiences.  I
>believe it generalizes alot of the subject matter, but for a book like that
>to be read and taken to heart by the millions of people who are now reading
>it can only benefit our race IMHO.  I think it can open the door to
>spirituality for alot of people who need it.  Once the door is open they can
>individually dig deeper to find what's really true for them.  I have.
>
>I think it's an excellent book.
>
>Rick

        I didn't want to step in on this too early as i do have a hand in
this.  I have not attended any of the parties due to economic/geographical
problems and so i only get second hand information on what they were like.
I do know that this is a book that i _personally_ have found very
enlightening, not so much a door unto itself but a key.  Ok, there are
problems with it prose-wise (i was an english student 1st year ;) but i
think that that is beside point.  The ideas contained in this book are
nothing new to ppl who have investigated mostly every eastern religion (and
have even studied the words of the bible, less the 'religion') but when
these ideas, alien to most in the west, are presented in an easily read but
stimulative package...well i agree, only good can come of it.  I personally
believe that 'beleif creates reality' (if that isn't too hard to follow,
sorry, haha). For example, i think that something as simple as positive
thought is a _direct_ neurochemical trigger.  It's also dialectical, if one
has certain 'happy chemicals' running through their body, positive thoughts
will arise.  The point i'm trying to make is that if you invest faith in a
belief system it will affect your 'real' life.  Maybe this is why the world
is so messed up as the attainment of material wealth and various other
belief systems which underlie all of our actions are, IMHO, false and can
act as the backbone to our present social order...but i blab too much...
        i say believe what you want to believe, do what you want to do just
as long as it doesn't step on anyone's toes.
        ps-->there are a lot of bits in the insights that are actually
being substantiated by chaos theory and modern physics, if this is 'proof'
enough of their worth.

> 
> I thought I had read all their was to read in pretentious  flyers until 
> I read the flyer for the next Prgress party.  People here know that I 
> do not care for manifesto's or people telling me what to think; this 
> is not what rave culture is all about.  BUt the people who wrote 
> this flyer are obviously unaware of this fact so what they are doing 
> in the rave scene in the first place is a tatal mystery to me.  Why 
> don't you all try going to church instead if you people like hot air 
> so much?  And anyway, your party sucks: I went to the first one and 
> it was bad, really bad.  So get off the religion tip now and people 
> might then start taking you seriously; because right now Prgress, 
> and the people involved with it, are the laughing stock of the 
> entire SF rave community.

i'm not partying much these days so i haven't been to a progress party 
myself, tho i'm curious to see just how they integrate the Celestine 
Prophecy stuff into the party... 

but i couldn't let this one fly by without a response (cuz my funny virgo 
mind really enjoys picking apart people's arguments!)
first, a flyer about spirituality and/or ideology is not necessarily 
"telling people how to think."  it's one way of looking at the world, 
that's all. you can take it or leave it or modify it if you want.  and 
rave culture is whatever we want to make it and it's certainly not 
homogenous and there's certainly room for spirituality/religion.  
second, dance can be spiritual.  and why confine spirituality to a 
church?  i live and breathe it every day (tho if you simply want to 
breathe exhaust fumes that's up to you!)

actually, i'm done "picking apart" (ain't that much to pick! might as 
well pick my nose!), but i've got a question:

does anyone have a copy of The Celestine Prophecy they would lend out?  
i've been tempted to read it just to see what the fuss is all about, but 
i've only seen it in hardback (unfortunately a pretty damn exclusive 
format. alas.)

anyway, please email me in person if you have this bok floating around, 
looking for a temporary home (and i take very good care of books!)

thanks and take care everyone!\
monicat

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Summer continues with outdoor parties from Frequency 8, 
Gateway Systems, and Sunset.  Check 'em out and support the underground!
In SF, Frankie Knuckles is at the Sound Factory on Friday night, and
catch Garth in his retro phase at Wicked on Saturday.  (he's been diggin
out the oldies at the park last weekend and Come-Unity).  

Thanks everyone for the updates, and keep on helping me clean out the
weeklies if you know something has ended.  I don't really go out to
everything on the list!


                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html
    
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, July 7th - Frequency 8 presents Cybertrance Waveform
   DJs Cyr, MysterE and Mars. $5 donation for the sound system.
   415.541.5019
   
   Friday, July 7th - Groove Trip's Higher Love
   DJs Barry Weaver, Karizma, Swing Kid, Kid Iree, Rockit. 415.522.9958
   916.556.4684
   
   Friday, July 7th - Mystic Alliance presents Climax
   DJs Simply Jeff (LA), Donald Glaude (Seattle), Carlos, Jazz-E, Tony,
   Corey, Orbe (Australia), Kenneth Paul. 415.284.6343
   
   Saturday, July 8th - Wicked 
   Jeno Markie Garth Rob Doten. 174 King St, 21+, 11pm-8am. 415.512.5713,
   info@wicked.com
   
   Saturday, July 8th - MetroJazz
   DJs Mark Farina, Jay-J, Peter, Tom Thump. 22 Belden Alley.
   
   Saturday, July 8th - Gateway Systems gives you Moon Light! Family
   Movement
   Minor, Monty, Tracy & John Carel. Ambient opening and closing with the
   Consciousness Lab. Please carpool and bring water, flashlight,
   blankets, etc. outdoors, free! 1am-8:30am 415.536.9453.

   DJs Dan, La Paix, Zone, DRC, Jam N J, Gabe, Chris Harshman (Disco
   2000), Damon Wild (NYC). Visuals by Liquid Sircus Delight and Eyz
   Mind. 10pm-7am. 209.573.7900 415.469.6946.
   [will honor tix for ExWhyZzz's Animania - call 415.979.3052 for info]

   Emma (DIY), Jeno, Tony, Spun, Mystic Bill + Talizman. $5, 21+. 1015
   Folsom, SF.

   Trocadero, 520 4th St.

   Main Arena: DJ Disciple, Mystic Bill, Mark E Quark, Spun, Eli Star,

   King St. 11pm-6am, 21+, $12. 415.241.1560.

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

On Wed, 5 Jul 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:

> Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 08:55:05 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.edu>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: Progress.
> 
> I thought I had read all their was to read in pretentious  flyers until 
> I read the flyer for the next Prgress party.  People here know that I 
> do not care for manifesto's or people telling me what to think; this 
> is not what rave culture is all about.  BUt the people who wrote 
> this flyer are obviously unaware of this fact so what they are doing 
> in the rave scene in the first place is a tatal mystery to me.  Why 
> don't you all try going to church instead if you people like hot air 
> so much?  And anyway, your party sucks: I went to the first one and 
> it was bad, really bad.  So get off the religion tip now and people 
> might then start taking you seriously; because right now Prgress, 
> and the people involved with it, are the laughing stock of the 
> entire SF rave community.
> Also, all this stuff about the Celistian profocies is also 
> bullshit.  It's all a lie invented by the Illuminatai in an effort 
> to brain wash people who can not believe in God.        
> TRISTAN.

Dear Tristan,

	I suppose I should know better than to take issue with anything 
you post, if I want to keep my dialogue with other sfravers invective and 
flame-free.  The reason I do so is that I do not believe the author of 
the Progress flyer is on sfraves currently herself to be able to respond 
to you, and what you said above deserves a response, assuming you meant 
it and were not merely trying to get a rise out of the rest of us.  :)
	Let me ask you this, Tristan.  Do you feel our scene would be 
better off without any spiritual or intellectual content?  I can 
understand you disagreeing with the philosophy expressed by someone and 
taking issue with it, but you seem to be complaining that no one should 
express any philosophy on their flyers *at all*.  Is this really what you 
want?  Whether Progress is a "good" or "bad" party is a separate issue 
entirely -- throwing in your negative opinion of it is just adding insult 
to injury.
	Please remember, no one is telling you how to think.  You're free 
to ignore the ideas you see printed on rave flyers, posted to the list, 
or anywhere else.  
					*** Starchild ***

In the past has been know to keep company with the Dreaded Stranger On An 
Ostrich, although neither of them have a break-dance move to boast about 
at the moment and one can't help but wonder that maybe if Jesus Christ 
had gotten laid a bit more often Planet Earth wouldn't be so uptight at 
times.  

Even so, fun has never proven to be hard to find.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul  6 23:14:56 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id XAA24041; Thu, 6 Jul 1995 23:14:56 -0700
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id XAA24036; Thu, 6 Jul 1995 23:14:53 -0700
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id XAA26392 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Thu, 6 Jul 1995 23:14:49 -0700
Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 23:14:49 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <199507070614.XAA26392@well.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Holiday Weekend Massive Report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I made my first serious Bay Area trip in two months this past weekend
and had a really good time.  Just a few of the sights'n'sounds . . .

Friday evening I arrived at the Oakland airport, completely relieved
at the cloudy 70 degree weather after an increasingly stifling week
in Portland -- by the time I left town that afternoon it was 100!
A bit much for us Northwesterners . . .

Due to misreading the calendar, I missed Diverse City and only got to
hear about Ethan's way-hot set later on :)  Brothers & Sisters was not
nearly as juiced as the last couple of times I went, the crowd thinned
out early and missed a decent set from DJ Dan (who I finally got to hear
live) and an excellent follow-up by Kelly, who played a track on the
Shindig label and thus got my loyalty (Shindig is a virtually unknown
label from north of London which, like Cancan and a couple of others,
can do no wrong in my book)!  Overall she played a solid pumping set
but the response from the assembled was hardly "massive" . . .

Saturday afternoon was another Organic-in-the-Park, mercifully without
the distractions of the rumored MTV video crew (but it was fun to rant
about it anyway).  I thought Galen and Garth both played pretty well,
and the MV (massive vibe) was definitely present.  Lots of friends,
lots of talking, lots of dancing raising a buncha dust!

Saturday night I took a nap and then Allen Ameba and I and another friend
drove out to Livermore for the annual Freedom bash.  Quite a few people
reported they had a fantastic time there.  My response was a bit more
ambivalent.  When we got there right before sunrise, Spun was playing 
a crackling, thumping set with a bunch of new stuff he said he just
brought back from Chicago.  But there wasn't much of a cohesive vibe,
just a swirling crowd and a bit of shuffling and dancing up front.
I climbed the hill to watch the sunrise, a fine moment indeed.  About
that time Joe Rice cranked up in the ambient tent, playing an eclectic
mix of beats, and even though I promised him I wouldn't say it, here 
it is . . . he played a dub-plate-special jungle track!  Meanwhile Garth
was treading the same grooves he had at Organic, repeating several tracks
including 'Rockit', and got the crowd going cohesively for a good aprt
of the set, at the end of which we briefly connected hand-in-hand around
the ring and then rushed into the center for some serious dancing frenzy.
I didn't think Freedom was all that fantastic, but I'm glad I got to
see the site (an old dirt motorcycle racetrack next to a gravel pit
way the hell out in nowhere north of Livermore), and Martin seemed pretty
happy in the aftermath.

Sunday is Sunset day, of course, and it was probably the best of the 
handful I've been able to attend, back on the water side of the Berkeley
Marina with beautiful if windy weather and a great crowd.  I thought
Monte stole the show with a wonderful old-style breaks-and-aciiiieeed
set that made me thank the heavens for the likes of DJ Pierre and the
golden age of acid house.  More hands-together-and-then-rush in, jumping
and waving.  So I got to see both the sunrise and sunset this time!

Monday I did some work and then a little record shopping at Tweekin.
I'd already been invited to spin at Stinson Beach for the 4th with
the Frequency 8 crew, and when I got to Ameba late in the day it turned
out plans were a-hatchin' for a Bolinas beach bash as well.  I ended
up playing first at Stinson, at the Village Green town park right at
the center of town, followed by Mars, Cyr and Mystr-E.  I played mellow
house and they played more trance.  We got some curious stares but no
static from the expected local complainers, one request to turn down
the bass and a next-door-neighbor complaint that was fairly well resolved.
The clouds lifted around 3 and it was a fine time indeed.

Later I was able to get over to Bolinas where the Ameba gang had already
been on the beach for hours.  A really good happy scene with fantastic
weather (if a little windy), surfers right off the beach, a fishing boat
or two off in the distance, and a couple hundred people just hanging 
around or grooving to the tunes.  Allen Ameba finished up with an excellent
Ameba-dub-mindwarp set, and graciously let me play the final track of the
day, LTJ Bukem's extraordinary "Horizons," which seemed appropriate as
the sun set behind the cliff above us and the Pacific stretched out to
infinity past the beach . . . 

Then we went to the Bolinas Bakery and, in traditional fashion, got
*stuffed* with desserts'n'stuff, while dodging the local drunks and
taking in the Bolinas 4th of July atmosphere . . .

A pretty damn fine weekend.  If I could have a complaint, it would only
be that there was so much good stuff to do that I only got in about
two hours of record shopping.  But naaah, I won't complain!

c ya
phred
