	This is not (directly) related to the rave scene in any way, so 
if you are not interested in political issues relating to our freedom in 
cyberspace, go ahead and delete it and move on.

	I hesitated before posting it at all, but knowing who Jim Warren 
is, when I read his statement that this is one of the most important 
messages he's ever posted, I felt obligated to pass it on, even though I 
lack complete understanding of the technical concepts involved.

	As freedom-loving ravers who use cyberspace to communicate, I 
think we have common cause with others who do not want this ability to be 
curtailed by large telecommunications companies charging us ruinous 
access fees.  As detailed below, we apparantly have a window of 
opportunity to make the case for maximum public access (i.e. electronic 
democracy) before the rules governing the Internet are written in stone 
to the advantage of big government and big business...

					*** Starchild ***

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 17:06:54 -0400
From: Freematt@aol.com
To: libernet@Dartmouth.EDU
Subject: GovAccess.154-CRUCIAL!!!: Free, high-speed regional telecomm!


---------------------
Forwarded message:
From:	jwarren@well.com (Jim Warren)
Sender:	owner-govaccess@well.com
To:	GovAccess@well.com, foi-l@listserv.syr.edu (FOI-L)
CC:	frezza@radiomail.net
Date: 95-07-05 23:31:44 EDT

This is one of the most important public policy items I have ever posted!

This can be a *real* Declaration of Independence for the 21st Century.

This is one of the most important battles that citizens, community
organizations, educators, local government officials and newspapers (if
they plan to continue to exist beyond newsprint) will fight in this decade,
against government-granted monopolies and regulation-protected cartels!

I have been trying to find time to write about this ever since Dewayne
Hendricks told me about it about a month ago.  Bill Frezza's done it; done
it well; and Interactive Age has just published it. [below]

=46olks, if we, the People, can successfully lobby-the-hell outa Congress,
the White House and the FCC - *right now*! - "mere" American citizens and
otherwise-deadmeat consumers can bypass the upcoming monopolistic regional
telecommunications and cable cartels and their for-certain gouge'em-deep
rate increases that will occur as soon as the current secret-deal
Telecommunications Deform Act passes and next year's elections are safely
behind the Washington Beltway's deal-makers.

IF WE ACT NOW - and persevere - we can have the economical, technological
viable option of completely bypassing local-loop telecomm monopolies of the
telcos, cable operators and other big-bucks telecomm giants.

=46REE voice and data communications for residential, educational, business,
community, city, county, rural *and* mobile voice and data-communications.

ALL OF US can have FREE metropolitan-area voice, data and compressed-video
communications - point-to-point, and for that matter, point-to-multipoint
(i.e., everyone becomes a broadcaster, but only to those whom they permit
to receive!).


But we *must* act now - because the TELECOMM GIANTS *DON'T* WANT THIS!

ONLY massive public pressure can overcome their massive lobbying megabucks.


The idea is simple:

Have the FCC declare a tiny portion of what was once *understood* to be the
public's broadcast spectrum to be - in fact - PUBLIC SPECTRUM (a range of
frequencies available for free public use).  The formal petition has
ALREADY BEEN FILED with the FCC.  The rule-making PROCESS HAS ALREADY
BEGUN; public comments have already been solicited.

Open that public spectrum to FREE use by EVERYONE, subject to NO
restrictions at all except (1) broadcast power that will limit range to,
typically, about 15 to 30 miles, and (2) require use of a given frequency
for only a very brief time - seconds or even milliseconds (assumes use of
well-developed, nonproprietary "spread spectrum" techniques, where an
ongoing communication takes place on one frequency for tiny time, then
moves to another frequency, then another and so on; the most efficient use
and sharing of broadcast spectrum that is possible!).


24-megabits per second - that's 3 megabytes per second!

NO phone bills!

NO corporate owners!

NO wires - just a teeny weeny antenna. At most.

NO fees - just a one-time purchase of cheap home, office, car or beltloop
transcievers, and whatever you wish to plug into them ... phones, data
modems, video cameras, temperature monitors, etc.

NO operator licensing - just type-licensed transceivers, exactly the same
as police, cabbie and CB-band radios.

NO eves-droppers - since the spreading algorithms can be infinately and
dynamically varied (and communications can be further scrambled, to boot).

NO censorship needed - since content is *inherently* "scrambled".

METROPOLITAN area range (far beyond a single cell-phone site).


REAL content competition - not the fake "competition" of
government-created, government-licensed, government-protected conduit and
content corporate cartels.

Pollution-free, environmentally-sound, wire-free regional electronic public
parks.


WRITE AND FAX *NOW* - to the FCC *and* to your Congress-critters and the
Clinton White House that has been so busy selling the public's spectrum to
the few who can afford it.  Or ... obediently wait and watch the cartels
raise our rates.


&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&


What Do We Want?  Nonproprietary, Free Bandwidth!  When Do We Want It?  Now!

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 15:47:10 -0700
To: jwarren@well.com
=46rom: Bill Frezza (via RadioMail) <frezza@radiomail.net>

If you want to repost it [the following] be my guest. But if you do, please
preface it with a note that it is from the July 3rd issue of Interactive
Age Magazine and at the end add the following:

COPYRIGHT CMP PUBLICATIONS JULY 1995.

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 14:14:23 -0700
To: jwarren@well.com (Jim Warren)

>From "Interactive Age" July 3, 1995

Where the I-way meets the skyway

By Bill Frezza     [via dewayne@warpspeed.com (Dewayne Hendricks)]

The visionaries at Apple Computer Inc. are at it again, pushing the
envelope of technology, regulatory policy and business development.

While Microsoft Corp.'s Bill Gates focuses on the here and now of elbowing
into the online business, Apple has fast-forwarded to a kinder, gentler
future where free spirits wirelessly surf the Web and the unstructured,
self-organizing chaos of the Internet is extended to the rigid disposition
of the airwaves.

Weaving together the politically popular themes of international
competitiveness, enhanced educational opportunities, free market solutions
for the info have-nots, health-care reform, quality leisure time and hard
core mobile computing, Apple's recent petition to the FCC for an unlicensed
"NII band" is this summer's best read. Check it out at

        http://www.apple.com/documents/fcc.html

        [Better still, use  http://www.warpspeed.com/ , explained below. --j=
im]

What they're asking for is simple enough: 300 megahertz of prime real
estate up at 5 gigahertz, enough to accommodate high density
24-megabit-per-second connections in a fluid mix of local and wide area
networking. This amounts to about $40 billion worth of spectrum, if you go
by the size of the checks the phone companies wrote for Personal
Communications Services (PCS) frequencies. And, oh yeah, they don't want it
for themselves. They want it made available free to all comers, subject
only to interference--reducing technical standards. No auctions, no license
fees, no regulations on what it's used for, and no airtime charges.

Does this renew your faith in chutzpa or what?

It's certainly a different model than either the newfangled auction
approach or the tired old lobbyist-take-all system. Think of it as spectrum
homesteading, a uniquely American experiment in don't-fence-me-in,
anti-industrial policy.

Before you scoff, remember that Apple has been down this path before. It
first petitioned the FCC for Data-PCS frequencies for nomadic computing
back in 1991. This resulted in the allocation of a juicy 20 MHz slice smack
in the middle of the aforementioned PCS bands. Unfortunately for the PC
industry, defeat was snatched from the jaws of victory when the entrenched
telephony interests shanghaied the band in pursuit of a home for cordless
PBXs. (A chagrined FCC later tossed the computer folks some crumbs at 2.4
GHz).

The petition proposes spectrum sharing by fixed and mobile users on a
completely ad-hoc basis. This "spectrum etiquette" is a brilliant blend of
good science and free market ingenuity. Spectrum etiquette imposes no
centralized control and assumes no traffic prioritization.

Rather, it is a low level media access scheme similar to the rules we
follow for private conversations at crowded cocktail parties. You can speak
=46rench, German, or Chinese - whatever you please - as long as you exclude
bozos that stand up on chairs and give loud and long-winded speeches.
Beyond that, anything goes.

But beware of the lobbyist-loaded coterie that frustrated Apple's plans
last time. Flying under the WINForum banner, the telephony interests are
angling for the same spectrum with a rival petition. Their technical
approach, however, asserts the primacy of circuit-switched voice,
necessitating a hierarchical architecture with choke points and centralized
control.

Haven't they hogged enough bandwidth? They call their system SUPERNet. I
think SUCKERNet fits a lot better. The Europeans developing HIPERLAN didn't
buy their jive, so now they're trying to peddle it here.

And they may succeed unless the Washington-averse PC industry files
supporting comments before July 25.

        [=3D=3D=3DIMPORTANT ACTION ITEM!=3D=3D=3D]

        Drop a letter or postcard referencing petition RM-8653 to:
        Office of the Secretary
        Federal Communications Commission (FCC)
        Washington DC 20554

        or send e-mail to  jlovette@apple.com  and offer your help.

Apple's decision to position this as the NII band is perhaps their best
hope, part of a savvy constituency shopping game. But posturing aside, if
this dream comes true what we'll really get is an entrepreneurs band. Not
the kind of fake entrepreneurs with half a billion dollar war chests, or
some bogus designated entity front organization. But real entrepreneurs
that hock their cars, quit their day jobs and go for the glory. The kind of
people that founded Apple and created the PC industry in the first place.

So good luck intrepid infobahn warriors. May your vision become our
reality. I can barely squirt 8 kilobits per second out of my antenna today.
With 24 mbps to horse around with and no physical connections to trace, who
knows what mischief we can cause?

Bill Frezza is president at Wireless Computing Associates and co-founder of
the online forum DigitaLiberty. You can reach him at frezza@radiomail.net .

[Dewayne Hendricks has been deeply involved in wireless datacomm for years,
and has spent several years trudging around Washington's endless
bureaucratic circles and serving on various industry committees, that
eventually got pre-empted by the telecomm giants.  He's walked the walk;
it's time for thousands of us to join him!  --jim]

At 15:47 7/4/95, Bill Frezza (via RadioMail) wrote:
>Jim,
>
>If you want to repost it be my guest. ...

        Again, very nice article Bill.  I pulled it off the IA website and
sent a copy to Jim Lovette of Apple ...  He called me to discuss the
story after he read it and together we have the following comments:

o       Jim and I would [prefer that people use] the URL for my
website instead of Apple's.  We wanted to have the petition up for public
access on the Internet at a non-Apple site ...

                        http://www.warpspeed.com/

o       Jim is preparing a lot of additional content on this issue that we
were going to post on my website in the coming weeks.  That's another
reason why we wanted the URL to be for my site so that people could have
access to this additional material.  There was/is no plan to post this new
material on the Apple site.

o       In your story, you refer to comments being due at the FCC by July
25th.  The correct date is the 10th.  Reply comments are due on the 25th
and there is a major procedural difference between the two dates as far as
the FCC is concerned.  Reply comments are supposed to address issues raised
by the comments that are filed.  No real harm done, but we thought we'd
mention it.

        My website has been hit quite a bit since I put the Apple NII
petition up.  Here is the stats that I generated today:

                        ----------------------------

        Jim and I have no idea how many comments are going to be filed with
the FCC on this matter.  To date, we have gotten very few queries on the
issue.  Lots have people have access the petition, but there has been
no followup discussion, etc.

Alas, if this doesn't change and a fair number of comments are filed in
favor of this concept, then it will die an early death.

        Asking for 300 MHz of spectrum to be turned over to the public for
its own use, without an auction, was a pretty gutsy move on Apple's part I
believe.  It continues in the tradition of the original Data-PCS petition
they submitted to the FCC four years ago.  At that time, no one really
thought that the Commission would respond favorably to such a bold move on
the part of the computer industry.  Well, they did and the spectrum
allocation for Data-PCS is history.  Problem is, I don't think that in this
case, without major public support, lightning will strike twice in the same
place.

Thanks again,
-- Dewayne

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jul  7 10:42:05 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA27936; Fri, 7 Jul 1995 10:42:05 -0700
Received: from netcom12.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id KAA27931; Fri, 7 Jul 1995 10:42:02 -0700
Received: by netcom12.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id KAA15236; Fri, 7 Jul 1995 10:40:54 -0700
Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 10:40:50 -0700 (PDT)
From: Peter Fogel <peterf@netcom.com>
Subject: individuality and unity
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9507071028.A11362-0100000@netcom12>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Raving is teaching me many lessons about UNITY.  As I experience unity I 
find that I crave unity.  This craving often draws me to raves to experience 
a hieghtened sense of unity.  I find that going to a rave might not 
always do it, but it can as I can outside of raves as well.

Sometimes my desire might cause me to want to jump to this state of 
unity, but I find that without mine and others individuality there is no 
sense of unity.
Validating my own individuality  allowing me to own my feelings then 
helps me feel more secure to share them with others.  Validating others 
feelings helps others feel more secure with their feelings making it easier 
for them to share. Through this sharing a greater sense of unity is felt.
I find that the walls that I and others put up making them more separate 
can become bridges to unity.  Celebrating our individuality is part of 
celebrating our Unity.  I feel so much joy in my heart just thinking and 
writing about it.  Life can really feel like a party, when I understand 
how to party.  Thanks everyone just for being, because it is your 
beingness that adds to the party.

;)
peter

At 11:28 AM 7/7/95, Andrew B. Lawson wrote:
>This was the first Come-Unity that I have missed all year.... Wahat's
>with all the silence.  I haven't read one report on it yet (or maybe in
>ckimming over my messages I deleted one).  How was it?  Inquiring minds
>want to know.


I'll be brief...

It was clubby.  Very much so.  Felt like a different party than the past
couple months.  The music and lights had their usual trance enducing
energy, but the people seemed like they had come to check out what all the
fuss was about from the months before.  It was a friend of mine's first one
and while she liked it (we managed to get pretty wasted), I felt like she
wasn't experiencing the true vibe that this "school-night party" can really
produce.

It was a pretty busy week for most people it seems, that may have had
something to do with it.  There was no line at 3 a.m. when we left....if
that says anything.  I doubt there was a line at all.

I saw very few familar faces.  Don't get me wrong, I don't think that's bad
in itself, but certainly different from the past four months or so.

That's all I have time to write....Oh, the chill room was a sight.
Artistic dancers everywhere, as if a dance class had gotten out and decided
to do extra credit in the basement of 1015.  It was actually pretty cool,
but unfortunately several people in the audience were rude about it;
laughing and shit...

Peace!

Tony

P.S.  I know that C/U can have a strong club feel to it, and I really kind
of like that, but there was one incident a few months ago that I meant to
relay to everyone:  As I was hanging on the stairs leading from the stage
to the lounge area on the second floor I got completely drenched by a gin
and tonic.  (Not so bad given the temperature of that place.)  I turned
around to witnesss the drink owner tell his friend in a very hostile tone
that this third guy spilled his drink.  The third guy had no idea what was
going on, besides the fact that he was about to be assaulted, but I do know
that he did not intentionally dump this guys drink.  The two proceeded to
stand directly in this poor guys face and scare the living shit out of him,
threatening him in a beligerent manner unless he bought the guy another
drink.  I truly thought it was going to come to something very non-PLUR
like, but finally the thrid guy managed to get away from there and the two
went on there way grumbling about "the motherfucking piece of shit..."  It
was the kind of incident you see happen at Sunset all the time.  ;^)

Hang on to those drinks folks!  (And see you at Wicked...)

>in the case of religion, however, there is a reason to reclaim the 
distasteful  
>word instead of replacing it:  the first amendment to the U.S. 
constitution  
>protects the free exercise of religion, not free exercise of

I could not agree with you more.   The fact is raving is more spiritual 
and religious for many ravers than christianty and church are for many 
many christians.  This goes the same for most organized religions.  I 
don't think that true faith exists in a good deal of these people 
because they were born and raised of that religion.  They have not 
discovered it.  True faith comes from realizations.  This faith is 
Sacred. 

     As time goes on we may find ourselves needing the 1st amendment to 
justify our actions.  To protect one of the few true religious 
experiences occuring in this nation.  Just as American Indians fight to 
protect their use of certain herbs.

Dont get me wrong about other religions.  I know their our many 
christians who have had true spiritual experiences.  I just feel that 
most of them may know their bible inside and out but just dont 
Understand it.

love chris

Oops.. sorry about the last one.. misfire!

> On Fri, 7 Jul 1995, Jonathan Santos wrote:
> > I know, I'm probably going to get flamed for this one... But theres WAY TOO
> > MUCH of this being played in SF.  I like ambient stuff.. but I really enjoy
> > going out to *dance* to some good techno (Jeff Mills, DBX, Dave Clark, UR,
> > Paul Johnson, Eric Martin, etc. etc. etc.)  Doesn't anyone play anything
> > else besides trance, ambient, and happy house?

Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU> wrote:
> In order to listen to other kinds of dance music others then those 
> mentioned [above] one really needs to go to London or New York.

...or Chicago or Milwaukee or Detroit or....

I realize that straight up techno is not very popular right
now in SF, but please don't make the mistake of thinking
that trance, ambient and happy house predominate in EVERY
city...

In chicago, the main styles are trax (paul johnson, dbx,
green velvet, etc) and jungle, while in detroit, the main
styles are techno, techno/house, electro, etc.  Milwaukee is
predominantly hard acid and hardcore, while Baltimore is
hard trance and slow breaks..  ..and in each of these
cities, sub-scenes flourish.

I realize that not everyone is going to like the same kind
of music that I do, but I hope I'll be able to find some
people who are on the same musical wavelength as me when I
move out there.  

-Sho
--
sho@hyperreal.com

On Sat, 8 Jul 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:

> In order to listen to other kinds of dance music others then those 
> mentioned below [trance, ambient, happy house] one really needs to go to 
> London or New York. 

If you want to hear techno at a big, expensive party, then yes, one needs 
to look elsewhere.  But, there are plenty of small, cheap parties which 
pop up periodically catering to a more techno-friendly audience.  You may 
have a hard time finding much true harsh/fast/driving techno, but keep 
your eyes open- just a couple of weeks ago there was a Berlin/SF party at 
dv8 with none other than Jeff Mills and a handful of other Berlin types.  
Even sfrave dj's Ethan and Bryce (when he's not playing ambient) give a 
much appreciated alternative to the SF "sound".  Also check out events 
with Alex, Jonah, or Minor Minor.  SF has lots going on.  You just have 
to look harder for some things then for others...

Seth

>> In order to listen to other kinds of dance music others then those 
>> mentioned below [trance, ambient, happy house] one really needs to go to 
>> London or New York. 
>
>If you want to hear techno at a big, expensive party, then yes, one needs 
>to look elsewhere.  But, there are plenty of small, cheap parties which 

what are you talking about?  When I lived in Detroit..  There were parties
that were about 5 dollars, in a small quaint sweatbox,  about 300 people,
and you got to hear Dan Bell, Richie Hawtin, Stacey Pullen, Juan Atkins,
Carl Craig.. etc. etc.

>pop up periodically catering to a more techno-friendly audience.  You may 
>have a hard time finding much true harsh/fast/driving techno, but keep 
>your eyes open- just a couple of weeks ago there was a Berlin/SF party at 
>dv8 with none other than Jeff Mills and a handful of other Berlin types. 

I did keep my eyes open, and I did go to the dv8.  Instead of hearing happy
house, it was primarily happy hardcore.  I don't know which is worse.  As
much as I enjoyed Jeff Mills, and Blake Baxter... The rest of the party was
a bit annoying (IMHO)

It's funny, because most SFRAVErS feel that techno is fast, pumping,
chainsaw terror music.  I think this has alot to do with why *alot* of
people won't even consider going to a techno related event (big or small).  

And for the record..  Jeff Mills is from Detroit.  I couldn't understand why
everyone keeps insisting he is a German DJ.  (kinda funny)

-Jon

Since people are talking about music that is not exactly the same ole SF
sound - last night I was in the woods "north of the gate" with Frequency 8...
These guys spin wonderful cybertrance from Germany and Northern Europe
ranging from 140-160 bpm mostly.... I was talking to J. Cyr and he said
they usually do this type of music and they are working on warming a crowd
up to it... I'm warm I'm warm  !

  I keep wondering if the people who are talking about "happy house" are
hanging out in the clubs too much? There are wonderful DJ's that are doing
a wide variety of things in the SF underground. And there seems to be a
very healthy underground... I keep hearing about Wicked and C/U over and 
over like a broken record but I keep going to better parties with better
music in the underground. *** Of course "better" is in the experience of the
person and your mileage may vary ;)

 Mike

 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

When I first started going to parties, before any of the English people came,
the strongest aspect that drew my interest to this scene was the diversity of
styles of music played by the DJs. Calling attention to this memory may spark
some variety-outbreak amongst those who might read this message, but it would
only be a top-down aberration (Garth playing Rockit) that trickles down
somewhere to influence somebody, maybe. But still it would only be an extra
wrinkle in the features of the scene, since it long ago ceased to be a part
of its foundation.

.eh

np: Robert Daniel tape

Frequency 8 was wonderful as anticipated. The crowd was intimate (ie. small).
 Although I only had time to sit (ahem, I mean dance) thru Myster-E and Mars
sets (which could be described as fire and water).  It was worth the drive.
 Since I was on the floor (or should I say trail) I didn't do too much
conversing nor chatting w/my fellow raver's.  But all in all a good time was
had.....

See-ya at the sunset...

Adam.

Ps: A special hiya to all those who had the opportunity to ride the 1st class
shuttle to the event, and all of you sfravers I met taking ya there (although
i only remember brian darkness and a few people named seth)...... 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jul  9 00:12:03 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id AAA11729; Sun, 9 Jul 1995 00:12:03 -0700

	(1.37.109.11/16.2) id AA260563810; Sun, 9 Jul 1995 03:10:10 -0400

To: SFraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Happy House Crap
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>thats why SF is kind of lame.  because the >people/promoters/djs have a hard
time deviating from the >mean.   I think it sucks that I can't go out and
here the music >that we grew up on (or the style) that we are  accustomed to
>out east and midwest.  To be honest.. There is just no variety >in the scene
here.  There is no progression.

Well, I believe that SF shoudn't be considered for naught... It's just that's
how this generation of SF dj's are spinning.  I remember in the early 90's
when when the beats were more breakbeat with the likes BUCK, JOSH, SPUN,
NOEL, GHOST and others.  But the scene changes as all things do.  I don't
think SF is dull, but what it is doing is creating a niche in the Techno
archives.  In a year or four someone (say Gailen or Ethan) will spin in
detroit, London, Tokyo or wherever, and someone will say, "woha, listen to
that SF style!"
I was brought up and learned to dand to hardcore 160-180 BPM, and I
understnad that my dancestyle can be intimidating but that's the vibe.  As
the music creates the scene too, that's why I tend to feel such unity with my
fellow (and fella) ravers, such warmth and friendship.  
And the next generation will probabaly take us to the next level (I've even
jumped on a pair or turntables in the past week to see what kind of magic I
can create...).  I we can do is wait and see.  Or move across the country.

So hey, happy, trancy, trippy house is sappy.
So shoot me.

Not ducking the drive-by huggings,
Adam....

> >>
> >>>> I know, I'm probably going to get flamed for this one... But theres WAY
> >>>>TOO MUCH of this being played in SF.  I like ambient stuff.. but I really
> >>>>enjoy going out to *dance* to some good techno (Jeff Mills, DBX, Dave
> Clark,
> >>>>UR, Paul Johnson, Eric Martin, etc. etc. etc.)  Doesn't anyone play
> anything
> >>>> else besides trance, ambient, and happy house?
> >>
> >>There are people who do, but since nothing outside of those styles is
> >>popular, people who don't play them don't get asked to play.
> >
> >thats why SF is kind of lame.  because the people/promoters/djs have a hard
> >time deviating from the mean.   I think it sucks that I can't go out and
> >here the music that we grew up on (or the style) that we are accustomed to
> >out east and midwest.  To be honest.. There is just no variety in the scene
> >here.  There is no progression.

i found these series of posts rather amusing...:)
being from the midwest and only here for a short while, house is
considered the norm...even though i didn't really care for it, i kinda
ended growing up on it.

take a good look at the scene here. trance, ambient, etc. can be found in
abundence. but you can also find techno (something that was 4 floors a
while back), house (nation), jungle, acid jazz, etc.

this scene HAS variety, it DOES deviate from the norm.
where i go to school, we have one type of music, and only one type (that
being the type you grew up on).

you never find an ambient party. never ever will you see trance. acid jazz
only at clubs, gabber is not even touched (though i haven't heard gabber
here, either).

in my opinion this scene is way more diverse than in the midwest.
although there is always room to get more diverse and offer more (like
gabber), i don't think you can say there is no variety

> >
> >-Jon
> 
> 
>

Subject: "Drive-by huggings"

My computer tells me that on Sun, 9 Jul 1995, Adam shared, in part:

> Date: Sun, 9 Jul 1995 03:10:10 -0400
> From: Foustus@aol.com
> To: SFraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: Re: Happy House Crap
> 
> Not ducking the drive-by huggings,
> Adam....

...which reminded me of the following news item that may be of interest 
to sfravers:


ASSOCIATED PRESS - SAN FRANCISCO

San Francisco Police Chief Fony Riviera held a press conference yesterday 
to reassure the public that a concerted effort is being made by his
department to counter a recent crime wave that has left citizens smiling and 
city officials scratching their heads and pulling out hair.

A worried Riviera told media representatives that police were following 
all available leads in a string of drive-by huggings that have occurred 
during the past several weeks in San Francisco's trendy South-of-Market 
warehouse district.

Official details on the crimes are scant, but victims and witnesses have 
been more forthcoming.  In the most recent attack, Dan Officeguy said he was 
walking on Harrison Street near Third at around eleven o'clock p.m. on June 
27 when he was assaulted.

According to Officeguy, he had little or no warning.  "I heard a car 
pull up, and it was blaring this, I guess you'd call it music, it sounded 
like somebody playing PacMan and banging their fist on the machine." 
Officeguy said he initially paid it no heed.  "You hear these kids with 
their cranked up auto stereos all the time down here," said the 47 
year-old Prolific Bell employee.  "I didn't even bother to look."

The police report filed on the incident says that in the following moments, 
two young women jumped from the back of the vehicle, ran up, and violently 
hugged him.  The intensity of the hugs and the smiling faces that 
accompanied them startled Officeguy, who says he hasn't been hugged since 
he moved here from Chicago seven years ago.  "There were parts of town where 
you had to worry about that sort of thing," he said.  "I never thought it 
would be a problem here."  Still, mused Officeguy, "It was kind of fun."

The two huggers were described by witnesses as white and Latino, probably in 
their late teens or early twenties.  One was said to be wearing a pair of 
baggy overalls decorated with rainbow patches and a large floppy velvet 
hat.  The other was variously described as dressed in what appeared to be 
a furry trenchcoat or rainjacket, and was carrying either a large purse or 
some sort of lunchbox.

Officeguy said one of the girls also tried to kiss him. "I might have 
consented, but she had a sucker in her mouth, and my mom always warned me 
those are dangerous.  A close friend of hers lost an eye once."

Persons at the scene of previous drive-by huggings have reported a 
variety of different suspects, although a young man with a large stuffed 
bee puppet was spotted driving away on two separate occasions.

Although police say no motive has been established for the huggings, 
one inside source who chose to remain anonymous said investigators are 
looking at the city's late-night dance promoters and participants.  "It's 
common knowledge that these parties are going on illegally, and the 
individuals involved have little respect for law and order.  They lure 
kids from the suburbs into seedy after-hours warehouses with colorful 
fliers and get them high on illegal drugs.  Some of them even use fireworks."

Indeed one drive-by hugging victim, who chose to be identified only as 
Beverly, reported that her assailant, a "large black man" wearing a 
t-shirt with the letter "E" emblazoned on it, tried to hand her something 
that may have been a flier for an illegal party. "He stuck something out, 
it was glossy and colorful," she recalled.  "I assumed it was a robbery 
note, so I just threw my purse on the ground and ran."  The purse was 
later retrived intact.

Police reportedly have in their possession fliers left at the 
scenes of several of the drive-by huggings, all of which have occurred in 
the South of Market area known to locals as the city's nightclub 
district.  At one crime scene, officers also discovered a more ominous 
message left by the assailants:  The word P-L-U-R was found carved 
into the sidewalk with large colored chalk.  Lieutenant Clokendager, head 
of the department's juvenile crime division, believes the letters 
represent a warning to rival gangs.  Others are not so sure, however.  
Security at the Federal building on Golden Gate Avenue has been  
increased, and a spokesperson for the FBI said the agency is looking 
into a possible connection to the Unabomber.  City Supervisor Susan Seal has 
responded with a measure that would require minors to be with a parent when 
buying chalk.  Some neighborhood association members and local 
businesspeople are urging her to take up again the issue of the ban on 
dancing after two o'clock a.m. for those under eighteen, and expand it to 
include all ages.  "There's no socially redeeming value to dancing all 
night," said one resident {actual quote from September 1993 City Hall 
hearings on after-hours dancing!}.

San Francisco Mayor Wank Warden, who is currently running for reelection, 
says he is appointing a special commission to look into providing 
alternatives for troubled youths.  Last week the San Francisco 
Chronic-Ill reported that Warden is close to agreement with the Board of 
Supervisors on a drug-testing program for youths apprehended on the 
streets after curfew.  Lackluster Video, which already has mandatory drug 
tests for employees, has offered to help the City develop its program. 

The office of former State Assembly Speaker Sillie Clown, who is among the 
contenders for Warden's job, sent out a fax today charging the mayor with 
lack of leadership.  "Wank Warden is guilty of gross negligence in 
running this city," the release states.  "Arrests of homeless activists 
at Civic Center Plaza are up, while across town, people walk in fear of 
drive-by huggings.  Where are his priorities?  San Francisco needs a 
Sillie Clown in City Hall to introduce some common sense."

In person, Clown was a bit more conciliatory.  "I understand that Wank is 
not entirely responsible here," he told reporters.  "The Republican 
budget cuts are affecting all of us deeply.  If we could only restore the 
funding for midnight basketball, we could get these poor neglected 
children off the streets."

Meanwhile, police have yet to make an arrest, and are advising residents 
and tourists to exercise caution.  "They got my daughter.  You could be 
next," scowled officer Blowhard of the South of Market precinct station.  
"These huggers are armed and dangerous."

Persons interviewed on the street this morning seemed more amused than
alarmed, as did many of the drive-by hugging witnesses and even the
victims themselves.  "It's nothing to get up in arms about," said
city-dweller Chas Glynn, 29.  "Everybody needs a hug now and then," 
agreed his girlfriend, giving him a hug.

				*    *    *
 
 ;)  Starchild!

Precedence: bulk

In a message dated 95-07-09 15:34:43 EDT, you write:

>The people/promoters/djs are playing
>what a "majority" of people want to hear, and this "majority" is always
>changing and evolving

Maybe this is the problem I'm having. 

Like I said in one of my previous replies, some of the reasons I got into
this music and its mode of performance were the sheer diversity of musical
styles that could be heard in one stretch, and that I could go out and hear a
bunch of new music that I'd never heard before. Somehow I got it in my head
that DJs were people who took the time to wade through the myriad releases
from week to week, picking out the best and newest to expose to the fans of
the genre. Promoters find the most cutting edge and put that in a club/party
for you to enjoy and dance to.

I've long suspected that this is not the case at all. That it is based on the
lowest common denominator mechanism that typifies pop music. Is this a
desperate ploy by a scene to perpetuate itself in the face of lagging income
and/or interest? Can a scene that has this approach be considered underground
anymore? In the rave scene, has the word "underground" been reduced to a
substitute for "no flyers" or "illegal"?

.eh

np: open window

Subject: House is my hero
In-Reply-To: <950709222840_111305435@aol.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950709233249.11736A-100000@aurora>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Precedence: bulk



The first rave music I heard had lots of energy, lots of techno, lots and 
lots of sound.  I loved how the Dj could play a certain song and change 
the energy level.  People would go crazy over the sounds they were 
hearing.  It made me feel charged, like I could do anything... it was 
lots of energy.  That's how I remember it.

The house music I hear lately makes me feel whole, free,  It touches more 
of the soul.  The DJ then adds energy by the mixing.  Mix different 
feeling sounds together and it's just so powerful.  Makes me want to 
throw my hands up, go "woooo" and all that.  Not many things make me go 
"woooo", unless I'm trying to act cheasey... So if I go "woooo" it must be 
something totally phenomenal.  

Energy by itself is good.  But I'll take mine with alittle "woooo" on the 
side, served up between two thick slices of vibe.

Willis
Hey! this house only has four walls, a heart in the center and a roof 
that is on *fire* who will save us! Jeno the wonder cat?

S.P.A.Z.end-of-the-world-tour update:

the story so far-----tecno on the plains near Lincoln ,Nebraska

                 St. Louis----party in the park---park ranger from Mars 
says "i dig this music!"

           South Bronx, New York -park rave invaded by hordes of 
Pennsylvania hardcore fanaticswho all happen to be dj's......

                 present moment-----preparing to check out Sugarlump 
sound system party in south London......

july 7th weekend----free partyprotesting criminal justice act...

july? Teknival near Prague?

August 13---Big Chill party in Wales

August 20--Free party with 5th street squatters , Manhattan...

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sun, 9 Jul 1995 02:06:17 -0700 (PDT)
From: Ellen Steuer <ellen@ramona.cyborganic.com>
To: Foustus@aol.com
cc: SFraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Happy House Crap

this is exactly the conversation i was dreading to see on this list.  you 
see, i just moved to SF from milwaukee where (as sho mentioned) there is 
lots of hardcore, but there is also a wide variety of other types of 
music as well.  chicago has lots of house and jungle, detroit has its acid 
and everything else is nearby as well.  midwest promoters are into 
bringing in talent from all over.  for example, just last week in dayton, 
OH i saw the UK's system 7 perform and laurent garnier and at the same 
party there were chicago's terry mullan, detroit's john aquaviva, 
pittsburgh's dieselboy and SF's dj dan. now i love going 
to a party and hearing all types of music but the downside is cost.  when 
you have to fly people in from all over the world it's not cheap.  the 
parties will be bigger, more commercial (no, mtv was not there) and more 
expensive (no lack of vibe though!).  but in the midwest that doesn't 
necessarily mean bad, which i 
kinda get the feeling that means here just from previous posts about big 
parties.  i guess that is because the midwest is so spreadout and a big 
party will draw people from every state in the area.  from what i can 
tell so far an advantage for parties here is the smaller size.  i suppose 
if you want a variety of music away from house and trance you will either 
have to travel or bring in different dj's from all over.  anyway, it's 
nice to be in sf and i have plenty of mix tapes of all sorts of dj's if 
anyone wants to broaden their horizons:)

peace,

ellen

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * 
Ellen Steuer				http://www.cyborganic.com/People/ellen/
ellen@cyborganic.com


On Sun, 9 Jul 1995 Foustus@aol.com wrote:

> >thats why SF is kind of lame.  because the >people/promoters/djs have a hard
> time deviating from the >mean.   I think it sucks that I can't go out and
> here the music >that we grew up on (or the style) that we are  accustomed to
> >out east and midwest.  To be honest.. There is just no variety >in the scene
> here.  There is no progression.
> 
> Well, I believe that SF shoudn't be considered for naught... It's just that's
> how this generation of SF dj's are spinning.  I remember in the early 90's
> when when the beats were more breakbeat with the likes BUCK, JOSH, SPUN,
> NOEL, GHOST and others.  But the scene changes as all things do.  I don't
> think SF is dull, but what it is doing is creating a niche in the Techno
> archives.  In a year or four someone (say Gailen or Ethan) will spin in
> detroit, London, Tokyo or wherever, and someone will say, "woha, listen to
> that SF style!"
> I was brought up and learned to dand to hardcore 160-180 BPM, and I
> understnad that my dancestyle can be intimidating but that's the vibe.  As
> the music creates the scene too, that's why I tend to feel such unity with my
> fellow (and fella) ravers, such warmth and friendship.  
> And the next generation will probabaly take us to the next level (I've even
> jumped on a pair or turntables in the past week to see what kind of magic I
> can create...).  I we can do is wait and see.  Or move across the country.
> 
> So hey, happy, trancy, trippy house is sappy.
> So shoot me.
> 
> Not ducking the drive-by huggings,
> Adam....
>

On Sat, 8 Jul 1995, Jonathan Santos wrote:

> >In a message dated 95-07-07 20:22:20 EDT (or so), you write:
> >
> >>> I know, I'm probably going to get flamed for this one... But theres WAY
> >TOO
> >>> MUCH of this being played in SF.  I like ambient stuff.. but I really
> >enjoy
> >>> going out to *dance* to some good techno (Jeff Mills, DBX, Dave Clark, UR,
> >>> Paul Johnson, Eric Martin, etc. etc. etc.)  Doesn't anyone play anything
> >>> else besides trance, ambient, and happy house?
> >
> >There are people who do, but since nothing outside of those styles is
> >popular, people who don't play them don't get asked to play.
> 
> thats why SF is kind of lame.  because the people/promoters/djs have a hard
> time deviating from the mean.   I think it sucks that I can't go out and
> here the music that we grew up on (or the style) that we are accustomed to
> out east and midwest.  To be honest.. There is just no variety in the scene
> here.  There is no progression.
> 
> -Jon
> 

I really don't think it is a matter of SF being lame. Because you don't hear
the particular style of music you want at the parties you have been going to
does not mean it is not played anywhere. The people/promoters/djs are playing
what a "majority" of people want to hear, and this "majority" is always
changing and evolving. I have seen more jungle lately, for example. When 
you call a scene lame, you are also insulting the people that make up the
scene, their musical tastes, etc., which when properly done can be good 
thing. Everyone needs to be shaken up now and then. Try offering 
constructive critism, and people may be a little more open to what you 
have to say. Just a suggestion.... And remember, if the grass is greener....

                                              Black Adder

How would you define "happy house"?  In my own view, SF has been
awash with relatively "unhappy" house for the last two years or so,
lots of minor key or downbeat tracks which seem aimed more at getting
some kind of immediate reaction than the more thought-provoking and
phat trax we used to hear.  Like what Monte played at Sunset last week,
that was a big thrill for me, remembering how great acid house and its
near relative styles sound.

phred

Also . . . if you only go hear the most popular DJs at the most publicized
events, you'll get worn down on whatever type of music they prefer (whether
it's "happy house," "gabber handbag" or whatever).  Variety is definitely
the spice of life.

phred

 Just a "SFRaves South Bay Lunch" reminder for this Wednesday.

[ I haven't made any progess with planning a South Bay Dinner,
  as my life has become quite a bit busier lately ! Maybe in
  August , or a weekend later this month , or ??? ] 

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules. At special times,
we've met at a restaurant ( no boom-box , tho' .... ).

 It's on a Wednesday , depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I hope to see you folks there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFRaves South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

Well I guess this would be as good a time as any to stop lurking and
introduce myself...  Soon Ill be getting to one of these things (Ive
been here for 4 fucking weeks but have no car).  This is something 
that surprised my uninformed person, however.

Im from Pittsburgh PA and as you may have heard the scene there is
picking up in a weird way.  First of all, its been pretty heavy
into what I call the good stuff (hardcore jungle, happy hardcore,
hardcore whatever).  It would seem that a lot of the parties here are much 
more "laid back" which isnt at all what I expected/was looking for.  And
(for me...  I dont have the DJ names and specialties yet) its ruff
to figure out whats gonna be playing at these things.  I have no
problem with parties that play the housey stuff (though I think it
produces the wrong vibe and belongs primarily in the clubs).  It
would be cool tho if some of the heavy stuff was mixed in.  

  David Parks                           | Clowns to the left of me
  Univ. Pittsburgh - CS/App.Math Senior | Joker's to the right
  UCBerkeley - SUPERB Eng. Summer Prg.  | Here I am
  davidp@cory.berkeley.edu              | Stuck in the middle with you

> Like I said in one of my previous replies, some of the reasons I got into
> this music and its mode of performance were the sheer diversity of musical
> styles that could be heard in one stretch, and that I could go out and hear a
> bunch of new music that I'd never heard before. Somehow I got it in my head
> that DJs were people who took the time to wade through the myriad releases
> from week to week, picking out the best and newest to expose to the fans of
> the genre. Promoters find the most cutting edge and put that in a club/party
> for you to enjoy and dance to.

Yes, and as the genre is expanding, several subsets are emerging, and as 
we are all seeing, most DJ's have a tendancy to specialize in one of these
subsets, be it Trance, Happy Hardcore, Ambient, etc. I agree that there 
tends to be much more Trance around S.F. than say, Techno. But this is 
represenatative of both the tastes of the D.J.'s as well as the tastes of the
audience. And there are always alternatives. These parties tend to be 
much smaller as the audience for that particular style is not as 
developed, but they do exist, just look at Derek's weekly list. There is 
now no all-encompassing word that describes (for lack of a better term) "rave"
 music, where as 6-7 years ago there very well may have been.

>From what I have experienced, I am always hearing new tracks spun by 
D.J.'s of parties I am going to, so I believe they have been wading 
"through the myriad releases from week to week."

> 
> I've long suspected that this is not the case at all. That it is based on the
> lowest common denominator mechanism that typifies pop music. Is this a
> desperate ploy by a scene to perpetuate itself in the face of lagging income
> and/or interest? Can a scene that has this approach be considered underground
> anymore? In the rave scene, has the word "underground" been reduced to a
> substitute for "no flyers" or "illegal"?
> 
> .eh
> 
> np: open window

Hehehe. Ya know, I think that "underground" is one of the most commonly 
misunderstood concepts that exists. For example, the goth scene(which I 
still enjoy now and again.) This is definitely considered underground by 
those involved. Here is a group of people bitching about the blandness 
and sameness of the mainstream, and I still believe that to be correct. 
But what happened? Been to a goth club? What do you have? A bunch of people
dressed the same, listening to the same music they were 10 years ago, 
bitching about "mainstream" commonality. Kinda hypocritical, huh?

I use the above simplified example to illustrate a point. "underground" 
is an oxymoron. When you take numerous people who get into a "sound" or a 
style of music because it diverges from the "mainstream," you now have a group
with common interests and tastes, to varying degrees. While the movement 
may still be considered "underground" in respect to the mainstream 
mindset, continuing to consider what you are doing "underground" when it 
has become a normal part of your existance seems a little delusional. 

D.J.'s like to spin what they want to hear for PEOPLE who want to hear same. 
Promoters(most, with some notable exceptions around here) like to break even, 
which requires a certain amount of people to be at an event. It's all 
about people. If you are so "underground" that no one comes to your 
events, you are going to be a very lonely person indeed....


                                                 Black Adder

view of their value or usefulness.

House?  the Norm?  That all depends on exactly 'where' in the Midwest you
are from. If you were in the Chicago are, you probably got a taste of GOOD
FUCKING Paul Johnson style house.  The hard stuff fused with minimal techno
bleep trax (aka Robert Armani, DBX, Armando, etc)  SF Happy House can't
even touch this deep ass house shit.  As far as Detroit goes, we grew up
with Chicago style house as well as local stuff (submerge).  I don't hate
house music, but I guess we were listening to a different kind.

>take a good look at the scene here. trance, ambient, etc. can be found in
>abundence. but you can also find techno (something that was 4 floors a
>while back), house (nation), jungle, acid jazz, etc.

But<  techno is notably absent in this scene > at this point in time.

>this scene HAS variety, it DOES deviate from the norm.
>where i go to school, we have one type of music, and only one type (that
>being the type you grew up on).

Most college towns only have one type of music.  And > obviously, you have
no idea what I grew up on

>you never find an ambient party. never ever will you see trance. acid jazz
>only at clubs, gabber is not even touched (though i haven't heard gabber
>here, either).

What place are you talking about?  Because it doesn't sound like the place
I'm from..

>in my opinion this scene is way more diverse than in the midwest.

How can you say that!?  You probably didn't check out other scenes in your
area (chicago, Detroit, Cinci, Columbus, Pitt, etc.)

>although there is always room to get more diverse and offer more (like
>gabber), i don't think you can say there is no variety

The only place I ever heard gabber was in Milwaukee Wisconsin.  Home of the
Drop Bass Network..


-Jon

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)
Subject: Moon Light
X-Mailer: <Windows Eudora Version 2.0.2>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Let me just say that this party had about the best organization of any party
I've been to.  I was truly impressed with being guided into the parking area
by flashlights, with my headlights off, and greeted with smiles and warm
energy from all those involved.  

The party "went off".....WELL.  I was most impressed with John Carel, and
Consciousness Lab's Ambient set at the end.  

The location was incredible.  A valley area between two small foot hills
(200 or so feet) next to a small pond.  It was well worth the three hour
drive it took to get there.....well at least til the morning when we found
out the party was a break-in and was on private property.....and the owner
showed up and locked the remaining 15 or so cars, including mine, inside the
gate of his property.....and placed everyone under citizens arrest.....and
made us wait there about an hour or two until the police arrived.....and
took down everyones name address and car registration info.

You should have seen Mr. Owner Man...it was unbelievable.  He was majorly
pissed, which was understandable considering a lock had been cut, and a no
trespassing sign had been removed.  I consider it my own carma for not
heeding the warning as soon as I was told it was a break-in, but the place
was so incredible and I was having such a good time I didn't listen to my
intuition.  I also consider it "me getting my carma" after having the
intuition to move my car off of the property while waiting 15 minutes for
the last member of our group to say goodbye to everyone.  I felt I should
move it and wait outside the gate, but something told me to just sit in the
car and stay put....so I did and that 15 minutes got me busted.  Oh well, I
had alot of fun anyway.

Very Very Very Special Special Thanks go out to Claire for all her work in
organizing such a great party.  And for her agreeing to be arrested on the
spot and take the heat for everyone.  She took full responsibility for
everthing and for any damage created by the party and its goers.  The deal
was arranged with the owner that if she took the heat, everyone else would
be released(although we did have to give our names and stuff, and were
warned we may recieve a warrent to appear in court in Santa Cruz at a later
date).  Ethier way, Claire was very "big" about the whole thing, expressed
piles and piles of "tact" with the understandably assholish owner and the
cops, and deserves much praise IMO. 

A collection was started to help her to pay the fine she will probably be
slapped with.  Hopefully someone with more information on it will post
something to the list.  Law or no law, IMO Claire deserves our help, for
organizing and taking the heat for a wonderful "FREE" party.  Please help
her if an opportunity presents itself.

Love

Rick

After I had closed Ameba last night I got a call from Mark telling me to put 
on my make-up and get over to a bunker in the Marin headlands. Rob from 
J.K. sound had this free, permited, outdoor raver's wet dream going on! Mark 
Farina, Andre Lucero, Robbie Hardkiss and Charlotte were there + more. It 
was stompy and happy and funky and groovy. Over looking the bay and the 
GG bridge from above, 2 generators,( one for lighting, ) 3 bunkers of  wierdo 
and  friendly chill space (carpeting and plants, art etc). They played music 
which would be called crap by some on this list, BUT I ASK YOU : HOW 
FABULOUS DO YOU HAVE TO BE!!???

>I really don't think it is a matter of SF being lame. Because you don't hear
>the particular style of music you want at the parties you have been going to
>does not mean it is not played anywhere.

I don't mean to call the entire SF scene lame.  But maybe I just feel left
out.  :(

>The people/promoters/djs are playing
>what a "majority" of people want to hear, and this "majority" is always
>changing and evolving. I have seen more jungle lately, for example. When
>you call a scene lame, you are also insulting the people that make up the
>scene, their musical tastes, etc., which when properly done can be good
>thing. Everyone needs to be shaken up now and then. Try offering
>constructive critism, and people may be a little more open to what you
>have to say. Just a suggestion.... And remember, if the grass is greener....
>
>                                              Black Adder

And how do you constructively criticize an entire music scene?    I could
do this if i had enough time to think that though completely.  But I guess
I've just been going to some wack parties for the last 4 months.  I have
offered constructive criticism to promoters and DJs, but they don't seem to
care.  People just wanna make a quick buck I guess.  Just like some said,
promoters and DJs only play what the crowd wants to hear.  I remember a
time when DJs would play stuff that they wanted to hear.. thats what made
their set special.  It was music that meant alot to them.  Thats why I look
for in a dj.  What music makes their soul happy..

I remember 2 years ago talking with Mike Huckaby, and Claude Young about DJ'ing
overseas.  They said it was fucked up becuase most DJ's played music that
the crowd wanted to hear, not what they actually liked.  I think it's
better when it just so happens that the type of music that you play moves
you, as well as the crowd.

-Jon

even Milwaukee isn't hardcore/gabber central anymore.  I just moved to sf 
from living in milwaukee all my life and the last all gabber/hardcore 
party i was at at least a year ago.   DBN isn't focusing as much on 
parties anymore, their record label is their main focus there days.  
infact the only pure gabber dj i can even think of from the midwest is 
dj earache and he isn't even from milwaukee but minneapolis.  other 
milwaukee promoters are trying to get milwaukee out of that hardcore rep 
by bringing in all sorts of styles.  supposedly DBN is gonna throw an all 
hardcore party later in the summer but i will believe that when i see it.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1208      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Let's not let this degenerate into a "my music is better
than yours" contest.  Let's look at the main issue, which is
diversity.

I'm sure we can all appreciate different musical styles.  I
can groove on techno, house, trance, jungle.. even gabber.
I remember dancing to Lenny Dee at Earth in Milwaukee, and
the intensity was incredible.

Be that as it may, we all have a primary focus.  In my case,
it's techno.  Your love might be something completely
different.  

When we feel that our favorite musical style is
underrepresented, what we should do is to work to bring as
much diversity into the scene as we can.. throw small
undergrounds, pass out tapes, talk to people and find people
who share your vibe.  It's not about trying to change
people's minds.  It's about trying to share your passion
with other people and exposing people to new sounds.

Let promoters know that you crave diversity.  And back up
your words by keeping your minds open to other types of
music.  If you are into trance, go check out the acid jazz
scene.  If you are into ambient, listen to some hard acid
every once in awhile.  There is a lot of good music out
there, and there is no need to close yourself off.

Peace,

-Sho


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 10 12:25:20 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA13116; Mon, 10 Jul 1995 12:25:20 -0700
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id MAA13103; Mon, 10 Jul 1995 12:25:09 -0700
Received: from ultima.org by ultima.org; Mon, 10 Jul 95 12:30 PDT
Message-Id: <v02120d00ac26c750c9fe@[140.174.184.128]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Length: 2074
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 12:30 PDT
From: tic-tac@ultima.org (Joe Rice)
Subject: Moonlight
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Went down to S.C. Sat. for Moonlight - well worth the trip. Probably the
best party music format I've seen - ambient beginning, up to dance, and
back to ambient in the morning. Removes pressure on the first DJ to get
people to dance and gets everyone in the proper mood so that when the beats
come in everyone's up and grooving.

It was on some sort of farm with a pond right nearby (I hope those who swam
in it don't catch any weird diseases) and a beautiful view of the stars.
All of the music was spot on. I particularly enjoyed John Carel's set - I
hadn't heard him before. Minor played some great techno, almost turning me
into a trainspotter for much of his set. Monty followed in his inimitable
pumpin' acid house style and Tracy continued with a great energetic house
set. John Carel was the last DJ and brought things back into trance until
the ambient DJ trio took over with lovely winding down music.

Unfortunately the owner of the property showed up in the morning and was
extremely displeased with the situation. Evidently he knew nothing of the
party and the lock on his gate had been cut and No Trespassing signs
removed. Ahh, a bit risky. He called the cops and locked everyone in - he
wasn't interested in any payment and wanted someone in jail. The police
were a bit more rational and ended up citing Claire for criminal trespass
and something else and didn't detain her. They took down identifying
information on everyone there saying there was a slight chance we could all
be proscuted for trespassing. Ouch. We were stuck there for about 2 hours
after the party ended.

Looks like the next party will be a benefit for the costs of this last one.

Joe

I've long suspected that this is not the case at all. That it is based on the
lowest common denominator mechanism that typifies pop music. Is this a
desperate ploy by a scene to perpetuate itself in the face of lagging income
and/or interest? Can a scene that has this approach be considered underground
anymore?In the rave scene, has the word "underground" been reduced to a
substitute for "no flyers" or "illegal"?

Definitely something to think about.   This whole thread reminds me of the
transformation that the word "alternative" went through a few years ago...

Tom

I don't think it is possible to constructively criticize an entire scene,
but it is very easy to damn the whole thing :) . I guess you have to do it
on an event by event basis. There are some really shitty, greedy 
promoters out there who are out to make that fast buck. But that is not 
the sum of things. Take Friends & Family, Pacific, and Cloud Factory. Always
free, or VERY reasonably priced, nice people, nice vibes, and some great 
music(IMO.) I don't know what parties you have been to in the past four
months, but I have always had a good time at anything thrown by the above
crews. 

In regards to constructive critism of events, if the promoters and D.J. 
don't seem to care, screw 'em and move on, it is probably not somewhere 
you want to be. I really believe that many D.J.'s are still playing what 
they want to hear. Isn't it possible for this to coincide with what 
people want to hear? If a D.J. is spinning stuff that he likes, and the 
crowd also likes it, you really can get a synergistic effect, as I am sure
you have seen at one time or another. 


> I remember 2 years ago talking with Mike Huckaby, and Claude Young about DJ'ing
> overseas.  They said it was fucked up becuase most DJ's played music that
> the crowd wanted to hear, not what they actually liked.  I think it's
> better when it just so happens that the type of music that you play moves
> you, as well as the crowd.
> 
> -Jon
> 

You are absolutely correct and I should have stressed this more in my 
original response. But remember this thread all resulted from your 
observation that there is not a lot of diversity in the S.F. scene, which
may or may not be true, depending on what events one has been to, and 
your idea of diversity. In your statement you said that no one plays 
techno around here. Is it possible that at the parties you have been to, 
that the D.J.'s are indeed playing what they, as well as the crowd want 
to hear, and it just happens that this does not include techno? So if a 
D.J. were to play techno because you wanted to hear it, and not because 
they wanted to spin it, wouldn't that go against our shared opinion of 
what and why a D.J. should spin? Questions, not meant sarcastically.

                                              Black Adder

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Rick Riffle wrote:
> A collection was started to help her to pay the fine she will probably be
> slapped with.  Hopefully someone with more information on it will post
> something to the list.  Law or no law, IMO Claire deserves our help, for
> organizing and taking the heat for a wonderful "FREE" party.  Please help
> her if an opportunity presents itself.

Hmm.  While I admire her tact and willingness to take the heat so others 
can avoid trouble, I don't see breaking and entering itself as something 
that should be recognized, let alone lauded.  As someone who spent a lot 
of time way back when scouting for places to throw outdoor parties, I 
know that such spaces are indeed rare, but they are out there.  As for 
private property - some property owners just might say yes if you asked 
them nicely (or perhaps paid a fee or something).  I know many 
anarchists/socialists out there dismiss the notion of "owning land", and 
while I strongly sympathize, I think it's unfair to draw unwitting 
participants into the battle....

	Brian

Thank You to all the fun loving people that came out to our Sat. night party.  
Without everyone's teamwork the party wouldn't have worked.  We are already 
busy planning the next "light" party and look forward to seeing everyone out.  
I must apologize to those of you who were detained at the end of the party.  It
was very trying to be so tired and have to deal with such a sad situation.  We 
have learned a great deal from this experience!  The court date has been set 
for August 31st and a copy of the police report will be posted as soon as I get
the case report and formal charges from the DA.  I do not believe anyone
else will face charges. (The owner only seems to want revenge on me-)We are 
not discouraged but more determined to not get caught. He-he!  Any
suggestions or possible locations anyone would have will happily be taken.
A special thank you to Harmony who worked getting all the cars into the party 
quickly and efficiently!   Despite  the unfortunate last two hours, we hope
everyone enjoyed the energy, and beauty of the gathering itself. (We sure
did!)  See you soon! FEEL IT- LOVE!

                                 -Gateway Systems


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 10 14:50:15 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA21941; Mon, 10 Jul 1995 14:50:15 -0700
Received: from MPLVAX.SRI.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id OAA21929; Mon, 10 Jul 1995 14:50:11 -0700
Date:    Mon, 10 Jul 1995 14:49:16 PDT
From: HARTLEY@MPLVAX.SRI.COM
Message-Id: <950710144916.8b55@MPLVAX.SRI.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Vmsmail-To: SMTP%"sfraves@hyperreal.com"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

who said the san francisco scene is lame?  who said it has no diversity?
i have only been here for a month i know, but in that time i have been
completely blown away!  don't take what you have for granted.  over the 
last four years i have raved all over the east coast, from new york to
atlanta (i have to say i've never made it to rollando) to chicago and 
just about everywhere in between, but i have never seen any place that 
compares to here.  
if music is the center of our scene, what is it that we aren't getting 
here?  sure, it's mostly house here, but in the time i've been here i have
heard just about everything else.  whoever thinks baltimore and new york
have better scenes needs to go check them out.  160-180+bpm all the time
gets boring as hell, no matter how much you like it (and i love it!), and
god knows people in the southeast have no idea what acid jazz/trip hop is.
don't get me wrong, we have diversity, too.  just before i left there was
a jungle party in d.c. - now i love jungle, too, but jesus, jungle all
night long  |b .  in one night here i have heard more variety than in months
of partying there.  don't get me wrong, i've heard some phat tunz everywhere
- fever (in baltimore) had flashback just before i left with old tracks
from the storm/catastrophic raves ... ahhh, flashback time again - but 
some of the ones i hear here just don't compare.  my friends told me that
Carlos (when he played in Va.) was the best dj they'd ever heard, they 
say when Dubtribe played a few weeks ago people were crying with joy and
holding their heads, and the best party i ever went to in the southeast
had Galen and Robbie Hardkiss headlining.  san francisco may be mostly 
house, but it's the best house in the world, and i, at least, haven't had
to look too far to find other stuff, and i haven't had to drive 6 hours for
it either!
a lame scene, huh?  i have never seen any other place where people from
four generations gather together on a sunday afternoon just to get down and 
watch the sunset in the park (try that in baltimore!).  sure, music is
crucial, but so are the people, and the people here are some of the best and
brightest i've ever met.  here i tell people at parties i study physics and
get responces like, oh really, i'm an engineer, or i'm a chemist or an
artist, or whatever.  my friends and i even talked about shakespeare with
a caltrain conductor.  try that in the southeast (even try to find a
train).  diversity!  every time i go out i come home thinking i have never 
seen any place as beautiful as where i've just been - frequency8 this weekend,
for example, or berkely marina for sunset - and then the next week i go out 
again and say the same thing!  
this ain't no lame scene!  this is the most magical place i have ever seen.
if you're not getting what you want, then maybe you're in the wrong scene, or
maybe you just want to bitch.  either way, it's cool.  there's space here
for everybody.  and i certainly haven't been everywhere and done everything,
so maybe there is something better somewhere else.  more probably it's just
a matter of perspective.  whatever.  but this place definately IS NOT lame!
and thanks to all of you who make it the way it is.

peace!
seth

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 10 15:27:57 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA24138; Mon, 10 Jul 1995 15:27:57 -0700

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 15:27:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: Mike Battaglia <mike@organic.com>
Subject: the 'lame scene' clarifications
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9507101528.F21948-0100000@eat.organic.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


i think that this discussion is wavering. the topic is the *music* in
the scene, and not the scene itself. for some of us, the music is
everything, and it defines the scene. i love that fact that the scene
here is so vibrant and prolific and, well, big, but out of 6-10 parties
every night, i have to struggle to pick *three* out of a *month* that
look really good to me, parties where not only am i excited about the
lineup and the party itself, but where i know i'm going to have a good
time, because i know that i'm going to like the music there. If the
music ain't there, then man, i'm *bored*. i went to alot of parties when
i first moved here and the more money i spent and the more often i went
out, the more dissappointed i was. I went to see the orb earlier last
month and now the next party i'm looking forward to is the next Area 51.
Nothing else i've seen really turns me on. For instance. Went to United 
last month. coupled with the fact that 1)i'm 21 and i was one of the 
oldest people there (yes, i'm an over 18 facist) and 2)it was in 
Pittsburg (!), the music was flat out *boring*. Thank God Dan was on 
the bill...he saved my evening from being completely wasted. So as you 
see...great vibes are simply not enough for people like Jon and I (and 
others)...

mikebee



::Michel.Battaglia::::San.Francisco:California:::::mike@organic.com:
::mikebee@freenet.scri.fsu.edu::::http://organic.com/~mike::::::::::

To: brycer@ultima.org, ethan@bass-station.com
Cc: Deleuze101@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Happy House Crap

Precedence: bulk

> Excuse me? When was the last time you had a look in my crate?
> 
or mine...or heard my latin house, happy house, funk, retro, new wave,
top 40, experimental, breakbeat, hardcore, punk, hip-hop, trip-hop, acid
house... sets?  i understand that many of the larger events i have played
at i've played largely acid trance, but that's hardly my entire repetoire.

What's up with the litany of "styles"?   Does it really matter how many a DJ
can fit into his set? Does this impress anyone?  Shouldn't the quality of the
music, (IF it's of any quality), and it's ability to move people be the only
things that matter, not what "flavor" it happens to be, and whether or not
the night's diversity quota is being met?   I don't know if this is of much
relevance, but I was at a party friday night, (Climax).   Overall, it was one
of the best parties I've ever been to.   The space was great, the size was
nice, the vibe excellent.   I pretty much spent the night in the upstairs
room, listening to a bunch of Breakbeat.    It was THE SHIT!  The DJ's were
moving the crowd, people really seemed to be enjoying themselves, and the
music really didn't change much while I was there.    So I guess my point is,
(relevant or not) that as long as the tunes are good, it doesn't really
matter if some DJ is trying to move from "tribal acid funk" to "ambient
gabber didgeridoo"...

it's really very interesting for me to hear how other people classify
my "style".  i'm curious how other people would describe the music that
i play.

 I'm curious why people get so caught up in the naming and labeling game?
 Just play good music, that you like.   Any DJ that plays to please,
(pandering) to a crowd, belongs at weddings and birthday parties.   If you
don't like what the DJ plays, then go somewhere else.   If that somewhere
else doesn't exist yet, then do something about it.  Obsessing over
categories and styles can make people lose sight of the important things.
  But, to add my .02, I like all sorts of things I hear around here, as long
as they're short on piano riffs and divas.    

Tom

...deletions ...
>What's up with the litany of "styles"?   Does it really matter how many a DJ
>can fit into his set? Does this impress anyone?  Shouldn't the quality of the
>music, (IF it's of any quality), and it's ability to move people be the only
>things that matter, not what "flavor" it happens to be, and whether or not

I agree fully with this.  I was living with a DJ buddy of mine for nearly
two years and he happens to be one of the best (in my humble opinion) dj's
going among the lesser-known folks here in Vancouver (fellow canucks - DJ
oliver!).  He NEVER plays the same "label" of music all through a set - he
grabs all sorts of stuff that sounds good and moves your feet and heart and
makes you grin and bounce.  That's the kind of DJing I like the best.

Not to say that "styles" of DJing don't have their place (whenever they
play jungle I get a chance to sit down and chill ... *shudder*) .... but I
think it SHOULD be less important then the kind of VIBE that's created.

k

> discover more trance parties (IE:  Freq-8,  6th house,  etc).   Then I
> go to the DV8 when the Germans were in town and actually hear the same
> Happy Hard Core songs I heard in Australia,   I'm beginning to think
> that there is nope for the SF scene.   But there is always room for more
> variaty,  thats for certain.
> 
> Crunchman
> 

yes, i see your point. also, reading over my last message, it sounds like
i say that there is only one kind of music in the midwest. what i wanted
to say was the scene is much more diverse here.

but don't lose hope, otherwise nothing will ever change.

Hey everyone..  I am not playing the 'my music is better than yours
contest', I am just (once again) stating my opinion of what the party scene
is to me.

>Let's not let this degenerate into a "my music is better
>than yours" contest.  Let's look at the main issue, which is
>diversity.
>
>I'm sure we can all appreciate different musical styles.  I
>can groove on techno, house, trance, jungle.. even gabber.
>I remember dancing to Lenny Dee at Earth in Milwaukee, and
>the intensity was incredible.
>
>Be that as it may, we all have a primary focus.  In my case,
>it's techno.  Your love might be something completely
>different.
>
>When we feel that our favorite musical style is
>underrepresented, what we should do is to work to bring as
>much diversity into the scene as we can.. throw small
>undergrounds, pass out tapes, talk to people and find people
>who share your vibe.  It's not about trying to change

we are working on this..

>people's minds.  It's about trying to share your passion
>with other people and exposing people to new sounds.
>
>Let promoters know that you crave diversity.  And back up
not many promoters listen.

>your words by keeping your minds open to other types of
>music.  If you are into trance, go check out the acid jazz
>scene.  If you are into ambient, listen to some hard acid
>every once in awhile.  There is a lot of good music out
>there, and there is no need to close yourself off.

I'm not closing myself off to anything.  I love some acid jazz, I like
ambient stuff, trance is cool.. But <  What I am trying to say is..

WHERE IS THE TECHNO??????????????????????????????????


-Jon

> i think that this discussion is wavering. the topic is the *music* in
> the scene, and not the scene itself. for some of us, the music is
> everything, and it defines the scene. i love that fact that the scene
> here is so vibrant and prolific and, well, big, but out of 6-10 parties
> every night, i have to struggle to pick *three* out of a *month* that

> lineup and the party itself, but where i know i'm going to have a good
