I hate this, I hate that, I'm tired of this, I'm tired of that, I was just
making an observation this, I was just noting that, I really meant to say this,
no what I really meant was that..... arrgh!!

I am sick of people sniping my city for stuff they have easy control over...

You don't like happy house eh?  Try any of the clubs or parties that don't
specialize in a genre then.  Techno is hard to find, but there are PLENTY of
people who still play it (I say still since I have gone through *my* techno faze).

try out the many DJ's here on the list who play that type of music.
The same can be said of acid or house or garage or whatever.

SF has one of *the* most diverse music scenes I've seen in a long time.  Yeah,
there are areas that are lacking in certain styles of music, but if you look
hard enough, or just ask "Hey, I wanna hear some techno, where do I go?" I'm
sure the 300+ memebers of SFRAVES would steer you in the right direction.

If you *still* don't find what you're looking for, the start a gig yourself.
All it takes is time, and some money.

SF = Hip-Hop, Trip_hop, Jazz, Acid Jazz, House, Garage, Techno, Deep, Ambient,
Raggae, Rock, Soul, Funk, Fusion, Punk, Hardcore, Gothic, etc. etc. etc.

I do wish people would live here long enough to sample the flavors before 
mouthing off about how so and so ain't all *they* expected so and so to be.

And if it ain't there...CREATE IT!

I'm outta here,
John

P.S.  I *LOVE* SF!!!!  And so do most of the 750,000+ residents.  I think there
is a reason people continue to move here.  The various scenes being a part
of that factor.

Much Peace.

Dear All;

	This weekend, one took the heat for many. I would like to offer 
my suppport, love, advice, & services to Claire & Gateway. Such unselfish, 
selfless, actions should never go unanswered. Actions like this must be 
the rule of our scene rather than the exception. We as a group of kind 
people are only as splittered as our intolerance for one another, 
selfcenterness, & selfishness.

	If you've ever had a brush with the crimial punishment in-justice 
system, it really sucks, trust me. Take the inititive to tell your 
friends who were there, who aren't connected via the net, that help and 
support are needed for a wonderful, caring, & selfless person, who saw to 
it that they had a wonderful time on Saturdaynight at Moon Lite. Make it 
your responsibility to make sure that those services and support reach 
Claire or Gateway. Our scene is my responsibilty, I hope you feel the 
same way.

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian Darkness, LMT/EE/CET
		(510)-530-6452 CT Active Voice & Fax
	     (800)-590-4993 CT Active Voice Mail & Pager

>> >>There are people who do, but since nothing outside of those styles is

I don't like happy house carp. ALl they ever do is swim around in
listless circles, gobbling up floating fish pellets like there's no
tomorrow. Sometimes they'll suck yer finger when you stick it in the
water, if yer lucky, and that's it. Pointless glimmers of light in a
murky indoor pond. That's why I like happy house carp.

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, John S. Lee wrote:

> I do wish people would live here long enough to sample the flavors before 
> mouthing off about how so and so ain't all *they* expected so and so to be.

why is it so difficult for some people on this list to accept the fact 
that not all of us think it's the best place on earth?

there are pockets here and there of people playing harder styles of
music...but usually they're either difficult to find, or in a case like
this: ex, why zee threw a party and joey beltram was one of the
headliners. unfortunately the party was like $25 and the promoters were
not (and still aren't as their track record has proved) something i'd
want to spend $25 on. I mean...I personally would like to see more
Imported dj's....for a city with such a world class reputation i don't
think we see this nearly as much as we should...in addition to the
hometown talent in places like the UK you get foreign dj's all the time
at clubs...all the detroit pioneers, alot of new york dj's, people like
josh wink, laurent garnier, darren emmerson, (we even had justin
robertson here back in January...)

my point is, and has been, that there isn't enough harder music. 
ask Dutch, who is on this list, and who is one of my favorite dj's 
here. He's immersed int he scene and i'm sure he'll tell you the same 
thing. This is one reason why i'm looking forward to area 51. 
christophe, dutch, and carlos have delivered in the past and i'm almost 
guaranteed to have a good time at this party. i can't wait. 

i don't think this discussion can go anywhere else. I don't mean to put
down SF because i love it here....this just one thing bugs me and makes
me dissatisfied. especially because of the expectations i had when i
came here - do most of you know the reputation this city has in the rest
of the country? in the summer of '93 you couldn't go to a single party
without someone spinning the 'sf sound' or some big SF hit, how san
francisco was kicking it seriously live, how amazing the whole scene
was...and you come here and it's like the music hasn't really progressed
from '92, it's still 125 bpm acid house. the scenes in the east and
midwest went through slow breaks, hard acid, hardcore, progressive
house, gabber in places, happy breaks and jungle, the old-school
revival...yet here, if you want to party every weekend, you get house. 
before moving here i didn't think i'd ever look back, but i keep 
yearning to go to a party back in baltimore, or even Pittsburgh - or 
better yet, to bring the dj's and music *here*, to bring the parts that 
are missing into the picture to make it whole for me....

because if it's one thing that SF's got going for it, and going for it 
*bigtime*, it's the vibe.

mikebee

Precedence: bulk

Hey all,

Moonlight was by far the best party I have ever been to.  It was so 
beautiful.  Not just the 2 million stars, or the gorgeous hillsides, or 
the awesome music, but the people.  WOW!  What a vibe.  I was so 
overwhelmed by it all that I lost my head and freaked for hours.  I met 
some amazing people and truly danced like I never have before.  Purly 
tribal.  Throwing my arms in the air and losing all inhibitions.  I 
could go on forever about this party and how perfect it was but if you 
didnt go then you better check out claire and gateway's next party.  
She truly is a visionary who knows what raving is really about.  

I also can say that any of us who had to deal with the owner, especialy 
the people who put the pary on, would do it all again without a second 
thought.  It was just so amazingly beautiful.

love chris

p.s.  thanks to brian phudge for some powerful (sober) energy and rick 
riffle for a ride (we should get more connected since we both live in 
Sac.).

And now, a message from Dorena,


I have never felt so much love from a group of people than at Moonlight 
this past saturday might.  The happiness that surrounded me was so 
overwhelming, and yeah the ecstasy I took helped too.  I was overcome 
with so much joy from the beauty of the people, the music and the 
scenery.  Pure beauty.  It were as if this party belonged in this 
valley, everything was so in synch,...just powerful.  For those of you 
who didn't make it, make sure that you make it next time!  We were a 
complete family, sharing our energy.

Everywhere I looked there was a smile in front of my face, I even think 
that the mountains were smiling down upon us!!  Although we came upon 
some negativity from the property owners, our positive attitude and 
outlook made everything go very smoothly and hopefully everything works 
out well in the end for claire and gateway.  And it will!

Bye bye, Dorena :)

From: Minorminor@aol.com

Subject: minor setlist, Moonlight

  Goddamn, Moonlight was one to remember!  A heart-stoppingly gorgeous spot,
lovely weather, excellent music, a wonderful crowd of 150-200some people, and
just enough foresight and organization to prevent it from getting busted.
 All respects to all involved.
  Schedule-wise, I had the best opening spot you could ask for.  By 2:30 AM,
Consciousness Labs had everyone primed and ready to rock.  And everyone there
was so enthusiastic, it felt likethe records were just mixing themselves.
 Here's what I played:

2:30 AM
-------
TAGC - Magnesia
Bhasmantan - Black Hills
Pob - The Essence
Darin Marshall - 7th Hour
Holy Ghost - Mad Monks on Zinc
Mole People - Break Night
Dj Skull - Maximum Waveform
Mike Dearborn - Destruction
Skin Deep - Body to Body
Random Generator - Zone Paging
Blue Minds - Push
Atomik Locator - Overdose
Holy Ghost - Heavy Water
Claude Young - Concentration Factor
Outerealm - Welcome to the Storm
Hole in One - Gateway
Nigel Richards - Philadelphia Acid Experiment V2
Jam & Spoon - My First Fantastic FF
Pump Panel - Remover
Chemical Bros. - Leave Home (Underworld mix)
Psilocybin - Delicate Substance
Retrofit - Helium Bubble
Locker - 7 Deadlies
-----
4 AM

  I'm playing at the 8th House this Thursday, the 13th. (415-487-5436) is the
voicemail, it's on 1190 Folsom, by 8th, 21+ and $5 cover.  I'm going to bring
the wildest most fucked-up techno I've got, so if that's your thing, please
come!

   -franklin minor minor

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Dusko Pavlovic <dusko@CS.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: Re: Moon Light
To: brian@hyperreal.com (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 15:46:44 PDT
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

 > Hmm.  While I admire her tact and willingness to take the heat so others 
 > can avoid trouble, I don't see breaking and entering itself as something 
 > that should be recognized, let alone lauded.  As someone who spent a lot 
 > of time way back when scouting for places to throw outdoor parties, I 
 > know that such spaces are indeed rare, but they are out there.  As for 
 > private property - some property owners just might say yes if you asked 
 > them nicely (or perhaps paid a fee or something). 

Yes. And some police officers might also agree to be passionatly
hugged on street, under the same above mentioned conditions. Law
abiding and respect for private property should be the first
preconditions for a respectable rave. Last but not least, to emphasize
our commitment to legality, we should consume lots of Anheuser-Busch
beer all the time.

On a more serious side, I actually wondered how the SF party system
manages to survive without even collecting contributions for the
finest parties, while letting you get quite easily on the guest list
for others (thanks ameba!). This is a scene with genuinely great
moments, and one should take care that neither money nor a shortage of
it spoils it.

Perhaps someone can tell me how to "pitch in" now, for Moonlight in
trouble.

-- Dusko

> > mouthing off about how so and so ain't all *they* expected so and so to be.

I love SF.  BUT, the music (not the scene...the MUSIC) is my least 
favorite.  I don't dis it..but I'm telling you, I like the music out east 
orders of magnitude better than I do here.  And it also seems that many 
people out here just don't understand constructive criticism.  No one has 
flamed the music here from what I've read...but they've been flamed for 
expressing dissenting opinions.  So, just lie down on the floor and keep 
calm...everything will be ok.  It's not the end of the world if someone 
doesn't like the same things you do.

-John

Dear Brian, Lee & All;

	I care about & like both of you very much, we talked via e-mail
often, and I still care about & look forward to exchanging our feelings,
thoughts, and ideas. I respectfully, however disagree with the level of
navievity present at Moon Lite with regard to the break in. For people at
the rave, at least when they arrived and were present for a while, were
indeed very aware that this was a break in, and that we didn't have
permission to be there. Gateway didn't try and hide it, & were quite open
about it, for most of the people I talked with were aware of it, and if
they had a problem, had the option to leave once they got the news. 

	A message to all would be, if the people say that it's a break in,
take them seriously if you have a problem with that. 

	I stayed to pretty much the end, in fact I missed being one of the
people who got caught by about 15 - 30 minutes. I guess I inherited my
mother's, better than an AWACS survailence plane's radar, intution. I
enjoyed the party, helped out, had the knowledge, and am a co-conspiritor
by the laws defination and am just as responsible & accountable for the
consequences as the promoters. I feel that if you fall into that
defination, and if one is selfless enough to bear the brunt of the
consequences & shared responsibility, that they should be supported no
matter what, not that Brian's saying that we shouldn't support her. 

	In fact, my after feeling and wish is that we all would have said
that yes, I'm guilty, take us all to jail, and let them deal with the
impact to their punishment in-justice system. They would have had gotten a
bus, and I bet they would have talked with the farmer & never sited any of
us, cause we all no how police hate paper work, and that's 50x paperwork. 

	Tresspassing on so called private property which when you really
look at it, is just rented from the government. Anyone who pays property
tax and doesn't believe that is a fool, I dare you to stop paying your
property tax and see how quickly you lose "your" land. The crime of
tresspassing is just not that serious of a crime, it's at best a minor
infraction, and am surprised that she was even taken in to a jail where 
criminals are present.

	However this was a party, a rave by it's true defination, as I
understand it, and am sure I will be corrected by someone else's
defination, as they understand it(sarcasum present). I don't thing it was
a statement about the state of landownership in America, less I'm the
naieve one. It's about us, our music, our scene, our love for one another,
we who are made up of individuals, for we are the most diverse group of
kind people goin, and we will show the world that we shine, by our
individual actions in our group effort. 

	I remember when womyn would tresspass at the Senaca Weapons Depot,
in New York for the purpose of protesting Nuclear Weapons. Our actions are
a protest against the system thats said's we have to have a permit to have
a party, which in my opinion is against our constitutional right of
assembly, perhaphs it would have been better to hold the party illegally
in a public park, or government facility, and let them arrest us by
refusing to leave, as the generations before us did, maybe we need to make
our political agenda clearer by having protest parties where we make our
political ideas and statements clearer. I feel we would be much more
sucessful at doing this cause, we are connected world wide by the net,
unlike our 60's counterparts, but unlike them rave is not a national
movement, it's a worldwide movement don't ever doubt that for second. 
Remember that the people in power thought the younger generation was
disrespectful of the government when they pulled stuns like this &
protested nukes, war, hunger, gay liberation, racial & sexual equalality,
I think they called us "commie, pinko, fag, junkies" freaks, by any other
name. 

	For me it's about personal liberty, and the fact that today the
powers to be are tring to systematically take away your presonal freedom &
liberty, with more & more government restrictions, at every level. We've
had a lot more restrictions, then constitutional amemdendts garenteeing us
personal liberty, and I think it's about time for some new amendments to
that document so we can bring it into the 21st century.

	Lee, I got your post late, I don't remember seeing you there,
never the less. We all particpate in illegal activities; everytime we lite
up, drop, take #, it's illegal, and our government considers those a lot
more serious than tresspassing on private property. Remember Lee that
there's a war on drugs out there with a DEA. I don't remember a war on
tresspassing however. I was there and there was no descruction of private
property, I don't think she was cited with that. It wasn't a $10,000 lawn
on an estate either, it's where pigs graze, get real. 

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Brian Behlendorf wrote:

> anarchists/socialists out there dismiss the notion of "owning land", and 
> while I strongly sympathize, I think it's unfair to draw unwitting 
> participants into the battle....

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Lee Fogel wrote;

> Next time you plan to destroy private property for a party, please
> put it on your flyer and phone message.  I like being aware of when
> I'm about to participate in blatant criminal activiy.

Dear All;

	One final statement/question, if one/group of us throws a party
and is cited/fined/jailed by the powers to be for something relating to
the throwing of that party, and we fail to support or go as far as to even
shun/chastise that person/group, who will throw parties then, and will 
anyone be able to afford them? We either stand as a group, taking the 
good with the bad, or the only people throwing parties are going to be 
the clubs. Cause after this I would be kinda scared to throw a party, in 
fear that I would be judged, and left out in the cold, if something went 
wrong.

	I remember when F&F were cited by the powers to be, for something as 
unhinkable as assult on a police officer, and in the fire departments 
judgement we were in extreme danger due to overcrowding. I don't remember 
one anyone judging Ethan & Company, all I remember was a thread of 
nothing but support. Something to think about.

	All we have is each other, please don't forget that, else there 
is no scene, no PLUR, it must start with us, we are human, we make 
mistakes, and to forgive goes behond being human. Careful he who judge, 
less you be judged yourself.

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian Darkness, LMT/EE/CET
		(510)-530-6452 CT Active Voice & Fax
	     (800)-590-4993 CT Active Voice Mail & Pager

	Internet(LINUX Shell Account):	brianvan@liberty.com

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Brian D. informs:
>  We all particpate in illegal activities; [...]

I tend to be choosey about the laws I break.  And there are even some
laws, depending on how they are presented to me, that I respect.  If I
had driven the 1.5 hours to Santa Cruz to find out that a lock was
broken and a No Trespassing sign had been torn down on some guy's
property, I would have been pissed.  It's not the law-breaking as much
as the total disrespect for the owner's wishes.  I have no problem with
a party that trespasses, cleans up after itself, and leaves the land as
it was found.  

>  It wasn't a $10,000 lawn
> on an estate either, it's where pigs graze, get real. 

The fact that the farmer earns his living from those pigs means nothing
to you, I guess.  

Also: this farmer will surely tell his land-owning friends to be on
the lookout for trespassers now.  And the Santa Cruz police will share
the story with their peers; not of a bunch of innocent kids just making
too much noise, but of a blatant, in-their-face, intentionally
criminal act.  I'm sorry, but the only PeaceLoveUnityRespect that
happened at this party was with ourselves.  I'm glad everyone had a
good time.  I'm glad I wasn't there.


Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com

i think discretion though is necessary to keep the long arm of the
law and authorities at bay, and out of our raving faces.  this is
best accomplished by keeping things as underground and out of sight
as possible.  freq 8 was a wonderful fab time, and attracted the 
attention of no one.  i think an effort should be made to stay off
private land, and not attract attention of the law, cause with that
attention, comes increased awareness and restrictions and busts and
crackdowns.

i also dont agree with associating political or anarchic agendas with
raves.  i rave cause in the presence of the dance and company, comes
a seperation of my mind that brings about a complete unawareness of
my body and mind physical.  i has very little to do with promoting
any political agenda.  the ability to do this is put at risk by 
confronting the authorities.  i dont think confronting the authorities
is necessary if extreme care and discretion are used to pick outdoor
sights.

doug

Subject: Re: Moon Light
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950710173121.19975E-100000@liberty.liberty.com>

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Brian Darkness wrote:
> 	I care about & like both of you very much, we talked via e-mail
> often, and I still care about & look forward to exchanging our feelings,
> thoughts, and ideas. I respectfully, however disagree with the level of
> navievity present at Moon Lite with regard to the break in. For people at
> the rave, at least when they arrived and were present for a while, were
> indeed very aware that this was a break in, and that we didn't have
> permission to be there. Gateway didn't try and hide it, & were quite open
> about it, for most of the people I talked with were aware of it, and if
> they had a problem, had the option to leave once they got the news. 

I suppose we could take a poll, but it didn't sound like that from the 
people who had posted.

> 	I stayed to pretty much the end, in fact I missed being one of the
> people who got caught by about 15 - 30 minutes. I guess I inherited my
> mother's, better than an AWACS survailence plane's radar, intution. I
> enjoyed the party, helped out, had the knowledge, and am a co-conspiritor
> by the laws defination and am just as responsible & accountable for the
> consequences as the promoters. I feel that if you fall into that
> defination, and if one is selfless enough to bear the brunt of the
> consequences & shared responsibility, that they should be supported no
> matter what, not that Brian's saying that we shouldn't support her. 

I disagree that someone who martyrs themselves on crosses of their own 
making (sorry for the strong language) deserve support.  I'm sure it was 
a fantastic party, really - but I'm also sure that the fantastic-ness had 
very little to do with the fact that it was a break-in.  

There used to be this implicit code of ethics when you threw a party - 
this was a very strong set of ethics, and to me it was what made the 
scene as vibrant and *peaceful* as it has been for 4 years now.  And when 
that code gets violated, the trust between party-thrower and part-goer is 
hurt, and that's a bitch to try and build back.  

To make people unwitting participants in a misdemeanor is just
unacceptible.  In our "three strikes you're out" world this puts them 33%
closer to a long time behind bars, particularly if they're already on
parole, and what for?  

> 	In fact, my after feeling and wish is that we all would have said
> that yes, I'm guilty, take us all to jail, and let them deal with the
> impact to their punishment in-justice system. They would have had gotten a
> bus, and I bet they would have talked with the farmer & never sited any of
> us, cause we all no how police hate paper work, and that's 50x paperwork. 

Tell that to the crowd at 15th and Guerrerro the other night.  The police 
were more than happy to haul them all off.  

> 	Tresspassing on so called private property which when you really
> look at it, is just rented from the government. Anyone who pays property
> tax and doesn't believe that is a fool, I dare you to stop paying your
> property tax and see how quickly you lose "your" land. The crime of
> tresspassing is just not that serious of a crime, it's at best a minor
> infraction, and am surprised that she was even taken in to a jail where 
> criminals are present.

It's a misdemeanor, or a felony if you're on parole.  And despite utopian 
visions of what repetitive beats do for the terra, there was certainly 
potential for lots of property damage to occur.

> 	However this was a party, a rave by it's true defination, as I
> understand it, and am sure I will be corrected by someone else's
> defination, as they understand it(sarcasum present). I don't thing it was
> a statement about the state of landownership in America, less I'm the
> naieve one. 

*Exactly*.

Look, the question isn't even one of whether throwing unauthorized parties
on private land is an appropriate method for protesting land ownership. 
That doesn't matter.  The question is - what right does the promoter of a
party have to put their unwitting party attendees at serious legal risk?

> 	Lee, I got your post late, I don't remember seeing you there,
> never the less. We all particpate in illegal activities; everytime we lite
> up, drop, take #, it's illegal, and our government considers those a lot
> more serious than tresspassing on private property. 

As Lee said, I prefer to choose the laws I violate.

	Brian

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 10 21:14:41 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA13928; Mon, 10 Jul 1995 21:14:41 -0700
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA13916; Mon, 10 Jul 1995 21:14:38 -0700
Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 21:14:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>

cc: hyperreal <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Moon Lite
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950710193948.21339B-100000@liberty.liberty.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950710210115.13498T-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Brian Darkness wrote:
> 	One final statement/question, if one/group of us throws a party
> and is cited/fined/jailed by the powers to be for something relating to
> the throwing of that party, and we fail to support or go as far as to even
> shun/chastise that person/group, who will throw parties then, and will 
> anyone be able to afford them? 

Yes, because if I can make a distinction between people who Do The Right 
Thing and Do The Wrong Thing when it comes to throwing a party, then I 
can definitely choose who deserves my respect and support and who doesn't.
As long as there are enough promoters doing things right (which there 
are!) then we'll have a healthy economy of parties.  

> 	I remember when F&F were cited by the powers to be, for something as 
> unhinkable as assult on a police officer, and in the fire departments 
> judgement we were in extreme danger due to overcrowding. I don't remember 
> one anyone judging Ethan & Company, all I remember was a thread of 
> nothing but support. Something to think about.

I distinctly remember threads about how people felt unsafe in the 
building.  I was genuinely worried as well - when I felt the upstairs 
floor give a couple of inches with every beat, I got *very* concerned.
F&F learned from it - and I think Claire will learn from this too.

Ultimately this gets down to: what are *your* fundamental goals when it 
comes to "raving"?  If it's just to get really sorted and have a good 
time without ending up in too much trouble, sure, a breakin is probably 
alright.  But if you'd like to see the memes and mindset perpetrate into 
other parts of our world, if you'd like to see as many other people as 
possible get a clue as to what this is about, and if you'd like to be 
able to have fun at the same time, then it requires a slightly more 
mature perspective on the planning and execution of the events.  Wouldn't 
be a wonderful world if the owner came out in the morning, saw what was 
going on, and joined in dancing?  Hell yes!  Are you going to accomplish 
that by cutting his locks?  Hell no!

'Nuff said.

	Brian


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 10 21:19:19 1995

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Doug Fairclough wrote:
> i think discretion though is necessary to keep the long arm of the
> law and authorities at bay, and out of our raving faces.  this is
> best accomplished by keeping things as underground and out of sight
> as possible.  

One final comment - at a couple of the full moon parties and other outdoor
undergrounds I've been the one to go up to the cops and say "hello
officer, we're just having a party, here's my ID, you can check this out
if you like, just a bunch of kids having fun" etc.... and for a large
percentage of the cops, it flat out worked.  Honesty is indeed the best
policy at times.  "No booze, officer, maybe some pot here and there but
this is SF after all..."  And you know what?  After a few rounds of this,
I realized that at the end of the night, I was *happier* if a member of
the "other side" had come by, and left us in peace, than if they never had
stopped by at all. 

	Brian

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Brian Behlendorf wrote:

> I suppose we could take a poll, but it didn't sound like that from the 
> people who had posted.

	First, I'm not Gateway, I'm just supporting an event, that I feel 
is getting a lot of shit unnescessarilly, and am tring to keep things 
here in a real prespective, that's all.

	So out of all this I see the main concern is whether or not people
knew whether or not this was a break in? I was there, people were told to
come to a map point, extreme secrecy was exercised(more so than any other
event I've been to out here), people were made to turn their head lights
off bout 200 feet before the gate; this should have been the 1st
indicator, that it was a break in, that's if you didn't know. They were
then guilded in by flashlights, and told to stay very quite. The
rumor/scuttle butt was that this was a breakin, everyone I talked with
knew that, and if they didn't and their were a few, I told them myself. The
only other thing I think that Gateway could have done & didn't was put it
on the net(not a good idea for obvious reasons), and stick in on the
voice mail, (ditto). If you ask promoters to do this you mite as well call
the police yourselfs, cause not only are you providing them with the 
information, your giving them effidence. 

	Remember the old rule never commit a crime with a paper trail, I
like to extent that to never commit a crime with an electronically
recoverable trail. For those not up on what our government can recover
from electronic media, you should be very scared, for it's amazing what
they can pull off even a wiped drive. 

> There used to be this implicit code of ethics when you threw a party - 
> this was a very strong set of ethics, and to me it was what made the 
> scene as vibrant and *peaceful* as it has been for 4 years now.  And when 
> that code gets violated, the trust between party-thrower and part-goer is 
> hurt, and that's a bitch to try and build back.  

	I think you should post it, I would certainly like to see it.

> Look, the question isn't even one of whether throwing unauthorized parties
> on private land is an appropriate method for protesting land ownership. 
> That doesn't matter.  The question is - what right does the promoter of a
> party have to put their unwitting party attendees at serious legal risk?

	I think everything that could have been done, without sending up a
flare or leaving evidence, was. I wouldn't have put myself into a
situation where I could have been busted, for some very personal reasons,
you'll just have to trust me on that one. I think a lot of people were
told, and that word "breakin" is tossed around so carelessly that it
didn't have the punch or recognition that it needs to have with certain
people. 

	Also if your on parole, you're not suppose to be doing drugs,
drinking, and or staying out late, leaving you county of parole, doing
your piss test every month or every 2 weeks ...etc.  Anyone who has that
much to lose, like a felony, shouldn't be at a rave anyway, People need to
take responsibilty for their own actions, if your on parole and at a rave,
any rave, you need to ask yourself if this is the best place I could be.
If I was on parole, I wouldn't even think about going to rave. 

	I think this forum come use some positive suggestions with regard
to the proper way to do a breakin.

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Brian Behlendorf wrote:

> Look, the question isn't even one of whether throwing unauthorized parties
> on private land is an appropriate method for protesting land ownership. 
> That doesn't matter.  The question is - what right does the promoter of a
> party have to put their unwitting party attendees at serious legal risk?

Hmmm, I think the party promoters may have put an unwitting farmer 
at legal risk too. My understanding is that he's liable for injury that 
occurs on his property, so if any of those ravers swimming in the pond 
had drowned (thank god no one did), I think the owner could have been held 
liable, or at least brought to extreme legal grief by someone who thought 
he *should* be held liable, despite his level of knowledge about the event.  
Now before the flames begin, I don't claim to be a lawyer, so I'll happily 
stand corrected on this point. 

Kathryn

>On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, John S. Lee wrote:
>
>> I do wish people would live here long enough to sample the flavors before
>> mouthing off about how so and so ain't all *they* expected so and so to be.
>
>why is it so difficult for some people on this list to accept the fact

Why is it not so difficult for people to engage in tedium.  Fact is I nor
anybody said SF is a godsend.  Fact is there *might* be places better,
depending on your point of view.

I think SF is one of the best places on earth.  My stats tell the story:
Population 759,000 or 15490 people per sq. mi.  There is only one place
with more polupation density, New York City I believe...with that in mind:

Lowest Crime rate for it's size in the US.
*THE* most diverse population in the country.
*THE* most integrated city in the country.
The lowest incidents of rape in the USA.
One of the few if not only city/county municipalities.
Better than average public transportation.  You *really* don;t need a car
to live here.
Arguably the best food in the country, second only to say NY.
One of the easiest places to enage in entreprenurial activities.
A tourist mecca.
Best beers.
Best coffees.
Best Bread.
Best babes, oops I meant chicks, oops I meant wimmins ( double :)'s ).
Higest number of interracial people.
Highest number of interracial marriage, couples, etc.
Largest gay & lesbian population.
Largest sex positive population.
Some of the most easy going cops you'll ever find (ALERT:  I am comparing
this to cities of equal or greater density.  Ever tried Miami, LA, or NY
PD's.  Sf's are QUITE cool when compared to other big cities.)
Most muli-cultural events.
The most lax Marijuana enforcement (a low priority on the Law Enforcement
rouster).
Most diverse music scene since man became bipedal.
Some of the coolest people you would ever want to meet live here in lovely
SF (and the surrounding Bay Area I might add!).

So personally with all this going for it, I have a sense of pride about
where I've chosen to live.  SF!  I've been here 5 years now, my son was
born here overlooking BOTH the Golden Gate & Bay Bridges (now that's a cool
way to be brought into the world!  Besides, he's one cool kid!!!)

There is some shit I hate about this city, but when taken in whole, this
place is the bomb.  How the hell can 750k+ people be so wrong and stay in a
place they hate so much...get with the program.  Enjoy living here.  Or you
could *always* move to Concord, Kentfield, Orinda, BlackHawk...

Ok, let's consider this for a moment.  Let's consider DISTANCE & the COST
of travel.  It is cheaper to go from Chi to NY than it is to get from
either to SF.  Basic airline economics.  Now who covers the cost of bringin
in the DJ?  The promoter.  SO it costs $500 for a RT tickect to from CHI to
SF.  AND you have to pay the DJ what they want to, to spin.  Now you're
talking $$$. SF is expnesive due in large part to it's lacation.  We're on
the other side of the country.  One reason you don't see much outta town
talent is due to this fact.  The reason people charge $25 for imported
talent, is partially due to the ticket prices.  With a littel greed (i.e.
capitalism) thrown in for good measure.

Dear All;

	In California law there is something called clean hands, meaning if 
you break a law and then try and sue someone because you got hurt in the 
process that it was taken into account and weaken your claim excessively.

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Kathryn Ankrum wrote:

> at legal risk too. My understanding is that he's liable for injury that 
> occurs on his property, so if any of those ravers swimming in the pond 
> had drowned (thank god no one did), I think the owner could have been held 
> liable, or at least brought to extreme legal grief by someone who thought 
> he *should* be held liable, despite his level of knowledge about the event.

> stand corrected on this point.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 10 22:02:18 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id WAA16463; Mon, 10 Jul 1995 22:02:18 -0700
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id WAA16458; Mon, 10 Jul 1995 22:02:15 -0700

From: "Fred Heutte" <phred@well.com>

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 22:01:56 -0700
In-Reply-To: "Bryce Ryan" <brycer@ultima.org>
        "Re: Happy House Crap" (Jul 10,  1:50pm)
References: <199507102044.NAA17476@taz.hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: "Bryce Ryan" <brycer@ultima.org>, ethan@bass-station.com (Ethan Miller)
Subject: Re: Happy House Crap
Cc: Deleuze101@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I think the point Ethan and Bryce are making about variety is quite on
the mark.  In fact most DJs, even the Wicked crew, have a fair amount
of variety, though you won't really hear that if you just go to Wickeds
and Come/Unitys.  Anyone who's heard me spin knows that I'm fiercely
eclectic.  Take a look at my practice list from last night (a fairly
typical one in its diversity, I didn't do it to specifically to make
a point here but it illustrates it quite well), and tell me what kind
of DJ *I* am -- house, techno, trance, breakbeat or what?  

  Nick Lowe - Heart of the City (my traditional retro-opener)
  Xpando - Here for the Love (acid house)
  The Magi (Chris Nazuka & Derrick Carter) - Clap Your Hands (disco-house)
  Mad Mike - Trance Patrol (Detroit house)
  Danell Dixon - I Saw the Future (acid house)
  Atlantean Love Machine - Dub Your Wig (progressive house)
  Towa Tei - Technova (George Llanes remix) (trance)
  Luna Eclipse - Return Home (Aquatherium remix) (progressive house/trance)
  Bass Bin Twins - SF2UK (breakbeat)
  Bass Kittens - Jack the Biscuit (breakbeat)
  K&M - Funk & Drive (funk house)
  T-recs - Trancepiration (trance)
  Time Warp - Jungle Drugstore (trance)
  Chez - Groove II (acid house)
  I Pooley - Sure (Detroit trance)
  Grip - On & On (trance)
  Humate & Rabbit in the Moon - East (trance)
  Airfix - I Found You (progressive house)
  Remy & Sven - Tsjika-Boem-Tsjak (trancey house)
  Drum Club - Drums Are Dangerous (techno)

When you actually analyze the sets being played by DJs in San Francisco
even at the big events, many of them are actually quite diverse.  The
problem comes when they play a limited range of beats or of sonic styles
at any given event.  The availability of beat-matchable tracks has led
to over-reliance on the single-BPM set, in my view.  124 or 134 or
whatever BPM might be fine for, say, half an hour, but the ear and the
body both get tired of monotony.  Like many DJs, I tend to move upward
in my set, the one above goes from roughly 126 to 135 but I often play
somewhat lower and a little higher, and sometimes jump up or down by
quite a few BPM.  The range may seem narrow, but the effect is quite
substantial when you change by, say, 5 BPM.  If it's not done correctly
it can really be a bad idea, of course, but that's part of the skill
involved in playing records for an audience.  

If I have a criticism of the mainstream DJs in San Francisco, it's that
they rely too heavily on what I'd call the Strictly Rhythm sound.  Now,
Strictly is a great label with tons of output that is generally quite
high quality, and they have an excellent mix of well-known and unknown
remixers.  But they rightfully have an overall "style" which has become
the pivot point for a lot of the big-room sets in SF over the last two
years.  I don't want to criticize Strictly per se, they don't put out
cheeze and they are in many ways a model of how a serious dance music
label should be run, but to some degree DJs have used the ubiquity of
their catalogue as a crutch.  

The other thing to realize is that the audiences for this music have
congealed into somewhat separate microclusters.  In part this is because
what was fresh and demanded attention in 1990 has now become familiar
and background in 1995.  The tremendous push for innovation in dance
music has to a great degree run the course of the musical flexibility
available in the 4x4 beat and current technology, and so I hear much
more conscious efforts at standing out from the crowd which achieve
that objective but at the sacrifice of musicality.  Take Josh Wink,
for example, one of the premier remixers of the time and clearly a
major force on our music scene now and for years to come.  When I hear
him put out "Don't Laugh" or "I Am Ready" or other recent tracks, you
can hear how he uses the techniques that he's developed from years of
putting out records to produce tracks that are gosh-darn-guaranteed-
surefire "hands in the air floor fillers."  I greatly respect that
ability, but frankly after I hear those one or two times I've had
enough.  When something completely brilliant like Wink's "Meditation
Will Manifest" comes along, I want to play it to death because it
has such great textures and rewards you with different flavors each
time you hear it.  

People who produce records for a living have to go for the "floor fillers"
to pay the rent.  I have a bunch of respect for people like Wink and
Strictly who do put those out, but who also put out full-on musically
innovative work as well.  To me, then, the burden falls back on the DJ
to strike a balance between pleasing and teaching the audience.  
I have my preferences among the SF DJs, as does everyone, but most of
them seem to me to work hard at finding that balance to their own
satisfaction.  It's only when they clearly fall back on a standard
game plan that I start getting annoyed.  Punching a clock isn't the
way to play music in public, even if it's your job.  

But San Francisco is not dominated by any one sound or approach, even
in the relatively narrow circles we travel in.  Ultimately, as a
listener or participant it's our responsibility to seek out the new
and unusual and demanding and rewarding music out there.  It means
giving up a sure-fire good time, sometimes, but as long as the hits
outweigh the misses it's well worth it.  Otherwise, you might as well
stay at home and watch MTV.

Well, Jon, if you don't like "fluffy diva house music" don't go to Spundae
and other events at DV8, or the End Up, or whatever.  Actually, I'm not
real big on that style myself, but like anything, I love it when it's
played well, at the "right" time (depends as much on the crowd as the
time'o'day) and not overplayed.

like Roger S, Frankie Knuckles and Serious Rope.  If so, I'm in trouble
because those are mainstays of my current playing!

I can't condone break-ins.  Using public land "off hours" is one thing,
breaking locks to enter private property whether a building or a field
is quite another.  I'm not a property absolutist; in fact, I spend a
good portion of my life in political work designed to oppose that
proposition.  But using private property without permission for our
parties is not only illegal, it's stupid.  I don't care how perfect
the site is.  No matter how stealthily it's done, eventually it will
be found out and the consequences will set all of us back because
as always, bad news travels instantly and good news takes the slow
path.

Sorry I'm so hard on this, but it's my strong feeling.

phred

I was at the party with 2 friends.  We were among the first to arrive
and among the last to leave without getting busted.  Upon leaving the
party we had NO IDEA it was a breakin.  In fact, when I read the first
posting saying it got busted I was convinced the author was joking.

I am not exactly on parole, but my legal status is somewhat sketchy;
my immigration status is even more sketchy; getting busted would have
been BAD.  VERY BAD!  Had I known the party was a breakin I would NOT
have gone; had I learned this at the party I would have probably left.
I understand posting such info on the net is not a good idea, but
telling us at the mappoint would be reasonable.  Or at least at the
entrance to the parking lot.

I agree with Lee.  I should be able to decide for myself which laws I
may want to break.  And when.

But it was a great party.  One of the best.  I was very happy to have
been there, and am very happy for not getting busted.  Thank you
Claire for taking all the responsibility.  I will do what I can to
help you deal;  you should post an address for donations to help with
the legal fees.

Peace and love

SASA

Two things in response to jsl's comments.

First, be careful about categorizing the scene in the East Coast.
(MOVE was in Philly, not Pittsburgh, by the way.  And Kurt Schmoke,
one of the better mayors in the nation who happens to be African-
American, runs Baltimore hella better than Schaefer ever did.
Racism?  That'
s everywhere.  I've heard horribly racist comments in San Francisco
as well as my own town of Portland.)

Second, I just discovered one of the reasons that bigtime DJs don't
often make it to the west coast.  It turns out that it costs more to
fly to Detroit right now ($750) than to London ($600), which is why
I'm not going to the Detroit music conference this week after being
jazzed about going there all year long.  

I do wish more "name" DJs from out of town would come to the west
coast, and in fact if you look at the last year or so, it's starting
to happen.  It's just that they don't play the big "underground"
parties very much, so you have to watch the club listings carefully.
But if Roger S, Justin Robertson, Jeff Mills, Emma (DIY), Pierre,
Frankie Feliciano, Sasha and Mixmaster Morris aren't "big names" in
the DJ world, I've missed the mark somehow.  And they've all played
SF in the last year.

phred

Dear All;

	For clarity, I'm not condoning breakin's & when Gateway makes
their statement, I know they won't either. I'm just tring as I said to put
things in perspective; tresspassing, is a minor offense, and should not be
blown into murder, or rape of a farmers land. Anyone who does drugs
commits a much more serious crime than does someone tresspassing, at
least in the eye's of our government. 

	Obviously, the fact that there were some people who appear to
have, either been uninformed of the status of this event, or just didn't
fiqure it out. I personally made every attempt to let people what was up,
and I believe so did Gateway. It's unfortuate this happened, and I don't
believe Gateway intentionally tried to get people in trouble with the law,
or make them accessories to a crime. I will still, stand by what I said,
if your on parole, say away from raves, there is way to much temptation
present there for all sorts of things.

Im not so sure that anyone is hip to the fact that the majority of the djs
that are taking the music to new limits are not in this city.  What I mean
is, they live here on the weekdays, they shop at all the record stores
(including my favorite: Sound Works), but they fly away every weekend to
all parts of the country.  This pack of rebel SF djs includes myself, John
Williams, Carlos, Graeme, DRC, and a bunch of others I'm sure. The
stationary djs are the ones that you always hear and always see on SF
flyers.  That is unless you like to venture to the sounds of Theta Blip,
H.A.L.F.(Happy Alien Life Force), Alex, Ethan, Mars, Goa Gil, Chizaru, and
many others if you look in the cracks.  A nice alternative to the syndrome
of the happy house movement is a party known as The 8th House Experiment
(8th House, has not one thing to do with house).  Its at the Cats grill,
1190 Folsom. Other that that, if your so unhappy about the music situation,
as so many of us are, do something about it.  Please!!!  If you are
unwilling or just unable to provide us with your own taste of nightclub,
just educate our fellow naive ravers, who were'nt around 5 yrs ago to
witness the root of it all.

By the way,  HOW DID HOUSE MUSIC EVER GET INTO THE RAVES?

                WHAT WENT WRONG???

dutch
CDC
P.S. I still love house music.

Subject: happy snappy get my pappy...finale
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I know my last post was kinda sharp, but under the circumstances, it was
necessary.

Many people who are new to the area bring all their expectations with them.
I stumbled into the house scene after moving here from LA/OC.  It opened
my eyes to the possibilities.  I have made more friends and associates than
I could have possibly dreamt, and the people who I have met have been
genuine gems in many ways.

People will always have a bone to pick with something, but as many of you
have come to know me, the first question I always ask in "What are *YOU*
gonna do about it?".  Whether it was 18-- parties, or smokeless gatherings
I have always asked what action people planned to take against the elements
they did not care for.  After waiting a little while people began to RISE
to the occasion.  MOST notably Ethan & Bryce. Here are two guys who did not
like what they saw, and instead of droning on and on, they did the next
logical thing:  If you don't like it, change it.  They changed it by doing
thier own thing, right in the midst of SF for all to see.  After continuing
for a year they now have a rep, and are quite well known in the community
for throwing quality gigs (word on the street) @ more than fair prices.
They are well respected in the promoter & clubgoer community as a reputable
crew & family.  These days you nary here from them on the list about
"...promoter this..." or "...promoter that...".  Why?  They are too busy
doing their own thang, and suffer little from the distractions that come
with watching others instead of watching yourself.

The same can be said of the SMILE posse, who are just starting to push up,
but have not sacrificed their integrity just to get a name.  Their purpose
is true, and like F&F time will be on their side if they decide to stick it
out (I KNOW they will).  That's the whole point.  I think that the same can
be said of a SCruze resident who now does gigs in that part of the Bay Area
(Sean, is true non?).

Its not as if some criticism is not valid.  But what I have believed from
the start is that criticism w/o action or any intent to do such, is a waste
of time, and breath.  There are plenty of people who can point out all the
bad, but few are those who are willing to make a difference.  Making a
difference requires committment & will.  I admire those who show such
qualities.  Personally I would rather emulate a doer than someone who
observes.  Don't we have enough pundits?

So if the music does not suit you, BUY the music you want to play, become a
DJ.  Oh you don't wanna do that?  Then get the people you want to spin,
forma a posse, and throw your own gig!  If that doesn't suit you then try
to talk w/ the person throwing the event and change their minds.  If that
doesn't work, then you can at least say I tried.  Flights leave every day
from SFO or Oakland.

* I LOVE SF *
* SF & THE PEOPLE IN IT ARE THE BOMB *
* THE BAY AREA ROCKS d00D ! * "Heh, heh" "Uhh, huh-huh!"  "Yeah, rocks
dude, heh-heh!  Hey, I didn't know there we're zeroes in the word dude."
"That's cuz you've been munching too much
assmunch...huh-huh,huh-huh,huh-huh!"

I'm done wit this tedious old ass thread,
John bka Da Chief

                "Prejudice is the reason of fools." - Voltaire
              jsl@netcom.com - public key available upon request

we can acheive. What we acheive is totally up to us but we can do it!

would go off in Chic-a-go. I probably even take the weekend off and fly
down there to see it.


Andrew Dressler is SOUNDGOD@iccse.com

>First, be careful about categorizing the scene in the East Coast.

I stand corrected Phred.  Rightly said I might add...  I couldn't remember
the city, but the opportunity was too good to pass up ;).  Thanks for the
correction however....HOWEVER:

SF is the most integrated city bar none.  I lived on the SE for the
majority of my life.  Got to visit many places in the NE.  W/O a doubt SF
has the most integrated scene.  And that is VERY important to me as an Af.
Am.  Hell, when you go to a hip-hop event in this city its all about the
brown, red, black & white.  Now that's integration, and *THAT'S* beautiful.

As for Af. Am. mayors.  Wilson Goode was the one who bombed the HQ of move.
He was Af. Am. as well. Af. Am. mayor does not always mean good mayor.  I
am quite aware of this fact.  As for Baltimore itself.  C'mon, Baltimore
gives So. Boston a run for the money when it comes to racism (black mayors
HARDLY remedy racism, note: Detroit, Chicago, LA, for starters).

I'd rather be here than anywhere else.  Hearing it and living it are two
different things.  You may hear racist shit here, and the city right now is
playing eject the blacks (it won't happen :) ), but overall SF/Bay Area is
much better than the rest of the country when it comes to race relations.

There are some places in Oregon that give me the creeps.  I'd hate to get
lost going to Portland (the sound of dueling banjos comes to mind! :) ).

>

>often make it to the west coast.  It turns out that it costs more to
>fly to Detroit right now ($750) than to London ($600), which is why
>I'm not going to the Detroit music conference this week after being
>jazzed about going there all year long.
>

>Frankie Feliciano, Sasha and Mixmaster Morris aren't "big names" in
>the DJ world, I've missed the mark somehow.  And they've all played
>SF in the last year.
>
>phred

The other factor is the smaller promoters are not privvy since they have a
smaller netowrk of people to work with.  If you know they're coming, you
can get the talent at your party.  All these pople triple book up the ass!
You just gotta know who to ask.

Rightly said Phred :):) !!!

 After reading the recent "H*ppy H**s* Cr*p" posts , I have noted two 
themes - 

#1. Newcomers and locals without extensive scene experience find it hard 
    to predict what the music is going to be like at an event.

#2. Predictable DJs are somehow "lesser" than eclectic , hard-to-
    catagorize DJs. ( not my opinion totally , just what I perceive 
    from the posts ).

 After 3 years of going to local events , I still feel somewhat in the
category of the folks in #1 above. This is because I still don't have 
a handle on ALL the regularly working DJs in the area , although I do
have a mini-list of favorites I'd go see if an event has them on its
flyers.
 
 But, this is seems like being a rock music fan , trying to figure out 
what style a band plays by who else is on the bill and whether it's 
"Molybdenum Alloy Metal Grunge" night at that club. There are "rock"
musicians who I'll go out of my way to see if they ever came here on
tour ( Bill Nelson ) , and there are tons of local hard working bands
who I know nothing about and don't have the time to check out.    
  
 There are so many DJ's in this area I couldn't possible know them all,
so I take a guess - DJ * is on the same lineup as Jeno and Garth,
so DJ * probably doesn't play gabber ( at least not at this event! ).

 If I'm in the mood for a good dose of a certain style , it's good to
be able to have some predictability in DJs. And , since I don't go out
as much as a S.F. resident would , I haven't burned-out on any DJ's 
individual style yet. 


 I wish I could come up with some grand unifying statements at this point,
but I'd rather go to bed!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Well good luck, I think the bottom line is you should go for it.
If your parties are good and the music is hitting then people will come
and you will get a following, if the party and or music is "lame" then you
won't get a following and you will loose money which is how it generally
goes.  Don't blame the "SF scene" if a certain type of music is not popular
here then in other places, 4 years ago Techno was very popular here, other
styles predominate now but lots of people (including me :) will go to a party
that plays Techno or hard trance or whatever if the music is good, if the DJ is
lame or his/her choices are cheesey, then I don't want to hear it.

Toni at the last Freedom played some pretty hard techno-y stuff, that made 
me put my head in a bass bin :) something I haven't done since the days of 
Techno at Toon Town :)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jul 11 03:01:37 1995

From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199507111003.DAA23004@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: jsl@netcom.com, mike@organic.com
Subject: Re: Happy house wha?....
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

> because if it's one thing that SF's got going for it, and going for it 
> *bigtime*, it's the vibe.
> 
> mikebee
> 

Yeah dude, and that's what it's all about.
If your into those styles maybe you should start throwin parties or hook-up
with others like you and throw a party together, it doesn't cost much to
throw an underground all you need is a generator for $40 - $50 and a
sound system, there are a lot of small systems floating around.

Now as far as BIG events, well they cost a lot of money to throw, it will be
hard to convince a large promoter to throw an event that s/he KNOWS they will
loose money on (because at least right now, a hard techno party won't
fill up  a large event, but if you look at the musical history of San Francisco
from the 50 , 60 on, San Francisco has ALWAYS been the home of the funky groove
thang, people here prefer that to jumping on whatever musical bandwagon
comes through at the moment.  As a DJ wannabe and someone who has been going
out in SF for a few years, the music has changed tremendously over time.
It still is groovy and still is funky.  SF people like to dance and this is
why there is so much VIBE.  It is really hard to exhibit any type of graceful
moves at 160 BPM, I suppose you could jump around but for many of us, it's not
trance inducing (maybe we're just getting too old :). It takes several hours
of dancing and music before large numbers of people can easily enter the trance
state the we refer to as the VIBE, if you start off at 140 and go up from there
most people won't be able to keep up for the 3 or 4 hours needed to break 
down there ego enough to enter trance.  I remember early parties that would
open with Happy House, get to Hard Techno around midnight, at high BPMs and
then on to some Tribal so that by the time 4 am came around, everyones minds and
bodies were conditioned for Jeno to come on and mash their Egos to a pulp.
Such is not the case today but... 

there is always tomorrow.


				G

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, sean t starbuck wrote:

> By the way,  HOW DID HOUSE MUSIC EVER GET INTO THE RAVES?
> 
>                 WHAT WENT WRONG???

---------------------------------------


                           AMEN!!


That was the beauty of the Rave ideals in the beginning (at least on the 
west coast)  that raves where seperate from clubs.  They were a completly 
different alternative to clubs and clublife, and the music was not club 
music....It was Rave music, and TECHNO, music that had massive breaks and 
suprises coming in from all over, not just formula house tracks that will 
move the feet but not the mind!  Keep house in the clubs and house 
parties, but please dear god let me hear the "MUSIC FOR HUGE SPACE 
ARENAS"  at the raves.  Raves to me, are massive parties where the 
boundarys are being pushed on all senses, where people are gathered for 5 
or more hours on a dance floor to be taken on a journey through the most 
sonically amazing and avanced techniques possible.  Most house music 
relys soley on the groove and the beat, while not nearly enough attention 
is paid to the sound and the structure of the song.  I will give San 
Fransico credit for having some amazingly technically talented dj's, many 
who are very good at creating a groove and keeping a dancer on their feet 
for hours at a time.  This groove is not as hard to create as I once 
thought when I realized that most of the songs are all in the same BPM 
range and have similar moods (happy).  I am much more impressed with a dj 
who can push the boundaries further, but still be in control of the 
energy level while flucuating in a larger range.  Too much predictability 
is something that bores the shit out of me, especially when I am dancing.


Derek

moses@teleport.com        Inportland Techno Acid Ambient Mail Order
DJ Rumpleforeskin              Import Domestic Records-C.D.'s
0--\___/--\___/---0                 phone/fax 503-620-3340
SUBMERGE TO THE DEEPEST DEPTHS IN ORDER THAT THE HIGHEST BE ELEVATED TO LIGHT
                                                           *Alfred Rosenberg

Subject: Moon Light & Property Rights
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950710173121.19975E-100000@liberty.liberty.com>

My computer tells me that on Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Brian Darkness shared (in 
part):

> Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 19:15:32 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
> To: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
> Cc: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>, sfraves@hyperreal.com,
>     Gateway Systems <reza@uclink.berkeley.edu>,
>     Lee Fogel <lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com>
> Subject: Re: Moon Light

> 	Tresspassing on so called private property which when you really
> look at it, is just rented from the government. Anyone who pays property
> tax and doesn't believe that is a fool, I dare you to stop paying your
> property tax and see how quickly you lose "your" land.

Brian, I see where you're coming from, in fact I feel exactly as you do 
about most of what you mentioned here, but we must realize that land isn't 
"rented" from the government; they're *extorting* the money from us.  The 
land is ours, not theirs.  Just because they have the power to take the 
land, doesn't mean it's their right to do so.  Might doesn't make right.

> The crime of
> tresspassing is just not that serious of a crime, it's at best a minor
> infraction,

Be this as it may, trespassing on privately owned land is still wrong, 
and should in my opinion be avoided.  Not only is it disrespectful of the 
owner and a violation of his/her right to privacy among other things, it 
may expose an owner to liability for things that happen on their land as 
a result of the trespass that he or she had no knowledge of or control over.  
Surely we can all agree this should not happen to an innocent party.

> and am surprised that she was even taken in to a jail where 
> criminals are present.

Don't be surprised; our government has done far worse to people for far 
lesser offenses.

> 	However this was a party, a rave by it's true defination, as I
> understand it,

Yes!! I wish I'd been there...

> defination, as they understand it(sarcasum present). I don't think it was
> a statement about the state of landownership in America,

Unfortunately in this case, actions speak louder than words.  I think it 
was in effect a statement about the absence of respect for property rights 
in our culture, even if that was not the intent.

> 	I remember when womyn would tresspass at the Senaca Weapons Depot,
> in New York for the purpose of protesting Nuclear Weapons. Our actions are
> a protest against the system that's said we have to have a permit to have
> a party, which in my opinion is against our constitutional right of
> assembly,

It most definitely is!  "Freedom of assembly" should be on the lips of 
everyone whenever a party is busted where the owners of the site have 
given permission for it to be held there.

> perhaps it would have been better to hold the party illegally
> in a public park, or government facility, and let them arrest us by
> refusing to leave,

Yes.  Public land belongs to we the people, not to some government agency; 
there is no need to get a permit to hold an event there unless it 
interferes with someone else's use of the land, who by the same token has 
equal rights to its use.

> as the generations before us did, maybe we need to make
> our political agenda clearer by having protest parties where we make our
> political ideas and statements clearer.

I couldn't agree more.  Ravers in Great Britain are way out in front of 
us on this issue.  (See "Raving Injustice" post for more on this...)

> I feel we would be much more
> sucessful at doing this cause, we are connected world wide by the net,
> unlike our 60's counterparts, but unlike them rave is not a national
> movement, it's a worldwide movement don't ever doubt that for second. 
> Remember that the people in power thought the younger generation was
> disrespectful of the government when they pulled stuns like this &
> protested nukes, war, hunger, gay liberation, racial & sexual equalality,
> I think they called us "commie, pinko, fag, junkies" freaks, by any other
> name. 
> 	For me it's about personal liberty, and the fact that today the
> powers to be are tring to systematically take away your presonal freedom &
> liberty, with more & more government restrictions, at every level.

I think Americans are waking up to this, and it's about time.

	Yours in liberty,
				
				*** Starchild ***

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jul 11 05:11:04 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id FAA07659; Tue, 11 Jul 1995 05:11:04 -0700
Received: from blizzard.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id FAA07654; Tue, 11 Jul 1995 05:11:01 -0700
Received: by blizzard.berkeley.edu
	(5.65c/IDA-1.4.4.1-DomainOS) id AA10349; Tue, 11 Jul 1995 05:10:56 -0700
Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 05:10:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: Starchild <rrose@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
X-Sender: rrose@blizzard.berkeley.edu
To: hyperreal <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Cc: Doug Fairclough <kensey@wired.com>
Subject: Discretion and Appeasement (Philosophical)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950710211610.13498U-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.APO.3.91.950711040208.10200A-100000@blizzard.berkeley.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


My computer tells me that on Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Doug Fairclough shared:

> i think discretion though is necessary to keep the long arm of the 
> law and authorities at bay, and out of our raving faces.  this is
> best accomplished by keeping things as underground and out of sight
> as possible.  

Doug, I appreciate what you're saying.  I just hope we can all keep in 
mind that there's a fine line between discretion and appeasement.  
Discretion is standing for your freedoms, but choosing when and where to 
exercise them, how to frame the issue in a non-confrontational manner, 
and so on.  Appeasement is retreating from your beliefs in the face of a 
threat, and allowing yourself to be intimidated.  I'm not saying you or 
anyone else is necessarily advocating this, I just want to get it said...

Appeasement has short term benefits.  It may allow a party to go off, 
prevent people from getting arrested, avoid ugly scenes with the police,
etc.  The problem comes when you look at the long-term effect.  It's kind 
of like borrowing money to pay for social programs, and passing the cost 
on to future generations.  Great now, not so fun for those who pay.

Imagine a situation where someone hijacks a plane and threatens to blow 
it up unless other dangerous terrorists are released from custody.  If the 
authorities cave in and release the terrorists (in other words, tolerate 
a wrong in order to avert a greater immediate wrong), the outcome is 
going to be much better for the people on the plane than it would if the 
authorities refused to grant the demands or attempted a rescue of the 
passengers and provoked a violent response from the hijacker.
However this sends others the message that you can get what you want 
through terrorism.  Terrorist acts will become more frequent, and the 
demands will become greater, as long at it is perceived that the 
authorities will always give in rather than risk an unpleasant situation.

In our situation, we are being asked to give up little bits of our 
freedom by the government, whether it's the right to dance without a 
permit, the right to set off fireworks, the right to do drugs, the right 
to attend events before reaching a certain age, etc.  When we give in on 
these points, we avoid having the police spoil our parties.  But we also 
send the message that it's okay for them to take our freedoms away, and 
this encourages them to continue doing so, since they now know that they 
can get what they want (power and control over us) from this type of 
"terrorism".

The long and the short of it is, if we give legitimacy to the authoritarian 
demands of the government by quietly doing their bidding on the implicit 
understanding that they let us alone thereafter, we merely open the door 
to more unreasonable demands, and soon we may not have the right to rave 
at all.  There wasn't a lot of partying going on in the former Soviet Union.

	With liberty and justice for all,

				*** Starchild ***

______________________________________________________________________________
"They came for the Branch Davidians, but I wasn't a Branch Davidian..." -?
______________________________________________________________________________
"He who would trade essential liberties for a little security deserves 
	neither liberty nor security." 		-Ben Franklin
______________________________________________________________________________

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jul 11 08:18:25 1995

From: Doug Fairclough <kensey@wired.com>

Subject: Re: Discretion and Appeasement (Philosophical)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.APO.3.91.950711040208.10200A-100000@blizzard.berkeley.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.950711080143.17154J-100000@get.wired.com>

my intent was really to say, be discreet and respect the law as much as
possible in order to not attract undue attention to yourself, in order to
accomplish your true aims.  society does pass laws and make restrictions 
that end things.  i think the movement in England is more restricted by
laws than it used to be.  i remember reading about ravers descending into
towns, scaring the shit out of the inhabitants, trampling shit, and then
laws were passed. 

i'm not saying to back down from agression, or to sacrifice in any way
your rights to assemble, etc, but if your know what your intent is, and
are self confident about it, it is probably best preserved by keeping it
as low key as possible.  is it really about confrontation ?

doug

> 
> On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Brian Behlendorf wrote:
> 
> > Look, the question isn't even one of whether throwing unauthorized parties
> > on private land is an appropriate method for protesting land ownership. 
> > That doesn't matter.  The question is - what right does the promoter of a
> > party have to put their unwitting party attendees at serious legal risk?
> 
> Hmmm, I think the party promoters may have put an unwitting farmer 
> at legal risk too. My understanding is that he's liable for injury that 
> occurs on his property, so if any of those ravers swimming in the pond 
> had drowned (thank god no one did), I think the owner could have been held 
> liable, or at least brought to extreme legal grief by someone who thought 
> he *should* be held liable, despite his level of knowledge about the event.  
> Now before the flames begin, I don't claim to be a lawyer, so I'll happily 
> stand corrected on this point. 
> 
> Kathryn

No, I believe you are absolutely correct on this one. And for those that say,
"Oh I would never sue if I got injured," you might not, but your families 
might. This has happened... more than once....


                                                Black Adder

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)

To: brianvan@liberty.liberty.com
Subject: Re: Personal: Sorry
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Lee, I assure you that hurt wasn't in
> my heart when I wrote what I wrote, I'm just not wired that way, 

Brian, I never think of you as someone who would intentionally hurt 
anything.  If a fly landed on you, I bet you'd offer it a free massage. 
So no apology is necessary.  Anyway, I don't tend to take these things too
personally.  Besides, it's fun to get flamed once in a while.  Now if
only I can get Niels to flame me, then I'd really feel special. ;)

Raving inspires idealism in many of us, and sometimes I think we can make
mistakes by trying too hard to perpetuate our personal vision of how we
want things to be.  I've been as guilty of this as anyone.  When we start 
stepping on people toes in order to push agendas of peace/unity/freedom/etc, 
that's when I feel a fresh perspective can be helpful.

I've met Claire a couple of times, and I think her heart is in the right
place.  I have contributed to her efforts in the past, and I plan to
continue supporting the Gateway Systems folks in the future.

Lee

i'm new to all this, but it seems to me that over time, scenes
change, the people in the scene change, the people spinning 
change, the political environment changes.  in sum : everything
changes !  as the media humps any new thing into the ground,
it seems like the rave scene is still somewhat untouched.
look at how fast Seattle came and went.  there are probably
a lot of people up there asking 'what went wrong'.  i'm
surprised at posts like this, as the whole rave experience
for me has been incredibly enlightening and fulfilling.

doug

Subject: Re: The Reason For Happy House Crap
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I think my Portland colleague Derek might be a *leetle* bit confused about
what "house music" is.  I was briefly under the same misconception when
I started getting into this scene in 1991.  At that point, house to me
seemed to be cheesy vocal-oriented discoey club-oriented slush.  There
was a lot of that then, just as there is now.  But that's like saying
that all jazz is just like bad lounge jazz with cheesy vocalists, and
ignoring the whole history of jazz from Jelly Roll Morton to Branford
Marsalis, with side trips for Ellington, Basie, Beiderbecke, Bird,
Byrd (Charlie that is), MJQ, Goodman, Miles, Hancock, Haden, Blakey,
Shorter and so many more who innovated, shaped and matured the many-
faceted sides of jazz music.  

House music can be cheesy, sure.  So can techno (or jazz, for that matter,
or rock, or classical, or any music made to avoid challenge instead of
putting it on the line).  But never let it be said that *techno*
(especially the fast, hard Euro-techno that has dominated the discussions
of techno since 1990) was the origin of raves.  Of all the different
styles -- and again ignoring for the moment the futility of applying
simple words to encompass music having so many more degrees of freedom --
acid house holds the claim to being the foundation of what we call
"raves," although certainly they developed directly out of the house/garage/
club/party/all/night/long movement of the mid-1980s, which is itself 
directly descended from the true disco scene (as opposed to the commercial
one epitomized by Saturday Nite Fever and all-o-dat).  

Some localities missed out on the acid house phase of raving, but the
"party style" of DJs, lights and all-night events continued with the faster
techno styles so many people came into this with.  And that's just fine.

But now consider: let's say somebody disses the music you really love,
whether it's jazz, house, techno, bluegrass, gamelan, Bach-Beethoven-Brahms,
Finnish reindeer herder songs, whatever.  Doesn't that usually mean that
they've just been exposed to the "cheese" in that genre, rather than the
good stuff?  I mean, you *know* it's good because you *have* heard the
good stuff, that's why you like it.  My own feeling is that it's our
duty to *spread* the good stuff to our friends who haven't heard it yet.
Even the styles of music I like the least, like Nashville "country",
turn out to have quite worthwhile practitioners when I've dug into them
enough.  

There is no need to bash someone else's preferences in order to build up
confidence in one's own preferred musical styles.  The real story of
music is that it's *software* -- you can't use it up!  "Listen all you
want, we'll make more!"  So if you don't like Word, use Word Perfect,
and neither of us should cut down the users of emacs just because it
looks like an undigestable mush to us.  There is a great beauty and
wisdom in emacs, if you put up with the superficial cheese long enough!!

phred

Subject: A Light Lesson!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Thank You to everyone who gave comments and opinions about the light party
on Saturday night.  In retrospect we've realized the mistakes in our vision.
We are learning through our experiences throwing events and part of learning
is taking responsibility.  Which we have every intent of doing.  To clear up
details of the event - no one was arrested.  The police were not angry but
co-operative and suggestive re: better locations to do these type of events.
The police did not arrest anyone however the owner did place a citizens
arrest which if he wants to prosecute will pay the court fees.  I 
do not believe he will pay the costs to prosecute 42 or more people. We will 
continue to have our celebrations however, we definately will keep them as legal
as events of this nature can be.  We expect that most people have common
sense and that if a party starts at 1am w/ a map point, your lights off and
are told
that it is important that the police not get involved that you consider your
personal situation and make a decision.  We realize many of you were not aware
until after the 2 hr drive (This is noted!) - our apologies.  We care about
what happened and the danger we created for someof the party goers - however
danger lerks in all forms - attention and awareness are your protectors! We
have taken full responsibility and can do no more than that.  We want to
communicate about these events - it can only improve them.  Lets be
respectful and considerate about how we choose express ourselves - more
people might listen and make change.  Thank You all again.  See you soon.
FEEL IT-LOVE!
                                     -Gateway Systems
