Ummmm...and for now there are lot of good reasons why you may want to
use one of the "big corporate nazi providers."  For instance, if you
travel alot, like I do, then you can dial-in to the local pop rather than
paying for the long distance charge to SF.  That definitely saves you
money.  Also, AOL, Compuserve, Prodigy, etc. provide value-added services
that you can't find or find easily on the Internet.

So, let's take care not to make broad generalizations and associate
legitimate companies with fascism.  I personally don't see AOL,
Compuserve, and the like as dictatorships promoting aggressive
nationalism, militarism, and racism.

Which leads me to one final point.  There has been a great deal of
anti-establishment (almost anarchistic) sentiment in some of the postings
over the last few days.  I am actually surprised at the naivete regarding
taxes equal a lease payment to the goverment (NOT!), who owns the land
(the people or the government), and (dis)respecting other people's
ownership rights, etc.  People are fabricating "arguments" to support
their views and in the process they are perverting reality.  This is
rubbish and more than a little paranoid.  C'mon lets apply some
sensability *and* do the necessary homework before posting stuff.

Flame suit on.

Bradley

On Tue, 11 Jul 1995, Bradley Graham wrote:

> 
> Ummmm...and for now there are lot of good reasons why you may want to
> use one of the "big corporate nazi providers."  For instance, if you
> travel alot, like I do, then you can dial-in to the local pop rather than
> paying for the long distance charge to SF.  That definitely saves you
> money.  Also, AOL, Compuserve, Prodigy, etc. provide value-added services
> that you can't find or find easily on the Internet.
>

> legitimate companies with fascism.  I personally don't see AOL,
> Compuserve, and the like as dictatorships promoting aggressive
> nationalism, militarism, and racism.

software with Win 95.

>Dear All;
>
>        I've noticed a sudden influx of America Onliners(aol.com); it
>would be truely wrong of me not to tell you people that you are getting
>throughly ripped off. Netcom, Liberty, & Well(I personally don't like
>them); as well as some of the other smaller providers will give you higher
>connect rates, UNIX shells, Virtual & Dedicated ppp & slip, multiple
>accounts for a lot less than your paying those big corporate nazi
>providers. You will actually get to know your sysop, Dave at liberty is
>great and will bend over backwards for you. Liberty also offers a great
>deal; for every person you bring in, its something like $3.00 off your
>monthly charge of $25.00; which gets you a real LINUX shell, a virtuall
>slip connection, 4 hours a day of Internet & BBS access, a Galacticomm
>Front End, no setup charges, 2 accounts; (one bbs internet address & a
>LINUX address); if you get enough people to sign up, you canactually get
>paid to be on there system with no upper limit, Liberty uses it's
>subscribers as it's sales force. Do whatever you like; I personally I'm
>not into selling people anything, well maybe selling them on the idea to
>respect & love one another, buts that's it. See ya; in computers & the net
>smaller is better.


Alot of people go to aol because they don't give a shit about unix shells,
slipp and ppp, and or/ the hassel.  Personally, I prefer a little bit of
everything- but think of the majority of AOL subscribers as non-tech
people.  We're talking about the mainstream consumer market here... The
same people who watch 'the price is right' religiously, QVC, etc.etc.
These people don't want to be bothered with trumpet winsock, and endless
config problems.. And hell- you can't even get support if COnfig PPP
doesn't work!  They want the easy way to the super highway...

My AOL account is free, and I don't think I would of ever checked them out.
But, The company I work for just happens to be one of their partners.
This doesn't make me an AOL fan, but I know more about their service and
how it works.  It's not all that bad- considering the internet access and
the user-friendliness..

personally- I like unix and eudora for mail..

-Jon

Oh.. and about the NAZI comment.  I don't think thats the case since we
("the Gateway to Afrocentric Culture") get full support from everyone at
AOL..

At 04:06 PM 7/11/95 -0700, Black Adder spoke thusly:
>
>
>On Tue, 11 Jul 1995, Bradley Graham wrote:
>
>> 
>> So, let's take care not to make broad generalizations and associate
>> legitimate companies with fascism.  I personally don't see AOL,
>> Compuserve, and the like as dictatorships promoting aggressive
>> nationalism, militarism, and racism.
>> 
>
>Take a look at their business practices. Right now the only thing keeping 
>all the bigger services from focusing on their asperations of "owning" the
>Internet is their greater fear of Bill Gates bundling Microsoft Network 
>software with Win 95.
>
>                                                 Black Adder

        I would have to agree here. Although you may or may not like what
you get for the money, a lot of these larger services aren't exactly the
greatest people to do business with because of the way the companies are
run.  For instance, last summer I actually used one of those ubiquitous
10-hours-free AOL disks.  Sure, I got my ten hours free.  I used them, then
never touched it again.  However, I was never informed that by using those
hours I was becoming an AOL customer, therefore requiring me to call and
cancel my service.  They claimed that this was in the initial login screen,
but I looked thoroughly for anything like that (aware that they were
probably trying to take my money) and didn't see anything.  Not only that,
but after I called to cancel my membership they still billed me for another
two months and I had to call again to have them remove the charges.  I've
heard that Prodigy is even worse about cancelling membership, though I have
no firsthand experience.
        I guess the bottom line is that regardless of the services they
provide, they aren't the best businessmen in the world.  If you don't dial
up from multiple locations or use some of their commercial services, you're
better off with a smaller company.  If you do, keep in mind that big
corporations are hardly sympathetic to your personal needs.  

                                                        Jake

think of the house you live in, and the music you listen to..

theres:

Garage          the garage
Ambient         the roof (and maybe you bedroom)
Jungle          the stairs (running up and down)
Techno          the basement
House           the frame of the house
Trance          hallway (a really long one)
Dub             the bathroom
Disco           your mom and dads trunk in the attic
Grunge          the toilet
New Age         the living room


just a little thought..


-jOn

Warning: This post contains NO information about DJs, music, Brian's
.signature, or any other sfraves hot topic.

> Which leads me to one final point.  There has been a great deal of
> anti-establishment (almost anarchistic) sentiment in some of the postings
> over the last few days.

And...?

> I am actually surprised at the naivete regarding
> taxes equal a lease payment to the goverment (NOT!),

Let's see.  If I don't pay my property taxes, the government kicks me
out and "sells" the land to someone else, or maybe just keeps it for
itself.  All "landowners" have a landlord -- the US government.

What, then, are property taxes, if not rent?

> who owns the land (the people or the government), 

Right now the government does, because it can take your land for many
reasons.  Maybe there's a pot plant growing on it.  Maybe they really
want to build a road through there, or expand a military base.  Maybe
it's now a wetland so your house is illegal.  

I believe in private property, but I do not believe in land ownership.
You cannot own land any more than you can own the wind.  Look around
(at someplace not defaced by concrete, please).  Walk up to a tree and
tell it, in all seriousness, "I _own_ this tree.  You are now mine, and
must do as I say."  Tell the grass not to go to seed.  Tell the birds
to shut up because they're disturbing your late sleeping habits.  Tell
the bear not to fish in your stream and take your Power Bars.

Poot.

Land is not just a square of dirt and rock: land is a complex web of 
growth, death, and rebirth of thousands and thousands of different kinds
of plant, animal, mineral, gas, and whatever else.  We are part of this
web.  Our actions change it, and its actions change us.  If you hack down
an acre of rainforest to graze cattle for Jack In The Box, it erodes into
the stream or depletes itself of nutrients in 2-3 years (average arability
for clear-cuts of tropical rainforest).  If you spew enough pollution into
the air from cars, it gets hard to breathe and you die of cancer.  If the
Sahara spreads in Africa, climate can change in China or Britain.

If we persist in thinking that we can own land, that we can use it up and
discard it like a worn-out sock, we will choke to death in our own shit.
You can't throw anything "away" -- there _is_ no "away".  You can pay 
someone else to take the consequences for a while, but the earth is not
infinite.  Gods, we can't even go OUTSIDE without getting skin cancer!
Where's my right to walk in the sunlight without contracting a fatal
disease?  Where's my right to drink water from the stream without falling
sick or being poisoned?  Where's my right to breathe air that won't kill
me just as fast as cigarettes?

I know where it went.  People (Kodak, Monsanto, ConAgra, GM, me, you, etc.)
thought they "owned" land, and could use it up without anything bad happening.
Well, the Industrial Revolution dropped a big brick into the web, and we're
just starting to feel the bounce-back.

Why is it that we have to work so hard and go so far just to find a place to
dance outdoors?  This alone should say something.

To use a baseball metaphor, which people seem to understand ("three strikes"):
The Earth bats last.

> and (dis)respecting other people's
> ownership rights, etc.

What is that "right", in this case?  Someone gave someone else a bunch of
little green pieces of paper, and signed something at the county clerk,
and gives more pieces of paper to the government every so often in exchange 
for them agreeing to chase off
anyone else?  Why is this series of rituals more compelling than dancing
all night, which does a lot more people good?

Whose magic do you believe?  The magic of mortgage, lien, and enclosure,
or the magic of dance, moonlight, and agape?  Choose wisely.

> People are fabricating "arguments" to support
> their views and in the process they are perverting reality.  

So what is your reality, sir?  You are implying a lot more than
you are saying.

> This is
> rubbish and more than a little paranoid.  C'mon lets apply some
> sensability *and* do the necessary homework before posting stuff.

Please enlighten me.  Tell us how things _really_ are.  America,
SHOW US YOUR UNDERALLS!

// g

parties will be.  I'm not into the sneak-into-abandoned-warehouses

hardcore techno playing in L.A. clubs that week.

Last year (in Orlando) there was a very fun SGI/Alias/Apple party at
Typhoon Lagoon where D'Cuckoo played (followed by a DJ playing house
& modern pop), a pathetic disaster of a party put on by ILM at some
club, and a GREAT come-unity-esque party put on by the "ACM local
SIGGRAPH chapters" at another local club.  Some people named Bruce &
Karmi also threw a raging event one night, renting out the entire
Disney/MGM-studios theme park from midnight-5am and using it for a
huge park-wide festival party.  Wow.

So if this year lives up to what happened last year..

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 12 07:08:01 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id HAA16447; Wed, 12 Jul 1995 07:08:01 -0700
Received: from planecrash.Berkeley.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id HAA16421; Wed, 12 Jul 1995 07:07:41 -0700

	The following is the article on ravers in England and their 
experience with the heavy hand of the law I promised to post.  It is a 
photocopy that was given to me -- if anyone recognizes it and happens to 
know the original publication it came from (what the "NSS" referred to 
twice in the article stands for), I'd be interested in learning.  
	This isn't the first or only piece I've seen on this subject.  
There was a fascinating story in I believe it was URB magazine about a 
major bust of a party in (Milwaukee, Minnesota?) that was a classic case 
of government repression in action.  But I see the experience of the 
Exodus collective as just as important, even though it happened elsewehere.  
Read on...


(header of article starts here)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Exodus dance collective holds peaceful parties and wants to cooperate
with the police.  Yet thousands of youngsters will soon be criminalised,
reports *Tim Malyon*

(body of article starts here)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
			RAVING INJUSTICE

	The Woodside industrial estate, near Dunstable, is dead at night, 
warehouses silent, no houses nearby.  But around midnight every Saturday 
it's the place to be for Bedfordshire youth.  Last week, there were 
2,000-3,000 people waiting patiently, cars nose to tail on both sides of 
the road and filling the car parks.  It's loud but orderly, the whole 
show marshalled by Bigs and his merry band of lieutenants.  "Ye kaan park 
there, that's dangerous, man, pull over, you wanna cause some kin'e of 
accident?"  Bigs is a "dread".  You don't disobey him, but his heart is gold.
	Bigs' "real" name is Paul Taylor.  He's from Exodus, the Luton 
dance and squatting collective.  Exodus' community farm was raided in 
January 1993 and all its equipment seized.  Police claim to have found 
Ecstasy tabs valued at (British Pounds)2,200.  Bigs was found not guilty 
earlier this year of possession with intent to supply.
	Supporters claim that police planted the drugs as part of a 
series of police operations (see NSS, 24 June) costing over (British 
Pounds)100,000, which, if successful, would have stopped the dances and 
destroyed the collective.  A senior serving police officer, chief 
inspector Mike Brown, who was negotiating with Exodus for licensed 
venues, has said there was political pressure to "get on the case."  He 
was given an hour's notice of the change of policy from negotiation to 
confrontation, "jaw jaw" being turned into "war war", as he put it.
	Exodus survived, not least because 4,000 supporters surrounded 
Luton police station after the raid on the farm, demanding the release of 
those arrested and the return of their equipment.  Now Exodus is back, 
busy putting on what it calls "demonstrations of the need for parties."  
There has been a dearth of parties and festivals this year, especially of 
the free variety.  Most police forces have been keeping a strict eye out 
for anything but the smallest and best-hidden "dos", seizing PA equipment 
and turning back punters as though the Criminal Justice and Public Order 
Bill, which will outlaw such events, was in force already.
	Around 12:45am, the Blue Star taxi firm brings the word to 
Woodside.  Lee is driving.  He's a dead ringer for George Micheal and has 
been helping Exodus stay mobile free of charge since the parties began.  
People wander back to their cars, engines fire up, and we're off, headed 
by the Exodus Land-Rover, green with a bright red star on the bonnet.  
>From the back of the Land-Rover, at a steady 30 miles an hour, it's an 
extraordinary sight, headlights stretching endlessly into the distance.  
Police sources reckoned the convoy to be more than 300 cars long.  
Someone said to me at the 24 July anti-Criminal Justice Bill 
demonstration: "You can't oppose oppression by dancing."  Yet there's the 
reply, lined out behind the jeep.  Dance mobilises youth in huge 
numbers.  As Billy Bragg put it, "Dance gives people a sense of 
community, a sense of togetherness that's lacking in our society."
	The Land-Rover indicates left, pulls up by the entrance to a 
narrow track, and Bigs jumps down, starting to wave people in almost 
before his feet touch the ground.  The car behind has been briefed where 
to lead the convoy so no roads are blocked, and the track is kept open in 
case of any emergencies.  A smartly dressed, white-haired man turns in.  
Bigs asks him if he's going to the dance.  He shakes his head, evidently 
confused as to how he ended up in a traffic jam at one o'clock in the 
morning.  Bigs makes space for him to get back out again.
	Up in the lane, the outline of a circular sandpit gradually 
emerges from the darkness, 500 metres across, surrounded by trees, cars 
parked on the far side, people settling into the dance on the near side.  
Glenn Jenkins is on the mike, Exodus spokesperson rapping to the tribal 
beat: "Public order section five/Government ready to take a dive/All 
tribes out there comin' alive."  There are at least 3,000 people out 
here, at the third party since Exodus restarted.  And that's without 
advertising, just a message a few days before on one phone line -- the 
bush telegraph.
	
	What is happening here in Bedfordshire focuses the spotlight on 
the massive problems of the Criminal Justice Bill.  "Thousands of 
Bedfordshire's young people are regularly doing something now that in 
three months time will make them criminals," explains Jenkins.  "We want 
discussions held with the police and the council to show that imposition 
of this bill by force to stop the parties would be madness.  What we're 
proposing is sanctioned gatherings, places where free parties and 
festivals can be held in accord with the authorities.  This is a real 
opportunity for an accord, rather than imprisoning and criminalising 
people.  We want Bedfordshire to be an anti-Criminal Justice Bill zone."  
Exodus is also waiting for planning permission on a large warehouse owned 
by P & O where it plans to establish a community centre and hold 
fortnightly licensed dances in winter.  This would help build up 
equipment for the free outdoor parties, more stalls, a fire engine.  
Exodus is more aware of safety considerations than most commercial 
outfits I've seen.
	The Bedfordshire police have already tried *de facto* to 
implement the Criminal Justice Bill through their previous operations 
against Exodus, blocking roads, trying to seize equipment and ban parties 
before they've begun.  They stopped the parties for a while, but not the 
demand.  And their actions are now being severely criticised.  Exodus' 
local Labour county councilor John Jefferson put a motion for "a full 
public inquiry into the Bedfordshire police's activities against members 
of the Exodus collective" to the Bedfordshire Police Committee.  Despite 
Labour and Liberal Democrat support, the committee's magistrate members 
voted with the Tories to defeat it.  Jefferson is now taking his motion 
to a full county council meeting.
	Exodus is insistent on an inquiry.  "The police have got to be 
made answerable so what they've done doesn't happen again," says 
Jenkins.  He is suspicious of recent police appointments, moving 
hard-line officers into positions previously occupied by officers keen to 
negotiate solutions.  An attempt by NSS to obtain an interview with 
Bedfordshire Chief Constable Alan Dyer was at first agreed and then 
refused.  When we asked Dyer about current policy towards Exodus parties, 
he pleaded ignorance to the fact that they were even happening.
	Meanwhile, at the entrance to the dance, Bigs is giving two local 
police "some lyrics" for trying to drive in without asking.  They are 
invited to come in on foot, on their own or accompanied, "for a cup of 
tea," but they refuse.  As they drive off, a barrel-chested figure on a 
bicycle swoops out of the darkness, says he's local and has heard "faint 
music".  He disappears up the track to see what is happening, to 
re-emerge about an hour later.  His name is David Taylor, an 
ex-policeman, now a fish merchant.  He stays chatting for over an hour 
and leaves his phone number.  He has a policeman's eye for detail.
	"I didn't feel at any time intimidated or frightened," he tells 
me.  "It was very orderly -- they even had a post with a red cross on 
it.  There was no menace, no idiots running about causing aggravation.  
And I didn't see any dealing.  There were some very young girls wandering 
around, but I think they were quite safe.  I got the feeling that the 
people at the gate could deal with any situation that arose.  They were 
running it very professionally.  Although I found the music crap."
	Returning home the next day, he asked around fellow villagers, 
whom police say reported noise complaints.  Two local newspapers reported 
"a flood of calls" and "a storm of protest" from local residents.  The 
district council has received six complaints.  Area environmental health 
officer Janet Wallace, who was called out by the police, says "there was 
a noise nuisance", that in some 70 houses was "unacceptably loud, like 
listening to your neighbour's barbecue".  She says the site was left 
"scrupulously clean" and that there was no further disturbance to the area.

	David Taylor's experience bicycling round the area that night was 
somewhat different.  "The people in the village had no idea it was going 
on.  It was just something faint coming from somewhere, nobody knew 
where.  We live eight miles from Woburn, where people like Tina Turner 
and Neil Diamond play.  You can hear those.  If you'd said to anybody, me 
included, before it happened, that there was going to be 3,000-4,0000 
people coming to your village tonight for a big party, you'd immediately 
think, I'm going to get my car broken into, my house burgled, there's 
going to be spaced out junkies everywhere.  It's fear of the unknown."
	I asked Taylor about the anti-rave provisions of the Criminal 
Justice Bill.  "If I want to have 200 people turn up on my land and do 
whatever, I should be allowed to do it.  You should be allowed to do 
anything you want that really can't be construed as detrimental to 
people's well-being in the near vicinity."  Taylor's final comment is 
disturbing given his first-hand knowledge of the police:  "Before long, 
everybody will get nicked.  I can just see it, busloads of police, wading 
in, crash helmets, big night sticks, a few dogs.  Because at the moment, 
Exodus is one up on the police -- not so much one up, but I think the 
police would think that."
	DJ Hazard is playing in the sandpit, tribal beats shaking bodies 
and minds.  Bigs has finished his marshalling duties at the gate and is 
quoting lyrics from Lynton Kwesi Johnson.  It starts to rain.  Tarpaulins 
are swiftly hung over the decks and PA.
	*"Even though they think they're bold/We know they're cold like 
ice with fear..."*
	The air feels fresh, the haze of dry red sand stirred up by 
stamping feet washed away.  Suddenly there's a flash and a great clap of 
thunder.  The crowd goes bananas.  "...And we are F-I-R-E."
	"When we say 'they' we're talking government," explains Jenkins, 
a former train driver and Aslef shop steward.  This transformation from 
union organiser to Exodus spokesperson gives him a unique insight into 
both old and new politics.  "We know they're worried, even though they 
give an impression of confidence.  The fire is the power of resistance of 
sound systems allied to community groups like us.  We're going to melt 
their Criminal Injustice law."
	Exodus is proposing a "blueprint for civic peace" in 
Bedfordshire, a Criminal Justice Bill-free zone.  Jenkins elaborates.  
"By the time the Criminal Justice Bill comes into force, we hope to have 
been involved in negotiations not just with our local police force, but 
with Liberty, local councilors and MPs.  We want to have a big 
round-table discussion on this issue.  The government's proposals for 
making us criminals and forcing the police into confrontation again can't 
be in anyone's best interests.  To do anything else when young people 
could be criminalised and have their heads cracked is criminal."
	Jenkins' argument is especially strong given the recommendations 
of the government's Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs.  In a 
suppressed report recently leaked to Duncan Campbell of the *Guardian*, 
the council said:  "We believe there are dangers in over-regulation and 
in resorting to the criminal law, which may well lead to conflict 
between young people and the authorities.  We recommend that the 
organisation of more legal raves be encouraged by local authorities 
exercising maximum discretion in the granting of licenses and by 
involving responsible organisers of raves in the process."
	I bumped into Eggy by the gate at dawn, 18 years old and wearing 
a legalise cannabis T-shirt.  A year ago he came to live at the derelict 
old people's home that Exodus had squatted.  They have a council license 
to occupy it now, as they do for the community farm.  Thirty people live 
there, with money from the dances being used to pay for repairs.  Eggy 
used to be in the army cadets.  He's called Eggy because that's how his 
shaved skull used to look.  I've heard what he says repeated in hundreds 
of different ways by hundreds of different people up and down the 
country.  Most politicians haven't heard it.  Most newspaper editors 
haven't heard it.  But among the coalition of groups protesting against 
the Criminal Justice Bill, the road protesters, travellers, squatters and 
ravers, the word is spreading swiftly.  "If they put through this 
Criminal Justice Bill thing, then everyone will rebel.  I'm going to 
watch it, see our freedom come.  In this way, the Criminal Justice Bill 
is positive, it's beautiful."  Standing in the half light, I ask Eggy 
what this is all for, the parties, Exodus, the struggles.  "We're doing 
it to save the youth, to save the people," he insists.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(end reprinted article)

	Although this may be a couple years old at my best guess, and I'm not 
sure how things have gone across the Atlantic since it was written, I do 
think it offers us some valuable lessons/reminders to draw on:

	(1) It is possible to stand up for your rights and be successful.
	(2) There is strength in numbers, and we have the numbers on our 
	    side, if we make use of them.	
	(3) Ravers will be more effective at preserving our right to 
	    party if we make common cause with others who have grievances 
	    with the government and work on coalition-building.
	(4) They will try to outlaw peaceful outdoors dancing, given the 
	    opportunity.

	A final note -- it may sound to some of you like I'm saying the 
government is our enemy.  I am.  :)  However, the individual people who 
make up the government are not.  I believe we should make every effort to 
extend to them the same love, respect, and compassion we would show other 
ravers.  They are human too, and I feel if they understand us better and 
do not see us as a threat, they would be more likely to respect our 
rights.  Fight the power, not the people.  Love on!
	
	One more time for liberty,

				*** Starchild ***

        Reply to:   RE>>Moon Light
Actually, I'd be suprised if anyone actually reads this by now, but...

Tell me again why we can't just ask the landowner's permission or even 
pay a rent? I mean, I have a lot of sympathy for the idea that only the 
earth owns the land, but I'd be pissed too if I came home to find someone  
throwing a party in my apartment (and I wasn't invited).

While I was living in New Mexico, I went to a number of outdoor events 
that were held on rented land. At least one of the landowners concerned 
was unrelated by family or friendship, just a guy who the organizers 
approached, who thought it sounded harmless enough, and gave them a key 
to the gate. It may give you a warm feeling to cut a deal with the cops 
when you're legally grey, but it's also fun to smile and wave at the police 
chopper spotlighting you while you're partying on private land with the 
owner's permission.

Maybe I'm ignorant of the local laws or the character of the local 
landowners, but wouldn't it be nice to smile before, during, and after the 
event (and maybe even get the cops to smile too!).

-nate

Dear Starchild,

I'm from San Diego area and the way I've been collecting the flyers is by going
to places that carry them.  I also have some friends in the LA area that collect
them for me.  I've already tried leaving my name and address on their voice mail
but they have never sent me any. 

I'm trying to cover my bedroom walls with rave flyers. So far I think I have
about 500 of them.  I'm willing to swap flyers with you.  Next time I  see some
I'll make sure I get one for you too.

*HUGS*

-Keihan

Any of you sfravers that are coming down to LA for SIGGRAPH can check 
out the socal-raves callendar at:  

http://infopages.com:80/socal-raves/Calendar/ 

(which is about a week behind at the moment)

or subscribe to the list by sending mail to socal-raves-request@ucsd.edu

with one of the following in the body of the message:

subscribe socal-raves

	or

subscribe socal-raves-callendar

There is going to be a Moontribe full moon gathering that week which I
*highly* recommend to anyone that can go.  Pics from previous FMGs can 
be found at: http://www.usc.edu/users/rslau/full_moon.html and 
http://mxm.com/FMG/Index.html

See you at SIGGRAPH!


Andy

and easy access to their e-mail is no reason to equate them with National
Enquirer readers, and those avid watchers of the Price is Right.  Talk about

because of the way they access e-mail!  I use Eudora and other such things,
but I find this is quick and easy, without any hassle, it doesn't diminish my
computer skills, but when you're working, and a student, you don't always

In a message dated 95-07-12 12:28:36 EDT, you write:

>>>>>*my* techno faze
>
>See thats the difference right there jsl.!
>It was just a faze for you...I know for me I grew up on it its part of my
>soul.its not something thats here today gone tommorrow... ......its the
>future.
>
>

Tell it sistah! House music is based on itself. Techno is based on an
approach to sound. So many people associate it with the four on the floor,
92-93 pop-techno a la Charly or Anasthasia that burnt them out through
imitation (the House mode of progress). Heck, I hate that shit too. But
techno, in its purest sense, is the music that tries not to repeat the past,
continually bringing up new sounds and rhythms. Techno is the music that gets
copied.

.eh

np: v/a-MINUTES TO GO! Hommage a William S. Burroughs

> Land is not just a square of dirt and rock: land is a complex web of 
> growth, death, and rebirth of thousands and thousands of different kinds
> of plant, animal, mineral, gas, and whatever else.  We are part of this
> web.  Our actions change it, and its actions change us.  If you hack down
> an acre of rainforest to graze cattle for Jack In The Box, it erodes into
> the stream or depletes itself of nutrients in 2-3 years (average arability
> for clear-cuts of tropical rainforest).  If you spew enough pollution into
> the air from cars, it gets hard to breathe and you die of cancer.  If the
> Sahara spreads in Africa, climate can change in China or Britain.

...or if a comet hits the planet it spews enough dust up into the atmosphere
to kill the life that fails to adapt.

> If we persist in thinking that we can own land, that we can use it up and
> discard it like a worn-out sock, we will choke to death in our own shit.

Nah, that's just our inability to evolve (which includes the failure to use
our big brains and bigger tools to find a way to survive in a modified climate)

Ownership is a moot point.  There is no such thing as a planetary norm, it's
been changing ever since the cosmic dust started clumping together due to
gravity.  Feel free to cut down all the trees... just realize that you may have
to live in a dome or splice your genes so that you can photosynthesize.

> You can't throw anything "away" -- there _is_ no "away".  You can pay 
> someone else to take the consequences for a while, but the earth is not
> infinite.  Gods, we can't even go OUTSIDE without getting skin cancer!
> Where's my right to walk in the sunlight without contracting a fatal
> disease?  Where's my right to drink water from the stream without falling
> sick or being poisoned?  Where's my right to breathe air that won't kill
> me just as fast as cigarettes?

Rights are a moot point.  You're a monkey, and you've got to learn to make the
best of your situation.  Some of us feel that working together and with
feelings of PLUR make the world a better place to live in.  Others feel
differently.  This will always be so.  Deal with it.

	Wonko the Sane

Precedence: bulk


> > If we persist in thinking that we can own land, that we can use it up and
> > discard it like a worn-out sock, we will choke to death in our own shit.
> 
> Nah, that's just our inability to evolve (which includes the failure to use
> our big brains and bigger tools to find a way to survive in a modified climate)

I don't see any effort being put forth to find a solution to this problem; all
I see is short term greed ($) outweighing long term greed (survival of yourself
and your descendents).

Our biology is incredibly complex -- we still don't know all the chemicals we
need to ingest daily in order to function correctly over a lifetime.  I think
it presumptuous to assume that we can reduce the earth's biodiversity by 90%
or more (as we are doing) and not take out something vital to us.

Besides, is it necessary to burn down your house to prove you've grown up
and can leave it?

> Ownership is a moot point.  There is no such thing as a planetary norm, it's
> been changing ever since the cosmic dust started clumping together due to
> gravity.  Feel free to cut down all the trees... just realize that you may have
> to live in a dome or splice your genes so that you can photosynthesize.

We agree here.  I see a bunch of people complaining that ecological sustain-
ability will require major changes in their lives, not realizing that their
current life of blind consumption will require even more drastic change for
survival.

>Rights are a moot point.  You're a monkey, and you've got to learn to make the
> best of your situation.

Yes.  So maybe part of that is raising my little electronic hand and saying,
"Hey, let's think about this, and maybe do something about it."  I have no
interest in becoming a replacement government or other coercive institution.
So what else is there?  Communication.

> Some of us feel that working together and with
> feelings of PLUR make the world a better place to live in.  Others feel
> differently.  This will always be so.  Deal with it.

Were you born into "the scene"?  Neither was I.  I found out about it 
through communication; people talking (and typing) about their beliefs.
"This will always be so, deal with it" sounds suspiciously like a sales
pitch for fatalism.  I _know_ other people will believe differently, I 
didn't just fall off the turnip truck -- but at least it's there for
people to read instead of me just sitting in my room thinking "Damn, 
everything's so fucked up." which does no one any good, including me.

// g

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 12 18:30:54 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA01879; Wed, 12 Jul 1995 18:30:54 -0700
Received: from mtshasta.snowcrest.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA01871; Wed, 12 Jul 1995 18:30:47 -0700
Received: from macshasta.com (macshast@localhost) by mtshasta.snowcrest.net (8.6.5/8.6.5) with UUCP id SAA08500 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 12 Jul 1995 18:23:37 -0700
From: ken_stuart@macshasta.com (ken stuart)
Reply-To: ken_stuart@macshasta.com
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: New CDs recommended
Date: 12 Jul 1995 16:27:10 GMT
Message-Id: <2515975999.5379061@macshasta.com>
Organization: MacShasta Consulting
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello,

Here are 3 recent CDs that I've enjoyed (all are US domestic releases and all
contain a mix of dance and ambient tracks) :

- Transmission from the Planet Dog

This is 2 CDs for *less* than the usual price of 1 , a compilation of 4
Planet Dog artists - Eat Static, Banco de Gaia, Timeshard and Children of the
Bong.

- G Spot   by   Speedy J

The best yet by Speedy J.  The ambient tracks are roughly similar to Global
Communication, and his dance tracks (techno) are excellent, much improved.

- The Trip-Hop Test (Part One)

Some of the tracks seem to be what I would consider Trip-Hop (ie Hip-Hop with
Techno/House sensibilities, ie Trippier), but some of this is also ambient,
and other tracks are yet their own style of techno.  Almost all of it is
excellent music, in any event...

Enjoy,

Ken
ken@macshasta.com

	Recently, with the assistance of a sysadmin pal of mine, I put
together a filter file for my mail -- in part prompted by what some people
have been complaining about.  It's not too complicated (if *I* can figure it 
out :-).  Rather than post the instructions here, I'd be happy to mail you 
a note explaining the details.  Take a look at the man pages for <filter> as
a good place to start.

>>soul.its not something thats here today gone tommorrow... ......its the
>>future.
>>
>>
>
>Tell it sistah! House music is based on itself. Techno is based on an
>approach to sound. So many people associate it with the four on the floor,
>92-93 pop-techno a la Charly or Anasthasia that burnt them out through
>imitation (the House mode of progress). Heck, I hate that shit too. But
>techno, in its purest sense, is the music that tries not to repeat the past,
>continually bringing up new sounds and rhythms. Techno is the music that gets
>copied.
>
>.eh
>
>np: v/a-MINUTES TO GO! Hommage a William S. Burroughs


Basically I move around in my musical tastes. It was just a phase for me,
it may mean more to others.  That does not make my experience any less
valid than anyone elses.  Nor does it make my experience any more valid
than anyone elses.  All I said was do something about it.  You can analyze
the hell out of something with little to show for such an intellectual
effort (i.e. mental masturbation).  If you like techno fine.  I no longer
get into it like i used to.  I don't like fast music either, but that's my
taste.  I respect everyones taste.  Maybe some understanding instead of
preaching to the choir is necessary.


To each his own...I thought this was a dead horse by now, but once again I
am worng.  Obviously there are not enough soap factories around these days
;).

I'm out,
John

P.S.  All that really matters is that you catch your own groove and create
a good vibe.  To me it's near 120-124.  *YOUR* mileage may vary...

                "Prejudice is the reason of fools." - Voltaire
              jsl@netcom.com - public key available upon request

In-Reply-To: <199507111003.DAA23004@nexsys.nexsys.net>

On Tue, 11 Jul 1995, Geoff White wrote:

>   SF people like to dance and this is
> why there is so much VIBE.  It is really hard to exhibit any type of graceful
> moves at 160 BPM, I suppose you could jump around but for many of us, it's not
> trance inducing (maybe we're just getting too old :). It takes several hours
> of dancing and music before large numbers of people can easily enter the trance
> state the we refer to as the VIBE, 

	I tend to disagree both with the statement that nothing 
"graceful" (that which produces vibe?) is going to come out of 160 bpm, 
and with this stuff about it taking several hours before the "vibe" comes 
out. Try starting with something slow but stomping (yes, stomping you 
see, a good kick drum is very important) and pick the pace up. I have 
seen the bpms go from hmm, 130ish to 190 in 90 minutes and people go 
through the roof. And who says there cannot be "soul" or feeling in fast, 
stompy beats... Jungle is fast and stomping and full of emotion (well, 
the good stuff is). Like any music, if it is done well, there will be 
more there than insane sounds (but those can be amazing as well)... If 
stompy won't do it for you, look at the hard trance that the Low Spirit 
djs spun, that had feeling, was fast, and harder, and very nice in me 
little opinion.

>  if you start off at 140 and go up from there
> most people won't be able to keep up for the 3 or 4 hours needed to break 
> down there ego enough to enter trance.

	3 to 4 hours to break down the ego?! Some of the most amazing 
times I have had, have been in the basements under this old city, a place 
called the Vaults, would get there around 10 to get in the queue, get in 
about 11 when it opened, and stay til it closed at 3 am. It didn't take 4 
to break down egos there, maybe the faster, stompier music had something 
to do with that. I don't mean to be negative, but everything seems to be 
looked at as good, even as the limits close in once again. I was spinning 
at a little party, some pretty fast stuff (~180 bpm) and this guy told me 
he hadn't heard stuff like that since 89 out here. `89?! I didn't know 
180 bpm techno was coming out then, much less that it was being played in 
SF (but in 89 I was no where to be seen, and wouldn't have like that 
repetitive shit if I had known about it then ;) )

dave

From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: Full Moon Rave outcome from last night?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I went down there to Santa Cruz last night to the Full Moon event.
The site was really, really, really beautiful.

It was a bit amusing that the speaker cables didn't show up (at least they
still hadn't by the time I was giving up and leaving at 4:30am!) but since
there was no music/dancing, I just spent more time exploring the area. I'd
like to go back there for some events in the future. It's definitely one of
those scenic places you see and tell yourself, *this* is the California
that I love!

A lot of the people there were freaking out thinking that I was a police
officer because my Chevron jacket evidently looks just like a police
jacket. I got a uniformly cold reception until (that is *if* in many cases)
they looked close enough or got up the nerve :) to talk to me that they
would see that I was there to party just like they were! I really like
wearing that jacket because it's so warm but the recurring downside is
being mistaken for an authority figure. :)

Any comments from anybody else that went?

-w

On Wed, 12 Jul 1995, 'Dave Bayer' wrote:

> 
> 	I tend to disagree both with the statement that nothing 
> "graceful" (that which produces vibe?) is going to come out of 160 bpm, 
> and with this stuff about it taking several hours before the "vibe" comes 
> out. Try starting with something slow but stomping (yes, stomping you 
> see, a good kick drum is very important) and pick the pace up. I have 
> seen the bpms go from hmm, 130ish to 190 in 90 minutes and people go 
> through the roof. And who says there cannot be "soul" or feeling in fast, 
> stompy beats... Jungle is fast and stomping and full of emotion (well, 

I completely agree... Just because something is fast doesn't mean it's not 
graceful, or that you cannot move gracefully to it. It's all a matter of 
easing yourself into the rhythm, and not feeling compelled to follow every 
single beat. I also find that a lot of the hard fast stuff, like the German 
hardtrance techno and goa is absolutely filled with "soul" and beauty, 
albeit soul and beauty of a very different interpretation than what is 
found in more housey oriented stuff. Personally, hardtrance moves me
physically, spiritually and intellectually the way no other type of
music does. I find it totally trance inducing.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 13 01:32:10 1995

Message-Id: <9507130831.AA10417@SIRIUS.COM>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 00:37:36 -0600
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: gabe@SIRIUS.COM (Gabe)
Subject:  labels and anger other thoughts
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey everyone,

i just was reading a lot of the things on this list and I was struck by a
couple of things. It seems that some people bring a lot of personal shit
and anger to this list. I think we all have a lot of stuff like that for
some it comes out here because they don't have to see someones face as they
read something posted as an assault on them. Thats a problem with this
medium, it can't communicate emotions very well; and some people need to
feel empathy with someone who will read their negative post that becomes an
attack. After all we ALL share some of the same feelings about raves. I'm
not even going to attempt to define them. They are common threads running
through everyones experience that are inherently positive. That is why we
put up with this list even, when it degenerates into name calling and
wounded egos. We can maybe put some balance back into this list by maybe
posting more about the great times everyone had. I'm not saying everything
has to be happy, I just think we could all use a couple more positive
posts.

Also it seems like their is a lot of derogatory labeling going on.  The
next time you find yourself thinking something along the lines of "Gee,
goddamn hippies(or anyother word that trys to classify groups of people),
they are so fucked up(or any other broad derogatory statement)" try and
think of as many characteristics of that group of people as you can.  For
Example,
Hippie-
Someone who loves the earth
Someone who gets high
Someone who loves to dance
Someone who thinks they can change the world
Someone who thinks that they have something to offer
Someone that thinks hugging(even kissing) people you don't know is a good thing
Someone who trips into new places
and anything anyone can say that  makes someone a true "hippie"

These are all things that I have seen or heard refering to hippies in a
negative way. I think we can always find a way to relate to most people by
looking for the common thread. We all know what it is like to be
classified, and stereotyped and put in a box. For me raving isn't about
putting people in boxes. Its lifting us up beyond the boundries that we
have between ourselves. Letting the love that people naturally have in them
come out in a frenzy of dancing, hugging, and talking and much more. But,
labeling people makes it hard for this to always manifest itself. Still i
find it more on this list than I do in the raves that I have gone to. Some
people have a hard time adjusting to communication when the music isn't
pumping and they aren't in an altered state. But I do see a lot of good
things going on which is why I still like this list so much. It creates a
good sense of community. Its good to learn from all of the positive as well
as negitive things that are happening. Thank you.

Hugs, kisses and love
Gabe

ps-I hope I didn't write anything that seems like I was saying "I know THE
WAY, just do this follow the TRUE path" Sometimes its hard to communicate
ourpersonal perceptions without it sounding as though we have it all
figured out. Maybe I should practice saying things like "I think it might
be" rather than "it is!" anyways I'm rambling. goodnight.



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 13 06:23:37 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: dutchcdc@slip.net (sean t starbuck)
Subject:  to Fred;  The Reason For Happy House Crap
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Great point Fred.  Just one thing.  I remember in the year 91-92, the music
>was truely diverse.  During that period you could enter a party an hear a
>multitude of different styles and speeds of music.  You would have to be Helen
>Keller to not see the difference today.  Toward the end of the Toon Town Era,
>there was a huge amount off shit talk regarding Techno.  Any electronic music
>was scoffed at and labeled, "Techno".  The house music revolution had begun.
>New ravers, in the now flourishing SF scene, would hear this, and be
>discouraged to open their minds to a different approach in music.  There they
>would stay, enjoying only house music, isolated by ignorance.  The parties
>changed also.  The attitude as a whole was altered.  Normally you would see
>all types of unique, often trippy, people.  Now, you encounter a group of
>people that just popped out of an MTV video.  Absolutely no interesting
>clothes, just gansta fashion.  What a shame.
>
>During my travels in the U.S., I have been given the opportunity to observe
>other scenes start, grow, and sometimes die.  With this knowledge, I have
>altered my perceptions about raves and people.  In the scenes where techno was
>never shot down, the spiritual side of the parties is more apparent.  Thes
>places include Montreal, Ohio, Boston, and Baltimore.  In scenes controlled
>predominently by house music, another attitude has emerged.  I like to call it
>"Look at me syndrome".  Fashion, glamour, politics, circle dancing, vogue
>dancing, etc.  The unity on the dancefloor was all but destroyed (this doesn't
>happen too often in SF thank God).  That is fine for some people, however, not
>for me.
>
>I have devoted all my energies and the mojority of my conscience thought to
>the SF scene.  Maybe, first for a bit of fame, but now for a more spiritual
>feeling.  The music, in all forms, has helped me to evolve my spiritual self.
>I believe that this has come about due to the variety of music that I've been
>in contact with.  This is why I have been so intent on bringing diversity back
>to SF.  I truely mean no harm to any of my brothers and sisters or the music
>in stating "What went wrong".  I just get angry when I see a room full of
>party people just sitting around, afraid that they will look stupid if they
>loose their minds for a couple hours.  Maybe I lash back because of a scar
>left by people who shafted my favorite music in 92, shattering my happiness so
>long ago.  I know, I'm weak!  I will continue to help promote a heathy scene
>through diversity, only a little more positively in the future.
>
>peace
>dutch
>CDC

> > > If we persist in thinking that we can own land, that we can use it up and
> > > discard it like a worn-out sock, we will choke to death in our own shit.
> > 
> > Nah, that's just our inability to evolve (which includes the failure to use
> > our big brains and bigger tools to find a way to survive in a modified climate)

> I don't see any effort being put forth to find a solution to this problem; all
> I see is short term greed ($) outweighing long term greed (survival of yourself
> and your descendents).

You're not looking hard enough.  There are political parties that pursue a
more enlightened environmental stance (example... the greens), and scientific
research of all sorts is constantly ongoing.

> >Rights are a moot point.  You're a monkey, and you've got to learn to make the
> > best of your situation.

> Yes.  So maybe part of that is raising my little electronic hand and saying,
> "Hey, let's think about this, and maybe do something about it."  I have no
> interest in becoming a replacement government or other coercive institution.
> So what else is there?  Communication.

Yes, but beside the fact that I think you're preaching to the choir here, this
is a *rave* mailing list.

> > Some of us feel that working together and with
> > feelings of PLUR make the world a better place to live in.  Others feel
> > differently.  This will always be so.  Deal with it.

> Were you born into "the scene"?  Neither was I.  I found out about it 
> through communication; people talking (and typing) about their beliefs.
> "This will always be so, deal with it" sounds suspiciously like a sales
> pitch for fatalism.  I _know_ other people will believe differently, I 
> didn't just fall off the turnip truck -- but at least it's there for
> people to read instead of me just sitting in my room thinking "Damn, 
> everything's so fucked up." which does no one any good, including me.

But it *will* always be so, and you *must* deal with it.  Personally, I try
to drive my car into work as little as possible, preferring my bicycle as a
more green mode of transportation.  It's a little difficult as I live 2,000'
above where I work and I need to ride a short way along the busy highway 17,
but I persist, because I feel that it's right.  I'm also a member of the
Greens, which advocates grass-root political activism and has what I believe
is a proper view of what government should do for us.  I deal with it.  I
also believe that this thread isn't quite the proper way to deal with it, so
I'll drop it here, and I'll suggest that you try to find more constructive
ways to deal with saving the planet.  Just remember, while you're saving
trees here by not doing this with paper, the electricity generated to give us
this form of communication is largely produced by coal and oil burning
generators :-).  Damn, caught raping the planet again....

		Wonko the Sane

     Well, as previously mentioned a while back, I'd like to get a bunch of 
     us together prior to Burning Man to address some of our local needs so 
     we can have more fun and less trouble having to think about the 
     following:
     
     water
     rides
     tent space
     meals
     
     Coming to this gathering _doesn't_ mean that you have to share 
     anything at Burning Man.  It's just meant to connect people who are 
     going _and_ providing a forum for those who want to address some of 
     these needs.  
     
     Let's do it in two weeks (7/23) around 5pm at Sunset.  Look for a 
     white kid's bedsheet w/brightly colored numbers towards the right-side 
     of the the speakers (facing the dj, that is).  If you can't go but 
     want a ride or something, e-mail me privately and I'll make your needs 
     known when we meet.
     
     Looking forward to meeting some of you sfravers whom I haven't met 
     before.
     
     Hugs,
     Diane
     
     P.S. If anyone is driving from Reno, there's someone out there who 
     needs a ride.  E-mail me and I'll hook you two up!

Gabe,
Nice post.  
Personally I like most of what comes out on this list including the personal 
conflicts that arise.  What I also like about this list is that the 
personal conflicts don't usually last too long, where there is usually 
someone like yourself that comes foward to give the group another focus 
of what we have in common in addition to our differences.  Like you said, 
it all helps give a good sense of community.
I think that some of the conflicts on this list helps us get to know one 
another a little better as individuals.  What I also like about this list 
is that it usually doesn't take to long for MOST of the people to be able 
to rise above the conflict and experience that common bond that you 
mentioned that draws most of us to this list giving us a sense of harmony 
along with the conflict and chaos.

:)
peter

From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>

Subject: Retro; Whatever Happened To?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950713112633.7916A-100000@liberty.liberty.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

	They were compared with Depeche Mode, Tangerine Dream, The Yello
Magic Orchestra, Kraftwork, and Brian Eno to name but a few. They are/were
definately one of the many significant pioneers of all electronically
produced music, & the hypnotic groove, yet touched many different genre's
from noise, to gothic & punk, to popular dance, and you will still findem 
on many a ravers shelf. 

	So whatever happened to New Order, anyone got a clue, anyone
really care besides myself, I hope so, else keep flames to yourselfs, I've
had my share for the year. I have a bunch of their CD's, most of which are
fried from too much play, and need to be replaced.  Listening to the
music, though a little on the dark side, is still fresh I think, even
after a decade, for I still like a ggod mix of digital & analog in my
diet. One of my favorite songs; True Faith, got me through a lot of tuff
times, for never have lyrics/music been written that so acturately
reflected a part of my life. 

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian Darkness, LMT/EE/CET
		(510)-530-6452 CT Active Voice & Fax
	     (800)-590-4993 CT Active Voice Mail & Pager

	Internet(Liberty BBS Account):	brianv@liberty.com
	Internet(LINUX Shell Account):	brianvan@liberty.com

		 Give me Liberty or Give me Death

		Beware the Tyranny of the Majority

		    It's not a Crime to Dance

		     (Messages for the 90's)

On 13 Jul 1995 Darren Atherton wrote:

>You forgot hard acid-swing- or any mix of swing would be cool- Swing has 
>allot in common with modern electric music. It's fast and almost all of it
is 
>instrumental- 

AAAAH... thanks for reminding me.
I was of course being facetious with my list,
but swing is an ingredient that could *really* work.
In fact, one of the most sublime experiences I have 
ever had on E was dancing to 1930s swing....
Now I'm inspired to create some kind of electronic mutation...
actually, I have written / arranged for a big band
in the past.   I'll keep you posted!
 
On 7 july 1995 Diane Tabellija wrote:

>     For Hawaiian trance you should definitely check out Martin Denny.  He 
>     created the exotic sounds people expected exotic places to be like in 
>     the 60's...though I'd label it ambient.  (Heck, what's in a label?  
>     IMHO, isn't raving about breaking down barriers of who, what, where 
>     and wear and being able to just go off?)
     
yes, I am familiar with Martin Denny.  I was lucky 
enough to grab a bunch of his records at thrift stores 
before this whole lounge thing took off and they started 
showing up at collectors stores for $25 +  :(
By the way, anyone interested in having a really warped
lounge experience should hear my friend Glenn spin at 
downhear next Wednesday.  He has warned us all that he 
is going to go off!

bye,
-BS

Don't say I didn't warn you - the Cool World party will be large, expensive,
and commercial, even if their DJ list is tempting.  However, I don't see
any sure bets this weekend until Sunset on Sunday.  Some of the other
parties could be cool, but it's guesswork for now.  

FYI, the KZSU link off this web page seems to have a lot of local music info.


                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html

Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, July 14th - Intoxication
   Jon Bishop, Carlos, Dreamer, Spinbadd, Tony, Pete Avila. Free Goodies,
   Erotic Dancers, Tribal Drummer. $12 w/canned food b4 midnite. free
   BART shuttle. 510.746.4440
   
   Friday, July 14th - The Prodigy 
   $10. All ages, curfew at 2am. Tix at Reckless, Neurotic. The
   Trocadero, 520 4th St.
   
   Friday, July 14th - Revolution: A Bastille Day Event
   DJs Jeno, Henrik, Sugar D, Jason Hayes, Nikki Rivera, Felix (Hawaii).
   On a boat departing Pier 1 next to the Ferry Building. 8pm-midnight.
   Tix $25 on sale at Ameba, 1732 Haight. Info: 415.709.4453
   
   Friday, July 14th - Passion
   DJs Julius Papp, Dedan, Henry, R-pos & Joshua stir you with deep house
   & soul. 10pm-, 174 King St, SF.
   
   Saturday, July 15th - Cool World presents Adventures in the Music Dome
   Main Arena: DJ Disciple, Mystic Bill, Mark E Quark, Spun, Eli Star,
   Steve Masters, Pete Avila, MC Flobug. Performing Live: Salmon,
   Savoire Faire & Dream w/MC Nizam, Darwin Chamber, Fidelity Bites.
   Arena Two: Carlos, Sandra Collins, Simon, Dutch, Ghost, Utopia, Dave
   Alga, Sifu, Kimo, MC Ray Vonie. Henry J Kaiser Convention Center, 10
   Tenth St, Oakland. Presale Tix $15 + service charge at BASS.

   Ave, Santa Cruz. 408.684.3434

   King St. 11pm-6am, 21+, $12. 415.241.1560.

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KALX
       90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

>A lot of the people there were freaking out thinking that I was a police
>officer because my Chevron jacket evidently looks just like a police

Yea my freinds and I saw you and it took us a second look to realize that you
were not the police=o)  Thanks to all who called me to let me know where the
thing was goin down.  I took 2 freinds who had never been to a Rave before
figuring that the full moon would be a great first experiance.  I was kinda
dissapointed it was a rather luke warm event.  I have not been to a full moon
for quite some time and it is not what it used to be.  There seemed to be a
lot of young drunk people ther when I arived at  2:30 and I saw a lot of the
cans etc. hit the beach which I later saw Mark from Ameba picking up...
 right on Mark!  at least someone there was being responsable.  

When the music finaly started around 6am it started off kinda slow with this
kiinda funky beat stuff...  it did not seem to be happining.  Then some of
that good ole four on the floor started happining and so did the party.
 Garth decided to take it back to the beginning of the party with a bunch of
non-solid groove stuff (some acid jazzy stuff slow hipy hoppy stuff etc.).  I
was very disapointed and most of the other people I talked to were also.  My
freinds were complaing about the music and wanted to leave so we did around 8
am.

This kinda brings up an experiance I had while sitting to the side of Dj set
up.  One of the people sitting with us who I had just met was sayingsome
rather interesting things to my friend about the Djs.  Actually it was kinda
disturbing.  He was pointing at all of the Djs and naming them and ranting
about how they were his "idols."    Idols?  What is up with that?  I know
that everyone has a right to there own thing but this kinda illustrates some
things that have been pulling the scene down IMO.  Since when was house or
rave about making idols?  Have we become that much like the rock n roll
world?  Will we end up like that?  I hope not.  My veiw of the rave scene is
that everyone should be important.  We don't need rave stars.  But if you
need to idolize someone why idolize a Dj?  All they do is play records that
other people make and they buy just like everyone else can.  My vote for rave
star for the full moon is Mark from Ameoba for picking up after everyone else
who were too busy dancing or running around with balloons etc.  That was one
of the brightest spots for me of the whole rave.

more + stuff
 I really loved the site and spent most of my time exploring the beach as
many others did.  I hope that there are many other things at this location
cause it is a great one.  In the light of dawn it looked just like a scene
out of KPT Bryce.  Did you all check out the echo of the sound sys off of the
back wall?  That was great!  It was like 2 sound systems the second one being
delayed about a half second from the first.  If you got really close to the
wall (which was a beautifull color of red) you could hear the different
frequencys being reflected off of different layeers of the cliff...   Really
cool...   a 3D sound wall!!!  =o)

See ya 
Rob

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 13 15:23:42 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA08822; Thu, 13 Jul 1995 15:23:42 -0700
Received: from emout04.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA08817; Thu, 13 Jul 1995 15:23:37 -0700
From: Phuture@aol.com
Received: by emout04.mail.aol.com
	(1.37.109.11/16.2) id AA036413983; Thu, 13 Jul 1995 18:19:43 -0400
Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 18:19:43 -0400
Message-Id: <950713181934_32162206@aol.com>
To: barnoc@presage.com
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Re: happy hut...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

cocktail ambient
hawaiian trance
lounge breakbeat
and don't forget EZ-listening hip hop (check out Coldcut's Autumn Leaves)

I'm actually fascinated with these possible styles and have done a couple
tracks along these lines myself.  They've gotten a suprisingly good response
from friends.

I've always felt there was a nice connection between cocktail/exotica and
modern electronic styles.  Try this:
Listen to Martin Denny's Firecracker then listen to YMO's remake and then
listen to Zero B's or the Shamen's remix of the YMO version(on the YMO
tribute remixes album.)   
RE the swing thing - there's a really neat track on the NinjaTune TripHop and
Jazz CD that has some big band swing over a nicely swung breakbeat(slow) The
rhythm or timing of swing really is the same as that in a lot of house,
hiphop and of course new jack swing(which I finally figured out is what the
British meant by swingbeat.)

Here's some miscellaneous suggestions if you're exploring:
Martin Denny - Exotica (definitive)
Ennio Morricone(his spaghetti western soundtracks are really amazing visual
soundscapes -- soundtracks in general are one of my favourite genres)
Esquivel(big band cocktail - the precision STEREO production, quirky
composition and flawless playing are weirdly reminscent of modern styles)
Les Baxter(cool cocktail cheese - just buy the album with the best cover)
And while we're at it there's some great - almost dub - reverby surf stuff
too(the Guitar Player compilation is good) 
BTW, I think the Orb has used all of the above.
 
Happy Trails!! ;-)
phuture

Subject: Full moon madness yet again

Precedence: bulk

Yet another full moon madness
=============================

Well,   it got off to a very slow start,   thanx in part to a phuck up 
on the part of the sound crew,   where they must have forgotten or 
misplaced a box of critical cables needed for the sound system.

ut when it did actually start,  it started with some amazingly phat 
phunkey beats that got everyone off their blankets and from their fires 
and filled the dance area very quickly.

There was a Dutch Camara crew there,   doing something on our rave 
scene.    Other than those interruptions,   it went off amazingly well.

Garth started off the funkey beats,  and took things well into daylight 
before Jeno went on.    I was a little disspointed 3/4th the say through 
Garth's set,   especially up until the music stopped (due to a fight 
somewhere towards the hill area).   When Garth finally started up the 
music again,   the beats were better (a little faster),   and even more
people were up there dancing.   When Jeno went on,   things really 
started hopping.    Jeno took things well into the late morning,   
groovin to some amazingly trancey house.   A perect setting for such a 
wonderful day.

Somewhere during Jeno's set,   I went off exploring the cavey cliffs,  
getting off on some of the wonderful visuals that nature provided,  and
sent back to dance the reat of Jeno's set.

Markie mark came over and visited our blanket,  said he was going on 
next,   GREAT!!

When Markey went on,   things really started to hop,  as he slightly 
stepped up the pace a little more and played some really tracey stuff 
that really put my head out there...    

I'm ot sure exactly when Markey finished,  but somehere during his set,  
I took a swim the the ocean (WOW!!  What clear beautiful and COLD 
water).

Anyway,  it was well into the afternoon when the FMR finally finished,  
and Craig helped with the speakers,  lugging them back up the steep 
cliffs.

So concludes yet another sucessful FMR....

Crunchman

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: <Windows Eudora Version 2.0.2>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> SINDAR wrote: >>All they(djs) do is play records that
>>>other people make and they buy just like everyone else can

It is in my opinion much much more than that.  If you have ever been in
front of turntables and even just played records "that other people make
..." it can be an incredible, even religious, experience.  If you are able
to match beats and find two records that sound good together the feeling
escalates and, I feel, has no upper limit.  Bringing the_right_song in at
the_right_time can create a entire reality that was not present before you
started.  I personally have had an experiences like this while dj'ing, and
was so astounded/taken back by the shift in my consciousness that I ended up
screwing up the mix and watched the whole feeling/vibe/state of
mind/body/whatever just fade away.  I aspire to experience it more and
control myself once there.  

But, I never thought twice about vinyl until I stated touching it.  In fact,
two years ago I said many-a-time, "I hate records".

Not No More.

Rick

going "what's this 'acid jazz' I've been hearing about?  You don't mean
they're actually combining good ol' fashioned jazz with that weird new
'rave' music, do you?  Boy, that's pretty funny."

Moral of the story: who knows in which direction music will evolve.  A
friend in the music industry told me that the new up-and-coming style is
hip-easy-listening, sort of Breakfast at Tiffany's with a beat you can dance to.

Hello all,

Just wanted to let you know about a free outdoor party we're putting on 
this Saturday night with the Cloud Factory folks.  

It will be at a choice outdoor Monterey spot that the CF has used 
successfully before, starting around midnight, with the location on the 
CF voicemail: 408.457.7726.

So come on out and celebrate our Mother Earth with us under the stars!!!

Be sure to bring warm clothing, flashlight, and all the other goodies 
you'll need to enjoy yourselves...

Peace + respect,

mother earth sound system
*************************
UNITE  CELEBRATE  SURVIVE

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


i could speak multitudes on this subject but i'd like to remind people
that the people who make dance music make it with the dj in mind. they
do *NOT* mind getting no credit by dj's for playing their music. As long
as it gets played, the word will get out and people will buy the
record.usually all it takes is hearing a good record for the masses to
run to their record shops going 'hey have you heard that track that goes
blah blahbla?' to sell thousands upon thousands of records. Alot of dj's
will just *tell* you what he's playing if you ask. The only people out
there making music and bitching about the fact that dj's don't give them
credit are only in it for the money anyway. Trust me. read magazines
liike Musik, the dance sections in Melody Maker or the NME or MIxmag or
DJ. The artists get their respect. 

mikebee


::Michel.Battaglia::::San.Francisco:California:::::mike@organic.com:
::mikebee@freenet.scri.fsu.edu::::http://organic.com/~mike::::::::::

Dear All;

	In order to give all the parties involved a forum, to air their
feelings with regard to Moon Light. I've taken the liberty of inviting one
of Farmer Whats His Names Cows(Ms. Bessy) in for an interview. 

(Darkness) Well gee Ms. Bessy, what did you think about these ravers?

(Ms. Bessy) Mooooooooo

(Darkness) Did they do any damage to your home?

(Ms. Bessy) Mooooooooo

(Darkness) Did at anytime did any of the ravers try a tip you over while 
you were a sleep?

(Ms. Bessy) Mooooooooo

(Darkness) Well did you at least like the music?

(Ms. Bessy) Mooooooooo

(Darkness) Well there ya have it, right from the horses err cow's mouth.
Cows like Techno

Sin
B. Darkness

Additions Welcome, but I don't know if I could stand it.

heros... but I guess vinal is thicker than your average Hefty bag so here we
go : )

  >   musician, I'm sure you've improvised off of someone elses music or

people who are DJs I do it too.  I just get a little bent out of shape cause
I think it is a little out of control.   Besides I was not doing much today
so I figured I would start some trouble...  changes happen more often when
there is trouble.  Heh he heh....

Well  maybe we have changed our minds...  =o)  Yea we do keep Djs in mind and
we put in a lot of things that make DJs look good.  The issue to me is not
totaly "who" gets credit...  it is more that no one gets too much credit...
 I know a lot of people write House and Rave style music are *not* in it for
the money or the recognition...  in fact a lot of them were attracted to the
idea of a NO ROCKSTAR music.  That is why most groups or persons making this
music do not push pictures of them on everything...  even the Orb if you
noticed were not Highly visable at the Warfield... I have seen them 2 times
ther and still can not tell you what they look like other than they have long
hair.

>It is in my opinion much much more than that.  If you have ever been in
>front of turntables and even just played records "that other people make
>..." it can be an incredible, even religious, experience.  If you are able


Thanks for all the response and yes I have had 1200s and a Numark for many
years now but not as long as I have actually been making music.  I have
discussed this thread many times here before and my opinion is kinda strong
on it.  I really love house music.  One of the things I like about it is the
lack of huge media figures involved with it...  I take offense to all that
stuff in the Rave scene...  if I wanted that I would go to a Michel Jackson
concert.  It is hard for many to see my point of view and I respect that...  

Yes Djing is fun and it does take some practace but I believe if credit is to
be given it should be to the musicians who pour more money and time into
making that music for DJs to play than I have ever _seen_  a   Dj work on a
set.  As always I will back that up with an open invitation to meet me and
hang out at my studio to see what goes into making the record that the DJ
buys...  which now days he or she seems to get more credit for than the
musician.  

I have only had one or 2 people show any interest in my offer and none have
made it out yet but I assure you that I actually do not bite and love to
share making music with others...  I am tiered of just talking about how
great Djs are...  yes they have their place and they are important (I do it
too)  but I would prefer a scene that does not propmote idoltry and media
commoties...  I want everyone to be important.. I think the musicians have
for the most part have been doing their part by keeping low key.  (but then
again maybe Im just a dreamer)  Hey I would like to discuss this further but
in person would be better...  Ill put up =o)  Of course anyone who wants to
come can bring records too.

Late 
Rob

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 13 19:05:24 1995

Precedence: bulk

For you vicarious partyers...

Wed. night @ 1015 (ie Jack's House) saw a crowd of not 
more than 80 people -- which is no a not necessarily a problem, 
except that there's so much open space @ 1015.  It seemed kind 
of a waste to be having Tony (doin' good in the basement) and Emma (main) 
spin to just a handful of dancers each.  Mystic Bill finished the basement
set w/some ok stuff -- found it hard to dance to tho'.  Things
picked up upstairs when Jeno came on, and continued w/some hard 
Spun beats.  

The crowd looked sorta tired (ie the 50% of the people who
weren't dancing).  Kinda had the semi-party atmosphere of
a weekday weekly, which I was hoping would not be the case. 
Overall, a nice gathering, tho' I didn't see too many of... 
well, dem big grins that I have come to expect @ certain 1015 
parties I've been to. An alright night overall. Good for catching 
up w/friends.      

ps. Might check out Progress on Sat. Bring dem big grins (=  

rok

I make music as well.  I know what it takes.  It can come to gether really
easily or take quite a while and alot of effort.

I agree with you on many-a-point.

I don't think we should make idols out of dj's, but mass respect goes out to
the ones out there who really know what there doing, can read a crowd and
work the vibe.  

I don't think we should make idols out of dj's, but I don't think is't fair
to belittle thier(our) "art".  That's all.

I don't dj to be an idol, infact my most incredible dj'ing experiences have
been when I'm alone.

Rick


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 13 20:41:11 1995

X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, nw-raves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Klub Kids on Povich show
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was waiting for a flight in the Phoenix airport this afternoon, and
watched a bit of the Maury Povich talk show.  The theme was: klub kids!
Despite every effort Maury made to make it seem like clubs are weird
and dangerous, all the "kids" had their shit together, the moms in the
audience (some of whom hadn't seen how their kids actually dress up)
were flustered but not unappreciative, and it was really kind of cool.

Povich mentioned they had tried to take videotape at a rave and were
denied (yay!).  Other than that, what can you say when every single kid
they interviewed was either working or in school and ready to go to NYU
or something :-)

Then the OJ trial came back from recess and they cut the show off halfway
through, so I stopped watching . . .

phred

It seems pretty unlikely to me that there was 180 bpm *anything* in 1989.
Remember, it was 1991 before the 140 bpm barrier was even approached by
the likes of the Prodigy and so on.  'The Bouncer' was considered *fast*
when it came out, and that's around 130.

phred

Concerning idolizing DJs, here's my quote of the week.  It's Juan Atkinas
from an interview in DJ (UK) magazine . . .

  Man, it's weird.  I remember a time when being a DJ didn't mean shit --
  when I started doing parties the only time people noticed the DJ was
  when the fucking record stuck.  I'm from that school of thought.
  Sometimes I find it hard to understand how DJ culture got so fucking
  massive in Europe.

c u 
phred
