i wore an sfpd jacket to Atomic Pig in the Oakland Coliseum Parking lot 
this year.  yup, strange looks!, but i think i also had a "funny" hair 
color so i definitely wouldn't "pass."  it's kind of fun wearing a cop 
jacket  you get to have lots of conversations with strangers about 
police brutality and stuff, cuz the jacket  is a conversation-starter 
(esp. if you don't look like a cop!)  on the downside, my friend who 
actually owns the jacket got pretty harassed by the piggies once for 
wearing it.   :(

Well, while we're on the topic of dressing up at raves, (wayne's chevron/cop
jacket) I decided to get decked out myself last week at Moonlight...
I was the guy dressed up as the devil with the white face paint, little red ho         
horns, and a gaudy silver disco shirt.  ...thought it'd be nice to turn the
"positive vibes!" giddiness upside-down and tiptoe around as MacPhisto himself.
Plus, how could I resist the opportunity to put myself in a place where I could
whisper to everyone, "Have you ever danced with the devil in the pale m                      
moonlight?"  --that was the clincher!  I'm mulling over Progress on Sat. night,
and if you see the devil stumbling about, smiling and giggling, say hi--it'll
be me.  I suppose I don't make a very *good* devil, though, I'm in too good a
mood... :)
'Mock the devil and he will flee from thee,'
Timothy

> Subject: Loretta Green Article/SJ Mercury
> 
> GREEN: PENINSULANS  JOIN JUSTICE RALLY  FOR JOURNALIST 
> 
> By LORETTA GREEN 
> 
> 
> PERHAPS it is the much-heard reminder that when the bell tolls, it tolls for
> all of us. Perhaps it is the much-heard sentiment that ''there, but for the
> grace of God . . .'' Whatever this commonality is that has grabbed the
> attention of some Peninsulans, they are joining the fight to save Mumia
> Abu-Jamal from execution Aug. 17 in Pennsylvania.
> 
> Why care about the fate of a man 3,000 miles away convicted of the terrible
> crime of killing a police officer?
> 
> One reason is the considerable doubt surrounding his guilt. Abu-Jamal, an
> award-winning public radio journalist, has adamantly denied killing the
> officer.
> 
> Another reason is that over the past few years, Peninsulans have gotten to
> know this African-American journalist through his regular broadcasts from
> death row on a KPFA-FM (94.1) radio program called ''Flash Points.''
> 
> That is how Palo Altans Barbara Hiken and Brian Coan got interested and
> Maxine Eggerth of Los Altos as well.
> 
> ''I hear him talking and he sounds like the most human, wonderful, rich
> person and one who has an open heart and an open mind,'' said Hiken. ''I
> guess I feel that this man can't be a murderer and if he is, then we have to
> look at what happened.''
> 
> NATIONWIDE supporters of Abu-Jamal want a new trial.
> 
> In 1981 Abu-Jamal, who had no police record, saw Philadelphia police beating
> his brother who had driven the wrong way on a one-way street. He tried to
> stop the beating and was shot in the abdomen. When the struggle was over, a
> police officer was dead and he was convicted.
> 
> Since then, the issues raised by supporters are numerous:
> 
> -- The judge in Abu-Jamal's case had sentenced 31 people to death -- more
> than any other judge in the country and all but two were people of color.
> 
> -- Witnesses reported seeing another man shoot, then flee the scene.
> 
> -- Police ballistics failed to match bullets in the officer's body with
> bullets in a gun legally registered to the defendant and his fingerprints
> were not found on the murder weapon.
> 
> -- Abu-Jamal formerly was a Black Panther.
>  -- He reported on police brutality in Philadelphia.
> 
> -- Prosecutors were accused of suppressing evidence that could have cleared
> Abu-Jamal.
> 
> Said Purusha Obluda, assistant director of the Peninsula Peace and Justice
> Center in Palo Alto, ''This is a national movement and it is much larger in
> this area than similar ones have been in a long time.''
> 
> Protest rallies are occurring in San Francisco and Oakland.
> ON JULY 19 at 7:30 p.m. at the Friends Meeting House, 957 Colorado Ave., the
> Palo Alto-based Peninsula Peace and Justice Center plans a forum to ''Save
> the Life of Mumia Abu-Jamal.''
> 
> Panelists include the co-producer of ''Flash Points''; Kiilu Nyasha, a former
> Black Panther, and longtime correspondent of Abu-Jamal; and a Bay Guardian
> journalist who has written about the case. For information call (415)
> 326-8837.
> 
> Meanwhile, Brian Coan continues handing out information, sending post cards
> to involved judges and President Clinton, and seeking petition signatures.
> 
> Los Altan Maxine Eggerth runs her Me-Do-Errand Service and, between calls,
> works for the cause.
> 
> And in five weeks, the bell tolls.
> 
> 
> Write Loretta Green at the Mercury News, 310 University Ave., Suite 200, Palo
> Alto, Calif. 94301; phone (415) 688-7565; fax (415) 688-7555; or send e-mail
> to LMGreen in Mercury Center or LMGreen@aol.com on Internet.
> 
> 
> MERCURY CENTER ID: me48088g
> 
> 
> Transmitted:  95-07-13 05:52:08 EDT
> 
> 



----- End Included Message -----

The calendar that is mailed out is essentially "lynx -dump"ed from the
web page on Thursday and comments added to the top.  The advantage
of going to the web page (besides the snappy graphics), is that it
is updated throughout the week and may contain more information than
the most-recently mailed calendar.

-Derek

On Thu, 13 Jul 1995 Phuture@aol.com wrote:

> There's something deeply soulful about techno -- a music perceived by many as
> the almost, if no entirely, souless.  Perhaps the ultimate expression of a
> thing is the total abscence of it.
> 
> phuture
> 
I agree, alot of times I feel that the more unconscious I become (while 
awake), the more conscious I really am.  Less self-conscious, more unity 
conscious. I feel as we all tune more into the state of unity 
consciousness we become more of who we truly are.  There is a place that 
many of us experience at a rave with the help of techno music that we are 
all one.   There is so much soul in the music, the 
soul runs through us all.  For deep down in our heart, we have the same 
soul.  The more I experience the soul in me, the more I feel like I 
experience the soul in others.  Techno has definitely helped me with this.

Greetings!

In my latest venture (the InterNet Salon), one of my plans is to have
a weekly Friday night get-together. My sound system (Liquid) is at my
office (great fun...easy to practice here :-), i'm in a warehouse, and
there's plenty of room to enjoy.

Ethan, Logos, and E-ric will be spinning.  It's my Open House...stop by
if you can.

If you'd like to play some tunes some Friday night, drop me a line, or
drop by.  I'm also interested in hosting performers and other interesting
people.  

The InterNet Salon is located at 938 Harrison St., at 5th, in San Francisco.

Subject: Newt supports Biodiversity and Ecosystem Protection
Date: 14 Jul 1995 17:31:45 GMT
Message-Id: <1663885245.33864@macshasta.com>
Organization: MacShasta Consulting
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello,

I had suspected, given his other viewpoints, that Newt was an
environmentalist, but up until now I've been unable to verify it.

But, in his new book, "To Renew America", Newt devotes a chapter to the
Environment.

Before he ran for office, he was the Coordinator of Environmental Studies at
West Georgia College, where he "taught students the concept of the ecosystem"
and the necessity of preserving them.

As I had heard, he did run for Congress in 1978 on a plank of Clean Air &
Water and was actively supported by the Sierra Club and League of
Conservation Voters.

After he was elected, he discovered that the major national environmental
groups had already allied themselves with the Left wing of the Democratic
Party -- despite the fact that conservation of the environment had been
started by Republicans (cf administration of Teddy Roosevelt).

He is very much in favor of preserving biodiversity, the Global ecosystem,
and the purity of air and water - but, he also feels that the current federal
laws are too heavy-handed and inefficient and need to be revised.  He cites
as an example, the EPA's insistence that the city of San Diego abide by
federal water treatment regulations designed for the Great Lakes region, even
though San Diego discharges its effluent far off the coast in the Pacific
Ocean.  The position of the City of San Diego is supported by scientists of
the Scripps Institute of Oceanography and would save the city $7 billion .

You can hear Newt talk about these issues on MTV's roundtable discussion with
Newt on Sunday evening at 7 PM (a 1 hour program).

Ken
ken@macshasta.com

Hello,

I had suspected, given his other viewpoints, that Newt was an
environmentalist, but up until now I've been unable to verify it.

But, in his new book, "To Renew America", Newt devotes a chapter to the
Environment.

Before he ran for office, he was the Coordinator of Environmental Studies at
West Georgia College, where he "taught students the concept of the ecosystem"
and the necessity of preserving them.

As I had heard, he did run for Congress in 1978 on a plank of Clean Air &
Water and was actively supported by the Sierra Club and League of
Conservation Voters.

After he was elected, he discovered that the major national environmental

Party -- despite the fact that conservation of the environment had been
started by Republicans (cf administration of Teddy Roosevelt).

He is very much in favor of preserving biodiversity, the Global ecosystem,
and the purity of air and water - but, he also feels that the current federal

Dear all,

Just out of WEB @ 1015 Folsom. Surprisingly ravey club: no unity, but
TOUGH vibe.

In a while I'll unsubscribe from your list, make a .forward to my uk
account, go to a beach, talk maths to some friends until 1; they will
take me to SF airport, and I'll depart for London (home; and through
to Amsterdam, to pick up my kids and then for holydays in Greece...
((Huh, why am I telling you all this? Sorry, it's been a long
night.)))

Actually, I just want to say

	BYE and 
	THANKS and
	LOVE and
	HAVE FUN

to all of you whom I have met and read from during last 10 weeks,
which I spent among you. 

You are the best scene I have seen. (What have I seen? I lived mostly
in Amsterdam, a bit in Berlin in 1988, three years in Montreal, last
two years in London.) Yes, London is the most sophisticated scene,
they say; music-wise, at least, it is indeed, I think. But I am a wise
old (36) prof, and I don't like sophistication but simplicity.

You are the best scene people-wise; I believe, the only one I would
not mind sending my children at (in a while, though: they are only 4
and 5 now).  At most fun scenes, there is enough power-play going on
that you often end up, especially when you are young, with more
frustration than fun.  Here in SF, I have seen less of that than
anywhere else. Perhaps that's, to some extent, nature of your life
here: the absence of madness in traffic, even sporadic courtesies, are
also completely new phenomena for me.

Sasa, Cory, Michelle, Geoff, Tracy, Mark and many others: YOU HAVE
BROUGHT ME IN DOUBT. I see what you mean. We do have a chance to
CHANGE THE WORLD BY HAVING FUN.

Have fun,
-- Dusko


PS Let me add a comment on house, if I may. 

The question WHAT WENT WRONG?  reminds me on my grandmother. She
wondered WHAT WENT WRONG between her Johann Strauss and my brother's
Roxy Music. "They just slam those drums and add repetitive noises; it
is NOT MUSIC." My music teacher was trying to explain to her that WHAT
WENT WRONG had actually happened earlier, i.e. between Beethoven and
Strauss, and that already Strauss was NOT MUSIC --- but she did not
get it.

The two last centuries of music history have been built by whatever
each previous generation called NOT MUSIC. Each new step forward had
destroyed more of the sublime tonal structures and added more
primitive sound effects, just working on your nerves. Stravinski was
like that, Schonberg was like that, jazz was like that, rock'n'roll
was like that, punk was like that --- house is like that. 

House is NOT MUSIC --- if you compare it with what they thought to be
music a day before yesterday. I believe it is silly comparing it with
techno, as it is silly comparing it with ambient, and almost as silly
as comparing it with classical music. 

If I may simplify a bit, ambient is whatever Brian Eno says it is,
ambiental music, techno is a similar thing, but speeded up for
cheerfulness --- whereas house is something COMPLETELY DIFFERENT.
Distorted voices, dramatic rhythms, going on and on and on, not
letting you go, taking over controll, so that you dance all night,
exhaust your fears, and smile to everybody. No, that's NOT MUSIC:
that's a psycho-technique.

But then, when everybody is waving to it, we change the word --- and
MUSIC becomes house. A new step in history: a further degradation of
structure. Thereby, MUSIC BECOMES MORE SIMPLE-MINDED, BUT MORE
DEEP-HEARTED, MORE MUSCULAR THAN EVER.

Don't be my grandmother: it's silly to complain about this. THERE IS
NOTHING WRONG with becoming less sophisticated and more primitive. We
have been developping in that direction for quite a while. And it's
fun, isn't it?

PPS Perhaps I am exaggerating, but I believe that house is on the
verge of inadvertently realizing some unachieved abstract ideas of
avantguarde. 

Firstly, the DISONANCE, on which serious composers philosophized all
the time, is, as far as I can see, for the first time being used for a
concrete purpose --- an actual emotional effect.

Secondly, the idea of MULTIMEDIA, which conceptualists were trying to
reach by combining in galleries oil paintings with potatoes and
bycicles --- multimedia is in house a real thing: above all, a
symbiosis of sounds and drugs.  (I don't know how terribly illegal is
it to say this, but do I think it is true.  Anyone out there able to
really feel the skin span by pushing it only from outside, or only
from inside, not both?)

Finally, the TECHNOLOGY. The boundaries between
spinning/dubbing/sequencing/producing/playing/composing music will
soon vanish: there will probably be a continuous gamut of
music-making. Composing is so often just sampling or sequencing, while
DJs should be viewed in the house manufacture: they assemble the final
product --- a party --- from parts they acquired from musicians, while
these usually buy lots of samples, programs etc. from...
(whateverthosepeoplehangingoutinthestudiosarecalled) Some of them
really COMPOSE music: they give you a theme A, then B, then go back to
A but faster, then C.... then in the end return to A again, to
"resolve" the dramatic tension... 

This is probably where computers will come in. I don't mean that
everybody will be sitting at a computer and move around musical
phrases in colours. There will always be PHYSICAL ACTIONS OF PLAYING:
DJs will FOREVER love rubbing their records, just as other people will
keep blowing their guts into a saxophone, while others will slide
their bows over deep celli between their legs...

Oh, sorry. Hope you have all already deleted this terrible morning
tirade of mine, and nobody has been bored to death. 

If anybody who knows Michelle reaches this point, please tell her that
I really hope to see her. Pity she had to work.

-- D


--

  Mixed feelings on this one!  It was an excellent
chance for me to play hard and fast for a crowd that
was going to go off, hard and fast, but ... it was
a technical nightmare.  I blame John Carel for spoil-
ing me rotten on his Gateway Sound System!  John is
one of the precious few who makes it his job to hunk-
er over the amps and compressors for the length of 
the party, making sure nothing overloads and that 
everything sounds as sweet as possible, while booming
as loudly as possible.  Not so on Thursday!  I was 
left to fend for myself, and carelessly overheated 
the amp about 4 times -- meaning the sound cut out
at all of the peak moments of my set.  Sorry!  Even
more frustrating was the fact that one of the turn-
tables was completely lacking pitch control.  The 
green 'perfect pitch' light stayed on no matter where
the pitch slider was on the +/- 8 continuum, and if
it was allowing me any pitch control at all it was more
like +/- 1 percent.  So most of the mixes I had planned,
which made perfect sense at home were just impossible.
I had to mix very quickly, with my finger dragging fur-
iously, and had to scramble through records by trial &
error rather than by intuition.  Bummmmmahh!
  Highlights of the evening were:
- Allen@ameba playing Whitehouse & Cabaret Voltaire
- Allen@ameba following the same fashion intuition I
followed, & wearing 100% black
- Andrew@ameba's dj friend Kelly helping me keep the
unruly amp in mind
- ADSR's intro sample
- My shaved-headed roommates Mike & Cody both getting
mistaken for me & hearing 'nice set'
- My lovely friend Abby in Pippi coiffure

  Anyhow, what I played was:

12 AM
----
Bill Nelson - Das Cabinet Der Dr. Caligari
Essit Musique
Bourbonese Qualk - Digital Domain\
Gianelli - Bewitching
Freddy Fresh - ?

Retrofit - Helium Bubble
~~~~
Philip's Phucking Phrolics with Pheedback
 (actually 60 cycle hum, but where is the
  alliterature in that?)
~~~~

----
1:40 AM

  Thanks to those of you who listened & danced!

"Gingrich proposed a referendum in which voters would be asked either to

diametrically opposed views of the same issue, and inability to perceive

illustrates a fundamental flaw of democracy.  51% decide you should get the

Received: from [198.93.4.222] (sr-tty12-ppp.well.com [198.93.4.222]) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id OAA02672 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 15 Jul 1995 14:12:58 -0700

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 14:14:53 +1000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: Car Sterio party - A concept
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

We all know what a hassle it is to get permits for amplified sound.
Last year,  Aaron from SPAZ had actually come up with this Boom Box
party concept where a sound sysem was fed into a small low power
FM transmitter,  and people would bring boom boxes in the hopes
of generating enough volume for a good vib.   I propose we go one
step further..... Car sterio systems (The beefy variaty).

I am willing to invest up to $250 for a small low power FM transmitter
from Steve Dunnifer (Of Berkeley Free radio fame) to put together a team
of DJ's and other interested people to put on a party that would not
likely to get busted for "Amplified sound".   This would open up a lot
more sites than previously available.

There are a lot of people around who have beefy car sound systems,  when
combined with several of them,  can produce a really good sound.

We can have these practically anywhere out in the open,  and without having
to lug heavy speakers,  and such.    I think I can pick an FM frequencey
somewhere below 92 Mhz that would permit me to throw out a signal strong
enough to cover any field with some good tunes.

This isn't a new concept of course,  SPAZ did it before,   but used a
transmitter tuned to a frequency that was used by another strong adjacent
station.

I already have my pair of 1200's,  a TIAC Model 3 mixer (which makes
beat mixing a dream - because it puts the right TT into the right earphone,
and left turntable into the left earphone... which most cross fader mixers
don't have).

All we really need are DJ's,  and a few other folks who want to continue
this amazing summer vibe an an unusual but amazing way.   Remember,  it
isn't illegal to play hour car sterio in a parking lot,  or have your
boom box booming in a park.

Comments anyone?

Crunchman

Dear All;

	Good idea, but naive.

	Better read up on frequency modulation, radio physics, and FM's
major modulation bandwidth limitation of the carrier frequency, before
spending any money. I believe the FCC limits the bandwidth of the input
information, meaning the music to 50Hz to 15Khz, not Techno friendly. 
Also due it's nature, FM frequencies, have a bandwidth which are
much wider than carrier frquencies would elude to, not to mention all the 
harmonics generated by all the radio stations round here. FM is and was 
never meant to be used for high quality audio reproduction, to many 
variables, and I feel most people would be very disappointed with the 
sound. Maybe PP Microwave would offer that, but they didn't teach us that 
in school.

	You would be better off with a van, a killer 200 - 300 watts car
stereo system, a mixer & turntables, some high quality cabinets, and a 
dedicated look out witha two way radio, and it would be much easier. This 
way if someone saw the police comnming, they would radio a head, and have 
the music shut down, the van doors closed, and when they got there they 
would find a bunch of cars, and people, in dead silence.

Sin;
Brian Darkness

> he also feels that the current federal
> laws are too heavy-handed and inefficient and need to be revised.  He cites
> as an example, the EPA's insistence that the city of San Diego abide by
> federal water treatment regulations designed for the Great Lakes region, even
> though San Diego discharges its effluent far off the coast in the Pacific
> Ocean.  The position of the City of San Diego is supported by scientists of
> the Scripps Institute of Oceanography and would save the city $7 billion .

These are the sorts of arguments that make me think that Newt is a
complete cretin; not the sort of arguments that give me a warm fuzzy
about Newt's attempts at reversing his self-generated PR damage by
attempting to  appear more centrist than he really is.

The fundamental flaw in the republican environmenal equation is that
there is no equation in the first place. Money is a meanlingless
concept to nature -- you cannot assign an economic term like "cost
savings" to the environment. The environment is priceless, once you
damage it, throwing money at the problem will not erase the damage
done. Also, cutting $7billion doesn't mean the taxpayers will get back
the money -- it will be successfully and secretely redirected into
other hidden coffers, or applied towards repaying existing debts, or go
right back to the politicians. I think the republicans AND the
democrats will achieve the greatest savings if  they all fired
themselves.

The republican environmental deregulation policies are nothing more
than a "business plan" for a final divide and conquer of the earth's
resources. Steal more of the wealth of the land from the people and
hoard it behind the guard gates in the mansions of the rich. Ensure
misery and suffering among the poor so that you always have slave labor
and human cannon fodder; make it impossible to sustain yourself unless
you are willing to put on those greenback shackles of slavery. The
republicans (IMHO) seek a full reversion to feudalism where a few own
everything and everybody else is a serf ...

One of these days you'll have to buy air to breathe safely -- imagine
the business opportunities!

Last time the republicans attempted to deregulate a stable system we
got the S&L crisis, which made a few men and women rich while the
taxpayer got to pay the bills. Let's have at it again with the
environment. Those republicans are tired of this miserable life/earth
they've created, so they might as well seek their rapture and everybody
else's armageddon.

Gotta run -- serf's up!

>        Better read up on frequency modulation, radio physics, and FM's
>major modulation bandwidth limitation of the carrier frequency, before
>spending any money. I believe the FCC limits the bandwidth of the input
>information, meaning the music to 50Hz to 15Khz, not Techno friendly.
>Also due it's nature, FM frequencies, have a bandwidth which are
>much wider than carrier frquencies would elude to, not to mention all the
>harmonics generated by all the radio stations round here. FM is and was
>never meant to be used for high quality audio reproduction, to many
>variables, and I feel most people would be very disappointed with the
>sound. Maybe PP Microwave would offer that, but they didn't teach us that
>in school.
>

Well,  I've built very good FM modulaters,  and if done right can have
excellent sound.   As an FCC First class commercial radio engineer,  and
with just the turn tables running on a sine wave inverter,  all the rest
will work on the DC,   so there should be little hum and noise.

>        You would be better off with a van, a killer 200 - 300 watts car
>stereo system, a mixer & turntables, some high quality cabinets, and a
>dedicated look out witha two way radio, and it would be much easier. This
>way if someone saw the police comnming, they would radio a head, and have
>the music shut down, the van doors closed, and when they got there they
>would find a bunch of cars, and people, in dead silence.

Possibly so...  !

> Police and its allies continues to this day. In a moving and powerful

> death warrant as evidence that "he is at the call of those who are
> calling for my blood." Ridge admitted as much when he told reporters
> that he acted "to fulfill a campaign promise." FOP vice president
> Kenneth Rocks hailed the signing of the warrant with a bloodchilling
> statement that Jamal "ought to write a short story. He might not have
> time to finish a novel." Meanwhile, in a crude attempt at
> intimidation, the Philadelphia District Attorney's office sent out an
> official letter on June 2 to prominent personalities like actor Ed
> Asner condemning their support to Jamal as an "insult" to police and
> "law-abiding citizens."
> 
 To join the fight to save Mumia
> Abu-Jamal, contact the Partisan Defense Committee, P.O. Box 99, Canal
> Street Station, New York, NY 10013, (212) 406-4252. Tax-deductible
> contributions for Jamal's defense should be made payable to the Bill
> of Rights Foundation, earmarked "Mumia Abu-Jamal Legal Defense," and
> sent to the Committee to Save Mumia Abu-Jamal, 163 Amsterdam Ave., No.
> 115, New York, NY 10023-5001.	Send protests to: Governor Tom Ridge,
> Main Capitol Bldg.., Rm. 225, Harrisburg, PA 17120; fax (717)
> 772-3155; phone (717) 787-2500. Write to Jamal to express your
> solidarity: Mumia Abu-Jamal, AM8335, SCI Greene, 1040 E. Roy Furman
> Highway, Waynesburg, PA 15370-8090. Mumia Abu-Jamal must not die!
> 
> 	- 30 -

   Great time last night! I was amazed to arrive at the high-ceiling 
baroque pillared antechamber- classic location! 
   It took me a while to finally wander up to the balcony and check the

from the great white north (ottawa) to treat us to the chill. Jeno then 
took over the groove wheels and spun it out, followed by another Canadian 
DJ LUV.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Having discovered the point which the idea of music is driven to its end, I am 
proud to announce the advent through DJ technology, a new hybrid and 
solution to the never-ending genre wars.

Combination of Whitehouse and Jungle is the end of music:

Whitehouse brought sound to its conclusion once having discovered the 
Sadian principle: that which causes  the most intense  reaction to the nervous 
system is the best.

Jungle is the manifestation of the principle Cage put forth when he predicted 
that in the future machines would have to make our dance music: Jungle is 
the most extreme result of this approach.

No combination of records or genres can produce such a glorious result as 
these: the end of music.

]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]]
salutations, allen@ameba

In regards to the stereo party I have a couple things to add.  First, have
you ever heard of a gathering permit?  I know this might sound
unconstitutional but, a gathering permit is something that you would have
to get if your expected attenDANCE was to be over 25 persons.  GOOD LUCK!
Second, if the men in blue ever got wind of it, they would surely stop by,
issuing noise volume tickets (or whatever they're called) to each sound
system owner.  I hear those tickets can be over a hundred bucks.  Lastly,
stop and consider the anti-rave variables.  Suppose an unhappy, sleeping
human was to hear the noise?

If you do get this off the ground, I would be more than happy to risk it
for the sake of adventure.

good luck

dutch
CDC

        Hey everybody,
        I just thought i'd pass along these words, which are now on 19" by
25" black and white posters that are being wheatpasted up around the city
right now.  They're for the party coming up this weekend (called either
'July 22nd' or '18+' depending on who you talk to). AK! i can hardly wait
to see spacetime continuum and turph live!
        Anyways, this is what's on the poster....

        it's not about the clothes you wear, how much money you have or the
        colour of your skin, who you sleep with, what language you speak or
your
        religion.
        These things are passing fads.
        You are today, this generation is more important than all before it.
        Wake up and dance to the beat of a different drum than history's.
        Wake up and follow your own path.  Seize the day.
        Forget the pain and fear and loathing of life, come together and
        celebrate.
        Lip service and intoxication will get you nowhere, we must change the
        way we think to change the way we live.
        Why do you belong? Where do you belong?
        It's not just about a party anymore.  Dancing is motion is music
        kinetic.   Release yourselves, unite as one and we shall all be free.
        Someday all music will be made this way.
        We are the future, this world belongs to you.
        Demand more, get more.
        Change yourself, change the world.

the text goes from 12 point (that's about a bit larger than the text you're
reading now) to like 200 point at the bottom (change yourself, change the
world). Interesting, i wonder if Jenny Holzer would have been a raver?
(sorry about the obscure art-skool reference..)
        just some ideas...i wonder what sort of affect this will have...

                brad

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: dutchcdc@slip.net (sean t starbuck)
Subject: Let's set the record straight
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

What is Techno?  What is house? Is there a middle ground?

To me techno is anything in the electronic spectrum of music.  This
includes ambient as well as Hard-core.  It takes you on a ride with goa
trance and drops you off between heaven and acid.  Its sort of difficult to
define, but the feeling is there.  You know when you have gone on a techno
journey.

House music is another story.  House just jumps into your soul and finds
you.  It will show you things you would normally never see.  And the
feeling.  Yea, you know the score.  Its on the soulful side of things.
That certainly doesn't mean it has to be mellow.

If you ask me, yes, there is a middle ground.  This cannot be difined in
print.  You would have to listen to feel it.  Feeling it is the only way.
Most of the djs that I know have a middle ground song or two in their set.
I know I do.  The stuff in the middle brings everything into perspective.

I was asked these questions just recently and thought about it.  I know
that these are the most vague of answers but, that's music.  You can't
discribe it any more that you can an emotion.  That's music.

peace

dutch
CDC

>         Anyways, this is what's on the poster....
> 
>         it's not about the clothes you wear, how much money you have or the
>         colour of your skin, who you sleep with, what language you speak or
>         your religion.
>         These things are passing fads.
>         You are today, this generation is more important than all before it.

>         Wake up and follow your own path.  Seize the day.
>         Forget the pain and fear and loathing of life, come together and
>         celebrate.
>         Lip service and intoxication will get you nowhere, we must change the
>         way we think to change the way we live.
>         Why do you belong? Where do you belong?
>         It's not just about a party anymore.  Dancing is motion is music
>         kinetic.   Release yourselves, unite as one and we shall all be free.

> reading now) to like 200 point at the bottom (change yourself, change the
> world). Interesting, i wonder if Jenny Holzer would have been a raver?
> (sorry about the obscure art-skool reference..)
>         just some ideas...i wonder what sort of affect this will have...
> 
>                 brad
> 
Wow, pretty cool stuff, and who is Jenny Holzer, (for those of us who 
didn't go to art school?)  Anyway, this kind of ties in with my weekend.  
I went to a party friday night, that I had been looking forward to for a 
LONG time.  Regrettably, what it delivered was far less than my 
expectations/projections!?  The end result of the party, and maybe a 
little sleep deprivation, was that I slipped into a WEIRD funky mood.  
This culminated saturday night in some pretty deep introspection.  I was 
hanging out at the Berkeley Marina before venturing to cool world, (I had 
to get out!) and I managed to work myself up pretty well, pondering "the 
meaning of life" type questions...  I kept asking myself "what's the 
point", "what really matters", and the like.  The worst thing was an 
overwhelming sense of disconnectedness, being terribly out of synch.  
Highly unsettling.  Coolio's world, on a positive note,  wasn't half 
bad.  We didn't dance much, just kinda grooved on tunes in the "small 
dome" which was the darkened end of a hallway.  I walked around a lot and 
met some REALLY cool people, and just *E*njoyed things.  About the only 
nice thing about all this, is that it's put the trivial stuff, (silly 
job, etc.) into perspective, showed that they really aren't that 
important, even though I haven't yet reached much insight about the 
deeper things.  It's kind of scary to see so many people so caught up in 
"career" and all the chaff of modern life, distracting themselves to the 
point that they probably never really ponder more important things.  
Perhaps a little knowledge IS a dangerous thing?!  I hope this random 
post doesn't annoy anyone too much, but I felt like sharing it, and 
asking if anyone has ever felt this, and how they dealt.   Take it easy.  Tom

My computer tells me that on Sun, 16 Jul 1995, Dutch shared:

> Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 23:48:37 -0800
> From: sean t starbuck <dutchcdc@slip.net>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
> 
> It costs too much to do Alcatraz.  I heard in excess of $100,000.

I went to Alcatraz a few months ago for the first time since I was very 
young, and was thoroughly entranced by the beauty of the setting.  You 
really can't get a feel for what the island is like by merely looking at 
it from across the bay.  There is a great deal of old stonework, ruins of 
buildings, and lush, verdant vegetation.  While I was there I kept 
thinking, Wow!  What a terrific rave site *this* would be!  

I was curious enough about the potential to discreetly inquire of the 
park rangers there whether anyone occupied the island at night, and I was 
told that two rangers spend the night.  But the place actually is quite 
big, and with the sound of the ocean and numerous places to be shielded 
from view, one might actually manage to hold a party there for 
considerably less than $100,000.   |)

Transportation to and from Alcatraz is allowed only by a ferry from San 
Francisco, which is actually very reasonably priced.  It runs daily every 
hour or two from near Pier 39, for something like $5 or $7 per person.  
If you want the headphones for the audio tour of the island, it costs a 
bit more (my friend and I passed on this).

I don't know much about sound equipment, but might a small generator be 
light (or easily disassembled) enough for one person to carry over, in 
say a large suitcase?  There's plenty of tourists on the ferry naturally, 
so a big heavy suitcase or two might not attract too much attention in 
the crowd.  Lugging it up the hill would be a pain though!  Only part of 
the island is open to the public, but like I said, it's large, and the 
tour is unguided.  My friend and I found it relatively easy to slip away 
and cross into some of the prohibited area to check it out.  You aren't 
required to leave Alcatraz on the next departing ferry -- you can stay as 
long as you want, up till the last departure, around 4:30 p.m. I 
believe.  Thus if a few suitably disguised ravers came over on each boat 
during the day, slipped away from the crowd, and simply never went back 
over, a good-sized group could be spirited onto a pre-arranged site on 
the island to wait until night for the party.

As an alternate to lugging sound equipment, maybe the stereo boom box 
idea currently being discussed could prove fruitful at this juncture...

On a brief sidenote, I learned during my visit to Alcatraz that the 
island has a short history of protests.  During the late sixties or early 
seventies after it was closed down as a federal penitentiary and before 
it was reincarnated as a tourist attraction, Alcatraz was occupied by a 
group of American Indians as a protest of the treatment of their people 
by the United States government.

It would certainly be a dramatic place from which to send a message about 
the Constitutional right to freedom of assembly.


				*** Starchild ***    ;)

"19", called "19 - The Final Story".  It's not anywhere near as good as 
the original, IMHO.  Just thought someone might be interested.  "19" used 
to be one of my favorite songs, and it's got some great bits to be sampled.

At 11:30 PM 7/16/95, tom porcella wrote:

>Wow, pretty cool stuff, and who is Jenny Holzer, (for those of us who
>didn't go to art school?)
        oh sorry :) haha, well she's an artist from NYC i believe who was
big in the 70s-80s i don't know what she's up to now, supposedly she was
working with U2 on their ZooTV tour (no comment, i have a personal bias
against these guys for the way they handled Negativland 'sampling' "i still
haven't found what i'm looking for" but i digress) Anyways, Jenny H. used
to put up these 'public installations' of text, usually on 'flyposters'
with just text. Here's some of her 'truisms' that i can remember off-hand:
        Money creates taste.
        Abuse of power comes as no surprise.
        ... and other things that my caffeine-depleted brain can't access
right now..
>Anyway, this kind of ties in with my weekend.
>I went to a party friday night, that I had been looking forward to for a
>LONG time.  Regrettably, what it delivered was far less than my
>expectations/projections!?  The end result of the party, and maybe a
>little sleep deprivation, was that I slipped into a WEIRD funky mood.
>This culminated saturday night in some pretty deep introspection.  I was
>hanging out at the Berkeley Marina before venturing to cool world, (I had
>to get out!) and I managed to work myself up pretty well, pondering "the
>meaning of life" type questions...  I kept asking myself "what's the
>point", "what really matters", and the like.  The worst thing was an
>overwhelming sense of disconnectedness, being terribly out of synch.
>Highly unsettling.  Coolio's world, on a positive note,  wasn't half
>bad.  We didn't dance much, just kinda grooved on tunes in the "small
>dome" which was the darkened end of a hallway.  I walked around a lot and
>met some REALLY cool people, and just *E*njoyed things.  About the only
>nice thing about all this, is that it's put the trivial stuff, (silly
>job, etc.) into perspective, showed that they really aren't that
>important, even though I haven't yet reached much insight about the
>deeper things.  It's kind of scary to see so many people so caught up in
>"career" and all the chaff of modern life, distracting themselves to the
>point that they probably never really ponder more important things.
>Perhaps a little knowledge IS a dangerous thing?!  I hope this random
>post doesn't annoy anyone too much, but I felt like sharing it, and
>asking if anyone has ever felt this, and how they dealt.   Take it easy.  Tom

        Hey, i LIVED like this for a long time, it sucks.  I don't usually
make sweeping statements but i'd have to say that the feeling of alienation
is _the_ worst feeling that a human being can experience. That you, and you
alone, are experiencing or thinking about something, that you are not a
part of _anything_ and that you are some sort of anomalous island in a sea
of ppl who have nothing in common with you.  Thing is, it took me a while
but i've realized that this is _never_ true.  The human commanalities which
bond us together will _always_ outnumber our differences. I won't get into
any personal political diatribes about how it is the project of advanced
capitalism to instill this alienation and divisive mindset in people in
order to create a spiritual vaccuum which can only be (supposedly) satiated
by consumer purchases (and we all know what a crock _that_ is).  Anyways,
it's good to be introspective, to question the self, meaning, purpose, and
all that. That's part of being a human with the unique ability to have
one's conciousness reflect upon itself.  Just don't forget the other side
of it which is that we're all hairless apes that need to go out and be with
others, to dance, to 'not-think', to laugh, to share physical contact.
         peace,
           more blab c/o brad :)

> nice thing about all this, is that it's put the trivial stuff, (silly 
> job, etc.) into perspective, showed that they really aren't that 
> important, even though I haven't yet reached much insight about the 
> deeper things.  It's kind of scary to see so many people so caught up in 
> "career" and all the chaff of modern life, distracting themselves to the 
> point that they probably never really ponder more important things.  
> Perhaps a little knowledge IS a dangerous thing?!  I hope this random 
> post doesn't annoy anyone too much, but I felt like sharing it, and 
> asking if anyone has ever felt this, and how they dealt.   Take it easy.  Tom
> 
Tom,
I had a similar experience at the sunset party, which by the the way was 
beautiful way to spend a sunday.  For a while I was dancing, feeling a 
good trance sharing the energy with my surroundings, then I was was hit 
with some cognitive thoughts causing me to reflect on my life a bit.
A part of me didn't really want to do this, as I was having more fun a 
moment ago trancing out and feeling more of the vibe.  Then there was 
another part that was alittle caught up in some self importance trip.
Feeling a bit of a conflict, I decided to take a walk down by the ocean, 
to see if I could find a little more harmony with this conflict.
I spent a little time acknowledging and validating some of my thoughts and 
feelings that had pulled me away from the vibe for a bit.
Doing this helped me reconnect to the vibe within myself, and it wasn't 
long that I was feeling entranced with the beauty of the ocean and the 
rest of the surrounding nature.
After chilling for a little while with this beauty, I felt a resurgence 
of energy, and it wasn't long before I dancing away, and feeling open and 
connected to all the people there, even more so than before I was pulled 
away from my trance with some comtempative thoughts.
I don't think "a little knowledge is a dangerous thing".  I think what we 
DO with the knowledge can be dangerous.  It also can be a very helpful 
thing.  
Some comptemplating (not dwelling) of one's life can be great.  After all 
we do all have separate lives outside of (and connected to) raving.

 
:)
peter

Subject: Re: Let's set the record straight
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Markie said: "It's all electronic I thought?  The common base for a great
deal of both these musics - I hate to make
distictions or labels :(  - is electronic drum and base."

I think the labels are historical and useful in that context i.e they make it
easier to analyze and discuss the past.  The danger of course is in limiting
the present and future by forcing new tracks into categories.   Before disco
died(went underground) in this country it was becoming electronic.  As drum
machines and synthesizers became more common and affordable to more
musicians, various styles of electronic dance music came into being.  As was
the case in the past,  different styles evolved in different regions/cities:
   Electro-boogie(and later house and garage) in NY, House(deep and acid) in
Chicago, Techno in Detroit, Freestyle in Miami, etc.  The Chicago sound(deep)
seemed to be more directly influenced by the late Philly disco sound whereas
the Detroit sound was more influenced by the newer european electronic disco,
in particular the "colder" variety i.e. Kraftwerk.  That's just my
interpretation and that was 10!! years ago.  The styles have progressed
considerably from their roots and the more progressive the track the harder
it is to say what its influenced are.  Outside of "academic" discussion
however, I agree that labels and distinctions seem to encourage division and
that ain't no good.  The beauty of minimal, electronic dance music is that it
is so easy to understand it can communicate across cultural and language
barriers.  Like Afrika Bambaataa said so long ago, "Rock, rock, the planet
rock, don't stop."

phuture

I was at Alcatraz just last week. It cost us $9 each to take the ferry 
over, and then we could return on any ferry we wanted at 45 minute 
intervals. It looks like a good site, but there is no way you could just 
walk in and set up shop in a prohibited area without being noticed. There 
was security all over when I was there. As I understand it, the island is 
still "technically" Federal property, until it's restored, and then it 
might become a state park or something. I know this, because they told us 
if we took home a piece of the "rock" (literally), then we were 
stealing/vandalizing federal property.

---mr.bill   :)

> On Mon, 17 Jul 1995 wicked@cyborganic.com wrote:
> > Kinda reminds me of something Heisenburg once said....
> 
> Something along the lines of "that which observes a thing, changes a 
> thing"?  The "Uncertainty Principle"?  Yeah, that could fit in here.  
> Same way people behave differently if there's a camera focused on them.
> 
> 	Brian

Speaking of Physics:

A few days ago, I read in the paper how scientists have created a new 
form of matter.  By using lazers and magnetic fields, a group of 
atoms were cooled down (their motion frozen) to a temperature which was
as close to absolute zero as ever achieved.  As the atoms entered this
state of compelte stillness, the quantum mechanical waveforms that defined
them expanded, overlapping one another, until reaching a point where these
waveforms become equivalent to each other.

The result, according to the laws of Quantum Physics is that these atoms
lost their separate identities, and *become each other*.  Their individual
identities had been lost, and they became *one* atom representing a state
of matter never seen before (though predicted by Einstein 75 years ago).

I couldn't help thinking about what happens to our individual 
consciousnesses when we, as a group, enter trance states while listening
and dancing to music that resonates with our psyches, focusing and
"stilling" that parts of our minds that tend to separate us from each 
other.  We often talk about the "oneness" and sense of unity that can be
achieved when we sync up on the dance floor.  Some folks dismiss such
ideas as new age babble.  But as the forefronts of science open up
new understandings about our universe, the intuitive concepts of the
spiritual realm are becoming every bit as real as the material world
around us.

Whether it's lazers & atoms, or house/techno & minds, we humans are
discovering some pretty cool things as we push beyond the boundaries of 
reality.

Lee
_______________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com

Cloud Factory rave report
=========================

This weekend offered the highly commercial Cool World event...   But due 
to the high admission fee,  none of my friends could make it,   not even
to Progress...   But I was able to scrape enough gas money to get down 
and check out the Cloud Factory/ MESS (Mother Earth Sound System) event 
in Monterey.

We wait around for the info number to be updated,  and eventually got 
the info.    The announcement said that the Map Point was busted,  and 
cautioned us to be VERY discrete when approaching the site,   turn off 
the headlights as we approach a big Phat Cat mansion and look for the 
parking attendant.

We left rather late,   but pulled out of SF around 1:30 am,   heading 
south down to Monterey.   We eventually make it down there by 4:00 am.
(Boy!! what  non-smoker has to do to rave...  but outside events take 
much higher priority,  despite the long drive).

As I arrive,  Scott was spinning some older well known house toonz,  but 
after sitting in a car for 2 hours,   I didn't make it to the dance area 
until after I stretched,   but it didn't take that long until I was in 
the groove.   There were lots of breaks in the beat,   so my dance 
sessions were short,   but eventually another DJ went on that was more 
consistent.   It wasn't long until the sun started coming up,   and I 
was getting in the grove,   although there were few people dancing at 
that time.

The site was excellent,   I would have to give it a 9 on 1-10 scale.   
Way to go,   wonderful selection.   The party went to completion totally 
un-molested,   despite the fact that a house was about a half mile away.

The site was surrounded on three sides by tall cliffs,  and as I looked 
around,   people were up there on the cliffs dancing.    Quite a sight.

Down in the "pit" was really soft and fine sand/dirt that was ideal for 
a soft chillout place for our blankets.

Eventually,  things closed down at about 8:30 am,   and we headed back 
north to Santa Cruz where we suspected that Sunset was to be.   We visit 
all the health food stores in Santa Cruz,   have breakfast,   look up a 
few friends before calling the info line for directions to Sunset.

Sunset
======

As suspected,  Sunset was at a great beach in Santa Cruz,  and we get 
there just as the sound system was in its final checkout....   I took 
the opportunity to check out the beach area and explore...   Really nice
spot...

Things traditionally started off on the slow side,  but it wasn't long 
before the groove started setting in and the SF people arrive (after 
driving down from Bay Area).    As usual,  the SFRave quotient was 
really high.

After dancing my first set,   I head down the beach to the water for my 
first (And only) swim.    I was amazed at how nice the water was.   It 
was actually warmer than usual.  Or perhaps I was so hot from dancing 
that I might have cause an El Nino....

Ethan finally got behind the turn tables after a rough start,  and the 
music got progressively better.    All during Ethans set,  the music 
started to gradually evolve into some the most insane house/trance tunz 
I've ever heard.   The critical energy level really started to peak 
towards the end of Ethans set.

Mystic Bill (from Chicago) finally went on,   but after dancing to 
Ethans entire set,   I decided to chill and go swimming again,  but 
listening to Mystic Bill develop his set.   After about 20 minutes,   
Noticed that Bill's set was really evolving into this deep house 
(Chicago style),   quite different than our stuff,   but really funky 
and danceable.

As the sun was setting,  in true Sunset tradition,   people up on the 
cliffs were all lined up holding hands and shouting and cheering as the 
sun was setting.   WOW!!  What an incredible sight...   Not sure what 
the numbers were,   but estimates were far above 1000 people for one of 
the biggest Sunset parties ever.

Ethan finally came on,   giving me another chance to chill until his set 
develops.   He started off kinda funky,   with lots of vocals but as his 
developed,  the energy level really started to increase.   It wasn't 
long before people were shouting and hollering with approval,  as time 
went on.   As usual,  his set was primo...

Spun finally went on,  and continued the vibe and intensity.  For me,  
there were no breaks in the dancing,   all the way until the end,   
which took us well into 11:30 that evening.

There was talk about an "after party" at panther beach,   and also a 
party in Santa Cruz but because I was with other people,   it was 
decided that we make it back to Mill Valley.    We hung around by the 
fire to warm up before leaving as we started picking up the litter to 
clean up the beach after the party.

We eventually make it back the Mill Valley,  and I'm still smiling from 
such a wonderful vibe.

Sunsets are becoming legendary now...   Most people opting NOT to go out 
on Sat evening so they can save their energy for Sunset parties.

So concludes yet another wonderful weekend....

Crunchman out...

Hey everyone,
I had a great time at Sunset it was beutiful. The day that we left to go to
Sunset. My friend Travis opened a random book of poetry to this poem.

A Land Not Mine

A land not mine, still
forever memorable,
the waters of its ocean
chill and fresh.

Sand on the bottom whiter than chalk,
and the air drunk, like wine,
late sun lays bare
the rosy limbs of the pinetrees.

Sunset in the ethereal waves:
I cannot tell if teh day
is ending, or the world, or if
the secret of secrets is inside me again.

Anna Arkmatova
translated by Jane Kenyon


Cool huh. Lots of Love,
GABE

"the secret of secrets is inside me again"

In-Reply-To: <9507172055.AA09557@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Message-Id: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950717162500.4362A-100000@aldebaran.oac.uci.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I really liked that little explanation you wrote.  I didn't know that 
sorta thing still goes on (I guess I have my head buried in my CS books 
for class...ughhh).  Anyway, it is pretty amazing what science is doing.  
However, there always has bn previously a large seperation between 
science and mysticism of any sort.  However, i believe that may change 
soon.  Take for example the one subset known as "ravers".  A large group 
of them are intelligent college types.  In fact there is a large 
percentage down here of CalTech and Harvey Mudd students who go raving.  
Since raving in a way is a very spiritual experience (at least for me 
anyway) I can't help but see how the next generation of scientists will 
be affected by this new spark of intrest in mystism/religion of all 
sorts.  I, for one, will be pleased to see it, because I think IMHO 
scientists need to learn a few more morals.   I won't get into the 
"jurassic Park" lecture but I am sure you all know what I mean.  

Sorry if 
this isn't too rave related (but yes raving is EXTREMELY SPIRITUAL for 
me), but I was just kinda putting in my $0.02 on this thread.  I am sure 
you all have had at least one experience where you have been dancing at a 
rave and (this has happened to me both chemically altered and not 
altered) then you realize the oneness in the room.  It is something that 
developed over time without your conscious realization, in part it is due 
to the groove, in part to all the nice and happy people around you, but 
mainly I feel it is all part of the energy that is us (perhaps I am going 
off the deep end here).  But recently I have gotten into the idea of 
everything made up of energy (which science has confirmed since matter is 
simply a transition state of energy if I remember correctly).  I am quite 
convinced that we each have a pool of energy within us, and by releasing 
this energy within us we can change attiitude/make amazing things 
happen.  Thats why when you get a room full of people giving energy of 
consciously/unconsciously you feel so invigorated and unified.  Also that 
is one of the reasons I feel so tired after raving.  During each rave I 
go to (well I have been selfish with my energy once or twice) I just try 
to slowly release as much energy as possible.  Coming home from raving I 
am often extremely spiritually tired (but also in spiritual bliss) as 
well as mentally/physically tired.  This is just my observations and I 
would really like to hear other peoples ideas on this issue.  If you 
wanna email me or something, i would be more than happy to discuss this 
with you.  Oh and btw, yes I have read Celestine Prophecy and I thought 
it was an excellent book, but it is only a starting point.  

Well I have babbled WAY too much for one day...hope to see you all soon.

	-Christian

wow... my first sunset... i thought i had seen some pretty cool things but
this was way up there on the list.

>Sunset
>======
>
>As suspected,  Sunset was at a great beach in Santa Cruz,  and we get
>there just as the sound system was in its final checkout....   I took
>the opportunity to check out the beach area and explore...   Really nice
>spot...

nice?  it was beautiful!  sure beats smelly wisconsin hick town barns
stepping on cow pooh (<---not a joke... i have been to parties like this).
i couldn't get over the fact that i was at a real beach with an ocean...
beats lake michigan.

>
>Things traditionally started off on the slow side,  but it wasn't long
>before the groove started setting in and the SF people arrive (after
>driving down from Bay Area).    As usual,  the SFRave quotient was
>really high.

i wish i knew more of you.  it felt strange being at a party and not
running in to barely anyone i know.

>
>Mystic Bill (from Chicago) finally went on,   but after dancing to
>Ethans entire set,   I decided to chill and go swimming again,  but
>listening to Mystic Bill develop his set.   After about 20 minutes,
>Noticed that Bill's set was really evolving into this deep house
>(Chicago style),   quite different than our stuff,   but really funky
>and danceable.
>

he is really very good.  it was nice for me to be in a new setting
listening to someone spin i have heard at least 20 times before and am
never sick of.  i love chicago house.

>As the sun was setting,  in true Sunset tradition,   people up on the
>cliffs were all lined up holding hands and shouting and cheering as the
>sun was setting.   WOW!!  What an incredible sight...   Not sure what
>the numbers were,   but estimates were far above 1000 people for one of
>the biggest Sunset parties ever.
>
you SFers need to give the rest of this country a lesson in VIBE!!:)

>Ethan finally came on,   giving me another chance to chill until his set
>develops.   He started off kinda funky,   with lots of vocals but as his
>developed,  the energy level really started to increase.   It wasn't
>long before people were shouting and hollering with approval,  as time
>went on.   As usual,  his set was primo...
>
>Spun finally went on,  and continued the vibe and intensity.  For me,
>there were no breaks in the dancing,   all the way until the end,
>which took us well into 11:30 that evening.

as i was dancing to spun i remarked to this girl next to me how slow it
was.  she laughed and asked if i was from the midwest.  i really liked it
and all... very groovy... just new for me.  i heard him spin in chicago
about a month ago and felt the same way then.  i will need to adjust my
dancing to a slower speed:)
>
>There was talk about an "after party" at panther beach,   and also a
>party in Santa Cruz but because I was with other people,   it was
>decided that we make it back to Mill Valley.    We hung around by the
>fire to warm up before leaving as we started picking up the litter to
>clean up the beach after the party.
>
>We eventually make it back the Mill Valley,  and I'm still smiling from
>such a wonderful vibe.

me too:) i really like it here.  glad i made the move.  everything here
seems much more chill and relaxed. i can't wait for my second sunset!  and
to meet some people so i an say hi to them and not feel like a loser with
no friends...


hope to see you all next week!

ellen

>
>Sunsets are becoming legendary now...   Most people opting NOT to go out
>on Sat evening so they can save their energy for Sunset parties.
>
>So concludes yet another wonderful weekend....
>
>Crunchman out...

>me too:) i really like it here.  glad i made the move.  everything here
>seems much more chill and relaxed. i can't wait for my second sunset!  and
>to meet some people so i an say hi to them and not feel like a loser with
>no friends...

Us too!  If I may speak for the group...You have friends you don't even
know yet.

My two favorite things about raving in and around SF are:  1) You never
need to feel embarassed/shy about introducing yourself;  2) You don't have
to go through uncomfortable conversation closure, in that you can just
dance off and not feel bad that you didn't extend great and lavish exiting
lines like, "Well, I'll see you later."  Or, "Well, um, I'm gonna go over
here now, but I'm sure I'll see you before I leave."  It's not that they
don't happen, it's that they don't have to that makes it cool.

Some call it Sunset, I've taken to calling it Sunday Mass.

To think a boy from Buffalo could contribute to such a uniquely San
Francisco/Santa Cruz event.  So cool it made my toes curl.  Which made
dancing even worse cause I'd scoop up these huge loads of sand and send it
flying, inadvertently burying someone's foot.

THANK YOU PACIFIC!!!!  You guys rock!

See you all in two and two (and two),

Tony

P.S.  Was that Steven King or did I eat too many of those ;^) ;^) brownies?

On 7/17 Starchild said:
On a brief sidenote, I learned during my visit to Alcatraz that the 
island has a short history of protests.  During the late sixties or early 
seventies after it was closed down as a federal penitentiary and before 
it was reincarnated as a tourist attraction, Alcatraz was occupied by a 
group of American Indians as a protest of the treatment of their people 
by the United States government.


That's because the island has been a sacred spot to the native people of the
bay area since long before we came along and decided to build a PRISON on a
sacred site. They manage to overlook this little bit of info on their touchy
feely tours.

-Bradfurd

Opus III, "Guru Mother" (1994 - pwl international... epm records... CD96291)

Kind of spiritual techno with a hint of eastern philosophy added for good
   measure.  Extremely kind.  A bit different from "Mind Fruit"-- less
   continuous, lyrics are kinder, less driving, more methodical, much less
   danceable and vocals more intense (imho: you can tell for yourself-- I
   sent to ftp://ftp.uqp.edu/incoming/lyrics/opus.iii/guru.mother)

Sorry- I don't have a way to do it, or I'd put up some samples for web access.

release the joy,
adam

The other very sad part of this was that the "19" that got all the radio
airplay and was hugely popular was withdrawn from the market. From what I
recollect it had something to do with him not getting the (CBS?) news
reporter's permission for the extensive sampling of his voice. (i.e. the
"None of them received a hero's welcome. guy"

"19" was then redone and re-released with another announcer's voice saying
the same words, and that's the one that I have on CD, but it's not nearly
as good as the original.

If anybody has the original one, I'd like to get in touch with you and get
a DAT copy of it.

thanks, -w

Dear Lee;

	First, sorry for the lenght, but I think its really neat stuff.

	There is great promise from the science of nuclear fusion,
everything from materials, antimatter, to energy, unlike fissions
descructive nature.  Sometime in the 80's, I think it was at Princton
University, but somwhere in New Jersey, that a small town there became,
for a few controled seconds one of the hotest(temperature wise) locations
in our known galaxy, due to a sucessful nuclear fission experiment, or at
least thats what they said. 

On Mon, 17 Jul 1995, Lee Fogel wrote:

> Speaking of Physics:
> 
> A few days ago, I read in the paper how scientists have created a new 
> form of matter.  By using lazers and magnetic fields, a group of 
> atoms were cooled down (their motion frozen) to a temperature which was
> as close to absolute zero as ever achieved.  As the atoms entered this
> state of compelte stillness, the quantum mechanical waveforms that defined
> them expanded, overlapping one another, until reaching a point where these
> waveforms become equivalent to each other.
> 
> The result, according to the laws of Quantum Physics is that these atoms
> lost their separate identities, and *become each other*.  Their individual
> identities had been lost, and they became *one* atom representing a state
> of matter never seen before (though predicted by Einstein 75 years ago).

	Don't kid yourself, we are all connected, whether on the dance
floor, or sitting at our terminals. I'm an engineer, who happened to have
the opportunity of going to a massage school, who's whole philosophy was
based on the exsistence of the mind body connection. While I was there you
got thoughly emersed with Anatomy & Physiology, for 6 months. 

	Engineers tend to be know it alls, I'm no exception. I've gotten
to work with a lot of nifty stuff as a engineer, but before school had no
appreiation for the human body. After, however it is a much different
story, you just can't image what you are, what your made up of, its just
so trippy, 70% water, & the rest connective tissue, but also much more
than that, they often used the fish tank as an analogy. All these tiny 
little organisums connected, but separtated, yet its life, persistant, 
resilent, and self repairing for a time.

	We are all made up of cells, each with its own celluar
intelligence, summed & linked together through a communications system,
also made up of cells, and powered, & surrounded, by an electro static
field, that I believe actually transmits on some very suttle level. The sum
of these millions of organisums, their celluar intellgence, our genetics, and
environment makes us who and what we are. Anytime you pass an electric 
current through a conductor, there is a colasping & expanding electro 
magnetic field around that conductor. So we in a very real sense have a 
field of energy around us at all times, that is characterized by our 
mood, genetics, history & experience, diet ...etc. Electro magnetic 
fields also induce a current into conductors, so your energy field can be 
passed on to another person, just by walking by them, or touching them.

	Now hears the really neat part, everyone has a bacteia called
macro-fozes(spelled incorrectly), these guys truck around the connective
tissue of the body removing waist products ..etc. They also have another
important job, which is identifing whether or not something in the
connective tissue is foreign to the body or not, and either disposing of
it, or labeling it as foreign, which call other types of immune cells,
like T4, Killer T Cells, ...etc, to help. These cells are all surrounded
by energy, and respond to energy. So when you get the chills(immune system
response) for no reason, and you notice someone sleazey just walked up to 
you, don't doubt it.

	I was trained in a modality of massage called Polarity, which is
Energy Work, created & discovered by a engineer, Dr. Stone, in order that
he could help his wife who suffered from unknown cronic pain. 

	He borrowed some work from a sciencist(I'm forgeting his name),
that believed the body could be healed using certain kinds of energy &
frequencies. Rumor has it that in sample dishes containing cancerous
tissue, he was, through the use of a device(forget it's name too, but I
think its on display at the Smithosian) he created, was able to change the
cancerous cells back to normal, without any effects to the good tissue. In
fact this sciencist was able to do it with most diseases, totally removing
them. However, & mysteriously his lab was raided by the FDA(by all the 
branches of the government), all his equipment & notes either 
destoried or confiscated, and forbidden to do anymore research.

	Well, back to Dr. Stone & Polarity. He went aboard, to Tibet,
China, India...etc and studied medince over there for years, because the
Eastern modalities were the only ones, at that point in time even
acknowledged the exsistence of these fields, or energy; chi.  Dr. Stone
believed that these electromagnetic fields around the body could at least
be manipuated through a sequence of very lite massage treatments. 

	There are like 12 - 15 treatments that you do on someone
requesting the work, and depending on whats wrong. It's very powerful
work, and brings up a lot of emotional stuff with clients, during and up
to 48 hours after the secession. 

	It also has an effect on the therapist, it can be very draining,
even though the work is extremely lite, a few specific holds, and motions
and thats it. I've also felt good, better than when I've started, and like
there was something inside me that didn't fit or belong, its weird, and I
don't do the work very much. You can actually feel the field on some
people from time to time, it can be an electric feeling, or heat, or a
pulsing where there should be no pulse ..etc, the more training and
Polarity type work you do, the more you can feel it, it's an awareness
thing, sorta like the Force:). For some it takes years to master, others
minutes, and I feel someone should study it for years before practicing
it. 

	Also being an engineer I was really sceptical when they were 
telling me about it, but feeling is believeing, and I believe, & respect 
energy work.

	So yes, I believe(being an engineer), with reference to our
bodies, our universe, we are still infants in our knowledge, ignorant &
fearful of exploring the more cosmic aspects of the body, breaking the AMA
ivory tower/iron triangle, an outta pride, not fully acknowledging a
system of medince thats been around since the dawn of civilization, but I 
like to think were growing.

> I couldn't help thinking about what happens to our individual 
> consciousnesses when we, as a group, enter trance states while listening
> and dancing to music that resonates with our psyches, focusing and
> "stilling" that parts of our minds that tend to separate us from each 
> other.  We often talk about the "oneness" and sense of unity that can be
> achieved when we sync up on the dance floor.  Some folks dismiss such
> ideas as new age babble.  But as the forefronts of science open up
> new understandings about our universe, the intuitive concepts of the
> spiritual realm are becoming every bit as real as the material world
> around us.
> 
> Whether it's lazers & atoms, or house/techno & minds, we humans are
> discovering some pretty cool things as we push beyond the boundaries of 
> reality.

Blatant Self-Promos from bands or promoters in SF is one thing, Zheam.  
BSP's from people outside the area, who join the list for one 
day, post their BSP, and then leave, is *not* cool.  

For the other SFRavers - Zheam has posted many messages to this and the
other rave lists, about once every two weeks, whenever he has a new record
out.  He has also sent forged mail shortly after his spam from a "satisfied
customer" to the same list of lists. Usually, since he isn't a member of the
list, they bounce to me and I don't forward them since I don't forward posts
from non-subscribers on principal.  However, Zheam has now decided to get
around that filter by subscribing to those lists, posting his ad, and
unsubscribing.  

I usually play a *very* light role in administrating this list - I don't 
believe in serious reprimands or unsubbing troublemakers or anything 
like that, I hope they would get a clue and context from the others.  
However, I also will not let the resource here be abused by marketers with 
no interest in the list itself.

Thoughts?

	Brian

The other very sad part of this was that the "19" that got all the radio
airplay and was hugely popular was withdrawn from the market. From what I
recollect it had something to do with him not getting the (CBS?) news
reporter's permission for the extensive sampling of his voice. (i.e. the
"None of them received a hero's welcome. guy"

"19" was then redone and re-released with another announcer's voice saying
the same words, and that's the one that I have on CD, but it's not nearly
as good as the original.

If anybody has the original one, I'd like to get in touch with you and get
a DAT copy of it.

thanks, -w

Rave party

 A large "rave" party at Four Mile Beach on Sunday drew hundreds of party-goers but created only parking problems, the Sheriff's Off=
ice said.
More than 100 cars were reported at the beach north of Santa Cruz. The party continued most of the day and was still going at 1O:30 =
p m, sheriff's Sgt. Gretchen Hurley said.
"Our past experience with the rave groups, the problem has not been with the party-goers themselves, our problem comes from just the=
 volume of them,'' Hurley said.
The California Highway Patrol said CHP officers and sheriff's deputies were ticketing illegalIy-parked vehicles.

---------------------------------3749238273812--

Precedence: bulk

This "What Is A DJ?" subject got me to thinking about my experiences as a
worship leader in a fundimentalist church (timewise, 7 years ago).  It was
my job, as with others worship leaders, to play the guitar and lead a
gathering of the faithful in song.  Every friday night I'd play in a band to
an audience of 2000 people.  Weds and Thurs I'd play solo to 30-70 folks and
once a month I'd go to prison to play for the inmates.  Anyway, all those
times I or the band never played with set lists.  We left the set list up to
God.   Somehow through a mechanism completely unknown to me, I (or the band
leader on Fri) would pick songs out on the fly (we knew hundreds) in the
right order to cause overwhelming emotional release.  Often I would enter a
trance state and when i came out people would be crying in joy, prophesing,
speaking in tongues, or dancing like crazy (it was a rock church).  I never
knew how it was going to come out, but if I prayed a lot (prepared my heart)
the effect was sure to be dramatic.

Anyway, that was a long time ago, but I was wondering, Is that was DJ's
do?

- PT

--
< Purple Tiger (ptiger@crl.com) >
            Be careful, its a vegan eat vegan world out there.

On Mon, 17 Jul 1995 ptiger@crl.com (Purple Tiger) said: 
 
 
>This "What Is A DJ?" subject got me to thinking about my experiences as a 

>worship leader in a fundimentalist church (timewise, 7 years ago).  It was
my  
>job, as with others worship leaders, to play the guitar and lead a
gathering of  
>the faithful in song.  Every friday night I'd play in a band to an
audience of  
>2000 people.  Weds and Thurs I'd play solo to 30-70 folks and once a month
I'd  
>go to prison to play for the inmates.  Anyway, all those times I or the
band  
>never played with set lists.  We left the set list up to God.   Somehow
through  
>a mechanism completely unknown to me, I (or the band leader on Fri) would
pick  
>songs out on the fly (we knew hundreds) in the right order to cause  
>overwhelming emotional release.  Often I would enter a trance state and
when i  
>came out people would be crying in joy, prophesing, speaking in tongues,
or  
>dancing like crazy (it was a rock church).  I never knew how it was going
to  
>come out, but if I prayed a lot (prepared my heart) the effect was sure to
be  
>dramatic. 
> 
>Anyway, that was a long time ago, but I was wondering, Is that was DJ's
do? 
 
In a very real sense I would say that you are correct. I've never been a
well-known dj or anything, but one party I played at it seemed as though
something took me over. It was like one minute, I was just playing killer
music but the next minute I looked up and saw the crowd, dancing and
cheering to what I was playing. That does something to you right there,
realizing that people are tuning in to what you are playing. I felt this
oneness with the crowd, feeling what they were feeling except building on
it with the music I was playing. It felt as though the crowd radiated this
intense energy everywhere, and feeling that made me more intense. It was
like a circuit of electricity in a sense, this circle of pure, primal
energy washing over everyone. I lost myself completely for a long time,
just keeping the energy escalating. It is one of the most powerful, almost
religious experiences I have ever had. One of my friends later on told me
that when he looked at me behind the 1200's he saw this intensity in my
eyes that he hadn't seen b4. I will never forget that ever... 
-- 
Christopher Silveira 
a.k.a. eric longfellow (the lost dj) 
Junior Dragon       -==(UDIC)==- 
csil@hooked.net            
http://www.hooked.net:80/users/csil/ 
- "...and mine eyes were lit by the light of an alien sun."

My computer tells me that on Mon, 17 Jul 1995, mr bill shared:

> Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 15:03:34 -0400 (EDT)

> Subject: Re: Alcatraz on less than 100 grand a day! ;)
> 
> 
> I was at Alcatraz just last week. It cost us $9 each to take the ferry 
> over, and then we could return on any ferry we wanted at 45 minute 
> intervals. It looks like a good site, but there is no way you could just 
> walk in and set up shop in a prohibited area without being noticed. There 
> was security all over when I was there. As I understand it, the island is 
> still "technically" Federal property, until it's restored, and then it 
> might become a state park or something. I know this, because they told us 
> if we took home a piece of the "rock" (literally), then we were 
> stealing/vandalizing federal property.
> 
> ---mr.bill   :)

	I'm sure it wasn't as much as $9 for the ferry when we went, but 
I think that was around December; prices may have risen, or they might 
charge more during the summer.
	According to the ranger I talked to, there were eight rangers on 
the island during the day to act as tour guides (and provide security, of 
course).  It certainly didn't seem like they were "all over".  It was 
easy to get out of sight of them and the other tourists.  Trying to lead 
a bunch of people at once into a prohibited area, or failing to be 
cautious and keep hidden would likely get you noticed, but done properly 
it seemed quite possible to me.  Perhaps after this discussion others 
will visit the island and provide more feedback.

			*** Starchild ***
