This is Zheam ibn Ismail,

I wanted to clear up a few things especially to Brian:

First of all, I didn't sub and unsub from the list just to post my message
about my new release.  I have several email accounts and they get flooded
from time to time.  I'm seriously offended by Brian rush to judgement. The
reason why I recently subscribe is because I moving back to SF this fall and
wanted to no more about the current dance scene there.

Second, if anyone feel I'm abusing this list I apologize.  The only reason I
post what I did is not to make a cheap adveritsment or sale but just to
inform people of my new release as an independent artist.  There is not enough
people on this list to make an impact on my profits.  I only offered them to
go to those stores and listen to them for themselves instead of reading through
self-hyped dance magazines and posts by other people.  Nothing else.

And last, I'm work months and months releasing this 12" through my own channels
and anyone who been there know it ain't easy.   Please don't turn my hard work
Brian or Ellen, into one of your frivilous personal post. I worked to hard for
this, show some respect.....


Zheam ibn Ismail

a frenzy.  I really dug those records with the serated edges.

from a firedancer added to the pagan ritual feel of the evening and helped
break up the darkness of the night.  Didn't see the moon, but there were
plenty of stars, and a couple of UFOs disguised as airplanes.

Environmental Defense Fund
Action Alert -- URGENT

To:       EDF Activists
From:     Bill Roberts, EDF Legislative Dir.
RE:       S. 851, Wetlands Protection
Date:     July 17, 1995

    The dirtiest section of the industry drafted House "dirty water bill" has
resurfaced in the Senate in the form of the so-called Wetlands Regulatory
Reform Act of 1995, S. 851.  We urge you to add your voice to a nationwide
wetlands call-in day scheduled for Tuesday July 18 to help derail this latest
attack against wetlands protection.

    Wetlands provide habitat or food supply for 80% of all commercial fish,
naturally filter out pollution from water sources, absorb floodwaters, and
provide critical habitat for all waterfowl and hundreds of rare species.  The
United States has already lost half of its wetlands.

   If enacted, S.851 would:

    * Define 60% to 80% of wetlands out of existence.  S. 851 would set
    standards for wetland definition that have been discredited by the
    prestigious National Academy of Sciences.  For example, it would
    exclude many wetlands flooded even for months at a time because they
    are flooded in the winter or early spring, but not in the drier summer.
    According to these standards, S. 851's "unwetlands" will include vast
    portions of widely recognized wetlands such as Florida's Everglades, the
    Great Dismal Swamp in Virginia and North Carolina, and numerous
    areas bordering trout streams in the west.

    * Provide blanket exclusions from protective regulations for the few
    wetlands that do manage to survive S.851's definitional tricks.  For
    example, the entire oil-rich state of Alaska would be exempt from all
    wetland regulation.  Additionally, any wetland altered for any
    agricultural or forestry purpose, including grazing, would also be
    excluded outright.  This includes most of the forested wetlands of the
    south, the critical waterfowl breeding grounds of the midwest, and
    critical wetlands included in the San Francisco Bay Delta area.

    * Severely restrict protection for those few wetlands that survive
    both S.851's definition and exclusion hatchets.  Of the wetlands
    remaining, only those that serve as "critical habitat" for wildlife larger
    than 10 acres would receive roughly the current level of protection.
    Consequently, wetlands critical for flood protection or water quality
    could automatically lose protection.

   Contact your Senators on Tuesday July 18th and strongly urge them to
support wetlands protection by opposing S.851.  Contact the Capitol operator
at (202) 224-3121 to reach your Senators. Once you've completed your calls,
please contact EDF by email at Congress@edf.org to let us know you took
action.

Between the great music and the great people,  sunset turned out to be one of
the best parties in quite a while.  I did manage to speak with the sherif at
around 11:30 after all the tickets had been written. He had no complaints
about the people or the party
just the parking,  but given the limited parking if you carpool a 33.00
parking bill for a party as good as Sunset with no admission fee turns out to
be a great bargain.
One MAJOR DIAPPOINTMENT was the treatment of the the beautiful beach.
What  is the deal people?????  Bottles cans all kinds of crap all
over!!!!!!!!!
Your cleaning person is off on the weekends so please take out what you
brought in, the beach is not a club there is no payed staff picking up your
trash!!!!!!!
Most folks of course were quite considerate but those bad apples.....
Please if you see anyone leaving thier trash behind remind them how great it
was to share the vibe with them and "looks like you forgot some of your
things" .
Sorry to rant but after the full moon and Sunset I hope we can improve.
PLUR 
greg

Well this would have to be a very private party.  I mean if you have 100+ 
ravers going on the island, there is a big chance you are gonns get 
caught.  Heck, come to think about it, I am pretty sure it wouldn't 
work, for this simple reason.  A lot of the ravers I know are...hmm... 
shall we say unique in their appearance.  If 100+ ravers went onto the 
island, I would think that they ferry people would realize...hmmm.. 
"those strange guys never came back".  Now I have never had the chance to 
visit alacatraz, but I would imaging that you pass through some sort of 
counting device (like the turnstiles at Disneyland).  It would really 
make sense from a security standpoint.  Correct me if I am wrong, but if 
I wanted to know if people were still on the island at the end of the 
day, that is what I would do.  Of course, you could always borrow a boat 
and ferry people to an isolated part of the island youself at night.  I 
mean if the sound from the sound system won't carry (which I am not so 
sure about) then a small boat engine should be nothing in comparison.  I 
guess that is just my take on the situation.  Hope to have been of some 
help...

	-Christian

why not do Angel island ?  you can legally just, like, sail there
and legally camp there, so the problem of spearheading an entry is
solved.  you would have to scout out a discreet place to crank it
up and party down, but that should be do-able.  the problem with
Alcatraz is just mere presence will get you busted, and probably
committing a misdemeanor at that, so they could just open up the
old prison and toss you in :)

     KKSF did the first amplified concert there a few months ago so I'm 
     sure it's possible to hold a permitted rave there.  Evidentally 
     there's one or two sheltered beaches where the winds aren't too bad 
     but I've never been there myself.  Also rangers do a search on the 
     island after the last ferry for stragglers 'cause I had a friend who 
     missed the ferry last year.
     
     If an industrious person has the time, money, and energy to pursue 
     this--much less anything!--it's a better bet to host a rave on Angel 
     Island than to get a citation from the feds for doing a renegade on 
     Alcatraz, IMHO. 
     
     Cheers,
     Diane

Purple Tiger spoke to us thusly:
>

>when they were making a few thousand (at least) on the parking tickets.  Did

Hey, if this is the worst problem that occurred there with the law, I'd say
that's a pretty good sign of the local authorities attitude towards raves in
general.  I mean, if they wanted to they could make it much more difficult
than they have.  For instance, some of you may not have noticed yet but it
seems that certain people are taking ILLEGAL SUBSTANCES with them to raves.
Some people are even getting them there <gasp>.  Now, if the police really
wanted to give us any grief, that would be a perfect reason to start
something at a party.  I think what it comes down to is that most police
officers really are into just making sure that people aren't harmed against
their will (i.e. their rights are respected).  Sure, they have to ticket
parked cars because that's a pretty blatant breach of the law, but they do
let an awful lot of things slide that are illegal as long as no one is
getting hurt.

Subject: Physics & Raving
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Speaking of Physics:
>
>A few days ago, I read in the paper how scientists have created a new 
>form of matter.  By using lazers and magnetic fields, a group of 
>atoms were cooled down (their motion frozen) to a temperature which was
>as close to absolute zero as ever achieved.  As the atoms entered this
>state of compelte stillness, the quantum mechanical waveforms that defined
>them expanded, overlapping one another, until reaching a point where these
>waveforms become equivalent to each other.

Well, now, this seems like an appropriate time for ol' Jake to put in his
two cents.  I remember reading about this same thing about a year or two ago
and being thoroughly amazed.  If anyone _ever_ tries to tell me that science
is dull and boring, then I tell them to have a look at quantum physics.
There are things there that are more magical then you'll ever read in a
storybook.  
        I was never interested in Physics until my senior year of high
school, mostly because I was totally ignorant of it.  After I started
learning about it, though, I was hooked.  I don't know how many other people
on this list have studied physics or at least dabbled in it, but I know for
sure that Brian has (being an Engineer and all).  Brian, I'd like to know if
your interest in the subject stems from the same place that mine does or
not, but I bet that it does at least in part.
        As opposed to people in many branches of science, I've found that
people involved in physics have a very strong regard for nature and
spirituality.   This is because you deal with it on such a primal level in
day to day life.  When you can see the fundamental tickings of the universal
clock so upclose, it is hard to feel that all of this is just a big
accident, that we're heading from nowhere to nowhere.  
        To be an effective physicist, especially in electronics or quantum
mechanics, you have to stretch what your mind is capable of believing.
There are lots of things that happen that defy what common sense would tell
you, for example that in certain instances electrons know that you're
watching them and behave differently.
        Now, tell me that you hear that and say, "oh yeah. physicists can't
appreciate spirituality."
        I've found that most physicists have a _very_ deep regard for nature
and what it can do that is very similar to that I've found in a lot of
rave-goers.  They recognize the interconnectedness of the whole world and
humanity's place within that chain.
        One example that comes to mind is a physicist I read about recently.
He was responsible for discovering Josephson junctions in the '60's, an
important discovery in quantum physics.  He dropped out of the scientific
community, feeling it was too stifling, and has since moved on to include
psychic phenomena and other less accepted ideas in his work.  Specifically,
he deals a lot with the way in which music and nature are intertwined, and
the way humanity uses that energy.
        Someone take that man to a rave!

Jake Reichert			|  Your talk is so terribly tired/

Jack wonders:
> I don't know how many other people
> on this list have studied physics or at least dabbled in it,

Check out http://taz.hyperreal.com/raves/spirit/technoshamanism/
for a couple of articles on raving & physics.  One of them is a transcript
of a talk by Ovid Jacob, an ex-sfraver who is a Physicist at Stanford.
This talk was given at a few raves (including a Friends&Family) with a
backdrop of ambient music, and once with Dubtribe.  Ovid is very well
respected in his field (particle physics) and has told me that some of
his best ideas have come to him while trancing out at raves.  He even
dedicated one of his papers to the Albert Hoffman (among others).

>         To be an effective physicist, especially in electronics or quantum
> mechanics, you have to stretch what your mind is capable of believing.

Don't forget Relativity.  Weird shit happens when you start seeing things
in four dimensions.

>         Now, tell me that you hear that and say, "oh yeah. physicists can't
> appreciate spirituality."

Many of them don't.  The field requires a high degree of specialization if
you want to be able to make a significant contribution.  This was why I
chose not to go on to graduate school.

>         One example that comes to mind is a physicist I read about recently.
> He was responsible for discovering Josephson junctions in the '60's, an
> important discovery in quantum physics.  He dropped out of the scientific
> community, feeling it was too stifling, and has since moved on to include
> psychic phenomena and other less accepted ideas in his work.

This sounds similar to Jack Sarfatti.  You might want to check out his
Physics Consciousness Research Group home page at:

http://www.hia.com/hia/pcr/

Getting back to raving:  I've always found the mathematical nature of
techno music to be very analogous to physics equations.  The way
sounds are used oftem speaks to us about fractals, frequencies, waveforms,
and spacetime.  This is true of much music, but *especially* techno,
which is music that is primarily *about* the structure of sound.


Lee

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jul 18 19:55:34 1995

Received: from manual3.com (uucp@localhost) by aimnet.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with UUCP id TAA10613 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue, 18 Jul 1995 19:53:15 -0700
Message-Id: <199507190253.TAA10613@aimnet.com>
Date: 18 Jul 1995 19:44:27 -0700
From: "Nathan Moser" <nathan_moser@manual3.com>
Subject: Music labeling & physical r
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Reply to:   Music labeling & physical raving
On the music labeling:
House, trance, techno, etc. are just names we use to help 
us figure out what type of sounds we like. We'll make up 
new ones when we get bored. 

I'm finishing up a book called "Trance and Music," by Gilbert 
Rouget. From the catalog description, it seemed like some 
sort of psychoacoustic guide to inducing trance states. 
Rather than turn me on to some sure-fire tricks to improve 
the music I've been trying to record, the book goes into a 
broad-based anthropological dissertation on the trance music 
of different cultures. The main theme of the work - backed 
up with empirical evidence to a fault - is that there is no 
discernible set of musical characteristics that elicit a trance 
response. Some trance music is purely vocal, some is vocal 
and instrumental, and it turns out that very little of the 
world's trance music is purely instrumental. It can be played 
fast, slow, or with a modulated tempo. The rhythmic patterns 
can vary every bit as much as the pitch and melody. It seems 
like people learn to trance to the music, rather than stumble 
upon music that causes a trance state. 

On the quantum mechanical implications of raving:
Quantum mechanics is just an analogy we use to help us 
understand the things around us. We'll contrive a new branch 
of physics when the universe gets bored with us.

Somewhat ironically, raving has helped me understand physics 
much more than the other way 'round. When I was in school, I 
became so disgusted with the quantum courses that I seriously considered bagging
my physics major in favor of music or 
literature. At the time, though, that would've meant leaving 
Harvey Mudd, and I guess the economics of the situation won 
out. I still think it's an ugly theory, but raving has helped 
me to lose most of the ego and objectivist hangups that rankle 
so hard with quantum. I did like your particle/vibe unification 
theory, Lee. :-)

The real problem arises when people lose sight of the fact that 
science is just a tool for understanding. Suddenly we're ready to 
kill, mutilate, and destroy "in the name of science." I guess that's 
another sense in which science and spirituality can merge. Perhaps 
that's reason enough to avoid making rave too much of a "cause."

take care!
-nate


PS - there's at least one other Mudd physics alum on this list, but he's 
prolly having too much fun as a house-luv'n thru-the-week-partying poet 
to ever admit he went to school with such a bunch of geeks. :-)

I'm going to pontificate about science and spirituality for
a bit, since this is a thread which I find quite
interesting...  Feel free to skip this message if you don't
feel the same way. :)

lxfogel@srv.PacBell.com (Lee Fogel) wrote:
> Jake wonders:
> >         Now, tell me that you hear that and say, "oh yeah. physicists can't
> > appreciate spirituality."
> 
> Many of them don't.  The field requires a high degree of specialization if
> you want to be able to make a significant contribution.  This was why I
> chose not to go on to graduate school.

You're right.. A lot of physicists don't understand and
appreciate spirituality.  As a physics student (btw, I just
passed my PhD thesis defense today!  yay!!!!!!), I think
that's a real shame.

Physics is the study of the physical world and its
properties.  It's a search for the underlying order behind
the universe.  To me, this has a spiritual flavor, although
some physicists would disagree.

In some sense, the scientific method may seem to be the
antithesis of spirituality.  However, it is important to
realize that the process of science involves much more than
the blind following of logical induction after logical
induction.  Some ideas come from great, intuitive leaps (as
symbolized by the fictional apple which fell on Netwon's
head).  These moments of enlightenment are the result a
tapping into an unconscious power within us, and a deep
reflection on the nature of the universe as a whole.

In my life, I've come to the conclusion that such progress
is most easily made as a part of an overall search for
harmony, balance, and meaning in life..  This is,
essentially, a spiritual quest.  

> Getting back to raving:  I've always found the mathematical nature of
> techno music to be very analogous to physics equations.  The way
> sounds are used oftem speaks to us about fractals, frequencies, waveforms,
> and spacetime.  This is true of much music, but *especially* techno,
> which is music that is primarily *about* the structure of sound.

yeah...  Me too.  I find myself making an analogy with
abstract mathematical systems moreso than physics
equations..  Take a 4 on the floor and add an acid squiggle
which doesn't repeat at the same rate as the basic rhythm,
and it's hard not to think of group theory and modular
arithmetic.. :)

-Sho
--
sho@physics.purdue.edu <<-- finger this account to find out what I'm
                            having for lunch!

<A HREF="http://physics.purdue.edu/~sho/homepage.html">Sho Kuwamoto</A>.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jul 18 23:15:15 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id XAA23060; Tue, 18 Jul 1995 23:15:15 -0700
Received: from netcom12.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id XAA23055; Tue, 18 Jul 1995 23:15:11 -0700
Received: from localhost by netcom12.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id XAA29621; Tue, 18 Jul 1995 23:13:52 -0700
Message-Id: <199507190613.XAA29621@netcom12.netcom.com>
To: Sho Kuwamoto <sho@hyperreal.com>
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Physics & Raving 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Tue, 18 Jul 95 22:03:10 PDT."
             <199507190503.WAA19617@taz.hyperreal.com> 
Date: Tue, 18 Jul 95 23:13:51 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> You're right.. A lot of physicists don't understand and
> appreciate spirituality.  As a physics student (btw, I just
> passed my PhD thesis defense today!  yay!!!!!!), I think
> that's a real shame.

Maybe physics is the only spirituality some physicists need. Who are
you (and who am I or anyone else) to decide on what form of
spirituality one needs to make better sense of the
world/life/universe/existence? Isn't that the ultimate point of 
spirituality, not the way it is attained/practiced?

Or must one ascribe to some fuzzy mumbo jumbo mystical explanation of
reality to be "spiritual"? And therefore, in your eyes, most 
physicists are not spiritual. ...

Sometimes I feel like the human mind has a special "bullshit" cortex
that feels pleasure when you can hold a deep belief about reality based
on "faith" alone, and that this "faith" is what people are calling
"spirituality" rather than the actions/practices/beliefs of the
religion/faith/etc. All questions bottom out at the articles of faith,
and these articles are held as being dogmatically true. 

Look at Christianity for a good example on this one -- certain
practices that we might find  innocuous or based on personal choice
(drugs, sexual orientation/interest/activity, abortion) are "of the
devil" with Christians. So you simply don't sit down with a Christian
and discuss the pros/cons of, say, abortion. Abortion is of the devil,
and you don't argue with the devil. 

Likewise, physicists/scientists bottom out their explanations on
"rationality" and the scientific method -- that parameters and their
effects can be individually controlled. Unfortunately, nature rarely 
works from a few small, well-behaved interactions, but rather, Billions
and Billions of fuzzy, random underlying interactions create an
emergent whole that cannot be parametrized or explained by a
rationalistic decomposition of reality into subcomponents. Nonetheless,
many scientists cannot let go of "rationality" as a method of
explaining reality. Rationalism is their faith.

> Physics is the study of the physical world and its
> properties.  It's a search for the underlying order behind
> the universe.  To me, this has a spiritual flavor, although
> some physicists would disagree.

I agree. I think most physicists would agree.

> Some ideas come from great, intuitive leaps (as
> symbolized by the fictional apple which fell on Netwon's
> head).  These moments of enlightenment are the result a
> tapping into an unconscious power within us, and a deep
> reflection on the nature of the universe as a whole.

Sounds like that "faith" talking here. Yeah, you can ascribe it to
"unconscious power" and other mystic mumbo-jumbo, but sometimes the
time is ripe for a new idea to come into play, and all you really need
is a bunch of related discoveries/findings/developments, the
appropriate social milieu to foster communication/collaboration, and a
small intuitive leap resulting from a synthesis of ideas, a right
place, and a right time.

Of course, "reality" can be described through a variety of domains, so
one might look at the social/communicative/zeitgeist view I put forward
above in the "energy domain" and come up with a theory of "unconscious
power". SImilarly, you can look at any object in the
frequency/spacial-frequency or time/space-time domains and come up with
unique explanations for behavior in each domain.

I think it's probably most important to be able to take in lots of 
perspectives at the same time, and that's where empathy and
enlightenment come in....

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

the BSP thing is really not supposed to be that big a deal.  I hope
nobody here would object if someone here has something to offer they
want us to know about.  I *want* to know about these.

What I don't want, and most others don't either I think, is misuse of
this list for self-aggrandizement or profit.  Subscribing just so you
can post a promo fits that definition.  Subscribing so you can post
a promo and then stick around and participate in the list would be fine
with me.  

I also object to the idea that posting something here is like some big
favor that maybe we don't deserve or something.  We're friends here,
we're interested in each other projects and we want to know.  Doesn't
need any mo 'tude than that, word.

phred

Niels P. Mayer writes:
> Sho Kuwamoto writes:
> > You're right.. A lot of physicists don't understand and
> > appreciate spirituality. [...]
> 
> Maybe physics is the only spirituality some physicists need. [...]
> 
> Or must one ascribe to some fuzzy mumbo jumbo mystical explanation of
> reality to be "spiritual"? And therefore, in your eyes, most 
> physicists are not spiritual. ...

I'm not saying that the scientists at Fermilab should throw
away their accelerators and stare into crystals all day..
Believing in untrue things does not make you spiritual.
Spirituality is the development of the self.

> > Some ideas come from great, intuitive leaps (as
> > symbolized by the fictional apple which fell on Netwon's
> > head).  These moments of enlightenment are the result a
> > tapping into an unconscious power within us, and a deep
> > reflection on the nature of the universe as a whole.
> 
> Sounds like that "faith" talking here. Yeah, you can ascribe it to
> "unconscious power" and other mystic mumbo-jumbo, but sometimes the
> time is ripe for a new idea to come into play, and all you really need
> is a bunch of related discoveries/findings/developments, the
> appropriate social milieu to foster communication/collaboration, and a
> small intuitive leap resulting from a synthesis of ideas, a right
> place, and a right time.

Listen... I didn't mean to offend you with the use of the
words "unconscious power".  If I did, I apologize.  I'm not
saying that scientific developments come to us through some
kind of psychic link with the big electron in the sky!  By
"unconscious power" I didn't mean to imply that there was
anything mystical going on.  

What I was trying to get at is the process by which our
minds arrive at scientific insight.  Sometimes, it comes
through a series of logical deductions.  Other times, it
comes from an "aha" moment, in which we see what the answer
MUST be.  Of course, this insight is not useful unless we
can back it up our hypotheses using the scientific method.

I'm saying that we spend years and years absorbing it
all... trying to figure out how things work.. (this is the
deep reflections on the universe part) and that our mind is
somehow able to use that information to make leaps that we
sometimes can't explain right away.. "Aha!" we say, "I KNOW
that this must be the solution!"   

To me, these aha moments.. these moments of lucidity in
which everything becomes clear.. have aspects of
spirituality.. it's like an epiphany. 

-Sho

sho@physics.purdue.edu <<-- finger this account to find out what I'm
                            having for lunch!

<A HREF="http://physics.purdue.edu/~sho/homepage.html">Sho Kuwamoto</A>.

Sho:
> > You're right.. A lot of physicists don't understand and
> > appreciate spirituality.  As a physics student (btw, I just
> > passed my PhD thesis defense today!  yay!!!!!!), I think
> > that's a real shame.

Niels:
> Maybe physics is the only spirituality some physicists need. Who are
> you (and who am I or anyone else) to decide on what form of
> spirituality one needs to make better sense of the
> world/life/universe/existence? Isn't that the ultimate point of 
> spirituality,

I think the point Sho & I were making was that many physicists don't
see physics as a way to make sense of the entire realm of 
life/existence/reality/etc.  Usually, physics is seen merely as a
tool for explaining how a particle decays, or how a star is formed.
Just like christians who use their religion mainly to justify
their version of morality, or folks who rave just to get high and
hang out with friends - such a specific focus ignores the bigger
picture, which as you say, is the ultimate point of spirituality.

For example; in certain circles, theories of physics are merging
with theories of consciousness, time travel, alternate realities,
parallell universes, etc.  Most mainstream physicists have a dim
view of the legitimacy of extending physics into these realms.
Why?  Because they still think think that physics must reside in
the realm of more "rational" and observable phenonema.

> Likewise, physicists/scientists bottom out their explanations on
> "rationality" and the scientific method --

Only the less spiritual ones. :)  Actually, the forefronts of
even well established theories like QM and Relativity
challenge rational thinking.  Or at least they redefine what we
mean by rational thought.  There are paradoxes that defy logic.  
And once the mere existence of an observer affecting the outcome
of an experiment, the "scientific method" itself gets redefined.

> many scientists cannot let go of "rationality" as a method of
> explaining reality. Rationalism is their faith.

There's a big difference between rationality that continues to
evolve into areas once considered to be irrational, and a faith
in a fixed concept (i.e. God).

> I think it's probably most important to be able to take in lots of 
> perspectives at the same time, and that's where empathy and
> enlightenment come in....

I agree.  Physics appeals to me because it has the potential to
explain many things on the way to the *big* questions.  There's
something inconsistant (to me) about a belief system that claims
to tell my why I exist, but doesn't even attempt to explain why an
apple falls to the ground.


Lee

 My own opinion developed while I was in chemistry grad school is that I
observed two major types of scientists ( AT LEAST )... I'll call these the
technocrats and the dreamers - for lack of better labels.. Although both
groups were involved in studying science the technocrats usually plodded
along day to day building on other people's ideas and adding their own
contributions without any major insights. These people usually thought along
well developed channels and added only small increments to the overall body
of scientific knowledge. For them science was usually a job and not 
particularly a spiritual forum... 

  This contrasted with the dreamers. For this second group science was 
often a spiritual form of work. They immersed themselves in it and very 
often used intuitive insights to make "leaps of reason". They created 
ideas where none had existed before. These people were excited by their
work and were exciting to be around....

I'll give you 3 guesses as to which group was larger... and 2 of the guesses
don't count... many many of the famous early quantum phyicists fell into
the latter group (IMHO) and often wrote books on spirituality and/or the
meaning of life and had great interest in philosophy and arts. Many of the
scientists who simply plod through the system and then move into defense
contracts making a slightly better laser weapon or a better missle guidance
system often fall into the former...  Talk about generalizations :) 


But then I've noticed the same two groups in the arts... one copies other
peoples work adding their own small insights while the other group creates
stunning new styles of art by applying deep intuitive insights....

Oh well there seems to be a human condition buried in here somewhere...
While Michelangelo lay painting the Sistine there were 1000's of people
simply groveling to make it from day to day ( or wine bottle to wine
bottle ).....

My $.02

Mike

 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 19 11:19:50 1995

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 11:17:40 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Michael E. Clay" <meclay@netcom.com>
Subject: UNITY - science, religion, raves
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9507191031.A2471-0100000@netcom11>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


All this tread about science etc. has brought me to something that attracted
me to " serious ravers " ( assuming it's possible to have serious FUN )

Science:
  I think Lee nicely summarized that the ultimate place for science is as
a methodology for unifying the whole of existence. And it's agreed that
many scientists don't use it this way....

Religion:
  When I consider religion, I assume the same - it should be a force to
unify all existence. Too often it's not.. For example Christians worship
a male god with no others... my line of questioning was always: Does god
have a penis ?  Answer ( after much confusion ) : I guess so - he's a man
and we're in his image.  My next question: So what does he use it for ?
Is there a Mrs. GOD ?  ( Try this line of questioning sometime - it's
especially amusing to watch young females struggle with it )  Bottom line
for me:  I have little use for a religion that ignores the beauty and
contribution that the female and/or female principle makes to the whole
of existence... there can be no true unity without it.

Raving:
  Many people go to raves to simply party and hang out. Often it makes little
difference whether it's a club rave or an underground. They are simply there
to be part of the scene or where the action is..  On the other hand, I was
both surprised and pleased when I found a group of people that experienced
raving as a means to unity - both self unity and group unity. Those whose
experience leads them to realize that it is fun to be high, aware and in
unity with both yourself and those around you. It is an expression of
ecstatic love to feel yourself moving to the beat of music and then to 
expand this experience to realize that you have become part of a larger whole
also moving to the beat of the music. This unity when experienced can take
us beyond our normal limits and move us into a state of ecstatic bliss...
exactly like the samadhi bliss state the masters describe when there is 
complete realization that all things are one... music has been used 
throughout history to help induce this unity state ( as have drugs, scents,
sex and visuals ).... raving in its purist form seems to be another 
manifestation of people seeking this unified state....

  And the beauty of it all is that during the experience the less thinking
that occurs and the more "doing/being" - the better the experience of unity.
ie this is not something to think about as much as it is to do.... so
let's get out there and smile, communicate and dance... these are special
times we are in so be sure to enjoy them.....

Just some ramblings from your local mad chemist/artist

Mike

 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

Subject: Re: Physics & Raving
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: ScoMail 3.0.Bd
MIME-Version: 1.0
Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 11:51:18 -0700 (PDT)
Message-ID:  <9507191151.aa20596@andrewk.pdev.sco.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 
	As a (former) physics undergrad I've watched the physics back and forth 
with some interest, but I do have to comment on this:

> For example; in certain circles, theories of physics are merging
> with theories of consciousness, time travel, alternate realities,
> parallell universes, etc.  Most mainstream physicists have a dim
> view of the legitimacy of extending physics into these realms.
> Why?  Because they still think think that physics must reside in
> the realm of more "rational" and observable phenonema.

	Physics, by definition, concerns itself with observables.  The purpose 
of theory is to predict observables.  As the observations become more detached 
from day to day reality, the theories become more abstract and 
counter-intuitive, but nonetheless they are still only there to "explain" the 
observable universe.

	This is not to say that many theories do not have a philosophical basis, 
or that I think they shouldn't be used as models for things other than the 
physical world.  However, I think many physicists are a bit wary of the 
popularization of theory because they don't want to have to concern themselves 
with popular philosophical or spiritual implications when they create/extend a 
theory.  That idea is anathema to modern science...  look what happened to 
Galileo.

Andrew

PS he was jailed for making a theory by observation rather than religion.
AK
-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

>It's not that uncommon among DJ's to not understand musical structure.

I understand, I used to live with a fairly good DJ who didn't know barely
anything about musical structure.  He has since started composing and is
learning more all the time, but at first, it was wierd how much he did'nt know.

 
>Almost every time I go out these days I hear a DJ mix together two tracks 
>that are off measure.  House and techno tends to stay around 8 measure 
>progressions and it sounds funky when a DJ isn't aware of this and drops 
>in a track on the wrong measure.  Just last weekend my partner and I 
>played at a party at a friends house where the DJ mixed two tracks which 
>were on the wrong beat in the measure!  This guy was somebody who was 
>getting flown all over the country to spin and he can't even figure out 
>where in the measure he is!
>
>Oh well.  I'm not a classicly trained musician myself but that's rediculous!
>
>-robert

I've heard good DJ's do this and if done correctly it can add to the mix.
I've sometimes dropped the needle into the middle of a song and got mixed up
in my head where the "one count" is supposed to be, and the song sounds
totally different.  I know it is possible to pull-off mixing on the off
count, but maybe this guy just didn't do it good enough.  I'm not trying to
argue or anything, I've just heard it done, and sometimes it sounds really
good. IMHO.

Rick

        Reply to:   RE>UNITY - science, religion, raves

Deep, especially the part on the raves.  So very true...  On the religious
tip, several Christian groups are opening up the idea of GOD being a being
not necessarily a person male or female, as well as viewing other ways of
worship (in other words other religions) as a means of bringing unity and
harmony to themselves and their surrounding environment.  I know quite a few
Catholics who practice or observe many of the Zen Buddhist rites, I also know
quite a few people who incorporate traditional Native American or African
concepts, ideas, and prayers into their Christian worship.  It's not so much
as New Age movement (by the way I know several Native Americans offended by
the New Age movement), but rather an expansion of bringing themselves in
touch with their surroundings and themselves... I would say it's all good :>
RSB
RSB

--------------------------------------
Date: 7/19/95 11:27 AM
To: Robynn Battle
From: Michael E. Clay

All this tread about science etc. has brought me to something that attracted
me to " serious ravers " ( assuming it's possible to have serious FUN )

Science:
  I think Lee nicely summarized that the ultimate place for science is as
a methodology for unifying the whole of existence. And it's agreed that
many scientists don't use it this way....

Religion:
  When I consider religion, I assume the same - it should be a force to
unify all existence. Too often it's not.. For example Christians worship
a male god with no others... my line of questioning was always: Does god
have a penis ?  Answer ( after much confusion ) : I guess so - he's a man
and we're in his image.  My next question: So what does he use it for ?
Is there a Mrs. GOD ?  ( Try this line of questioning sometime - it's
especially amusing to watch young females struggle with it )  Bottom line
for me:  I have little use for a religion that ignores the beauty and
contribution that the female and/or female principle makes to the whole
of existence... there can be no true unity without it.

Raving:
  Many people go to raves to simply party and hang out. Often it makes little
difference whether it's a club rave or an underground. They are simply there
to be part of the scene or where the action is..  On the other hand, I was
both surprised and pleased when I found a group of people that experienced
raving as a means to unity - both self unity and group unity. Those whose
experience leads them to realize that it is fun to be high, aware and in
unity with both yourself and those around you. It is an expression of
ecstatic love to feel yourself moving to the beat of music and then to 
expand this experience to realize that you have become part of a larger whole
also moving to the beat of the music. This unity when experienced can take
us beyond our normal limits and move us into a state of ecstatic bliss...
exactly like the samadhi bliss state the masters describe when there is 
complete realization that all things are one... music has been used 
throughout history to help induce this unity state ( as have drugs, scents,
sex and visuals ).... raving in its purist form seems to be another 
manifestation of people seeking this unified state....

  And the beauty of it all is that during the experience the less thinking
that occurs and the more "doing/being" - the better the experience of unity.
ie this is not something to think about as much as it is to do.... so
let's get out there and smile, communicate and dance... these are special
times we are in so be sure to enjoy them.....

Just some ramblings from your local mad chemist/artist

Mike

 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

In article <199507190613.XAA29621@netcom12.netcom.com>,
"Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com> wrote:

> Sometimes I feel like the human mind has a special "bullshit" cortex
> that feels pleasure when you can hold a deep belief about reality based
> on "faith" alone, and that this "faith" is what people are calling
> "spirituality" rather than the actions/practices/beliefs of the
> religion/faith/etc. All questions bottom out at the articles of faith,
> and these articles are held as being dogmatically true. 

The bullshit cortex is quite amazing really.  Our minds seemed to be
designed/evolved (take your pick) to identify non-causal relationships. The
whole causality in reality bit is rather new to the human mindscape and
seems to be useful for a few things here and there. :-)  As a method of
thinking, causal analysis takes years and years to learn while we all do
non-causal analysis from the day we are born.

In my opinion, the human race has gotten a lot farther on non-causal
thinking that it has on causal. When you are chased by a tiger in the
jungle, the last thing you are thinking is A->B->C.  So, do not downgrade
the importance of non-causal thinking, or you may get eaten.

Ciao,

PT


--
< Purple Tiger (ptiger@crl.com) >
                   Rabbits are on the other side of God.

I find it interesting how our human condition seems to feel the need to 
make sense of everything.
 I find when I'm really involved in raving, my desire to make sense out 
of it deminishes.  I find that there is less need to make sense out of 
it, because raving is making so MUCH sense (sensations) to me.
So much so, that it seems that the making of sense is not happening, 
rather it feels more like the becoming sense, being sense. 
Does this make any sense? :)

:)
peter

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 20 11:41:29 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA07670; Thu, 20 Jul 1995 11:41:29 -0700
Received: from nova.unix.portal.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA07662; Thu, 20 Jul 1995 11:41:26 -0700
Received: from jobe.shell.portal.com (jobe.shell.portal.com [156.151.3.4]) by nova.unix.portal.com (8.6.11/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA09656 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 20 Jul 1995 11:40:32 -0700
Received: (grigsby@localhost) by jobe.shell.portal.com (8.6.11/8.6.5) id LAA23679 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Thu, 20 Jul 1995 11:40:30 -0700
From: Grigsbeast <grigsby@shell.portal.com>
Message-Id: <199507201840.LAA23679@jobe.shell.portal.com>
Subject: Your Brane (Was Re: Physics and ...)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 11:40:29 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2656      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


What we like to think of as the "logical" part of our brain is 
probably a very (evolutionarily) recent development, and only
becomes necessary in a modern society.  Here's how it happened.

The Alice in Wonderland quote "What I tell you three times is
true" is basically the way our brain works.  The more we encounter
a chain of events, the more we link them together in our minds.
"OK, I ate the purple thing and got sick.  Thak ate the purple
thing and got sick.  Grog was drunk and ate it anyway, and he got
sick too."  This is valid reasoning, and everything from an
amoeba to a shark can do this.  It requires none of what we call
"conscious thought".  So why isn't it enough?

In a word: deception.  Most of the information we get about how the
world lives is second or third-hand, thanks to modern technology
like speech, writing, and more recently television, movies, radio,
and so on.

This information has been shaped, molded, cast, fired, and painted by
someone else -- someone responsible for making a profit on their
presentation, whether it be the latest Bruce Willis action-adventure,
a Disney film about a Native American woman who died of clap, or the
nine-o-clock news.  (And let's not forget the advertising embedded in
all of these.)  Therefore, their primary responsibility is to tell
you something you _want_ to hear, so you will choose to consume their
pseudo-experience instead of someone else's.

Because of this divorce of experience from reality, we can no longer
trust our senses to give us accurate information.  Sure, we know
_intellectually_ that TV isn't real, but our hindbrain doesn't know
that.  It sees these images of women caressing big cars, and the 
connection "expensive car = women" is reinforced, despite its lack of
grounding in any reality but the wishes of car manufacturers.

This is why I never watch television, rarely go see films, and don't
read the newspaper much -- because I know I can't trust my conscious,
logical forebrain to ride herd on my poor, deluded hindbrain.  I wish
my desires to be my own, and over time I'm finding some of them through
actually going out and _experiencing_ stuff.

I still read a lot, but I have some control over reading -- I can stop,
think, and choose.  TV and other real-time spectacles don't leave 
you that luxury.

Does this make sense to anyone?

// g

References:  Julian Jaynes, _The Origin of Consciousness and the Breakdown
of the Bicameral Mind_.  Raoul Vaneigem, _The Revolution of Everyday Life_.
Guy Debord, _Society of the Spectacle_.  The second is the easiest and most
fun to read, available anyplace that has a good anarchist/situationist section.

Grigsbeast speaks:
> In a word: deception.  Most of the information we get about how the
> world lives is second or third-hand, thanks to modern technology
> like speech, writing, and more recently television, movies, radio,
> and so on.

John, your predeliction for blaming the perceived evils of the 
universe on modern society is starting to get boring.  Reality will
always be illusory to a large degree.  You were being deceived from
the day your momma stuck a pacifier in your mouth.  The animal
kingdom has always used deception in courtship, territorial
displays, evasion from predators, hunting, etc.  Plants too.
Things are never what they seem.  Solids are really mostly empty space.
The moon is bigger than it looks.

> I still read a lot, but I have some control over reading -- I can stop,
> think, and choose.  TV and other real-time spectacles don't leave 
> you that luxury.

Since when?

> Does this make sense to anyone?

Sure it does.  In our neverending search for the truth, we often
end up deceiving ourselves.

I guess you don't allow yourself to dream or fantasize either.
Or do you think you are in control of those things?

Sometimes when I rave (here's where I twist this into relevancy)
a part of me starts to feel what a phony delusion this sense of
unity/vibe/oneness/harmony really is.  And for some reason, I
decide that it doesn't matter.  Absolute Truth must include
falseness; every path is real.  I wish you the best on yours.

Lee

>This is why I never watch television, rarely go see films, and don't
>read the newspaper much -- because I know I can't trust my conscious,
>logical forebrain to ride herd on my poor, deluded hindbrain.  I wish
>my desires to be my own, and over time I'm finding some of them through
>actually going out and _experiencing_ stuff.
>
>I still read a lot, but I have some control over reading -- I can stop,
>think, and choose.  TV and other real-time spectacles don't leave 
>you that luxury.
>
>Does this make sense to anyone?
>
>// g

It makes perfect sense.  I don't watch TV, and involve my self with as
little media as possible (never read the newspaper - never really have my
whole life).  I do read alot and spend much of my time reflecting and
working on my spirituality.  I've found that less media can greatly increase
a persons vibrational frequency.  I can now physically feel the vibrations
of a TV and am amazed at what it has the potential to do to a person....what
it is actually doing to people all over the planet.

Rick

At 10:12 AM 7/20/95, Peter Fogel wrote:
>I find it interesting how our human condition seems to feel the need to
>make sense of everything.
> I find when I'm really involved in raving, my desire to make sense out
>of it deminishes.  I find that there is less need to make sense out of
>it, because raving is making so MUCH sense (sensations) to me.
>So much so, that it seems that the making of sense is not happening,
>rather it feels more like the becoming sense, being sense.
>Does this make any sense? :)
>
>:)
>peter
        very much so...i'm so thankful that i stubled upon things like the
Tao te Ching and the concept of thing just being 'as they are' (in western
terms i call it 'shit happens' ;) and i think that i used to think too much
(especially about how and why i was thinking about thinking...) the
revelations i got both from raving and reading about zen and taoism allowed
my mind to hop out of it's own self-imposed labyrinth and have that
'dancing no-mind' sensation.
        now, if i could only do it at home at will...
                brad

ps-->once you realize that the most beautiful and important things in what
we call 'reality' are inarticulable and not easily quantized by things like
'rationality' and/or 'logic' you can begin to simply be and enjoy...well,
IMHO at least :)

   The big show this weekend is in Sacramento - Funky Tekno Tribe. Closer
   to SF, try outdoor parties Frequency 8 and the :) party on Friday, the
   Genesis P-Orridge benefit at 1015 (he was seriously injured due to a
   fire in the LA studios he was staying at), or the opening of the
   Internet Salon. 

   Going into next week, check out the Bjork/Aphex Twin
   show at the Warfield (dunno if tix are still available) or
   Move/Butterfly if you don't get in. Then back in Sacramento, DubTribe
   returns with Doc Martin and others...

   quality time - 1624 California @ Van Ness. 21+.

   guests. $5. 10pm-4am, 21+, 300 DeHaro @ 16th, SF
   [7/26 - Ruben]

   415.241.8815. Afterparty at 201 Howard.

   and Jazz Picks. Live music with Josh Jones and Guests the Up&Down Club
   1151 Folsom

   live acid jazz. 9:30pm-2am @ Eleven, 374 11th St.
   
   the Spot - house, reggae, hiphop? - every other Weds. $3, 21+, 502
   Auzerais, San Jose
   
   Re-Groove-A-Nation - 10PM to 5AM, 18+, $5. 511 Tyler (off Fremont),
   Monterey. DJs Taylor Made (Santa Cruz), Juni, Lonnie, Greg Dean, &
   guests.
   
   Blinc - 111 Minna St @ 2nd, $5, 9pm-late - DJs and Info: 415.974.1719
   415.267.5912

   St, SF. $0. 415.673.8181

   guests. Live percussion by Fatt Family. 1190 Folsom @ 8th.
   415.995.9509
   
   Rhythmic Therapy - Funky organic house administered by DJ James. Deco,
   510 Larkin St. 21+, $2, 415.441.4007

   house music, Magic Circle is dub funk. DJs include Sifu, Tony Fader,
   Your Mama. The Oddball Lounge, 76 MInna St. 415.495.2851.

   Kearny. 415.615.8559

       281-3377.

       90.1 Stanford

       90.7 (Berkeley)

       90.3 (SF)

       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)

       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills

       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

On Thu, 20 Jul 1995, Rick Riffle wrote:
> 
> It makes perfect sense.  I don't watch TV, and involve my self with as
> little media as possible (never read the newspaper - never really have my
> whole life).  I do read alot and spend much of my time reflecting and
> working on my spirituality.  I've found that less media can greatly increase
> a persons vibrational frequency.  I can now physically feel the vibrations
> of a TV and am amazed at what it has the potential to do to a person....what
> it is actually doing to people all over the planet.
> 
> Rick
> 

A few years ago, this type of approach also made perfect sense to me; 
perfect sense, that is, until I started to feel quite isolated. 
Paradoxically, I also realized that the media concepts that I was so 
desperately trying to avoid, in my search for perceptual purity, in fact 
pervaded my life as much as they had in the past. These 
were communicated to me indirectly, via other people's behavior, via 
billboard advertizing, via junk mail, etc.etc.etc... There was no way to shut
out the reprehensible aspects of society by turning my back to 
them. They were there, everywhere. And working on my spirituality from 
within this idealized vacuum turned out to be utterly useless: the 
tenuous states of realization were always to be shattered by contact with 
the more "common" world. Any feelings of enlightenment just turned out to 
be levels of mental masturbation. I was really not all that different 
from my next door neighbor.

I now watch TV, read the paper, participate in all kinds of mass-media 
idiocy, and I am no worst off because of it, but I certainly don't take 
any of it seriously.

Isn't the rave thing all about breaking down barriers? Isn't cutting 
oneself off from the collective creating an *me*/*us* versus *them* 
mentality? Isn't this just another instance of repressing the Shadow and 
giving it more power?

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 20 15:19:10 1995

	(1.37.109.16/16.2) id AA251058713; Thu, 20 Jul 1995 18:18:33 -0400

Subject: Re: True Encounters with the rave Generation
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 >I know it is possible to pull-off mixing on the off count

I love DJs who can pull this off, especially if I'm familiar with the
track(s) it can really blow my mind.  Many tracks seem to encourage this with
HEAVY accents(not the kick but some stabby percussive thing like a 909 lo
tom) on off beats that are as easy to beatmatch to as the kick.  Mixing
another record in beatmatched to these off beats and slowly increasing the
volume subtly shifts the location of the downbeat until you're in the other
record and somehow the 1 ain't where it was.   Its a lot like the syncopation
common in latin styles and can have a poly-rhythmic feel.  Speaking of which,
someone told me that there have been some records released recently in 3/4
and 5/4.  True?  Some acid tracks have 303 lines that are so convoluted that
identifying where they repeat is hard and with a kick on every beat,
continuous hi-hats, and other percussion elements that drift in and out it
becomes very hard to say whether its in any time signature let alone whether
its 2, 4, or 8 bar phrasing.  

phuture

Found this at a WWW site, thought it was funny and someone else might enjoy it!

You might be a redneck, if... You've
ever had to climb a water tower with a can of spray paint to defend your
sisters honor. Your mother does not remove the Marlboro from her mouth
before telling the state trooper to "kiss my ass." Your front porch collapses
and kills more than three dogs. Your richest relative buys a new house and
you help take the wheels off of it. You ever cut your grass and found a car.
Your wife has ever said, "Come move this transmission so I can take a
bath." You refer to the time you won a free case of motor oil as "the day
my ship came in". You own a home that is mobile and 5 cars that aren't.
You think the stock market has a fence around it. Your stereo speakers
used to belong to the Moonlight Drive-in Theater. You keep a can of RAID
on the kitchen table. You hammer bottle caps into the fame of your front
door to make it look nice. You've ever spray painted your girlfriends name
on an overpass.

Love, Big Z



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 20 16:21:30 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA16358; Thu, 20 Jul 1995 16:21:30 -0700

Precedence: bulk

I understand your point and partially agree, but:

>A few years ago, this type of approach also made perfect sense to me; 
>perfect sense, that is, until I started to feel quite isolated. 

Since I've made my changes I've felt more connected, not more isolated.

>Paradoxically, I also realized that the media concepts that I was so 
>desperately trying to avoid, in my search for perceptual purity, in fact 
>pervaded my life as much as they had in the past. These 
>were communicated to me indirectly, via other people's behavior, via 
>billboard advertizing, via junk mail, etc.etc.etc... There was no way to shut
>out the reprehensible aspects of society by turning my back to 
>them. They were there, everywhere. And working on my spirituality from 
>within this idealized vacuum turned out to be utterly useless: the 
>tenuous states of realization were always to be shattered by contact with 
>the more "common" world. Any feelings of enlightenment just turned out to 
>be levels of mental masturbation. I was really not all that different 
>from my next door neighbor.

Your right, we arn't that different, but:

We all carry aroung "baggage" from our past (childhood, pastlives, past
universes, etc., take it where you wish).  I feel in order to evolve
ourselves we need to heal our past and let go or our "baggage".  In order to
heal our past, we must face it, and in order to face it we must remember.
(I personally can't/don't think/reflect/change while I'm watching TV)  In my
former life (during this lifetime), I was cought up with the media,
Republican (the kind that just votes thier party straight down the line), a
marketing major, my dream was to own a nice house, car, and be rich....then
I would be happy.  Well luckily I found God....From the beginning I knew
that God was not male or female or necessarily even a person at all....you
see, God's picture was always printed on the little tiny squares of paper I
would eat.  I ate lots of those squares, and saw God lots of times.  Those
little squares changed me. (not them alone, but that's where it started)

I've since done a 180 degree turn and changed my entire life.  I no longer
need a little square of paper to see or know God (or what ever you want to
call it).  I now work on my issues, programs, patterns, blocks, baggage, and
barriers my self. I've replaced the little square with tools from my own
mind.  I can now remove barriers myself.  There is no TV in my house, nor do
I receive the newspaper.  I find it much easier to work on my issues without
media exposure.  And my issues are what I need to work on.  The only way to
heal this planet of ours is to heal ourselves.  We need to work on ourselves
first.  I really do believe that for each person who "wakes up" it causes a
huge change for the planet and entire Univers.   Now all this doesn't mean I
run when I see a TV, I just don't like the feeling it gives me.  I know I am
different than before, and I will continue to grow and change.  I feel no
need at this point to integrate media into my life.  I don't need to know
that 13 people were murdered today in my city, or that Tide is on sale, or
that Tampax keeps me "fresh".  I believe the TV is used to keep people in
one line of thinking, and that's _fear_ or _just plain lack thereof_.  I'd
rather write music, read or something (I feel) is more constructive.


>I now watch TV, read the paper, participate in all kinds of mass-media 
>idiocy, and I am no worst off because of it, but I certainly don't take 
>any of it seriously.

My hat is off to you sir.


>Isn't the rave thing all about breaking down barriers? 

Yes, I can agree with that, but try to explain a concept like "Vibe" someone
like I use to be.  Or Unity.  I would have never listened before.

>Isn't cutting oneself off from the collective creating an *me*/*us* versus
*them* mentality?

No, not necessarily.  It can, but it doesn't have to.  I don't believe that
what's shown on TV and the media is really what the "collective" is.  By
removing media from my life, I've become more Earth conscious.  I now _care_
about this planet we live on, as well as all of the life that exists here.
I don't think media is inherently "bad", I just don't like what I see it
being used for, so I don't subscribe.

Isn't this just another instance of repressing the Shadow and 
>giving it more power?

I'm not repressing it, or giving it more power.  Judging it as bad or wrong
is repressing it and will give it more power.  I don't want it repressed or
necessarily removed, I'd really just like to see it change.  

Oh, and about the issues getting to me anyway from other sources, the
important ones that I need to know about do reach me.  The more I evolve,
the more redily available the important information is.  When I need to know
it, it will be there for me.  I no longer need to chase.  This has been my
experience.

Rick

Date: 7/20/95 3:18 PM
To: Nathan Moser
From: nvg8r
Isn't the rave thing all about breaking down barriers? Isn't cutting 
oneself off from the collective creating an *me*/*us* versus *them* 
mentality? Isn't this just another instance of repressing the Shadow and 
giving it more power?
---------------------------------------------------------------
YES!

That church-going, TV-worshipping, elvis-seeing person living in the trailer
park down the road just might know some things about life that would suprise the
hell out of you.

Seems we labor under a few misconceptions in this evil modern society of ours:

- that wealth implies intelligence
- that intelligence implies wisdom
- that wisdom implies happiness

Some of the happiest moments of my life have come from doing pretty stupid,
seemingly-childish things that definitely didn't bring in any income.

Elitism doesn't bring you any closer to truth, it just limits the number of
people you feel comfortable saying "hi" to.

-nate

Robynn said:

>And speaking of the speed of life... It's funny how songs from about 4 to 5
>years ago are now considered "old school" or "history of modern rock".  Are
>things evolving that fast or am I thinking that slow...

I once mentioned to a friend how sick I was of retro-
60's, 70's, 40's, 80/50's- oy vey! She pointed out that historically
it is common at the end of a century for retro-styles to 
be all the rage. I just thought that was interesting... 

Also, perhaps the advances that we are making in technology 
are a bit frightening on some level, and people are consequently
using nostalgia as a buffer to make that scary techno stuff ok 
to assimilate. Probably not, eh?

Jocelyn

One of my co-workers always tells me I look like a "dead-president's
wife" with my sunglasses on B)  I am so conflicted ;)


2012- the year of the rave renaissance! (the year for other 
interesting predictions, too)

wars at Macy's.

On Thu, 20 Jul 1995, Rick Riffle wrote:

> 
> different than before, and I will continue to grow and change.  I feel no
> need at this point to integrate media into my life.  I don't need to know
> that 13 people were murdered today in my city, or that Tide is on sale, or
> that Tampax keeps me "fresh".  I believe the TV is used to keep people in
> one line of thinking, and that's _fear_ or _just plain lack thereof_.  I'd
> rather write music, read or something (I feel) is more constructive.
>

I admire the change that you have affected in your life. And I agree that 
cutting oneself off for a while provides an ideal cocoon for 
introspective work. Yet, once on the other side of the process of 
breaking oneself down, and reintegrating the personality, I prefer to 
reconnect with the mass consciousness, knowing full well that it cannot 
have the same hold it had on me before. And my interest in the media 
comes partly from a desire to keep conscious of that state of awareness 
called middle America, knowing full well that most people live there. No, 
I definitely don't care that Tide or Tampax may be on sale, but I 
definitively do care that 13 people were murdered. I want to know what is 
going on, and how my state of mind stands with respect to other's.
  
Ultimately, I feel that the PLUR/community feel of some raves exists in 
the same way as does the "vibe" from the media, and namely as an 
interpretation of the world. While the former may appear better than the 
latter, it is nonetheless, a relative perspective.  Exclusively adopting 
one over the other may prove to be dangerous, not because of the 
pathologies inherent to a particular view-point, but rather as a result of 
the static and self-righteous characteristics innate in fixating solely on 
one interpretive system.

IMO, the sudden feeling of loneliness that some people have reported 
experiencing at the height of an rave, a feeling that has washed 
over me too, is a gut awareness that I am, within that ecstatic state, 
just as alone as I was before, albeit in a different way. And depending 
on my perspective, I am also just as connected. Both interpretations are 
true and valid. The one always seems to hit me when I am convinced that 
the other is other is all there is. Yet this is a good thing: I prefer to be 
blissed out and aware of the relativity of this state.


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 20 20:50:43 1995

Message-Id: <199507210349.UAA18511@jobe.shell.portal.com>
Subject: Fun Things to do if the vibe flags
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 20:49:43 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2297      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hey -- this is actually directly rave related!

We've all been at parties where, for whatever reason, things just
ain't goin' off.  Now what do you do?  Some ideas:

-DJ trainwreck!  Can't keep the trance going.  Try to dance to both
records at once!  Do those little shuffle-stutter steps, kind of
a soft-shoe action.  For advanced ravers, try moving one side of your
body in time with one record and the opposite side with the other.
Guaranteed to burn calories and exercise brain cells.

-No strobes!  Get up as close as you can to a steady bright light, close
your eyes, and wave your hand in front of your face with fingers spread.
Guaranteed to cause cool psychedelic-style imagery if the light is
bright enough.  A steady motion is best, for optimal 6-10Hz flicker.

-Too tired!  You're about to fall asleep on your feet and your ride
won't leave until 8 AM.  Find a cozy place behind the stacks and go for it!
Amazing half-asleep dreams will ensue.  Wear earplugs for best muffleage of
irritating highs, and passage of dream-inducing bass booms.  After 1/2 hour
to 45 minutes you will be fresh as a daisy.  Go to the WC and splash water
on your face for best effect.

-Nobody's dancing!  The dance floor is as empty and featureless as the Black
Rock Desert.  Who cares?  Go dance anyway.  Unless the music blows people
will join you.

-Attitude!  People look at you like you're from Mars.  Run with it!  Pretend
you're a Martian, studying primate mating ritual.  Try to guess who will be
hit on next.  Inquire of the bartender the chemical composition of sour mix.
Ask people strange anthropology questions.
There are lots of solutions to the attitude problem.  Bubbles are good; get
the kit with the different pipes.  The kazoo is best for big single bubbles,
the four-jet pipe best for lots of tiny ones.  The straw is worthless and
gets soap in your mouth.  If a fan is available use it with the regular
wand for truly impressive quantities.

-Angst!  You're feeling terrible and alone and the sun's never going to
come up and you're hungry besides.  Find an unoccupied person and ask
them for an exchange of hugs.  Sometimes it'll take a couple tries but
it'll cheer you both up.  Do _not_ just sit there and look depressed, it'll
just get worse and worse.

Anyone got more?

// g

From: Grigsbeast <grigsby@shell.portal.com>
Message-Id: <199507210638.XAA09626@jobe.shell.portal.com>
Subject: Re: Your Brane (only kind of rave related)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 23:38:04 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950720192913.7765A-100000@infinity.c2.org> from "nvg8r" at Jul 20, 95 08:37:52 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1984      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> called middle America, knowing full well that most people live there. No, 
> I definitely don't care that Tide or Tampax may be on sale, but I 
> definitively do care that 13 people were murdered. 

I don't.  This may sound callous, but let me explain.

If they were people whose murder I could be doing anything _at all_ about,
like people who lived in my neighborhood, or who I otherwise knew and 
could help protect by building a community in which this is less likely
to happen, I would care.  I can't do anything about Bosnians trying to
shoot each other -- am I going to walk on over the border and tap some
guy on the shoulder and say "Put down that rifle, can't we all be friends?"
<BLAM>

The Big Lie of mass media is an implication -- that what happens around the
world is more important than what's going on on your street, in your
neighborhood, with your friends.  We spend all our time worrying about
Eastern Europe and not much taking care of ourselves and our friends; at
least most of us do.  This allows the most outrageous invasions of privacy,
liberty, happiness, and love to take place, because someone can always
point to someplace where things are worse and imply that we should spend
our time helping the people there -- which, conveniently, we cannot.  How
much of Live Aid got to actual refugees?  Very little.  How much did it 
matter, even if it did?  Zero.  The next year, there were still too many 
people on too little arable land, and kids still starved.  Meanwhile our
own country continued to consume its own natural resources at a frightening
rate, institute mandatory sentencing for most drug offenses, and give $2-4,000
of YOUR money to rich people in CA and TX via the S&L bailout.  (That's
from EACH of us.  Yep.)

This is why raving is important to me -- it is a chance to spread some love
around, and build a temporary community of people that care for each other,
while often pushing the boundaries of what is acceptable to society.

// g

My computer tells me that on Tue, 18 Jul 1995, Doug Fairclough shared:

> Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 16:38:32 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Doug Fairclough <kensey@wired.com>
> To: Christian Barton <eaaa004@ea.oac.uci.edu>
> Cc: Starchild <rrose@ocf>, mr bill <whtanksl@hamlet.uncg.edu>,
>     sean t starbuck <dutchcdc@slip.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: Re: Alcatraz on less than 100 grand a day! ;)
> 
> 
> why not do Angel island ?  you can legally just, like, sail there
> and legally camp there, so the problem of spearheading an entry is
> solved.  you would have to scout out a discreet place to crank it
> up and party down, but that should be do-able.  the problem with
> Alcatraz is just mere presence will get you busted, and probably
> committing a misdemeanor at that, so they could just open up the
> old prison and toss you in :) 
> 
> LET'S DO IT !
> 
> doug

	Angel Island sounds like another interesting site.  The reason I 
mentioned Alcatraz though is because I feel the beauty and uniqueness of 
the place make it an ideal location for a rave, other considerations aside.
If I had to be in prison somewhere and had the choice of where to serve 
time, it would quite possibly be there.  The cellblocks have a lot of 
character and charm compared to more modern jails.  It wouldn't be a bad 
place to get some writing and thinking done.

...and on Tue, 18 Jul 1995, Christian Barton shared:
> 
> > 
> > Well this would have to be a very private party.  I mean if you have 100+ 
> > ravers going on the island, there is a big chance you are gonns get 
> > caught.  Heck, come to think about it, I am pretty sure it wouldn't 
> > work, for this simple reason.  A lot of the ravers I know are...hmm... 
> > shall we say unique in their appearance.  If 100+ ravers went onto the 
> > island, I would think that they ferry people would realize...hmmm.. 
> > "those strange guys never came back".  Now I have never had the chance to 
> > visit alacatraz, but I would imaging that you pass through some sort of 
> > counting device (like the turnstiles at Disneyland).  It would really 
> > make sense from a security standpoint.  Correct me if I am wrong, but if 
> > I wanted to know if people were still on the island at the end of the 
> > day, that is what I would do.  Of course, you could always borrow a boat 
> > and ferry people to an isolated part of the island youself at night.  I 
> > mean if the sound from the sound system won't carry (which I am not so 
> > sure about) then a small boat engine should be nothing in comparison.  I 
> > guess that is just my take on the situation.  Hope to have been of some 
> > help...
> > 
> > 	-Christian


	I don't think there would be a problem of too many people trying 
to attend.  The time committment of most of the day coming over on the ferry 
and waiting, not to mention the risk of getting caught and facing legal 
repercussions, would probably be enough to deter all but the most daring 
(some would say foolish) ravers.  Also the illicit nature of the event 
would dictate that it not be widely publicized.  I seriously doubt you'd 
get as many as 100 people, unless Wicked tried to set it up as the full 
moon party.  :)
	The idea of getting there by private boat occurred to me, but not 
knowing anything about boating or sailing, I don't know how feasible it 
might be.  My suspicion is that the rangers who stay overnight on 
Alcatraz are more on the lookout for secret landing attempts than the 
possibility of someone coming by legal means and simply staying on.  
Also, the geography of the island would appear to make it *very* risky to 
attempt a night landing anywhere but the single boat dock, which would 
increase the likelihood of being spotted.
	I don't remember any turnstile going onto the island or anyone 
counting heads, but I could be mistaken in this.  It's also possible they 
count you when you get on and off the boat at the mainland.
	There's all kinds of pitfalls in this idea, to be sure, but 
that's part of what makes it so exciting.  Alcatraz is forbidden fruit, 
and we all know what tastes best.  Besides, just think:  If Eve hadn't 
picked that apple, we might all still be a bunch of Forrest Gumps walking 
around without a clue.  ;)  

				*** Starchild ***

Honey, who Does your hair?

downhear at Cafe Dunord is leading the lounge movement 
in San Francisco.  This is a Divine little party.

I've been waiting _patiently_ for an ostentatious, ultra beautiful,
painfully fashionable, hip, trendy to a tee, new wealth, upscale, give 
me service or get out of my fucking way, network, contact, elitist, yankee,
schmoozefest, artful, collaborative, flower, candle, fine cigarette,
speakeasy, this band sucks, Lounge Gathering that is all Vibe and
terribly fun to Arrive in this fair city of ours.
...
this Is rave.

In from England, a trans-atlantic lounge dj informs me that this
type establishment is All the Rage.  He liked my tape.

Dave
---------------------------------------------------------

Everytime I encounter this lounge thing, I can't help but think of my
dad's box of circa '62 playboys I used to dig through as a kid: 
big hair, big breasts, with all the important stuff artfully concealed.

Not to revive any geographic flag-waving or burning (pleazse!), but my 
sources tell me LA's way ahead of SF on this tip.

Frankly, I can't see much in common between lounge and rave except
a bigass smile that leaves the uninitiated scratching their domes. And
I'm kinda wondering why this all didn't happen in the eighties, when the
well-heeled grin was definitely in. I guess that's first mistake 
fashion-clueless people like me make - trying to cast it into some 
socio-eco phenom.

The way I see it, lounge ain't rave, dave, it's wave, and hopefully I can 
duck under this big sucka.

-nate

(and just in case anyone thinks dave's jumping on some wagon, I saw him 
with a healthy stack of such ancient vinyl late last year, seeds for a 
budding DJ)
