hey, i'm back from tahiti; no raving there whatsoever...

  the operator of a roulette (yes, they gamble now down there!) wheel
    in papeete saw a tiedye i wuz wearing, and said, "looks like a raver
     shirt".  when we talked about the subject for a while, it became \
      clear that the french are frowning on all-nite techno parties,
       due to connections with certain chemicals, etc...  also, someone
        did once try importing international DJ's down there (maybe on
         their way to australia???) but it never caught on; apparently
          locals are too much in to older styles of dance music due to
           the third-world timelag factor you see in outlying areas...

anyway, regarding the implanting of thots by tv ads, movies, etc., i'd
   like to say, "bring'em on!"  personally, i love tv and find ads to
    be an endless source of absolute hilarity, especially the type which
     try to make you look cool if you buy the product.  maybe i've got
      a built-in bs detector (probably not), but whatever the case, 
       tv is meant IMHO to be mind candy, and should be taken as such.
        even the news is now edited to fit the music, if you know what
         i mean...
furthermore, even the rottenest tv is ripe material for plagerism into
     high art by a talented kid with a video toaster, so why not treat
      it as a raw material?

just my 2 franc's worth...


ia orana!

Dave Scruton

fin de siecle [French, end of the century]
 : of, relating to, or characteristic of the close of the 19th century and
esp. its literary and artistic climate of sophistication, world-weariness,
and fashionable despair

> The way I see it, lounge ain't rave, dave, it's wave

it's all the same.  it's all the people.  you tell me what it
takes for a party to be a rave ... is it club or a rave?  is alcohol
allowed or just cuz some people are idiot drunks does that ruin it?
how about nitrous? - you can't get any stupider than on that shit
and would you suggest that there aren't morons on e?

do there have to be lasers?  dancing?  what about ravers who dig 
chill rooms?  Do you have to wear baggy jeans?  What does the 
music have to be?  Can you rave while playing golf?
can you make fun of hippies, zippies, obnoxious bores?
Do you have to follow the rave code of ethics??
can you scam on mall babes?

narrow it down
to just what
you like
and then
stay there
don't do
anything 
outside of 
that cuz it
wouldn't be
truly rave
then
would
it?

who cares if your corny, or cheesy, 
or rude, or it sucks, or its obvious.
who cares if ya get slammed (vw)

pigeon holes are boring as shit.  so are half the raves being
thrown these days.  a room full of people going for it is as close
to a rave definition as I can think of.  open wide.
say aaahhhhhhh ...

Dave

I could not help but add this loving message to the topic-
<<<<<<<<<<<<Have SEX with your T.V.- It's safer>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>


In 1982 I was employed as a salesman at an audio/video store in New York City
and I would sit and stare at a bank of television sets. I have been involved 
with Zen meditation for over 20 years and while in a state of no- mind (at 
work) I discovered that the people on television were responding to 
fluctuations in my mental state. I was later to learn that I was producing a 
spot of bright light in the lens of the broadcasting television camera. 

Since 1983 I've been using this luminescent effect to wreak havoc in the 
incipient mind of the media/state. I have learned to control the effect so 
that I can induce more eye blinking, more stammering, etc. by changing the 
brightness and location of the spot of light which I cause to appear in the 
broadcasting TV camera. 

In 1991 I decided to create an experiment which would be verifiable to the 
public at large, so that I might prove the existence of the phenomenon to the 
skeptical community. So, I came up with the Thursday test. Every Thursday I 
illuminate the cameras of the ABC Evening News. Watchers of the show can do 
various things to prove the veracity of my claims. They can count the number 
of times Peter Jennings blinks on Thursday as compared with Friday or 
Wednesday. They can measure the reflected luminosity of the spot of light on 
Peter's eyeballs or they can count the number of mis-speaks. 

I've been zapping all presidential tv appearances since late 1983. If you 
watch the first 1984 Reagan debate you will notice my efforts. I zapped the 
presidential and vice-presidential debates in 1992 - in an attempt to prevent 
the re-election of Bush/Quayle. 

Millions of people know about this phenomenon and harbor knowledge of it
through a "cult of secrecy." There is no real conspiracy in the public, it is 
just that people do not tell others of this story unless provoked. There have 
been  quite a few pop songs written in homage; these usually use innuendo to 
refer to the phenomenon. 

My intent on Internet is to inform the public of this process. My intent is 
infinite and immaculate in its beautifully chaotic illuminative 
interventions; wreaking havoc with light. Photonic agents of bliss 
infiltrating the minds of commerce and
conspiracy. 

Jeff Harrington 
idealord@dorsai.dorsai.org
>From IdEAL ORDER web page http://www.dorsai.org/~idealord/

Hello,

I am the managing editor for URB Magazine, the underground dance music
publication. I am writing in an effort to reach out to the national on-line
rave community.

San Francisco is a very important place for me. We at URB feel that the Bay
Area is very important and should be represented to the fullest in the mag.
And as some of you may know (or not), Toph Evans, URB Magazine's San
Frandisco columnist, is splitting town and heading to Colorado. So, the
position is empty and the column is blank... Therefore, I welcome any and
all interested parties to submit in writing 1) an 100 word example of what
they would like to see in the column each month, 2) their affiliation with
the scene and 3) why they want the gig.

Also, the usual info:

Name (real name)
Address
Phone No(s).
e-mail address

Send it via fax (213.466.1207), e-mail (troberts@webstorm.com or
urbmag@netcom.com) or snail mail (1680 N. Vine St. #1012, LA CA 90028). And
please, NO PHONE CALLS. Thanks in advance for your response.


URB Magazine
urbmag@netcom.com

Dave-

This whole lounge thread is great...I think you started it didn't you?

There was a vague reference to Black Diamond in your first post and I just
wanted to let people know that if they like diversity (music, vibe, etc) they
should check this place out.

>> The way I see it, lounge ain't rave, dave, it's wave
>it's all the same.  it's all the people.  you tell me what it
>takes for a party to be a rave ... is it club or a rave?  is alcohol
>allowed...

>pigeon holes are boring as shit.  so are half the raves being
>thrown these days.  a room full of people going for it is as close
>to a rave definition as I can think of. 

Black Diamond is very much lounge (it's actually at a place called the
Oddball Lounge). No lasers, No fast pounding mind twisting
trance/techno/house. Not what most people would call a rave. But...

Big sound for a small space (Wicked sound system?) Great *diverse* group of
people, good vibe the couple of times i've been. No attitude detected. Good
beer selection with NO observed idiot drunks:)...

and the music... This is what actually draws me to this little gathering.
Very nice slower dub/triphop/??? but *heavily* techno influenced. Many of the
same elements that attract me to trance/ambient. This stuff definetely pulls
me to the dance floor and it's a nice change from the old standard
party/club. 

Anyway my 2cents. I just had a good time and thought with the lounge thread
and all it would be worth sharing. I would be interested in any other
thoughts on the atmosphere/music at Black Diamond (I know Ann posted
something a while back)

peace, 
martin

ps I kind of went back an forth between 8th House and Black Diamond last
night  and maybe the contrast/similarities got me really thinking...It was
just so interesting to go from Phillips set (Theta-blip) to who ever it was
at BD. Both equally danceable IMHO...

i don't wanna sound TOO critical, but regarding affecting the
  nightly news by gazing into a tv screen, i'm sure most peeple
    realize that NO nightly news is actually live; it's all tape-delayed.
does this mean yer gaze is transcending the space-time continuum, and
  if so, how does it know where to go, if the tape was shipped across
    the continent from the studio to the broadcast facility???

just a chaotic question

>distasteful.  But after reading your message, I realize you're right.

Honestly, I'm too shy to dance around naked in front of an MTV crew, 
knowing that a bunch of horny meister brau drinking teenagers will be 
jerking off as they watch mtv.

I talked to Larry Harvey, founder of Burning Man, about the whole issue 
of media at Burning Man, and he told me that they all media crews must 
go be oked and go through a training session which educates them about 
the event and shows them how important it is to not interfere with the 
experience.  He loved the t-shirt idea "MTV sucks... We swallow"!  He 
agreed that seeing the media as a tool to get our messages out is a 
great way to look at the whole thing. MTV HAS NOT CONTACTED HIM TO GET 
HIS APPROVAL AS OF THIS DATE, HE SAYS THAT IF MTV IS GOING TO TRY AND 
BARGE IN WITHOUT GETTING HIS APPROVAL, THEY WILL BE IN FOR A BIG 
SURPRISE. HE WOULD LIKE TO TALK WITH THEM IF ANYONE HAS CONTACT WITH 
MTV.

He suggested having a media camp which could have some funny things 
like suggesting to people that instead of watching Burning Man they 
should just watch reruns they have playing at the Media Camp, or having 
two computers separated by a partition and tell people to communicate 
with each other on line... to get people to take a look at how what we 
consider to be so technologically advanced has actually taken us a 
giant step backwards in many ways.  If anyone would like to help with 
creating Media Camp, they can talk to Larry at the Pre Burning Man 
event called: 

"Burning Man Out There In Here"
Friday & Saturday August 4,5,11,12
Show starts 8pm
S.O.M.A.R. Brannan St.
$10 Donation
415-985-7471 for more info
"THE ODD, THE STRANGE, THE WEIRD AND WHOLLY OTHER...AN INTERACTIVE ART 
EXPERIENCE"

Also, I have an idea to start an area which would be completely media 
free, no image recording devices allowed.  Anyone who is interested in 
helping with that idea can call me, Amy, at 415-771-3824.

I am really looking forward to seeing everyone at Burning Man!! It's 
going to be amazing :)

I am not a luddite by any maens.  Old fashioned in some cases but not a 
luddite.  I really see no need for things to be "exposed" the way they 
are in media today.  Reminds me of the "documentaries" put on by National 
Geographic and the like.  Just another excuse for them to photograph and 
show non-white breasts in magazines and television (when was the last 
time they did a "doc" on German sunbathers....).

Point is, not everything needs exposure, and certainly, not everything 
needs to be explained.  Some things should be left to the experience 
alone.  Not everything need quantification.  MTV is a commercial vehicle, 
hell-bent on profits.  They are no different than any large polluting 
resource conglomerate (read oil), taking, taking, taking, and in return 
charging you money to kill yourself and environs.  The only real 
difference is the medium.  Let's face it,  MTV pollutes the airwaves with 
mindless, yet sometimes entertaining drivel.  Using them to get a message 
across is like using Pete Wilson's brain to further realtions between 
the  U.S. and Mexico.  All you'll end up getting is dumped on.

This will be my first Burning Man experience, and I plan on having not 
only a good time, but a soulful one as well.  I would hato have my trip 
invaded by a bunch of media peddlers, who specialize in selling cheap wares.

Some things should be left sacred, some things should never be exposed to 
the light and scrutiny of day.  Some things are solemn, and should remain 
so.  Don't sleep with the enemy, or you'll awake in anger.

Don't beleive the MTV as illuminary messenger hype.  They suck and should 
not be allowed to have any recording equipment there.

Oh yeah, did I mention anything about that political sleazebag Pete 
"Double Affrimative A-Hole" Wilson.....


Slammin' beats,
John

my Political Science classes and geography/geology classes feeling 
like I was going to puke because of what I had learned.  Sometimes 
ignorance IS bliss.

Subject: No MTV at Burning Man

According to the powers that be, there has been no talk of big media
exposure at the BM festival. On the other hand, Larry Harvey and Crimson
Rose will be on the Alex Bennett show Mon AM from about 8:00 - 9:00 talking
about the festival and the show at SOMAR. I think that's about all the
media they want, maybe even more than they want, but Alex has talked about
it way too much already, so it will probably be better to get real
information straight from the promoter(s). Remember, this started as a
small gathering for less than 100 people, and has grown to monster
proportions, but the feeling of building a community for a week is/was the
plan, and needs to be preserved. This is not a spectator event (much like a
rave) it's all about living together for a week (or however long you stay),
as a family.

See ya there,

V.

The Happy Rasta Raver

Well I just wanted to post a problem I had.  Last night I attended
raindance after driving 1.5 hours from S.F. I couldn't have asked for a
better location!!
It was absolutly beautifull. My G.F. and I danced and then crashed in the
woods. Since this was her first rave exeriance I was very excited about how
well it was going......Then we walked to out car at about 6:30 Sunday
morning and someone had smashed/torn her side mirror off her car. What a
dissapointment! I couldn't believe that at a small event with no one except
ravers for miles around that someone had caused this destruction. We didn't
piss anyone off or anything. This really sucks and needless to say she is
pretty dissapointed.

I know that this didn't have anything to do with the party or 99% of the
people attending, it just really upset me especially considering the crowd.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Michael David
miked@ultima.org

drove out to freq 8 on friday night, and the map point was the small surf
shop right in Stinson.  the party was on Stinson beach, up about a half mile
back towards the city - pretty secluded, and the party was just really
starting to get off, a bon fire was lit was starting to roar and people
were crowding and dancing around it. a local from 'Bo' dragged me up
the rock above and we were dancing away high above the party.  

then, 3 cops showed up, and busted the thing up, claiming that someone 
had called in. highly unlikely considering how remote the site was.

more likely - they just did not want to have a party going
off and the corresponding liability. a bigger liability was the couple of
hundred who then had to then drive home in their current state.  cops suck ! 
they could not be reasoned with, instead saying, go up to a spot a half mile
further up the beach. a fine time to say that. the sight of people 
lugging equipment up a trail and over rocks at 3:00am with only a few 
flashlights was quite disheartening.

alas :( 

doug

Dear Sunset;

	It's truely ashame that the wonderful people of Sunset chose to
make it impossible for people who depend on public transist to get to
their events, by having them in areas that are totally inaccessable,
unless you have a car. Since I became vehicleless it's almost always a
problem if not an ordeal to try and find transportation to events, not
just Sunset. It often makes me feel like a beggar, or better yet a 
prostitute. 

	But Sunset, being a day time event, that has demostrated
responsibility to the authorites, still choses to limit there events to
locations inaccesable to public transist, when there are places available
that are accessable to public transit, eg Berkley Marina, the Park in El
Cerrito, GC Park, even The Marin Headlands ...etc. I would love to support
this event, as I know others would, if they could get to it. In fact the
only reason why I'm whineing, is that so many people in a similar
situation have said the same thing, and wonder why they continue to pick
the most out of the way, & inaccessable locations.  So Sunset/Pacific why;
inquiring, confused, disappointed, still loyal & dedicated minds want to
know? 

Sin;
Brian Darkness & the Countless Other Carless Ravers

Just a short report on the "scene" in Honolulu -

 Since I was just in Honolulu last weekend for a funeral , I was not
able to go out to any clubs or events. I did pick up some flyers , and
visited one clothing/music/spray-can culture store in Honolulu called
Funk Pistol ( located upstairs at 835 Keeaumoku , (808) 949-3103 ).
The gal at the counter told me that the rave scene had died down somewhat
since I was last there in 1993. 

 My last visit to Hawaii was in 1993 , and there had been a free tabloid
then called "DEEP" , somewhat in the same vein as XLR8R . DEEP covered the
local rave , hip-hop , and "Jawaiian" ( reggae & dub with a local Hawaiian
twist ) music scene. When I was back in Honolulu last week , I could find
it anywhere. The gal at Funk Pistol told me that it had folded - the editor
( Alan Thurman ) had moved to San Jose!!! ( Anybody know this guy ? ).
It was a very nice tabloid - too bad it folded.

 Even in Honolulu, there are DRC mix tapes! Funk Pistol had about four
copies of her "EARGAZMICA" tape. Local DJ tapes were represented by
DJ Felix ( who has also moved to CA ! ) and a DJ Pas-Sean . 

 I don't know if it's the same guy , but a DJ Felix C "from San Francisco"
and also our local guy DJ Harry Who will be spinning at a big rave called
"A MidSummer Night's Dream" on Saturday , July 29th. 9PM til' ???
Info number (808) 533-2080 .

 If anybody here on SFRaves finds themselves in Honolulu, I'd definetely
check out the Funk Pistol store. 

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

On Sun, 23 Jul 1995, Doug Fairclough wrote:
> they could not be reasoned with, instead saying, go up to a spot a half mile
> further up the beach. a fine time to say that. the sight of people 
> lugging equipment up a trail and over rocks at 3:00am with only a few 
> flashlights was quite disheartening.

Well, me and a group of about 40 others were still hopeful. At around 
4:30 am, however, word came from the F8 people that it wasn't going to 
happen -- 'twas too late. The rational side of my brain said, ok, they're 
probably right.  The other side said, "Who'ju talkin' 'bout Willis?!"... 
So I go down to tell the relocated partyers down on the beach that it wasn't 
going to happen. They all seemed to be in an late morning mellow funk 
accompanied/induced by the Jim Morrison (Doors) soundtrack playing off the 
boombox of a group of heavy-metalers (?), who were there before any of 
us. Initiative time. Went around to see if anyone had a mixed tape. 
Yes. Asked if my friend would lend her beautiful smile -- yes, but I 
guess she had dealt w/natives b4 because she knew what the best peace
offering would be. And wouldn't ya' know it, our long-haired friends had
their own peace pipe. Popped in my tape. He says: "This isn't rap, is 
it?" ... Well, for the next half an hour a handful of us danced to the 
Wicked boombox, while our new dazed and confused friends moved to 
the rhythm of their hacky-sack -- about 40 yards away. 
	Thank you (guys) for let-tin', me be mahh self, 
	a-gain (for 30 minutes b4 you left).         

Rok

At 22:19 7/23/95, Brian Darkness wrote:
>Dear Sunset;
>
>        It's truely ashame that the wonderful people of Sunset chose to
>make it impossible for people who depend on public transist to get to
>their events, by having them in areas that are totally inaccessable,
>unless you have a car. Since I became vehicleless it's almost always a
>problem if not an ordeal to try and find transportation to events, not
>just Sunset. It often makes me feel like a beggar, or better yet a
>prostitute.
>
>        But Sunset, being a day time event, that has demostrated
>responsibility to the authorites, still choses to limit there events to
>locations inaccesable to public transist, when there are places available
>that are accessable to public transit, eg Berkley Marina, the Park in El
>Cerrito, GC Park, even The Marin Headlands ...etc. I would love to support
>this event, as I know others would, if they could get to it. In fact the
>only reason why I'm whineing, is that so many people in a similar
>situation have said the same thing, and wonder why they continue to pick
>the most out of the way, & inaccessable locations.  So Sunset/Pacific why;
>inquiring, confused, disappointed, still loyal & dedicated minds want to
>know?
>
>Sin;
>Brian Darkness & the Countless Other Carless Ravers

Part of the problem is finding locations where the authorities will allow
large groups of people to gather and listen to loud music. The park in
Richmond is one such place. (although they'll only allow it every six
weeks) GG Park costs $400 for a permit which is only valid from 12-6. The
Berkeley marina is touchy this year after the problems of last year and the
Sunsets that have been there this year have been without official
permission and have run the risk of getting stopped. The East Bay Regional
Park District does not, as a rule, allow amplified sound in any of their
parks to the best of my knowledge. It's been difficult for Pacific to find
viable locations this year due to prejudice against raves.

Your best bet in getting your comments to Pacific would be to leave a
message on the voice mail, 415 985-5264. I know they would gladly
investigate any location suggestions you might have.

Joe

	Hats off to the sunset crew for another beautiful sunday!!! 
(Thanks :)

	Well, as some of you may know, Harmony will be having a two year 
anniversary party in August. This post is to explain a bit about what we 
are planning for the night!! 

	On Friday, August 11th Harmony and Beautiful People will be 
gathering to celebrate the two year anniversary of our family!!

	Djs for the night are:

		Graeme		Trent		Dj Dan
	Ethan		James 		Brandon		Galen
				    (solid Grooves)
	
	Plus a live performance by solid Grooves recording artist:
				E.B.E. Audio

	Visuals by Michael Clay 	Lasers by Hollywood Dog

	Chill Area by the Crew (Harmony)

	Plus a whole lot of surprises!!! :)       $10    :)

Call the following numbers for more info: (408)486-9591 (408)450-3044

	This party will be 100% outdoors on a new, (never before used,) 
comfirmed, beautiful, private ranch. (By comfirmed I mean, not a 
break-in... LEGAL!!!) Actually the location is sooo bad ass, that we are 
basically giving the owners half of the door money!!! ( $5 a head!) 
Outragous?, well not for this space!!! It is perfect for our two year 
party!!!! The location is in the south bay, (San Jose side of highway 
17,) and it is a couple miles off the 680 freeway, (easy to get to!!)
	
	The party will be $10 and go from about 9pm., until 7-8am (maybe 
even later if the crowd supports it!) Feel free to bring anything you 
want, such as: Candy, toys, lights, and even tents! There will be plenty 
of room for them. But most of all bring every single little drop of 
energy you have, cause we want you to use it all!!!! Also our entrance 
policy is still in effect: You must have a smile on your face to enter 
the party, if you friends don't have one, give them one of yours!!!

	There will be plenty of free water (and fruit in the morning!) 
So feel free to eat up! 

	Also, if you are not on our snail mail list, and want to be, you 
can either call us at the phone lines, or mail me your info at 
ascend@netcom.com  If you have not been introduced to our mailing list I 
highly recommend it. We promote smaller parties in our mailer that we 
don't publiclly announce!!! Plus you'll be surprised at the energy 
that we put into everysingle mailer!!! 

	Well, that's all for now, and we all hope to see you there!!!

Peace, love and harmony to all beautiful people,

Greg

There seems to be a situation where people are unable to reach events 
they'd like to attend because it's beyond their reach.

There also seems to be a situation where the people who throw these 
events are sometimes left standing to do trash detail and other such 
bunk things that they could do without.

events, both of these problems could be solved.

Just a thought.

Precedence: bulk

> Hi folks -
>
> I was just looking through the latest issue of XLR8R , and I have
>a question about terminology.
>
> what is the difference between "jungle" and "drum and bass" ?

from what i understand (and i am no junglist...just spent a lot of time in
chicago... so correct me if i am wrong), drum and bass is a type of jungle.
there is also dark jungle (that scary sounding stuff), intelligent jungle
(my personal fave, dj wickett from madison, WI who i am sure very few if
any of you have ever heard of spins some really great intelligent jungle.)
anyway, you get the idea i am sure:)

ellen
>
> ( I have other terminology questions , but I don't want to start
>   any extra-long threads! )
>
> Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *

Ellen Steuer                                           ellen@cyborganic.com

http://www.cyborganic.com/People/ellen/             mswiggles@anonymous.com

Hello everybody!!!
While I was at Funky Tekno in Sac last Friday, it kept bugging me 
throughout the night that many of you wonderful people were probably 
there, but I had no way to find you!!!

Then I came up with this idea: Why don't we have stickers printed up?
A sticker is small enough not to infringe on anyone's attire.
A sticker matches anything.
A sticker can be worn anywhere.
And hey-- a sticker can even be Funky! :)

So, here's my idea. To save bandwidth, anyone who is interested in 
participating in this project please mail me your ideas on what the sticker 
should look like. (Shapes? Colors? Pictures? Words? etc)

I figure that it would cost no more than $2 per sheet of stickers.
And, even better, we could take the leftover proceeds and donate them 
to a charitable organization in the bay area.

Anyone like this idea? 

Smiles~!!!   		          lv, Alex


      Alexandra Crocket   |  "Reality is anything 
      alex_c@scs.unr.edu  |    you can get away with" 
	         -------PLUR-------

From: Crossjam <xjam@bdt.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Your Momma's BSP

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 23:27:18 +0000

Precedence: bulk

You might have seen the article in the East Bay Express about Your Momma's
House cafe'. The place has a cool little concept, probably not absolutely
original, but it's the only execution I know of in the East Bay. DJ's come
in and spin while people lounge around reading, chatting, writing, doing
homework, whatever. They're down at the end of College Ave where it meets
Broadway, in Oakland. It's close to the California College of Arts and
Crafts and a big ole Safeway. Right next door to the Deep Threadz hip-hop
clothing store.

Merit, who runs the place, is trying to broaden the musical styles and so
I've been hooked up with the 11-1 Saturday evening shift with the express
mission of playing house music. There's also supposed to be another DJ
coming online next weekend, for another 2 hour house style set ahead of
me. Most of the other DJ sets I believe are hip-hop although I should check
that out.

If you're casting about for a place to chill out a little before going to
the map point, a place to meet some friends and shoot the breeze, or just
some coffee and munchies before hitting the club check us out.

Here's some of the set I played this past Saturday in case you're really
not into happy house carp (sic). I'm devising a really tweaky, retro acid
house set for this weekend.

The Black Science Orchestra		"New Jersey Deep"
The Bucketheads				"Tribal Rydims"
DJ Sneak				"Show Me The Way"
The Bucketheads 3			"Come and be Gone"
DJ Sneak				"Disco Erotica"
Roach Motel				"Work 2 Doo"
Morel's Grooves 8			"Officer Where's Your Brother"
Full Swing				"Freestyle Groove"
Matt Wood				"What Am I Gonna Do With You"
Houz' Neegroz				"How Do U Luv a Black Woman?"
Club Swing				"Survive"
Jump Cutz V1				"A Special Disco Re-Edit"
The Mole People				"Break Night"
Mark the 909 King			"Can You Dig It!"
Wink					"Higher State of Consciousness"
W.A.M					"The Drum"
Brian Transeau				"The Moment of Truth"
Kim English				"Time for Love"
Joi Cardwell				"Trouble"
Ruffneck				"Everybody Be Somebody"
Hustler's Convention			"The Chant"
MFSB					"Theme from Soul Train '94"
River Ocean				"Love and Happiness"
Glenn Underground			"Somebody Scream"
7th Movement				"Odyssey"
Disco Elements V3			"Feel the Body Heat"
Mr. Lee					"Pump That Body"

Latez.

Strictly Rhythm			xjam@bdt.com

worn as a pendant.

sweating .....

On Mon, 24 Jul 1995, Ellen Steuer wrote:

> > what is the difference between "jungle" and "drum and bass" ?
> 
> from what i understand (and i am no junglist...just spent a lot of time in
> chicago... so correct me if i am wrong), drum and bass is a type of jungle.
> there is also dark jungle (that scary sounding stuff), intelligent jungle

well drum&bass and 'intelligent jungle' are basically 
the same. 'jungle' describes the ragga-influenced stuff, lots of   
ragga mc's, "bloodclot!", "booyaka booyaka",  that 
sort of thing. see M Beat and General Levy's "Incredible" (for an albiet 
commercial jungle choon). the drum&bass is best typified by artists like 
Omni Trio, A Guy Called Gerald and LTJ Bukem. it's also becoming known 
as 'drum & space' these days...

mikebee

>--------------------------------------
>Date: 7/24/95 9:29 AM
>From: AUSAR@SIUCVMB.SIU.EDU
>Hey, I'm moving to SF this fall so like it or not, get use to me.  I hope to
>be

My god, you guys have to deal with THIS??  On _our_ list, we just have an
argument about the difference between abstinance and not getting any.

Zheam, if you're the same one who hangs out on Vrave, prepare for some
serious squelching.  The whole point of the rave scene is NOT whether or
not you do drugs or whatever ... it's about PEOPLE, VIBE, and UNITY.  If
you have decided that drugs don't fit your lifestyle, that's your business.
If, however, you feel it's your duty to insult other people whose
lifestyle choice includes drugs, you're in for a long, hard, lonely road
through university.

I too make music.  But I don't attempt to FORCE it on anyone through the
net.  I prefer to just play it whenever I get the chance.  It's a far more
effective way of marketing yourself than saying "HEY!  I MAKE GOOD MUSIC!
SO LISTEN TO IT!"

Good dance vibes come from the feel and soul of the artist.  From what I've
read from you so far, your music would be awful uptight, overperfected, and
soulless.


k

>>I'm not about drugs or hanging out doing foul shit
>>like most people do at raves I've attended.  I'm about making good dance

> The whole point of the rave scene is NOT whether or
> not you do drugs or whatever ... it's about PEOPLE, VIBE, and UNITY.  If
> you have decided that drugs don't fit your lifestyle, that's your business.
> If, however, you feel it's your duty to insult other people whose
> lifestyle choice includes drugs, you're in for a long, hard, lonely road
> through university.

If raves are about people vibe and unity, isn't it the raver's job to
take care of those that are overindulging? Where do you draw the line
between the "anything goes" attitude expected by this community and the
care that a community should have for it's members?

I believe there's a difference between use and abuse -- a fine line
really. Perhaps Zheam has some experience w/ the aftermath of abuse and
that is the cause of his attitude-laden "if you don't like it ...
tough" posting.  Even if attitude is "unhip" it probably shouldn't be
condemned until you learn the full story -- don't judge a man until
you've walked a mile in his shoes and all that.

I've known too many casualties from people I knew in college -- 2
tweak-depression inspired suicides, a few of coke/acid phreakouts that
are nothing more than hollow shells of their former
hyperintelligent/creative selves, pathologically dysfunctional X-heads,
etc. It's pretty scary really.

I myself am in somewhat of a conundrum because I have a friend that
I've known for a long time that seems to be getting into tweaking at a
dangerous level (using Xtal-M to stay up for weeks at a time). I'm
pretty scared about this, and I'm trying to figure out a way to bring
up the subject in a non-alienating fashion. Any suggesions on how to
approach this topic w/o getting in his face in a rude and
non-productive way? After all, It's really none of my business telling
people what to do or think...

I guess I could buy him a copy of David Crosby's "So Far" autobiography
which goes into excruciating detail on the liver and immune system
damage he sustained while tweaking (remember that he recently got a
Grateful-Dead funded liver transplant). Albeit, his tweaking was of a
more expensive variety than my friend's, it's tweaking nonetheless.

Thanks,
	Niels.

cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199507251825.LAA13737@netcom8.netcom.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Niels,
You bring up some good points in your post.  As far as your friend is 
concerned that's a tuff one.  Alot of drug abusers are often in denial 
about it.  Those that care for the person are left with alot of feelings 
of frustration and helplessness, as it is very difficult to help anyone 
unless they are open to it.  Am I cheering you up yet? (sorry, bad joke)

This is what I would do if I was in your shoes.  I would let your friend 
know that you were concerned, and share your observations that cause your 
concern.  I would also let them know that it is up to them, what they 
want to do with their lives, and to let them know that you are available 
for them if they want help.
If you get to the point, where they are willing to acknowledge that they 
have a problem, and are willing to except some help, then I'd be willing 
to give you some more suggestions based on the situation.
If he doesn't want to except the help, there isn't alot you can do, 
except let him know you care.  Sometimes people have to "hit bottom" 
before they will except help.  Letting someone know you care can 
sometimes open one up, as alot of the time their main relationship is 
with their drug as they are feeling quite isolated and cut off.  To 
releive the disconnectedness they turn to connect with the drug 
experience.  Unfortunately with a drug abuser the drug experience often 
causes more disconnectedness, and the vicious cycle continues, connecting 
in one way then disconnecting in a bigger way.  Your expression of caring 
can possible help them start to reconnect or feel a little more 
connected, reducing the need for the drug.  This is based on 
psychological addition.  If its physical addition, he could probably use 
some medical help.
Hope some of this is helpful.  Either way you got my empathy.

peter

>> The whole point of the rave scene is NOT whether or
>> not you do drugs or whatever ... it's about PEOPLE, VIBE, and UNITY.  If
>> you have decided that drugs don't fit your lifestyle, that's your business.
>> If, however, you feel it's your duty to insult other people whose
>> lifestyle choice includes drugs, you're in for a long, hard, lonely road
>> through university.
>
>If raves are about people vibe and unity, isn't it the raver's job to
>take care of those that are overindulging? Where do you draw the line
>between the "anything goes" attitude expected by this community and the
>care that a community should have for it's members?

You are right, there IS a line between use and abuse.  That's not the point
I was trying to make.  My point was that people shouldn't INSULT others for
their choices.

Of course, if someone's being an abuser, I do what I can to help, or find
out why they're getting into it so hard.  Most of the time if someone's
using drugs to the point where they HAVE TO HAVE THEM to have fun, there's
a deeper psychological reason underlying it....

I have drugs in my life as a choice.  I respect their dangers and monitor
myself carefully.  I don't NEED them to have a good time, but I like to
have them as a treat, as some ppl use alcohol or nicotine.  If someone just
calls me an idiot and weak willed and a junkie, it gets me angry, and I
think it's justified.

k

Sindar@aol.com writes:
> >I stand my ground firmly, I'm not about drugs or hanging out doing foul shit
> >like most people do at raves I've attended.  I'm about making good dance
> >vibes
> All I get from reading this is negative vibes...  if you hate all of the,
> "foul shit" that ravers do then please stay away.  I mean we would all be
> happy to have you but not ifyou are gonna come to just look down on us while
> you bless us with your, "pure 'n possitive" persona.  Isn't there some quote
> about casting stones or something that would be apropriate here? =o)

I believe the quote you are refferring to is "Let he who is without sin, cast
the first stone."  Don't ask for the biblical reference because that is all I
remember from religion class (I am a recovering Catholic :-)).  It is one of
the few sayings that I truely believe applies in this age.  There is so much
cynacism (sp?) going on; everyone I think needs to lighten up a little (comment
not directed at sfravers, just the world in general).

The quote I believe that is more appropriate is from Marcel Proust.  It goes
like this:  "The real voyage of discovery consists not in seeing new landscapes
but in having new eyes."  Don't expect to come to SF and have a good time
just because you changed the scenery.  Change your attitude and you will
enjoy yourself whereever you are.

As to Sindar's comments, I wholeheartedly agree here.  Even though I personally
don't get into (and I quote) "doing foul shit like most people do", I deeply
believe in the right of everyone to enjoy themselves as they see fit.  If that
means dropping some x, acid, whatever, ENJOY!  Just don't expect me to do it.

The point is about community and togetherness and positive-energy not
holier-than-thou attitudes.  If you want attitude, just go to some of the $25
cover/$15 per drink clubs in SF (there is more than enough attitude to go
around).  But if you want to enjoy the SF scene, leave you attitude behind
and chill.  You might actually enjoy yourself and meet some really awsome
people.

hugs
mike

-- 
Mike Lasmanis
mikel@cctech.com

Hi everybody!

My name is Todd and I'm writing a story for URB Magazine on "speed"
(amphetamines). I would like to invite anyone who has or know someone who
has any experience =8B good or bad =8B=A0with amphetamines to contact me abo=
ut
being interviewed for the story. I can do it via phone, e-mail or in person
so your anonymity is secure if you want it to be. If you want to go on
record, then cool, give me a call (213.993.0291). I'm not looking to
slanderize the scene or the people, but give a good objective view on drug
use and addiction.

I'm on a tight deadline and would like to commence interviews early next
week, so contact me pronto. I think it's a worthwhile topic. Thanks in
advance for your help.

Hye guys!
        Ok, first of all I don't even know if this will make it through.
I haven't posted in about a year and I just resubscribed. I'm not a sfraves
steady cause I commute back and forth between L.A. during school (Harvey
Mudd. Go Mudders!) and SF during summer. 
        But I absolutely HAD to subscribe to flap my lips about what a 
great party Frequency 8 threw last night (I don't know if anyone else has
flapped yet so I'll keep the details low).
        After driving over an hour on an incredibly curving road, and then
hiking down the beach for what seemed like a mile, it was absolutely
incredible to see the faint glow of light sticks finally guiding our way
hundreds of yards away as the dull THUD THUD of the music could just be
heard over the crashing of the waves. And then to walk around the rocks into
a cove and have the music hit you hard as the bright green lights
illuminated hundreds of crazy dancers. Absolutely incredible.
        Several things to note: 
        1) the music was wonderful
        2) the location was incredible
        3) the people were amazing (the vibe was great and the organizers
           knew their shit and were incredibly nice too)

        Unfortunately the cops busted it, but even then the cops were 
completely cool about it. Even with the early bust I'd still say it was one
of the best parties I've ever been too. 
        Hi to Jake (yes I told my friend Ami that you tried to find her) and
Reza (remember me? JASON!!! the temporary guru of the evening) and to Purple
Tiger, and hi to all you sfravers that I didn't get to mee this time. Maybe
next time... And a big hello to my wonderful friend Amy Starkey who I
haven't been able to see all summer long. 

Absolutely Incredible!

                                                        lots o luv,

                                                           jason

Phred:
>>"Drum & space" . . . HAH, the Grateful Dead have played that at every show
>>for going on 20 years!  Hmm, the Dead had the Gyuto Monks come out and
>>chant during drums&space at their last Shoreline shows, maybe we can get
>>LTJ Bukem to do a breakout when they play Madison Square Garden in the
>>fall ... nah, nobody would understand ...

Rick Riffle:
> Yea, I was at that Dead show and saw the monks,  alot of people didn't
> understand then ethier.  I heard lots of giggles, and "what the ..."

I dunno. I think the dead's drums and space is a great way to get
"rockers" to open up to other kinds of musics, rhythms, melodies, and
the experimental/improvisational. I wonder how many Olatunji or Mickey
Hart tribal rhythm drumming albums got sold from deadheads that turned
on to those sounds at a show? SO I kinda disagree that "people don't
understand" but maybe the monks were just a bit too much for 'em.

Course space is a real hit n' miss thing at a dead show anyways. I've
heard drumz/space sound at least as good as live electro-funk Miles
Davis, or as bad as some of those japanese noize bands that think that
music is the sound you get from kicking a spring reverb guitar amp
(turned up to 11) all over the stage.

I still find the dead boring nowadays when they play live (IMHO). But I
was really into their shows back when they seemed to be more innovative
and energetic. I still like to throw on my Frost Amphitheater '82 tape
(my first dead show) to hear just how good they used to sound, and that
includes a pretty intersting space. (Never heard the dead play more
up-tempo than that ever again...).

Dear All;

	Emergency brake applied again, god it's the second time this 
week. People kill themselves, or develop emotional disorders, not because 
of drugs, but because they are all ready present/latent, get real. I will 
agree that drugs can bring these emotional disorders out quicker, but 
all in all they will show up eventually if that's what's in your psyci. 
People who tweek, and who stay up longer than 48 hours, don't eat, I'm 
sorry to say deserve what they get, YOU have to take care of yourself, if 
YOu are going to do harder drugs. This intails forcing youself to eat, 
regardless of how dry your mouth is, everyday, at least once a day, or 
whatever your normally used to. If you haven't slept in 48 hours, go tout 
to a drug store, get some benedryl, and take 1 tablet every 2 hours until 
you do sleep, and believe me you will after about 3 = 150mg.

	The human body is suppose to get 8 hours for every 16 its up, 
people who stay up for a week at a time, are asking for all sorts of 
problems, where's the maturity here, if you not mature enough to know you 
need to eat and sleep, you shouldn't be going drugs, be in college, or 
anywhere but attached to a leash, with your parents holding the other end 
of it. People need to take responsability for there actions, and not 
blame it of guns, drugs, and sex. YOU do it to youself, not the drugs, 
not the sex, not the guns, please do GROW THE FUCK UP, THE REST OF THE 
WORLD CAN'T WAIT!!!!!!!!

Rick Riffle:

>> understand then ethier.  I heard lots of giggles, and "what the ..."

Niels P. Mayer:
>I wonder how many Olatunji or Mickey
>Hart tribal rhythm drumming albums got sold from deadheads that turned
>on to those sounds at a show? SO I kinda disagree that "people don't
>understand" but maybe the monks were just a bit too much for 'em.

I'm one who got truned onto the "tribal drumming" thing through the Dead
and from that trancing out to drums (Micky Harts book Drumming at the Edge
of Magic had some influence) and drumming myself.  From that it took 
awhile before I figured out that you could trance out to drum machines
and techno but I finally got that to.  As far as people "not getting it" 
about the monks there, I was really amazed at the wide varity that did 
get it.  Teeny-boppers to frat types to old dreadlocked tourheads seemed 
to get it where I was.  The amazment level was quite high with only a few 
sinckers from those who didn't get it and some giggles from those who got
it all to well and could not supress the joy and amazement they felt.

Dear All;

	I disagree when someones tries and applies THEIR sense of
compassion, reality, addiction awareness, or anything else for that
matter, on to another human being. Its not about YOU, its about THEM, and
THEIR reality, THEIR needs, THEIR desires, THEIR dreams, what THEY think is
compassionate, what THEY want. When you love someone, its about letting
THEM go and finding whatever, & whomever they want to be, without YOUR
guilt & the shame, even if it's to hell in a hand basket. For all YOU, 
know this person after staying up for a week, may have an experience, 
that changes them in a positive way for the rest of their lives, as a 
result, they may quit drugs, go into research and develop a cure of 
cancer. All this because WE are uncomfortable with THEIR behaviour and 
what THEY feel THEY need to do to get though life at this point, this is 
nothing more than oppression. If WE are uncomfortable, WE need to either 
leave the situation or person, or look at internaly why it's making us 
uncomfortable, but no, WE expect THEM to change for US; HA!!!, and go as 
far as forcing them to change for us, is this LOVE, I think NOT!!!!!!

	It just reminds me of "I know what's best for you", how many of us
have heard that, and hated it. HOw could anyone possibly know what I what
or need, all you can do is guess, unless you ask the person in ?. We used
to do a little excersise in massage school called "I Observe, I image",
observations are whatever the senses are, feelings, seeing, hearing,
..etc. I image is what we do with that data. So an example, you're sitting
on a bus, you see a stranger across from you; You observe that person
rubbing their face, most people will say with absolute certainity hmmm I
image their face itches. But you don't know unless you check it out, and
ask that person what they are doing, it's just YOUR imagenation, for all
you know they could be a secret agent signaling a bombing, or whatever,
you just don't know. 

	I'm sorry, but for me this is the root of oppression, people who 
are uncomfortable with the actions, lifesytles, hobbies ...etc whatever, 
and expect the others to change, for them. LIVE & LET LIVE, is & was an 
AA/NA slogan. All gods(not that I believe in one), have a right to live & 
be, and follow their natural path, whether in be to ruin via drugs, or 
excellence via other paths like education, or natural leadership. I will 
continue to fight for the highest forms of love & freedom, though they 
may never be obtainable, I will try an arroach them as the limit of x of 
f(x) as x approaches infinity.

Sin;
Brian Darkness

production/promotion company. I will support any 12" artist or DJ in a minute
before I pay $10 or more for a one-night party...that what seperates me from
most of you people out there posting negative shit about me.....

sherrif's office.  No doubt the sherrif noticed the unusual increase of
parked cars on a Friday night and followed some ravers over to the beach.

asked F8 to shut down for "playing amplified music without a permit."

coast out of their and the sherrifs jurisdiction.   All and all, they were
rather nice about the whole affair, considering there were glass beer

Subject: MTV Special--Herbal E

Does anyone know who is doing the MTV look into raves and herbal ecstasy. I
have been constantly tormented by the herbal ecstasy people, who have offered
me money to endorse their shoddy product.  They have ripped off my logo fonts
from my book, put my on a GoDigal CD ROM Magizine study into rave scene and
took clips from a three hour video interview they did with me and inter-
spaced it with a blissed out surfer visiting a rave and taking herbal
ecstasy. Also, at a Megatripolis event (before I learned the truths of
Megatropolis first hand) in which I lectured, they advertised that I would be
there selling herbal ecstasy. I'd like to talk to MTV as author of the book
Ecstay: The MDMA Story with my regard to this noxious stuff A lot of kids are
being ripped off because of this stuff.. 

Bruce Eisner

why a post about a $25 rave *is* supported and your BSP isn't is

what you posted HAD NOTHING TO DO WITH SAN FRANCISCO RAVES. It's not 
that some of us find (well, found, because i'm sure noone gives a shit 
about you now, with that last post) your post irrelevant to the scene 
as a whole but it's NOT APPROPRIATE TO POST IT HERE. you seem to have 
no clue about something we call 'netiquette' which are your basic 
Internet manners - one of those rules of netiquette is that when you 
post to subject-specific mailing lists, you keep on the topic of those 
lists, otherwise, the penalty for not doing that is that people get on 
your back and bitch at you and such.  This whole argument isn't about 
DJ vs Promotor or this vs that - it's about you not following the 
(really, really basic) rules. And being an asshole about it.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 26 10:07:43 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA04450; Wed, 26 Jul 1995 10:07:43 -0700

From: Derek Chung <dhchung@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <199507261707.KAA04440@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: interactive DJ turntables for the Mac
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SF Raves)
Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 10:07:40 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: tactile@crl.com, kevingo@microsoft.com, mw@sybase.com,
        giamma@cyborganic.com
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 709       
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I've been working on a 3-d rendered, interactive DJ setup for the Mac,
and I've got a beta version up on the web for people to download and
play around with.  

It simulates a scene with two turntables and a mixer, and most of the
controls are functional, so you can crossfade, change speeds, adjust
the pitch, backspin, etc.  Again, it's for the Mac only, and please
let me know if you have any problems downloading it, running it, or 
if you notice bugs.

It's a binhex file located in the demos page hanging off my company's
web page:  Go to http://www.crl.com/~tactile, the click on the "Demos"
header next to the turntable.  This will go to the demos page which has
a link to download the file.

-Derek

Mr. Almighty Zheam,

GET A LIFE! The San Francisco Rave Scene repeatedly continues to impress anyone 
who is new to it, or anyone who has visited it, because of one main reason. And 
thats the VIBE!

The spirit of all these folks on SFR and beyond is so great, it's positively 
ecstatic ( no drugs needed! ). Everyone who has ever visited here from the 
midwest.east coast says that, although there are good things about those 
'scenes', they still wish the people were as friendly and nice as out here. It;s
rreally really sad to see that you dont appreciate that, and that without even 
trying youre putting up this huge attitude!

By your own actions youre saying you wont fit in. I think thats fine with us. To
quote a friend, " We dont need any more bad-vibers anyways ". Think about it 
dude.

Regards, 

Sy

I disagree.  Although talk like this is threatening to what we beleive
this list should be about, the minute we isolate ourselves from such talk
we compromise those beleifs ourselves.  There are people who take
similar forms as the above at almost every party we go to, but it
would be wrong to tell those people that they have no right to be
there because they don't "share the spirit."  The presence of these
vindictive and mean spirited words challenge our faith in the
meaning of raving, and inspire us to grow large enough where
we can find a way to coexist peacefully with Zheam.  It is only
when we can understand his anger and accept him that we
ourselves will find our peace.
We have to give in order to get, and kicking people off the list
isn't giving.

-john.

Okay kiddies, I went and had a look at the sfraves badge
(http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/archive, I think) and I see a big problem
right away - they're in full colour.  Very nice looking, but how can
someone who only has a black and white dot matrix printer make one up for
themselves?

Our badge is a simple black and white graphic which we copy onto brightly
coloured card stock, stick a wacky back on them and laminate.  Some of you
saw mine when I was there...

I think you might find it easier to have badges if you make them more
accessible to technologically challenged folk! :)

just a suggestion

THE NW-RAVES BADGE LADY

At 10:26 AM 7/26/95, John Elias Darrow wrote:

>I disagree.  Although talk like this is threatening to what we beleive
>this list should be about,

That was no threat to "what we beleive this list should be about" it was
direct personal threat put in the harshest possible language.

>There are people who take
>similar forms as the above at almost every party we go to, but it
>would be wrong to tell those people that they have no right to be
>there because they don't "share the spirit."

Any person that threatened someone at a party I helped throw would
instantly be removed from the premises, not because they didn't "share the
spirit" but because they posed a demnstrable threat to the safety of the
other people at the party.

>The presence of these
>vindictive and mean spirited words challenge our faith in the
>meaning of raving, and inspire us to grow large enough where
>we can find a way to coexist peacefully with Zheam.

Are you suggesting that the world (or this forum) should simply tolerate
the active manifestation of evil while we all struggle towards
enlightenment? Given that this might take a while ;) I think not.

Let me refresh your memory. zheam said:

"...and some of you like meclay, I swear on my religion that if you said
that shit in my face, it will be the last thing you fucking regret..."

This is specific threat aimed both at an individual and at other
unspecified members of this group. Allowing him access to this group only
allows him access (email addresses, hence finger, hence whois, etc.) to
people he has suggested he would committ violence towards.

To do this is insane, beyond which I would suggest that defending these
abhorrent actions on first amendment or "meaning of raving" grounds serves
only to distort these all too important ideals. Free speach should be
protected and the "spirit of raving" and more generally of peaceful caring
coexistence should definitely be fostered, but none of this has *anything*
to do with protecting individuals from demonstrable threats to their
physical well being, ie, from what I've seen, I don't want zheam to have my
address (and I don't mean email), do you?

take it easy
ethan



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 26 11:51:38 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA13362; Wed, 26 Jul 1995 11:51:38 -0700
Received: from netcom15.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA13265; Wed, 26 Jul 1995 11:51:16 -0700
Received: by netcom15.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id LAA16427; Wed, 26 Jul 1995 11:41:08 -0700
Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 11:41:07 -0700 (PDT)
From: Peter Fogel <peterf@netcom.com>
Subject: tues party @ bolinas
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9507261141.A8054-0100000@netcom15>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This was a fairly small party with a special ameba/bolinas vibe to it.  
Starting off with the naked dj allen.  By the time the next dj (kelly) came 
on, a few more naked people were dancing around.  
There was a small break in the music when Mr. policeman came down in his 
best authoritative voice, demanding who was responsible for the music and 
saying that all the naked people can be put in jail, especially the men, 
because there were no complaints about the women.  
It didn't take long for Mr. policeman to soften up as he felt the 
friendly vibe and saw that it was just a friendly party.  Asked us to 
turn the music down a little, which was done, and said "you could do what 
you want when I'm gone, if I could take my clothes off, I would, I don't 
make the rules."  With that Mr. policeman frolicted a bit up and down the 
beach a couple of times with a smile on his face before leaving.
After kelly spun tracy played some good high energy music.  After tracy 
came rebecca who brought more of an ambient sound.  I left during her set 
taking  a nice ride back to to sf as the sun set.
Thanks allen for the education on the 13 moon calender, which was reason 
for this party.  All in all it was a friendly, somewhat mellow party, 
with a free spirited vibe on a nice sunnyday at a nice senic beach.

:)
peter

REPLY FROM: Atherton, Darren
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com>
From: Derek Chung <dhchung@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <199507261707.KAA04440@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: interactive DJ turntables for the Mac
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SF Raves)
Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 10:07:40 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: tactile@crl.com, kevingo@microsoft.com, mw@sybase.com,
    giamma@cyborganic.com
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 709       
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I've been working on a 3-d rendered, interactive DJ setup for the Mac,
and I've got a beta version up on the web for people to download and
play around with.  

It simulates a scene with two turntables and a mixer, and most of the
controls are functional, so you can crossfade, change speeds, adjust
the pitch, backspin, etc.  Again, it's for the Mac only, and please
let me know if you have any problems downloading it, running it, or 
if you notice bugs.

It's a binhex file located in the demos page hanging off my company's
web page:  Go to http://www.crl.com/~tactile, the click on the "Demos"
header next to the turntable.  This will go to the demos page which has
a link to download the file.

-Derek

>I can't seem to be able to down load this file- I received a message at the
>end of the transmission that states something to the point of,  "netscape
>needs more allocated memory or to quit all other applications."
>
>I adjusted the minium and preferred memory for netscape to 7320 megs and
>turned off all other non net inits and still was in the dark (I have 24megs
>total, with about 16 free)- I then tried another mac and still could not get
>the file- There maybe some sort of problem with the way the file was binhexed
>or you may wish to use another form of transmission, so that people will not
>have to make radical adjustments to obtain it-

Try loading direct to disk (on a mac, with sys 7.5 or drag n drop extension
you can just grab the link and drag it over to the desktop or any other
finder folder to do this). You don't wnat to have to cut and paste the
binhex into a text file anyway... Then just drag the text file over to
stuffit expander and you're good to go.

The demo is fun! I like it alot. There doesn't seem to be a headphones cue
type of function, though- mixing in the dark is HARD (not that I could mix
anyway :)

-Brian
http://www.cyborganic.com/People/paul/

"PS:Don't worry, I doubt it very much if I do want to hang out with most of

    Smells like sour grapes too.

"That's why in the areas that are
real like the east coast, you hear of the Josh Winks, The Derrick Carters,
The Basement Boys, Frankies Knuckles and NOT the so-and-so event, or
production/promotion company."

I hope you're not comparing yourself to some of the above.   I'll bet those
guys don't resort to some of your regretable tactics, or sink to your level
of maturity, or rather, lack thereof.   I just can't see Josh Wink getting on
a list and telling people to run out and buy his new single.   If it's real,
and good, then it only needs to get played.   You would have been better off
trying to get a few DJ's to play your tune, to test the response, etc...That
is, if they would have played it.   I don't know, maybe you tried that
already?   


"All I wanted to say is that what I learn from this list is what I've already
learned about SF when I used to live there back in '88 and that most of the
Cali people aren't true to the rave scene.  I've been visiting the Bay area
ever since I moved away and been there as recent as Spring Break and nothing
changed....:("

Hmm,  It seems your skull is a bit thick, if you learned the lesson in '88,
and then again from this list, why even bother with us.   And who are YOU to
say what the rave scene IS, and judge who is being true to it.  I think your
thinking is foul.  Why don't you just go away?   Seems like it would make a
lot of people, yourself included, a little happier, or at least for the rest
of us, alleviate a needless annoyance.   You really need to chill, and think
before you speak, or commit anything to this list.       Tom

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 26 14:25:59 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: high school
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Last night I was reminded of a particularly inspired moment
in high school.  At lunch my friends and I started running through
the hallways yelling "fight, fight, there's a fight!".  By the time
we got to the main courtyard there were about twenty people in tow.
By the time we rounded the gym at least a hundred people were
following us. 

We thought we were pretty damn funny. 

I've been frightened more than once by people on this list.

I don't know which is worse - public fronting or private email.
The latter leaves you feeling very violated.  It's like you are
sitting around whistling dixie and then all of a sudden you've
become someone's personal fixation.  When someone actually 
demands that I spend time on their problems my reaction 
has usually been an amazed - "wow, this is real"

I find it very stalkerish.  Instead of the misplaced connection
that nutcases feel they have with very famous people, on sfraves
the distorted sense of intimacy derives from someone projecting how 
they personally think of the list onto everyone else.

I guess I accept it as part of the nature of sfraves.  

Dave

At 09:06 PM 7/25/95 CST, AUSAR@SIUCVMB.SIU.EDU wrote:

>tell about BSP are out to get a profit.  Can't no promotor or a pagan
>moon-worshipping gathering offer the rave scene more than what the DJs  or
>beatmaker contributes to the dance scene. That's why in the areas that are
>real like the east coast, you hear of the Josh Winks, The Derrick Carters,
>The Basement Boys, Frankies Knuckles and NOT the so-and-so event, or
>production/promotion company. I will support any 12" artist or DJ in a minute
>before I pay $10 or more for a one-night party...that what seperates me from
>most of you people out there posting negative shit about me.....
>
Just a response from those of us who don't make or play music - we just
enjoy hearing it.  Where do you think _we_ hear all this great music being
made?  The vast majority of us don't have massive record collections...to
hear the best, latest music we go to parties.  I know many, many ppl who
upon hearing a particular track that they really like will go up, find out
what it is, and then buy it shortly thereafter.  Yes, DJs contribute a whole
lot to the scene, and they make damn good money from ppl who are willing to
pay $10 or whatever to see them spin at a party - I call that supporting the
DJ.  Promoters are a neccessary evil, and events are hyped up because of the
DJs playing at them.  You just don't seem to see the connection...

>PS:Don't worry, I doubt it very much if I do want to hang out with most of
>you anyway and some of you like meclay, I swear on my religion that if you
>said that shit in my face, it will be the last thing you fucking regret...
>
Hmmm, you're trying for the Mr. Congeniality award, aren't you?

Jim

On Wed, 26 Jul 1995, David Alves wrote:

> I've been frightened more than once by people on this list.

When you were with them in person or over cyberspace?

> I don't know which is worse - public fronting or private email.
> The latter leaves you feeling very violated.  It's like you are
> sitting around whistling dixie and then all of a sudden you've
> become someone's personal fixation.  When someone actually 
> demands that I spend time on their problems my reaction 
> has usually been an amazed - "wow, this is real"
> 
> I find it very stalkerish.  Instead of the misplaced connection
> that nutcases feel they have with very famous people, on sfraves
> the distorted sense of intimacy derives from someone projecting how 
> they personally think of the list onto everyone else.

Well, I'll bet you a million dollars that this Zheam character has not 
been on sfraves very long or has met one single person off of this list.  
I laughed at everything he wrote except for the threat of bodily harm.  I 
have gotten the pleasure of meeting *many* of you off this list and know 
that every one of you are wonderful.  To see someone such as Zheam make 
such rude remarks and generalizations without taking the time to get to 
know us makes me laugh at his ignorance.  I know what sfravers are like.  
We all know what  the scene is about.  We all have our version of our 
"truth" within ourselves so we don't even need to feel threatened by the 
likes of Zheam.  If I were to get flamed by him, I simply push the D 
button and move on.  I don't need it, so I won't acknowledge it. 

love,
Amy

On Wed, 26 Jul 1995, John Elias Darrow wrote:
> We have to give in order to get, and kicking people off the list
> isn't giving.

Kicking people off lists just doesn't work, either.  It only makes the
kick-ee more inspired to try and get back on, if not through the same
account, through other accounts.  Any barrier I put up can be worked around,
unless I want to make this a totally closed list whose entry requires filling
out a 15-question "are you a raver" form or something silly like that. 

Zheam's message was unusually harsh in that it contained a not-so-veiled 
threat of personal injury to another list member.  There are appropriate 
ways to deal with that behavior (which I have initiated).

	Brian

Dear Zheam;

	Wow threats, my haven't we stepped down from our religion, which
one is it The New Church of The Neo-Neanderthraw Rednecks of Jahbip, can I
sign up so that I to can, rightously threaten people, and make them
something less than my high and mighty self, because of what they think or
believe. If God's on your side, I don't want to believe. You talk hate
Zheam, I felt a very derogatory note when you mentioned Pagan Moon
Worshipping. I got news for you and your god, WE ALL SHINE; LOVE, WE ARE
ALL EQUAL, NOT ONE OF GOD'S CREATURES IS LESS THAN ANOTHER BY VIRTUAL OF
ANYTHING, THE LEAST OF WHICH ARE BELIEF SYSTEM'S. 

	Hon, I lived on the East Coast, I grew up there, North, New York,
Philadelphia, Baltimore, DC; South, Gainesville, Jacksonville, Orlando,
whatever & where ever, I feel you will not find a more dedicated vibe, than 
here in SF. Also every soul I've met on this list has been nothing but
upstanding, kind, honest, human, examples; to live & learn from, all. 
Even when we've argued, and disagreed with each other, they've always had 
a hug and a smile for me when I ran into them at a party, even 
after I opened by mouth & inserted by keyboard.

	However, vibe is something that is subjective, and you are
entitled to your feelings & thoughts, less the threats, which are
unexcussable for any person short of a thug. Zheam, despite either your
inability, or fear to communicate what's really on your heart, I don't
believe you are a thug. Any FOOL can go out and hurt, that's only imagened
power, it takes someone special to change the minds of humanity, and lead
by example, and there are many examples of that here on this list, and in
our ranks. 

	Funny you should mention DJ's rather than music creators, I've
seen Josh(From Me Home Town) & Derrick, on more the one occasion & they
rip, but I wonder what they would think of you threating a bunch of people
you don't even know. Some people make a ripple when they come onto the
list, others make a splash, I was one of those. I find it helpful when I
use the words, "I'm sorry", "I was wrong", "I made a mistake", or just I
statements, speaking from the self, sharing your feelings; is & will
always be welcome by most healthy human beings. Cause when you point that
finger, a funny thing happens, you have 3 pointing back at you. I've
appoloized to individuals here, and to the entire list at times, ya know,
it feels good when I do it, it takes the pressure of me having to be right
all the time, it allows me to be human. Your also the 1st person that 
I've ever met that said the East Coast was better, when we got western's 
back there, the 1st ? was why did you leave(in an assotonishing tone). 
The scenes & vibes are different for every part of the country, just like 
the music you here in the clubs, SF's house DJ's couldn't find work 
except in the Disco's of North Central Florida, rather than the Techno 
clubs, cause its's a big trance scene down there.

	DA people on here aren't promoters, for the most part, you're
talkin about less than 5% of the people here, The promoters I know like
Ethan M. & F&F, Greg S. of Harmony, Pacific, Drenalin & others of The
Cloud Factory, Geoff W. of Full Moon, Matt, Claire, & Jake ..etc of
Gateway Systems & others to numerours but worthy of mention have never had
a $25.00 party, maybe you mean Cruel World, anyway. How do I know cause
I've voulenteered/worked for-em all, and my heart & my better than a AWACS
survailence planes intutition tells me so. I assure that you will be given
the same latitute if and when we meet. 

	But at 1st glance, you seem to have a lot to prove, and equally as
much to lose. If some generalalites can be made about the people on this
list, their creative, their innovators, intelligent; academically,
technicially, as well as street smart, some are very gifted; they made
their own way in life, make their own rules, believe their own hearts &
minds, are leaders; and lead by example, are kind, loving, forgiving,
open, honest, politically/evironmentally aware & active, alternative
lifesytle affirmative, for choices, for liberty, respectful, tolerant,
questioning, open minded, artistic; both traditionally & in the
contempory, musicians, engineers, scientists, students, healthcare 
professionals, bums, rouges, vagabonds, hacks, non-violent, but all equal. 

	You will get a lot of attention coming in like gang busters, but
all negative, and I think that's not what you want. If what you have to
offer is good, it will stand out, and people will regonize it for that,
and you will be an asset to OUR scene. But threating people will only take
away from your work, and the long hard hours I'm sure you've put into
it(heart & soul). Raves are people first, it's a party, I come to be with
kind people not just to here the music spin, that's what rock n roll's
become, I come because it's about me, them, us, everybody, not just one 
person, or group, and that's just my opinion.

	People are fearful of someone who's got something to sell, prove,
preach, no one want's to be taken or oppressed by someone elses reality,
or belief system's, and especially if they don't know the person that well. 
When people hear your music that's when they will decide, but you've
already got them wearing colored glasses. We all have our own paths 
Zheam, and if WE CHOSE we can change the direction that where on. Again 
I've found the people on this list to be understanding, forgiving, and 
most of all their aware of their own humanity, and when you see it in 
yourself, it's hard to condem others for it, or at least hold a grudge.

> tell about BSP are out to get a profit.  Can't no promotor or a pagan

> beatmaker contributes to the dance scene. That's why in the areas that are
> real like the east coast, you hear of the Josh Winks, The Derrick Carters,
> The Basement Boys, Frankies Knuckles and NOT the so-and-so event, or
> production/promotion company. I will support any 12" artist or DJ in a minute
> before I pay $10 or more for a one-night party...that what seperates me from

Dear Deleuze;

	This is what I was told to do by a Doctor of Emergency Medince at 
Alta Bates Hospital, when I walked in, said I been doing ##### for the 
past 48 hours and can't get to sleep, what can I do to help myself. The 
first thing he said was don't do #####, the next thing he said was go get 
some benedrly and take it until I slept, in fact he even gave be an IM 
injection of 50mg to start me off. When it comes to the body, or the 
health of myself or others, I assure you I'm slightly more liberal than 
the doctors, but not much, and would never addvocate doing anything I 
haven't discussed with someone much more knowledgeable than me, and done 
myself first. DISCLAIMER: Of course when in these situtions always consult a 
qualified health care professional before taking any actions. abOVE ALL 
PLEASE TAKE CARE OF YOURSELF WHEN DOIN THE HARDER DRUGS; GET SLEEP, & EAT 
REGULAR MEALS, YOU MAY FEEL IMMORTAL, BUT THEY MAY JUST PROVE HOW MORTAL 
YOU ARE.

hello everyone.  i'm new at this (raving) after having been dragged in
kicking and screaming by jake (with the 4ad .sig).  i love it, and i love
the people.
just one thing : when i was growing up, one thing i learned was to
wait.  if a member of this community wants to blast sfraves, let him, and
take the wind from his sails.  as a former asshole (high school and back)
i know the most frustrating response to a threat is a smile. i (and i
encourage the rest of us to join me ) am smiling.
ok, another thing : the other lesson i learned (rather recently, in fact)
was to forgive.  why not?  why fall prey to to the inhumanity that most
ravers i've met are trying to escape?

peace within us, peace behind us, peace under our feet
peace between us, peace over us, let everybody be peace.

     etc.

     look at myself before I make a statement and to uphold what I believe.

     could do in life for myself and others.  (It's not so dismal, really!)

     positive (yin and yang) by reaffirming what brought us to this list.

     (okay, more than a few) negative posts from time to time on this list

     to take the heat.  We'll regain a balance much like nature only this 
     is in cyberspace.

     need a hug.

Subject: friends letting friends
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 18:08:34 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2848      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


So what _can_ you do if a friend is (in your judgement) abusing liquor/
coke/meth/weed/H/whatever?

Make sure you and others aren't encouraging it.  "Oh man, he's
_so_ funny when he's wasted."  "Who cares if you got to work tomorrow?
It's an FMR, dude."  "Sure you don't want another bong hit?"

Let them know, sometime when they're listening to you, that you think
they're out of control, and that you don't want to be with them when
they are.  Make sure they know that you _will_ be there for them if they
try to kick, and follow through on both sides of your promise.  _Don't_
keep saving people from their own drug-induced stupidity unless it's
literally life and death.  (I once helped shepherd a friend through a
bad night of downers and JD.  He was trying to kill himself with a Swiss
Army knife, beard crusted blue from all the pills he had taken (prescribed
for him by some not-very-good psychiatrist).
His other friend and I kept him awake and alive -- his friend
by staring him down and saying "Look, motherfucker.  If you die, I'm dying
with you.  Every one of these little blue pills you eat, I eat.  Every shot
you take, I take.  Here's a fifth of JD.  Come on, let's get started.  You
want to die?  Let's go."  By this time we had kept him talking long enough
that his previous intake got to him and he fell asleep after only a couple
of rounds.  I hung around for a few hours to make sure both of them were
a) breathing and b) sleeping on their side so they didn't swallow their
own vomit and choke.  The next day he went into rehab.  It's not fun to
wake up in your own bodily fluids with police citations you don't remember 
and can't pay stuffed in your pockets.)

You can't force anyone to do anything.  Only you can change the way you
live.  If someone doesn't want to kick, they won't, and they'll just backslide
once you're gone.

Be careful of AA.  They preach (literally) a strange brand of recovery, which
trades your addiction to drugs for an addiction to the group (you're always
a 'recovering alcoholic' even if you've been sober for twenty years), and
a dependence on a 'higher power' taken usually to mean the god of the Bible.
This is usually preferable to death, but I find twelve-step zombies just as
dysfunctional as drug abusers, albeit in a more societally acceptable way.

Know what you're talking about.  Don't give advice from ignorance ("X drains
your spinal fluid") or you'll be completely cut off when they figure out 
you're bullshitting.

Offer alternatives.  What else is there to do that drugs are preventing them
from doing?  If you can't answer this, take a serious look at your position.

Be there for them.

// g

-- Disclaimer: I am controlled by thought transmitters emanating from the evil
-- Xapulon Empire, and wish nothing more than to retract everything I say.
-- grigsby@shell.portal.com
