	Man!  This recent rash of violent/political/wayoutphilosophy posts 
seems to have watered down the rave review posts.  I thought that I'd 
interject a couple of pennies here.

	Friends & Family (#?)  aka the Joe Rice birthday party --

	mmmmmmm baby..... a little lower.  This party scratched my rythmic itch
in one fierce way.  I hadn't been out in a while -- solyluna in Berkeley 
being my last official outing -- so this was just what the doctor ordered.
The space was choice as usual.  Just the right size for an intimate, high vibe,
goin' off sweaty mess.  Lots of new faces at this one, as well as the usual
cast of characters that over the last year I've become accustomed to.  And the
tunes!  Plus, visuals that keep getting better and better.  Even though it's 
the same people doing them, the stuff doesn't get stale.  Some of the old 
movie footage worked really well. 

	My memory's a little cloudy, so forgive me if this isn't 100% correct.
I got there after a wonderful Thai meal at _Basil_, which is a reasonably
priced, very groovy little place to grab a bite.  We arrived just as Ethan 
came on, and he led us on an amazing deep trance/techno journey that got me on
the floor right away.  A very solid set led into some high bpm stuff played
very well by jonathan (last name escapes me).  That boy came on and worked the
floor hard!  By the middle of his set, I had exhausted myself and set out to
find a ride home.

	Amazing this community we've got here -- within five minutes of 
asking around, I found a way home from a couple of people I had only met once
before (my ride being the early bedtime types).  Thanks again to Don and
Nathan for the ride. This party was such a contrast to the more typical 
kegobeer gathering I had attended last week.  Even if the face was unfamiliar,
it was friendly. 

	Next on in the main room was Joe's cool friend :-) who played a nice
slightly more funky set -- the pace had gotten a little monotonous by then.
Didn't last long, and I was out getting a superb backrub by our very own 
susie.  Ask her for one next time, you won't regret it...  Unfortunately,
I missed most of Joe's set, but the part that I herd was nice.  By this time
(ca. 3am), the chill space had filled up, and things were starting to thin
out a bit.  We moseyed around four, missing Bryce's set which sounded, uh....
educational!  (whished I would have heard the godfather on a big soundsystem)

	An evening well spent.

take good care of it,

steve

OnNow: Creation Rebel and the New Age Steppers, _Threat to Creation_ 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
= 		    Steve Boyer (sboyer@violet.berkeley.edu)		     =
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Quoth: Grigsbeast <grigsby@shell.portal.com>

>So what _can_ you do if a friend is (in your judgment) abusing liquor/
>coke/meth/weed/H/whatever?
>
>Make sure you and others aren't encouraging it.  "Oh man, he's
>_so_ funny when he's wasted."  "Who cares if you got to work tomorrow?
>It's an FMR, dude."  "Sure you don't want another bong hit?"
>
>Let them know, sometime when they're listening to you, that you think
>they're out of control, and that you don't want to be with them when
>they are.  Make sure they know that you _will_ be there for them if they
>try to kick, and follow through on both sides of your promise.  _Don't_
>keep saving people from their own drug-induced stupidity unless it's
>literally life and death.

This a good start.

>Be careful of AA.  They preach (literally)

AA has no preachers. AA members traditionally share their "experience
strength and hope." On rare occasions someone forgets this tradition and
gets preachy. I just tune them out.

> a strange brand of recovery, which

A brand of recovery that has been working well for 55 years and has been
copied by nearly everyone in the recovery field. Including, almost
certainly the rehab your friend went to.

>trades your addiction to drugs for an addiction to the group (you're always
>a 'recovering alcoholic' even if you've been sober for twenty years), and

Well, kinda. However, for me, drinkin'n'drugin' took up at least 60 hours per
week. While recovery only takes about 6 hours per week.

>a dependence on a 'higher power' taken usually to mean the god of the Bible.

Not in the meetings I go to. Most of the sober people I know are into pre
x-tian spirituality. AA is different everywhere you go. Meetings close to
Haight street tend to have lots of pierced and tattooed nonx-tian freaks
(isn't that amazing?) You/your friends may find Haight area meetings more
to your liking.

>This is usually preferable to death, but I find twelve-step zombies just as
>dysfunctional as drug abusers, albeit in a more societally acceptable way.

Some are as dysfunctional. However they are the ones who are, in fact, not
working the 12 steps.

>Know what you're talking about.  Don't give advice from ignorance ("X drains
>your spinal fluid") or you'll be completely cut off when they figure out
>you're bullshitting.

That sounds alot like the "one addict helping another" one finds in NA and AA.

>Offer alternatives.  What else is there to do that drugs are preventing them
>from doing?  If you can't answer this, take a serious look at your position.

Also, what are drugs making them do. (puke, crash motor vehicles, spend
rent money...)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 21:02:18 -0700
From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
To: sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu
Subject: (fwd) REASONS WHY E-MAIL IS LIKE A PENIS:


Some folks have it, some don't. Those who have it would be
devastated  if it were ever cut off. They think that those who don't
have it are  somehow inferior. They think it gives them power. They
are wrong. Those who don't have it may agree that it's an nifty toy,
but think it's  not worth the fuss that those who do have it make
about it. Still, many  of those who don't have it would like to try it.

It can be up or down. It's more fun when it's up, but it makes it hard
to get any real work done.

In the long-distant past, its only purpose was to transmit
information  considered vital to the survival of the species. Some
people still think that's the only thing it should be used for, but
most folks today use it for fun most of the time.

Once you've started playing with it, it's hard to stop. Some people
would just play with it all day if they didn't have work to do.

It provides a way to interact with other people. Some people
take this  interaction very seriously, others treat it as a lark.
Sometimes it's hard to tell what kind of person you're dealing with
until it's too late.

If you don't apply the appropriate protective measures, it can
spread  viruses.

It has no brain of its own. Instead, it uses yours. If you use
it too  much, you'll find it becomes more and more difficult to think
coherently.

We attach an importance to it that is far greater than its actual size
and influence warrant.  If you're not careful what you do with it, it
can get you in big trouble.

It has its own agenda.  Somehow, no matter how good your intentions,
it  will warp you behavior. Later you may ask yourself "why on earth
did I  do that?"

It has no conscience and no memory.  Left to its own devices,
it will do the same damn dumb things again and again.



--

|   =(_^_)=   |         Amy

On Wed, 26 Jul 1995, Jonas Judd wrote:

> 
> >I have noticed that when people receive automated replies, 
> >they tend to get real pissed >:) 
> 
> Does this imply you enjoy making others angry?
> 
> 
When someone is continually posting "Your an asshole Blah Blah Blah" 
messages it tends to make one a bit upset. So rather than posting back a 
nasty message myself, I choose to filter. It prevents me from continuing the 
cycle of negativity by removing the cause. I think it a very valid compromise.
I am happy because I don't have to worked up about some twit, and 
aforementioned twit is often pissed because they can't send me nasty mail, 
generally forcing them to direct their negativity elsewhere. And that makes me
feel GREAT, because I am forcing the anger, etc. right back at the person 
without involving myself further in their inadequacy issues. 

> 
> If an individual emotes negative behavior, wouldn't it be in our best
> interest to affect the individual as positively as possible to help create a
> positive CHANGE away from negativity, as opposed to reinforcing it?  

An interesting question. But by doing nothing except refusing to accept 
negativity in the form of e-mail, how am I reinforcing it? Has it become 
my task to change the attitudes of the millions of disaffected? Sorry, I 
never signed up for that job. Involving yourself constantly with negative
people, situations, attitudes constantly will drain you.

I can only live my life based on my experiences, and beliefs that have 
come from those experiences. And what I have found in my own life, is 
that the individual had to decide their own mind set. Some people enjoy 
misery, hate and anger. Nothing is going to change that unless they want 
to change it. You can be as positive to them as you want, but unless they 
have the will within themselves to change, you efforts will have no 
effect. 

I see my job in life to be as happy a person as I can and to extend it to 
others. However, it is not my place to foist my happiness upon those who 
do not wish to be involved in it, just at it no ones' place to force 
their religion(spirituality,etc.) upon me.   

> 
> Perhaps I'm being nitpicky, but this I don't understand.
> 
> Jonas

No, I just think that we have differing views of how to relate to people. 
I respect your view and the way you live your life, but it is your 
formula for life. Please respect mine.

                                            Black Adder

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 11:45:50 -0800 (PST)
Subject: feed the fish
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Message-Id: <01HTD3FZSCS200JFR7@EDEN1.HAC.COM>
X-Vms-To: EDEN1::IN%"sfraves@hyperreal.com",EDEN1::IN%"socal-raves@ucsd.edu"
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

just thot i should add something positive to the mix; thangs have been
  getting down (esp on sfraves) lately...

i wuz on sabattical (sp?) for 6 weeks on the island of moorea last month,
  (it's right next to tahiti, about 2000 miles south of hawaii) just to
   get away from technology for awhile and to just watch the world go by.
my morning ritual was to make some breakfast, like eggs and bagettes with
  jam, and then to sit out on the beach with a cup o' java.  now, i wasn't
    just sitting ON the beach, i was actually halfway in the water.  over
      there, the islands are surrounded by a lagoon, which is as still as
        a mountain lake in the morning.  i mean you can clearly see clouds
         mirrored in it.
anyway, cut to the chase.  the lagoon has ZILLIONS of fish in it, and after
  a week, i had trained this rather large group of fish to recognize me as
    a source of bread.  i'd toss some little bits into the water, and the
      fish would come by and start nibbling the bread.  then, as their
       fear of peeple would pass, i'd stick a piece of bread between my
         two biggest toes and stick my foot in the water.  what a strange
          feeling, having hundreds of fish jostle for a piece of bread 
            around your foot!  these fish didn't have any teeth that i
              could determine, and so it basically felt like kisses or
                like a gentle touch. even after the bread was gone,
                  the fish would linger for up to an hour, hoping for more.
after a week, all i had to do was just plop my beach chair into the water
  and the fish would go for my foot.  over a hundred would show up within
    five minutes.  they knew the place and time, for sure.
hopefully, some of the pix i took will develop well, and i'll post them
  to my homepage; i even photo'ed the fish swarming around my coffeecup
    in about 2 inches of water; they were even swimming through the
      handle of the cup, if you can believe that!  

if yer ever in tahiti, make like a bastard for the lagoon with some bread.
  you won't be dissapointed!

Dave Scruton
Fractallonomy
http://hyperreal.com/~scruton  (soon to be updated, i promise)

From: csil@hooked.net
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

X-mailer: Pegasus Mail for Windows (v2.01)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>  ...the lagoon has ZILLIONS of fish in it, and after
>   a week, i had trained this rather large group of fish to recognize me as
>     a source of bread...

[SNIP]

> ...after a week, all i had to do was just plop my beach chair into the water
>   and the fish would go for my foot.  over a hundred would show up within
>     five minutes.  they knew the place and time, for sure.
> hopefully, some of the pix i took will develop well, and i'll post them
>   to my homepage; i even photo'ed the fish swarming around my coffeecup
>     in about 2 inches of water; they were even swimming through the
>       handle of the cup, if you can believe that!  

That sounds like an experience that you would never forget. The 
simplest things in life sometimes can be the most meaningful. Nature 
is truly beautiful and sometimes we all just need to take a break 
from eveything and just be with nature. Whether it be in the forest, 
a lake, a patch of flowers, we just need to appreciate our beautiful 
surroundings. I love taking long walks in the forest and just 
listening to all the truly beautiful sounds that emminate there. I 
feel like I am in another world, not bound by reality. It is a 
spiritual experience and after I decide to come back to the 'real 
world', I always feel so rejuvenated. I feel like I have received new 
strength to deal with the not so nice things we all so often have to 
deal with. 
 Please post or email me when you get your home page updated, I would 
love to take a short trip through your wonderful experience!

Luv to all! ;)
-----------------------------------------------------------
Christopher Silveira
a.k.a. eric longfellow (the lost dj)

Subject: New Moon party this Friday!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9507271353.A270-0100000@fly2.berkeley.edu>

hello friends--

this is heather, just back from the wasteland, and have to tell you how 
beautiful it is to be here, if only for a short time.  This seems to be a 
very special week, doesn't it?  The day out of time, the new moon, and 
weird and wonderful things happening every which way you look.  

The ever-growing new moon collective is celebrating the first new moon of 
the new Mayan calendar at a favorite place near Bodega Bay (where Glenn 
and I were married last June new moon)  on this FRIDAY.  It's about a 2 hour 
drive, but this party and this place are worth the trip.  The rangers are 
really nice, too.

We'll be starting at sunset and continuing well into Saturday.  Call (415) 
267-3076 for directions.  We will be dropping off directions at the 
amebas tonight as well if you want a written copy.

Things to bring:
--an open heart and mind:  this is a celebration of the sacred cycles
--extra warm clothes, as this beach can be quite windy and cold at night
--a flashlight per car is essential, as there is a rocky bit   
  on the way;  you need to be able to see
--blankets, sunscreen, lots of water, food, firewood
--flowers

One last thing--we are going to set up little bags with sand in them for 
ashtrays. They'll be up near the front somewhere.  Please, come and get 
one for your butts if you are going to smoke.

One other last thing--we are trying to put together a little first aid 
kit (I can't help myself--I'm a medical student).  If you have any of 
these things, and you feel like bringing them and lending them to us for 
the duration of the party, please bring them and give them to one of the 
new mooners. Also if you need any of these things, please come and find 
Heather.  We need/will have: bandaids, neosporin, emergency water, 
visine, sunscreen, tampons, condoms, calamine lotion, moisturizer, 
asprin, ibuprofin, antihistamines, a cellular phone.

A big warm welcome to the Hymns and Anthems Tribe--the circles are 
closing!

Hope to see you on Friday.  

This is (in the words of Mona Love)

The New Moon sometimes Afterglow always Great Day Times

	Hey, y'all! It's time for me to stop slacking in college and
get a Real Job (tm), and the paths of time and tide are drawing me
towards the Bay Area. I'm coming to town early next week (strictly
during the week so I keep my broke self down to business) and then I'm
moving two weeks after that.
	Here's where I make a shameless plea and throw myself on the
sfraves commmunity's mercy: I need somewhere to stay on Monday and
Tuesday nights of next week, and I'm also looking for an
apartment. Although I'm not exactly sure where I'm going to be working
yet, I'm sort of assuming that the best place for me to live would be
somewhere in the East Bay. But I'm not too set on that.
	Anyway, I'll keep this brief to keep the signal/noise ratio
level of this list at its usual high level. :| If any of you would
like to help a friendly, clean raver / DJ / computer geek type out,
I'd love to hear from you. All thanks in advance.

   Lotsa action this weekend - two new moon parties, plus big parties
   Area 51 and Catastrophic, plus the dependable Organic. There'll be
   free parties on Sunday, one in Golden Gate Park (at the bandshell, I
   guess) and probably Sunset again. Then Wednesday is Come-Unity at
   1015.
   
   If I may plug myself, I'll be spinning at the gathering at the
   Internet Salon Friday evening, along with SFRavers Paraffin & Phred,
   and I'll be demo'ing my 3-d interactive turntable simulation on the
   Mac there as well.
   
                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html
    
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Thursday, July 27th - free party under the new moon
   DJs Virgil, John Mac, Gouracandra, NYC Sen-Sei, Lil' Steven, Andre
   Lucero. free, 45 min north of SF. Bring water, blankets, warm clothes.
   415.679.3113
   
   Friday, July 28th - Catastrophic - The Next Frontier
   LA's Ron D Core & Simply Jeff, Seattle's Donald Glaude, Chicago's
   Zee-Que, SF's Graeme LaPaix, DJ Dan, Carlos, Tony, Jam N J, Utopia.
   Santa Cruz Civic Auditorium. 415.939.2468 209.991.4726
   
   Friday, July 28th - Fresh Brewed
   Brewmasters Rick Preston, Christophe, Henrik, Olivier. Doors 9-3,
   cover $10. free beer 9-1:30. 435 Broadway, SF. 21+. 415.995.1973
   
   Friday, July 28th - Organic 
   residents cesar, graeme, dj dan, jeno & australia's phil smart.
   9pm-6am, $10. 415.266.8215
   
   Friday, July 28th - Ethics
   Personifying the Sound: Spun, Josh, Christophe, Jeff Miller, Jon
   Bishop. Flavoring the Party: Psychedelic Workshop, lighting and lasers

       90.1 Stanford

       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)

       90.1 (Stanford)

       90.3 (SF)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 27 17:39:12 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA06649; Thu, 27 Jul 1995 17:39:12 -0700

	id RAA24479; Thu, 27 Jul 1995 17:36:49 -0700
Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 17:36:49 -0700
Message-Id: <199507280036.RAA24479@ix5.ix.netcom.com>
From: sequoia1@ix.netcom.com (Chris Chervin )
Subject: To us drug users
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Drugs can be a very positive thing.  They can open people up to the 
reality of the universe and the beauty of the inner being.  The lessons 
of certain particular drugs (IMHO psycadelics and especialy E)  can be 
the greatest gifts in the world. But we must be careful.

If we don't strive to live our everyday lives as we do when we are high 
than we must question our use of the drug.  We should get high to have 
a great time and most of all to learn.

Carry it over.  E has an afterglow.  In many ways this glow can last 
your whole life.  Hold on to the feelings of ecstacy as much as you 
can. Strive to reach the point where you no longer use drugs.  I know 
this must be possible.

love chris

On Thu, 27 Jul 1995, Chris Chervin wrote:

> Drugs can be a very positive thing.  They can open people up to the 
> reality of the universe and the beauty of the inner being.  The lessons 
> of certain particular drugs (IMHO psycadelics and especialy E)  can be 
> the greatest gifts in the world. But we must be careful.
> 
> Carry it over.  E has an afterglow.  In many ways this glow can last 
> your whole life.  Hold on to the feelings of ecstacy as much as you 
> can. Strive to reach the point where you no longer use drugs.  I know 
> this must be possible.

I echo these sentiments...
Drugs can provide people with rich, rewarding experiences, or they can 
tear apart one's perceptions and make a person dependent on 
them...everyone's just got to find that fine line between use and 
addiction and make sure that they stay on the right side.


always toasty,

- Opus

Hey all,

The main reason I pay for online service is to have sfraves.  The main 
reasons I like sfraves is because I find out info about raves.  To me 
raves include mix tapes, 12 inch records, house partys, and experiences 
from those partys as they effect our everyday life. SFRaving IS a way 
of life.

I may be out of hand as to the context of the list but please keep 
promoting yourselves.  The Power of internet is its ability to allow 
the underground to spread without the need of the media.

love chris

>Drugs can be a very positive thing.  They can open people up to the
>reality of the universe and the beauty of the inner being.  The lessons
>of certain particular drugs (IMHO psycadelics and especialy E)  can be
>the greatest gifts in the world. But we must be careful.

FINALLY!!! someone who actually makes sense on this admittedly touchy
subject.  You said this very well and I agree with this fully.

I must say though the only thing I wonder is why some non-drug users get so
defensive about it and class ppl like us with "losers" and "idiots"?  I'm a
26-year-old graphic designer who worked her way though printing school
courses, and have a steady job and a good enough income to live on my own
in a house with three cats.  I have never had to ask my parents for
finanicial assistance, although it's there if I need it.  I have a large
circle of very close friends, both drug users and non.  I graduated high
school with flying colours and am considering entering university to study
paleontology.  I read voraciously.  I make music.  I enjoy life to the
fullest.  I don't smoke, nor do I drink.  I choose to take e, acid and dope
instead, these being less harmful to my system and emotions.  And I also am
VERY aware of the dangers of these substances and treat them with
appropriate respect.

Now, why do I (and people like me) get classed as an idiot???

(sorry got a little rhetorical oh well it's been a long day.)

k

          You've got to let those strange hands touch you.

I'm helping a friend put on a sound healing workshop next Sat Aug 5 
during the day in the city.

The workshop is led by the Irish musician Phil Harrington (who I met at a 
Full Moon Rave in LA a couple of years ago). The process he has developed 
over the past seven years is called VOCE (vo-chay, Italian for voice). It 
consists of chakra toning, shamanic dreaming and ecstactic singing.

I participated in this process for four months while Phil was living in 
L.A. and I found it to be a great learning experience which opened up my 
creativity and produced profound states of consciousness.

If anyone is interested in more information please e-mail me privately 
and I will give you all the details.

peace,
ronan

"An individual uncovers his or her musical, creative signature, when they 
discover the well of their own source of regeneration and life energy."
						- Phil Harrington

Received: from mom.hooked.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA17099; Thu, 27 Jul 1995 20:23:57 -0700
Received: from localhost (csil@tuna.hooked.net [199.2.134.11]) by mom.hooked.net (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id UAA06146; Thu, 27 Jul 1995 20:23:41 -0700
Message-Id: <199507280323.UAA06146@mom.hooked.net>
Comments: Authenticated sender is <csil@mom.hooked.net>
From: "Christopher Silveira" <csil@hooked.net>
To: eidrah@wimsey.com (Karen)
Date:          Thu, 27 Jul 1995 20:26:53 +0000
Subject:       Re: To us drug users
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Priority: normal
X-mailer: Pegasus Mail for Windows (v2.01)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 
> I must say though the only thing I wonder is why some non-drug users get so
> defensive about it and class ppl like us with "losers" and "idiots"?  I'm a
> 26-year-old graphic designer who worked her way though printing school
> courses, and have a steady job and a good enough income to live on my own
> in a house with three cats.  I have never had to ask my parents for
> finanicial assistance, although it's there if I need it.  I have a large
> circle of very close friends, both drug users and non.  I graduated high
> school with flying colours and am considering entering university to study
> paleontology.  I read voraciously.  I make music.  I enjoy life to the
> fullest.  I don't smoke, nor do I drink.  I choose to take e, acid and dope
> instead, these being less harmful to my system and emotions.  And I also am
> VERY aware of the dangers of these substances and treat them with
> appropriate respect.
> 
> Now, why do I (and people like me) get classed as an idiot???
 
IMHO, it is because people that don't do our drugs have absolutely no 
clue what they do. When we do psychedelics, it puts us in another 
reality. This reality is something that only those who have also 
experienced it can understand. While we are in this different 
reality, we think and act differently also. People see us partaking 
in this reality while they cannot see it, cannot feel it, cannot 
understand it. And because of that a lot of people cannot relate, 
they become jaded, in some instances maybe even jealous. And they 
decide to call us crazy, tweeked, fucked up, losers, etc. It goes 
along with the syndrome of belittling other people to make yourself 
feel better about your short-comings. They don't reach the same state 
of mind as us, so of course we are the ones that are dangerous, we 
are the ones that need to be "turned around" so to speak. 
What it all comes down to is they can't even begin to imagine the 
experiences we have had, and how we use them to model the way we act, 
the way we talk, the way we think, the way we interact with others, 
etc. and that scares them.

Luv to all! 
-----------------------------------------------------------
Christopher Silveira
a.k.a. eric longfellow (the lost dj)
csil@hooked.net
http://www.hooked.net:80/users/csil/
Junior Dragon    -==(UDIC)==-
- "Beats so phat, you might gain weight!!!"

As long servers already know, I do not like big commercial raves because 
they are ussually frought with bad attitude from the organnizers and the 
security, high prices for a sound system that looks flash but sounds like 
shit and for spectacular vissuals that most of us can already do on our 
systems at home.  That's why I only went to the last one because I was 
helping out in the S.P.A.Z. room.  Imagine my surprise when I found out 
that of all the above was NOT true; it prooved that one can have a big 
all ages rave with out it being taking over by commercialism.  Area 51 
was probably the only big rave I have ever been to that still maintained 
that underground renergade feeling about it.  No small achievement by the 
organizers.
So if this Area 51 is even half as good as the last one it will still be 
a blinding party.  I'll be in the Alpha section and the Ameba room; 
please check me there.
Area 51: prooving that there is a vibe after commercialism.  See ya there!
TRISTAN.

Subject: A non-users opinion
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFRaves List)
Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 10:26:13 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2166      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I saw the drug user thread and thought that I would share my non-user
opinion on the matter.

IHMO, ...

First, I went through an phase where I ended up doing
most drugs that were available.  You name it, there is a good chance I did it.
I merely state this to avoid the "You never done it so you wouldn't know"
shouting matches.

I have just found for me that music alone is enough to lift me to a higher
platau (sp?).  I get myself so worked into the beat, I end up half
hypnotized.  At times I have gotten so lost, that my friends would swear
that I was on something.  It is a awsome feeling to get
into this state and then feel the endorphens and adrenalin racing through
your system.  My body feel so alive and full of energy.  I can feel my nerves
just reaching out, grabbing hold of the universe and carrying me away.  The
ride is as much driven by you as it is your surroundings and environment. 

For me, however, it is much harder to reach that state when under the 
influence of some other substance.  While the rush/high is usally really good,
I personally get more out of the natural high I get from music and dancing
(couple it with and outdoor location and I am in heaven....).  Not to say that
if a good batch of schrooms were passed my way that I wouldn't partake, I just
choose not too as a general rule.

The point:  For me and my friends, this works out real well.  I can share in
their experiences and they can share mine.   I feel that the state I reach
is compatible and on the same level as their's.  We trip together, it is just
induced my another means.  But when the shit goes down, they also know that
there is a sober person around to help them out (rides/crashes/bad trips/etc). 

In my mind, it is not important how you reach a plane of higher 
consciousness, just make sure you visit it every so often.  If you find
it through exercise, music, drugs, go for it.  Just make sure you can also find
your way back home.

Party safe, responsibly, and most importantly OFTEN!

hugs
mike
-- 
Mike Lasmanis     | "The real voyage of discovery consists not in seeing
mikel@cctech.com  |  new landscapes but in having new eyes."  Marcel Proust

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 00:01:27 -0400
From: AWerks@aol.com
To: idm@hyperreal.com, mjbrown@magnus.acs.ohio-state.edu
Subject: Astralwerks/ENIT News

FUTURE SOUND OF LONDON and FREAKY CHAKRA invited to join Lollapalooza
companion ENIT Festival

 Astralwerks recording artists Future Sound Of London and Freaky Chakra have
been invited to join the lineup of the ENIT Festival. ENIT is an all-night
electronic dance music event being held August 10-18 in four cities during
the Lollapalooza tour - Dallas, Phoenix, Los Angeles, and San Francisco in
conjunction with Lollapalooza '95.  Located in a venue away from the
Lollapalooza Main Stage, ENIT begins once main stage headliner Sonic Youth
ends.  The brainchild of Lollapalooza co-founder Perry Farrell, ENIT is a
proverbial 'gathering of the tribes,' combining live music, DJ's, dancing,
and avant-garde film into a full-on multimedia extravaganza.  
 Multimedia masterminds, Future Sound Of London will be screening Teachings
>From The Electronic Brain, a 20-minute film created by the band in
collaboration with graphic artist Buggy G. Riphead to accompany their
recently re-released ISDN  album.  Culled from Future Sound of London's live
broadcasts last year via the Integrated Services Digital Network, the initial
limited edition pressing of ISDN sold out within three days of release
(20,000 copies worldwide).
 San Francisco-based producer/remixer Freaky Chakra has quickly risen through
the ranks as one of the best up-and-coming American talents in underground
dance music.   Freaky Chakra's debut full-length album, Lowdown Motivator,
released this spring on Astralwerks, was met with overwhelming worldwide
acclaim from dance music press, DJ's, and partygoers alike for his unique
flavor that stands apart from his West Coast counterparts.  Live, Freaky
Chakra will be joined by fellow Bay Area cohort Single Cell Orchestra (billed
as Freaky Chakra vs. Single Cell Orchestra) in a soundclash of analog
electronics, funky beats, and soundtrack soundscapes.     
 Accompanying Future Sound Of London and Freaky Chakra on the festival dates
are Moby, ex-porno-star-turned-techno-diva-DJ Traci Lords, DJ Keoki,
Farrell's band Porno For Pyros (Dallas and Phoenix only),  U.K. ethno-techno
experimentalist Banco de Gaia, and German wunder DJ Sven Vath (Los Angeles
and San Francisco only).

-ENIT FESTIVAL DATES & VENUES-
Thursday, August 10 - Bomb Factory/Dallas, TX
Saturday, August 12 - Icehouse/Phoenix, AZ
Monday, August 14 - Shrine Auditorium/Los Angeles, CA
Friday, August 18 - Warfield Theatre/San Francisco,CA

For more information, contact:
 Amy Welch (212.886.7525) or Peter Wohelski (212.886.7506) @ Astralwerks,
Julie Arkenstone @ Lollapalooza Tour Media (310.859.4200) or Heidi Robinson @
Lollapalooza National Media (818.953.7910).




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jul 28 11:54:19 1995

Subject: Re: A non-users opinion
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>In my mind, it is not important how you reach a plane of higher 
>consciousness, just make sure you visit it every so often.  If you find
>it through exercise, music, drugs, go for it.  Just make sure you can also find
>your way back home.

I think this is one of the best posts I've seen on this subject.  Basically,
I think that you can only be your own moral police; you can try to help out
other people by sharing your thoughts and feelings with them, but ultimately
the responsibility for their actions lie with them.  So I don't really
understand when people start bad-mouthing drug users or non-drug users
because that is not the choice that the bad-mouther makes himself.  Do what
you need to to be the best person you can be and let other people do the same.

On a related note regarding other ideas from this post, have you ever
noticed that when you're with a group of people, especially a group of good
friends, if just one of those people are high on something, all the other
people with them start to feel and act the same way?  Some people say
psychosomatic, but I'd say just plain psychic.  Lots of things out there
that we still don't understand about the human brain, kids.

Actually, I think it's a good thing that this article showed up.  The more
people that react positively toward the scene, the better.  Sure, in the
long run this will probably lead to a bunch of glitzed-out hyper-commercial
raves, but that doesn't mean the smaller ones will disappear.  This means
that all us die-hard ravers :) will still have the atmosphere that we enjoy.
And I know that for most of us the scene is about the people anyways, so the
way I see it the more, the better.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jul 28 15:22:55 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)
Subject: Parthenon - BSP (but funny, kinda)
X-Mailer: <Windows Eudora Version 2.0.2>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Whoa, this is way long, you can skip to the bottom if you don't care about
my story.

An interesting thing happened to me last night at Thursday Night Market (a
event held every thurs. during the summer for downtown merchants in
Sacramento.  They sell stuff and theres music and what not.)  My girlfriend
Phelps and I were walking back to her car after the weekly movie they show,
Young Frankenstein...classic...(it's pretty cool, cuz they project it on to
the side of this old brick building, outdoors!)....Anyway, so we were
walking back to the car, holding hands see and Phelps looks down and just
stops and stares at the ground.  I walked forward a few feet.  She stands
there just looking an says something like "this is cool".  She pickes up
what she was looking at and says this is a cool flyer.  I caught a glimps of
the front and thought it looked like a rave flyer and pretty cool as well.
It said PARTHENON, AUGUST 4.  She turns it over and says "hey, DJ Dan is
playing.  I say "oh yea, let me have a look", I read the dj's: Karizma
(Sac), Swing Kid (SF), Donald Glaude (Seattle), Spun (SF), Jan Cooley (SF),
and DJ Dan (SF).  Then it says "Ambient Room Featuring: Rig-A-Tony's Ambient
Crew and I do like a complete back flip and say "WHAT?".  You see Rig-A-Tony
was my room mate for about a year and tought me about records.  I had hated
them previously.  I got my tables from him as well.  And at every Rave that
he does the ambient room, I've played.  I was trippin cuz he didn't say
anything about this to me, even though I've been termed as part of the Sac
Ambient Crew, who usually plays on Rig-A-Tony's system.  So I call him today
and he's all "hey, I was supposed to call you today".  Turns out I am
spinning at the show, and it is supposed to be a killer space.  The show is
at the Daily Grind Skate Park in West Sacramento, I guess there is supposed
to be like three sound systems, with the ambient room in it's own enclosed
space, with a door (YEEEAAAA!).  So there you have it, my funny BSB.  

PARTHENON
August 4
DJ's:  Karizma, Swing Kid, Donald Glaude, Spun, Jan Cooley, DJ Dan
Ambient Room:  Rig-A-Tony's Ambient Crew (Rig-A-Tony, Rick, Phil, Tim?)

Hello all,

After 3 wonderful years of partying in the Bay Area, Whitsitt and I are 
hitting the highways and byways of the United States for a while, to see 
the sights, party in other parts of the country, and hopefully do some 
parties.  It's been a great experience to live in the Bay Area and 
especially to participate in the house music community here, the parties 
and people are some of the most open, loving, and free that I've ever 
encountered.  The SFRaves party Connection II in Spring 1993, in the 
rain and cold at Berkeley Marina, was a huge influence in the formation of 
our sound system, and many other similar parties have continued to 
inspire us since then -- New Moon, Sunset, Harmony, Cloud Factory...and 
now we've decided to take to the road and visit and party with people 
across the States.  We hope to do as many free outdoor parties on the 
road as we can, and if you can help us get in touch with people who are 
interested in doing that, please do; I hope to be able to check my email 
while on the road, but a more sure way would be to call our voicemail at 
415.487.7681.  Any help in connecting us with people in any area of the 
country would be very appreciated!

But before we go, we're throwing ourselves a going-away party, tomorrow, 
Saturday the 29th, at the Chateau in Berkeley, starting at 9 pm and going 
quite late, $3, all are welcome, so come by and help give us a proper bon 
voyage!  Directions are: from SF, take the Bay Bridge and exit at Ashby 
Ave., go up Ashby to Telegraph and make a left, then make a right at 
Parker (at the 7-11), then drive 2 blocks and make a left at Hillegass, 
it's the big white house near the corner, 2545 Hillegass.

Also, just because Whit and I are leaving doesn't mean the Mother Earth 
Sound System will stop throwing parties -- remember Club Freaky on the 
first Friday of each month, and keep an ear out for free outdoor parties!

Well, until we meet again, remember to keep your feet "on-da-ground"!!!


Peace + respect,

scottie & whitsitt
mother earth sound system
*************************
unite  celebrate  survive

Hello again!

Well, the time has come, and although The Great M.E.S.S. Adventure isn't 
happening _quite_ the way we expected, it _is_ happening -- we're hittin' 
the road!  Unfortunately, not all of our crew is coming along, but myself 
and Whitsitt will be venturing forth in his car, armed with turntables, 
mixer, slide projector, banners, blacklights, and enough records to last 
us across the country and back!  We have no set plans other than 
to see as much of the States and meet and party with as many of you as we 
possibly can.  We're leaving from Southern California around the second 
week of August, heading east thru AZ, NM, and stopping in Austin for a 
while, then after that our direction is undecided.  Ideally, we'd like to 
do as many free outdoor parties as we can, but since our small car 
precluded bringing along much sound gear, we're hoping to meet people 
that can help make it all happen.  But regardless of whether you have a 
sound system or not, we want to meet you and hang out!  Although I hope 
to be able to check my email on the road, it's not certain, so the best 
way for us to get in touch with you is probably by you emailing your 
phone number to our friend Jacob, at DJStonie@aol.com, who can then relay 
it to us.  Emailing it to my account couldn't hurt, either.


We hope to see you soon!!!


Peace + respect,

scottie & whitsitt

mother earth sound system

In a message dated 95-07-27 23:26:06 EDT, you write:

>IMHO, it is because people that don't do our drugs have absolutely no 
>clue what they do. When we do psychedelics, it puts us in another 
>reality. This reality is something that only those who have also 
>experienced it can understand. While we are in this different 
>reality, we think and act differently also. People see us partaking 
>in this reality while they cannot see it, cannot feel it, cannot 
>understand it. And because of that a lot of people cannot relate, 
>they become jaded, in some instances maybe even jealous. And they 
>decide to call us crazy, tweeked, fucked up, losers, etc. It goes 
>along with the syndrome of belittling other people to make yourself 
>feel better about your short-comings. They don't reach the same state 
>of mind as us, so of course we are the ones that are dangerous, we 
>are the ones that need to be "turned around" so to speak. 
>What it all comes down to is they can't even begin to imagine the 
>experiences we have had, and how we use them to model the way we act, 
>the way we talk, the way we think, the way we interact with others, 
>etc. and that scares them.
>

Dear All;

	Well I do drugs, and have on & off for a long time, Tried them
all, but there is nothing like getting a massage(straight or high it's up
you); I would strongely suggest that you try it once or even twice; 
straight just to see what it feels like; from a professional practioner,
or a loved one, near you & that you trust. When you bodies producing so
many endomorphes, from all the external stimulation, some people,
including myself, just leave the table; mentally, and also body wise to
some extent. It real neat when you can't feel them touching you anymore,
but they are, you kinda enter into of the coolest altered states I have
ever experience, it's just good stuff for everyone involved. 

	You can always take like 2 pills and then go, I've never given someone
a full body massage yet that was on E, hmmm  would be truely experience.

	Hope to see you at Area 51.

On Fri, 28 Jul 1995, Mike Lasmanis wrote:

> Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 10:26:13 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Mike Lasmanis <mikel@cctech.com>
> To: SFRaves List <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
> Subject: A non-users opinion
> 
> I saw the drug user thread and thought that I would share my non-user
> opinion on the matter.
> 
> IHMO, ...
> 
> First, I went through an phase where I ended up doing
> most drugs that were available.  You name it, there is a good chance I did it.
> I merely state this to avoid the "You never done it so you wouldn't know"
> shouting matches.
> 
> I have just found for me that music alone is enough to lift me to a higher
> platau (sp?).  I get myself so worked into the beat, I end up half
> hypnotized.  At times I have gotten so lost, that my friends would swear
> that I was on something.  It is a awsome feeling to get
> into this state and then feel the endorphens and adrenalin racing through
> your system.  My body feel so alive and full of energy.  I can feel my nerves
> just reaching out, grabbing hold of the universe and carrying me away.  The
> ride is as much driven by you as it is your surroundings and environment. 
> 
> For me, however, it is much harder to reach that state when under the 
> influence of some other substance.  While the rush/high is usally really good,
> I personally get more out of the natural high I get from music and dancing
> (couple it with and outdoor location and I am in heaven....).  Not to say that
> if a good batch of schrooms were passed my way that I wouldn't partake, I just
> choose not too as a general rule.
> 
> The point:  For me and my friends, this works out real well.  I can share in
> their experiences and they can share mine.   I feel that the state I reach
> is compatible and on the same level as their's.  We trip together, it is just
> induced my another means.  But when the shit goes down, they also know that
> there is a sober person around to help them out (rides/crashes/bad trips/etc). 
> 
> In my mind, it is not important how you reach a plane of higher 
> consciousness, just make sure you visit it every so often.  If you find
> it through exercise, music, drugs, go for it.  Just make sure you can also find
> your way back home.
> 
> Party safe, responsibly, and most importantly OFTEN!
> 
> hugs
> mike
> -- 
> Mike Lasmanis     | "The real voyage of discovery consists not in seeing
> mikel@cctech.com  |  new landscapes but in having new eyes."  Marcel Proust

On Wed, 26 Jul 1995, Amy R Starkey Forwarded:

> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 21:02:18 -0700
> From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
> To: sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu
> Subject: (fwd) REASONS WHY E-MAIL IS LIKE A PENIS:
> 
> 
> Some folks have it, some don't. Those who have it would be
> devastated  if it were ever cut off. They think that those who don't
> have it are  somehow inferior. They think it gives them power. They
> are wrong. Those who don't have it may agree that it's an nifty toy,
> but think it's  not worth the fuss that those who do have it make
> about it. Still, many  of those who don't have it would like to try it.
> 
> It can be up or down. It's more fun when it's up, but it makes it hard
> to get any real work done.
> 
> In the long-distant past, its only purpose was to transmit
> information  considered vital to the survival of the species. Some
> people still think that's the only thing it should be used for, but
> most folks today use it for fun most of the time.
> 
> Once you've started playing with it, it's hard to stop. Some people
> would just play with it all day if they didn't have work to do.
> 
> It provides a way to interact with other people. Some people
> take this  interaction very seriously, others treat it as a lark.
> Sometimes it's hard to tell what kind of person you're dealing with
> until it's too late.
> 
> If you don't apply the appropriate protective measures, it can
> spread  viruses.
> 
> It has no brain of its own. Instead, it uses yours. If you use
> it too  much, you'll find it becomes more and more difficult to think
> coherently.
> 
> We attach an importance to it that is far greater than its actual size
> and influence warrant.  If you're not careful what you do with it, it
> can get you in big trouble.
> 
> It has its own agenda.  Somehow, no matter how good your intentions,
> it  will warp you behavior. Later you may ask yourself "why on earth
> did I  do that?"
> 
> It has no conscience and no memory.  Left to its own devices,
> it will do the same damn dumb things again and again.
> 
>

>----- Forwarded message  
>Assuming the  following is really true, I feel it my duty to forward it to
you  
>all. 
> 
>Carter 
> 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>>   My daughter & I had just finished a salad at Neiman-Marcus Cafe 
>>>>>> in Dallas & decided to have a small dessert.  Because our family 
>>>>>> are such cookie lovers, we decided to try the "Neiman-Marcus 
>>>>>> Cookie". It was so excellent that I asked if they would give me 
>>>>>> the recipe and they said with a small frown, "I'm afraid not." 
>>>>>> Well, I said, would you let me buy the recipe?  With a cute 
>>>>>> smile, she said, "Yes."  I asked how much, and she responded, 
>>>>>> "Two fifty." I said with approval, just add it to my tab. 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>>   Thirty days later, I received my VISA statement from 
>>>>>> Neiman-Marcus and it was $285.00.  I looked again and I 
>>>>>> remembered I had only spent $9.95 for two salads and about $20.00 
>>>>>> for a scarf.  As I glanced at the bottom of the statement, it 
>>>>>> said, "Cookie Recipe - $250.00."  Boy, was I upset!! I called 
>>>>>> Neiman's Accounting Dept. and told them the waitress said it was 
>>>>>> "two fifty," and I did not realize she meant $250.00 for a cookie 
>>>>>> recipe.  I asked them to take back the recipe and reduce my bill 
>>>>>> and they said they were sorry, but because all the recipes were 
>>>>>> this expensive so not just everyone could duplicate any of our 
>>>>>> bakery recipes....the bill would stand.  I waited, thinking of 
>>>>>> how I could get even or even try and get any of my money back. 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> I just said, "Okay, you folks got my $250.00 and now I'm going to 
>>>>>> have $250.00 worth of fun." I told her that I was going to see to 
>>>>>> it that every cookie lover will have a $250.00 cookie recipe from 
>>>>>> Neiman-Marcus for nothing. She replied, "I wish you wouldn't do 
>>>>>> this." I said, "I'm sorry but this is the only way I feel I could 
>>>>>> get even," and I will. 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>>   So, here it is, and please pass it to someone else or run a few 
>>>>>> copies....I paid for it; now you can have it for free. 
>>>>>> (Recipe may be halved.): 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> 2 cups butter                  4 cups flower 
>>>>>> 2 tsp. soda                    2 cups sugar 
>>>>>> 5 cups blended oatmeal**      24 oz. chocolate chips 
>>>>>> 2 cups brown sugar             1 tsp. salt 
>>>>>> 1  8 oz. Hershey Bar (grated)  4 eggs 
>>>>>> 2 tsp. baking powder           3 cups chopped nuts 
>>>>>> 2 tsp. vanilla                        (your choice) 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>>   Cream the butter and both sugars.  Add eggs and vanilla; mix 
>>>>>> together with flour, oatmeal, salt, baking powder, and soda.  Add 
>>>>>> chocolate chips, Hershey Bar and nuts. 
>>>>>>   Roll into balls and place two inches apart on a cookie sheet. 
>>>>>> Bake for 10 minutes at 375 degrees.  Makes 112 cookies. 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> ** measure oatmeal and blend in a blender to a fine powder. 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Have fun!!!  This is not a joke --- this is a true story.. 
>>>>>> ************************************************************ 
>>>>>>   That's it. Please, pass it along to everyone you know, single 
>>>>>> people, mailing lists, etc.....

internet hoaxes go, it could be worse. TOSS THIS COOKIE...

New moon turned out to be a wonderful little party.  It was my first 
time going to one of these events and most certainly won't be my last.  
The people who put this on are very special.  They must have gone 
through a lot of effort to get the system to the location and even

rock) and the music was great.  Somehow the dj's new the kind of trip 
we would be on and played accordingly.

spot!

some things i need to say:
it seems that since i have been in the bay area, the parties i go to
keep getting smaller..and keep getting better.
in the midwest, i usually pay $15 for a "rave".
here the most i have ever paid is 4 (cybertrance waveform via frequency 8, one
great party)

for various reasons, the new moon party on friday/saturday was the best 
party i've ever been to. thanks go out:
thanks to new moon for organizing this
thanks to the dj's (if i'm here for the next one, i'll help!)
thanks to the person who donated the soundsystem
thanks to the person who brought the watermellon :)
thanks to the athorities for not busting us
thanks to the people who showed up for supporting a renegade of this type
thanks to adam for driving me there
thanks to billy for driving me back (carless and loving it?)
thanks to the beach for being so wonderful, great view, soft sand
thanks to every one i met, i didn't meet that was there, and that didn't go
          but sent good thoughts our way.

if you guys need help with anything in the future, i'm here (with two new
 turntables next month! er...new used anyway...)

how did the chateau party in berkeley go, to only person i talked to and went
was totally wasted while he was there and didn't remember anything :(

see ya...where the sun sets and the sand is soft.
i have to go back to missouri on the 12th unless i can get out of it, so if you
see me, come up and say hi cause i may not be back for a while.

sorry i couldn't go to area 51, (too poor), but it looked great and i'm glad
every one had a good time and it was a great concept and if it happens again
i will try to be there!

-rk

oh yeah, thanks for some increadible ambience and trance one last time before
i go back to the land o' house!

On Thu, 27 Jul 1995 SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com wrote:

> just thot i should add something positive to the mix; thangs have been
>   getting down (esp on sfraves) lately...
> 
> i wuz on sabattical (sp?) for 6 weeks on the island of moorea last month,
>   (it's right next to tahiti, about 2000 miles south of hawaii) just to
>    get away from technology for awhile and to just watch the world go by.
> my morning ritual was to make some breakfast, like eggs and bagettes with
>   jam, and then to sit out on the beach with a cup o' java.  now, i wasn't
>     just sitting ON the beach, i was actually halfway in the water.  over
>       there, the islands are surrounded by a lagoon, which is as still as
>         a mountain lake in the morning.  i mean you can clearly see clouds
>          mirrored in it.
> anyway, cut to the chase.  the lagoon has ZILLIONS of fish in it, and after
>   a week, i had trained this rather large group of fish to recognize me as
>     a source of bread.  i'd toss some little bits into the water, and the
>       fish would come by and start nibbling the bread.  then, as their
>        fear of peeple would pass, i'd stick a piece of bread between my
>          two biggest toes and stick my foot in the water.  what a strange
>           feeling, having hundreds of fish jostle for a piece of bread 
>             around your foot!  these fish didn't have any teeth that i
>               could determine, and so it basically felt like kisses or
>                 like a gentle touch. even after the bread was gone,
>                   the fish would linger for up to an hour, hoping for more.

Nice story!  Reminds me of a Saturday Night Live skit in which Dan 
Akryod is talking about his book "Mauled", which is the story of how he 
attemtep to feed a Grizzly Bear a marshmellow out of his mouth.  :)

Nine Toes

OK, this is minimally rave-related.  There is a 
depiction of a NY club called NASA in the movie 
_Kids_ (I believe this to be the now defunct(?) club 
started by DJ DB.)  The scene is only a few minutes

raw, honest, and fucking uncompromising look @ a 
significant portion of today's teenage youth.

_SORRY, NON-RAVE CONTENT_

Tho' I agree that this movie doesn't accurately describe
all or even most of today's kids (can any one movie or 
theory do this?) I've known and been some of these people. 
And unlike on silly shows like 90210, the language and the 
situations are not sugar-coated.  All representational art 
entails a certain degree of artifice. The condensation of 
events to fit a "day in the life" should not be hastily 
rejected as unbelievable or unrealistic.  

Because of the _non-rave content_, let's continue this thread privately.

Rok =)

> >long, and is good. The movie, however,is great -- a
> >raw, honest, and fucking uncompromising look @ a
> >significant portion of today's teenage youth.
>

> drink and smoke pot and have sex but i think the movie was a little harsh.
> they only took a look at all the stupid shit kids do.  did you find one
> redeeming quality in any of the characters?  i didn't.  all i wanted to do

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 31 13:58:58 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA02070; Mon, 31 Jul 1995 13:58:58 -0700
Received: from xinet.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA02059; Mon, 31 Jul 1995 13:58:55 -0700
Received: from DialupEudora by xinet.COM via SMTP (940816.SGI.8.6.9/931108.SGI.ANONFTP)
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com> id NAA24218; Mon, 31 Jul 1995 13:58:46 -0700
Message-Id: <v02120d00ac42bc3fa583@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 13:58:53 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Shooting a Moon (New Moon Review-a novel)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It wasn't until the sound system was carried, dragged and almost floated
back the 1/2 mile along the beach and we spread out our blankets took off
our clothes and went for a dip in the nipple-hardening, bone chilling water
that we could objectively reflect back on the last 15 hours and ponder
where we came from, where we went, and how the hell we got where we were.
Unfortunately, a number of people never knew (where we were), and that is a
sad thing.  But for those who were fortunate enough to find New Moon, what
they found was a little slice of raver paradise.

This report is not intended to upset those that could not find New Moon,
but rather to try and share the engergy and power of what we did there.
It's not to rub your nose in it, but to help you smell the sand the surf
the sweat and the sounds of a most flavorful weekend.  Here goes:

The drive up there was long, given heavy traffic 11 miles before Petaluma,
and a nice slick fog that found us as we got close to the water on Route 1
near Bodega Bay.  The New Moon party was being held at a location 15-20
minutes North of Bodage Bay at a state beach called Goat Rock.  (Our first
positive omen was that after 30 miles tailing a slow-going car, Denise and
I realized that it was our friends Anne and Jeff from Sacramento that were
ahead of us. :^)  Once into Goat Rock we followed the road down toward the
beach and spent a couple minutes trying to find the parking lot next to the
enormous rock called Goat Rock.  We were lucky.  (Very lucky as it turns
out.)  We had arrived as the New Mooners were starting to carry equipment
down the beach.  I say we were lucky, because at least one car load of
people we know of arrived later and never found the spot.  You see, it's a
1/2 mile along the beach (some say a 1/4 mi., but I think it's further) and
you can neither hear the music from the lot to the spot, nor see much of a
fire.  The good in struggling with all of our stuff that far is that it's a
beautiful, secluded spot where the rangers don't hassle you, (hassle free
for two days!), the negative is that it's hard to find.

We trusted New Moon in finding such a nice place, and labored blindly with
the equipment for in the dark we could only hear how beautiful it was.  The
earth's contribution to repetitive beat music is the crashing surf, no?

Many loads of equipment were carried that night.  The energy started to
build as more people lent hands.  Finally enough equipment was brought out
so that the sound guys (Greg and Jason) could get that part rolling.
Someone started a fire (Morgan?), someone set up a shrine (Bill and Gaby),
someone directed other matters (Ann), we set up our tents; activity
abounded.  The generator started it's 13 1/2 hours of duty and the sound,
our life-blood, came on.  Nice ambient stuff to coincide with the constant
crashing surf.  We continued to settle in.

Things finally calmed down a bit and people trickled in.  At the site they
were erecting a tent over the tables to keep away the mist.  (Same tent,
BTW, that was in the ambient room of the Friends & Family bust party.  For
you trivia hounds.)

About midnight Jeff from Sacramento (aka BIOJeff of Hymns & Anthems) came
on and cranked things up.  Mixing some new with some "hella old" he brought
a good group of us away from the warm glow of the fire to dance in the
sand.  The wind played a bit with the needles once in a while, but part of
the New Moon creed is to bring in harmony the joy of our scene with the
elements and thus a few sliding needles only made for a more raw feel.  As
if the elements kept saying, "Hey, don't forget about us!"  No one was too
upset about a skip or two, accept maybe Phillip (New Moon) who was
recording the whole thing on dat.

Jeff threw down some really great trancy stuff that seemed to clear the
clouds from the sky as well as from our minds.  The stars were plentiful
and bright as Jeff passed the torch to Kelly(?) who, in a really cool and
deadpan presence, kicked ass.  I am not able to tell you exactly what she
was playing, but it was fucking good. (Anyone?  Music details please.)
People danced and chatted and sat by the fire and howled at the moon and
milled about, like a tiny Sunset at night, really.  By 3 am it was topping
out at maybe 60 or so people.

I went to bed in a tent at about 4 or 5.  Slept well with the music
floating around in my head.  Nice ambient stuff played throughout the
morning (DJ with green shimmering hair?) and then this really cool guy came
on and played some excellent house.  His name is Billy Haste and if you
don't have the pleasure of hearing him play, you'd be just as lucky to sit
and laugh with him for a while.  He played for a long time as people packed
up their stuff or slept in the sun or walked about or went swimming.  By
this time the generator had been working 12 hours (and only ran out of gas
once. ;^)

At about 1:30 p.m. or so our beloved life-blood was put to rest and packing
of the equipment commenced.  Rumors were spreading about a group staying at
the beach that night, but the New Moon people had to get the tables back
(thanks Joe!), so once again a handful of people carried all the equipment
back to the cars.  It was worth every back-breaking second I can tell you
that.  Leaving us with water and a nice blessing New Moon (Ann and Greg)
left us on the beach and we saluted them by derobing and running headlong
and screaming into the chilly water.  A tribute to their hard work and warm
hearts.

We stayed there all that night, about ten of us, watching the stars, making
grilled cheese (Rule of life #10: don't ever pass-up an opportunity to eat
a grilled cheese sandwich made by a Scottish woman on the beach. ;^) and
tending the fire. The waves played on, crashing against the giant rocks
along the coast.  We slept the sleep of lovers, friends and family.  Except
of course for me, because I had my face squished against the moist tent.
But alas, my comfort is trivial to the comfort of my family.  Plus,
everyone was so passed out I couldn't wake them to move them.  C'est la
vie.

We enjoyed a nice breakfast and another swim and drove back to The City in
a daze.

Thanks to New Moon, the DJs, and all the people who made it happen.  The
circle is complete.

Sandy and sunburnt,

Tony

P.S.  To those who missed it, I'm sorry for that, but rest assured there
will be others.  Now if only we could get a hand-truck that will work in
the sand...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 31 19:46:03 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA25560; Mon, 31 Jul 1995 19:46:03 -0700

Received: from  by ix2.ix.netcom.com (8.6.12/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id TAA00368; Mon, 31 Jul 1995 19:43:13 -0700
Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 19:43:13 -0700
Message-Id: <199508010243.TAA00368@ix2.ix.netcom.com>
From: scary@ix.netcom.com (Gary Burns )
Subject: Re: Us drug users
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk


	Thought I'd jump in on the subject, one thats been a fairly
	big part of my life the last several years.

	Much has been covered already; drugs can be a medium for 
	visting places that are much harder to get to through other 
	means; drugs are not for all; drugs are dangerous; drugs 
	can be pretty expensive (in a lot of ways); drugs are for 
	mugs; drugs make you thin, sext, cool...

	Drugs, for me, were a revelation - after being brought up
	on a Scottish working class diet of alcohol abuse, violence
	and the hard-man image, my first experiences with drugs 
	were eye-opening to say the least. Dabbling in E in
	particular, and just about everything else in general, has
	brought with it a wealth of experience and learning that I
	doubt I would have been blessed with should I have chosen
	not to jump down that path.

	Of course learning isn't always pleasant, and drugs can have
	a way of putting things over in a particularly nasty
	way. The axiom, 'there is no bad trips, only bad trippers',
	may be true but disreagarding its advice too many times, I've
	learned that chemicals can play around with your mind in the
	most unpleasant of ways.

	Drug use has brought me in touch with a lot of truly wonderful
	people (real and immaginary ;') and has also placed me in
	situations I'd rather not have been - the 'Drug culture' is 
	a mix of nirvana and the foul - the money involved brings 
	violence, there's addiction, greed and self-distruction. 

	Some of these things can be seen as personal failings (it could
	never happen to me), maybe they are, but some things have a way 
	of wearing you down.

	To end with something that has been said before, there's no 
	absolutes here - If you want to partake, do so, if you wish 
	to abstain, well...But before condoning or condemming, learn
	about the issues invovled, misinformation on drugs is very
	prevelant in this society - altough people on the list seem 
	much more informed than the GP - and when, if, you do choose
        to sample, or are simply continuing to do so, enjoy - and good 
	luck,

	Still learning,
	Gary			


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 31 21:25:20 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: andrew@cinemascope.com (Andrew)
Subject: cleansed doors  
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Alright, so everyone on this list could go on and on about the ups and
downs and other directions of drugs=8ABut I would like to just suggest a ver=
y
clear, concise and rather brilliant reference for some insight on the
subject: Aldous Huxley's "The Doors of Perception."

The book is quite short, but a deep provacative read. This puts words to
thoughts and feelings sensed in altered states as well as gives a vivid
description of a mescaline trip for the unexperienced. If you have the
patience, Huxley's brilliant command of the language, though with near
excessive sentences, may give you some clear images for the illumination
that fades too fast.

Give a peek through the doors - you'll be amazed how familiar it all is.


> > >>CinemascopE<< < <
andrew@cinemascope.com
